headline: On Broadway, ‘Honeymoon’ Is Over
text: “Honeymoon in Vegas,” a madcap musical that won positive reviews but failed to find an audience, will close on Sunday.

headline: Review: Ballet West Offers an Eclectic Mix at the Joyce
text: Ballet West has been in existence since 1963, but this Salt Lake City company didn’t gain national prominence until it became the focus of “Breaking Pointe,” a reality show more consumed by the dancers’ backstage lives than ballet. The program ran on the CW network for two seasons beginning in 2012. Now in the a five-night run at the Joyce Theater, Ballet West had a chance to put the emphasis back where it belongs, on dancing.

headline: Energy Company Samson Hints at Bankruptcy
text: When a group of investors led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts bought the oil producer Samson Resources for $7.2 billion more than three years ago, analysts regarded the deal as a triumph.

headline: Pillars of Holy Week Processions Put Teamwork and Brawn on Display
text: SEVILLE, Spain — On a recent evening here, a group of 43 men shuffled back and forth as they carefully negotiated a tight street corner during a practice run carrying one of the heavy religious floats that get paraded around this city during its Holy Week celebrations.

headline: With Auto Show, G.M. Hopes to Lessen Damage
text: After a huge safety crisis and a revolt by disgruntled investors, General Motors is eager to turn its attention back to cars and trucks.

headline: Rollout of New York City’s Taxi of Tomorrow Is Again Halted in Court
text: The Taxi of Tomorrow is delayed again.

headline: Seeing a Tax Refund as a Financial Opportunity
text: So far this year, the Internal Revenue Service has processed more than 66 million federal income tax refunds, averaging about $2,900 each.

headline: Arizona Orders Doctors to Say Abortions With Drugs May Be Reversible
text: PHOENIX — Once again, Arizona finds itself on the frontier of anti-abortion legislation: Late Monday, it became the first state to pass a law requiring doctors who perform drug-induced abortions to tell women that the procedure may be reversible, an assertion that most doctors say is wrong.

headline: Muhammadu Buhari, a Familiar, and Now Less Divisive, Choice in Nigerian Election
text: KANO, Nigeria — The 72-year-old former general elected as Nigeria’s new president this week is not exactly new to the democratic process: He spent much of the past decade campaigning for the office in three successive elections — and failing each time.

headline: East Village Explosion Might Have Followed Attempt to Hide Gas Siphoning
text: Law enforcement officials are investigating whether the explosion that destroyed three buildings and killed two men in the East Village last week resulted from an attempt to hide the unauthorized siphoning of natural gas for tenants in one of the buildings.

headline: ADM Announces Plan to Fight Deforestation
text: Archer Daniels Midland, one of the world’s largest commodities suppliers, has joined the growing number of major agriculture and food companies promising to take steps to conserve forests that are threatened by the global demand for commodities like palm oil and soy.

headline: Provisional Government in Libyan Capital Forces Out Its Own Prime Minister
text: CAIRO — The provisional government set up by the militias controlling the Libyan capital fired its prime minister on Tuesday. His departure removed a potential obstacle to unity talks organized by the United Nations to try to end the fighting that has divided the country.

headline: Indiana Governor, Feeling Backlash From Law’s Opponents, Promises a ‘Fix’
text: By turns, Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana was defiant then chastened, stern then contemplative.

headline: Azerbaijan Bars Entry to a Georgian Human Rights Worker
text: MOSCOW — Azerbaijan on Monday barred a veteran human rights worker from entering the country, the latest in a series of events that international rights advocates have condemned and cited as evidence of increasing political repression.

headline: At N.I.T., 30-Second Shot Clock Wins Support
text: Over the last two weeks, the National Invitation Tournament has used a 30-second shot clock instead of the current 35-second one, an experiment that even President Obama advocated for in early March.

headline: As Nuclear Talks Drag On, U.S. and Iran Find It Harder to Hear Each Other
text: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — As the nuclear negotiations dragged into overtime here on Tuesday, some uniquely American and Iranian political sensitivities were permeating the marathon negotiating sessions, leading many to wonder whether two countries that have barely spoken for 35 years are just not ready to overcome old suspicions.

headline: FEMA Awards New York City a $3 Billion Grant for Hurricane Sandy Repairs
text: New York City is set to receive about $3 billion in federal funding to repair and stormproof 33 public housing complexes that were badly damaged by Hurricane Sandy, a grant that officials said was the largest provided by the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

headline: Army Offering More a Fast Track to Citizenship
text: The Army will expand a program offering a fast track to citizenship for immigrants with special language or medical skills. Based on guidance published Friday, the program, Military Accessions Vital to the National Interest (Mavni), will increase to 3,000 enlistments this fiscal year and 5,000 in the 2016 fiscal year, up from the current limit of 1,500. An Army spokesman, Hank Minitrez, said the program was “extremely successful in filling our ranks with highly qualified soldiers who fill critical shortages.” Foreigners accepted to enlist have been legal immigrants on temporary visas. In September, the program also was opened to young undocumented immigrants with deportation deferrals under a 2012 initiative by President Obama. Mr. Minitrez said that a few had applied but that none had been accepted to date.

headline: Lawyers Chosen to Present Case for Gay Marriage
text: Gay rights groups announced Tuesday that they had chosen two lawyers to present Supreme Court arguments on April 28 in favor of a constitutional right to same-sex marriage. One of the lawyers, Mary L. Bonauto, a prominent gay rights advocate who was instrumental in establishing a right to same-sex marriage in Massachusetts, will argue that all states must allow such unions. The other lawyer, Douglas Hallward-Driemeier, a former assistant United States solicitor general, will make a separate argument that states must recognize same-sex marriages performed elsewhere. Ms. Bonauto will face John J. Bursch, a former Michigan solicitor general, in the first argument, which is scheduled to last 90 minutes. Mr. Hallward-Driemeier will face Joseph Whalen, an associate solicitor general in Tennessee, in the second argument, which is set to last an hour.

headline: Federal Scrutiny of a Youth Immigration Program Alarms Advocates
text: Among the myriad laws and regulations that govern the nation’s immigration system is a special program, created 25 years ago, that allows immigrant youths who have been abused, neglected or abandoned to apply for a green card.

headline: Adviser and Caretaker of de Blasio Family Image Is Leaving City Hall
text: In appointing Rebecca Kirszner Katz as a special adviser shortly after taking office, Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York described her as a close confidante of his wife and children who had become, at times, “the fifth member of our immediate family.”

headline: Finding a Home, and a Muse, at the Algonquin Hotel
text: As comfortable as if he were in his own living room, Michael Colby, 63, lounged in a plush chair in the lobby of the Algonquin Hotel in Manhattan and enjoyed a fruit plate.

headline: Conference to Aid Syrians Falls Short of Expectations
text: In an ominous sign of possible donor fatigue, delegates to an international fund-raising conference for victims of the Syrian war pledged $3.8 billion on Tuesday, less than half the emergency humanitarian assistance sought by the United Nations for this year, even as the number of Syrians suffering mass displacement from the four-year-old conflict showed no sign of easing.

headline: Why I Moved to Florida
text: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — When my daughter Deb told me that she was taking a job with The New York Times, humorously writing about crossword puzzles edited by no less than Mr. Will Shortz himself, no one was happier than me. There is something to be said about watching a child that you sacrificed your life’s dreams for grow up and become, if not a Pulitzer Prize winner, at least moderately self-supporting. As long as she’s happy, my wife and I said to ourselves.

headline: Can Chris Mullin Thrive on Name and Local Ties? Peers Say Yes
text: This was 15 years ago, in the twilight of Chris Mullin’s wonderful basketball-playing life. Springtime in Indianapolis had matched him and the Pacers against his hometown Knicks, but Mullin wasn’t part of the playoff action, not in the way he had so often been, shooting picturesque southpaw jumpers from all over.

headline: Yankees’ Masahiro Tanaka Is ‘a Bit Relieved’ His Elbow Is Holding Up
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Only Masahiro Tanaka knows whether the small tear in his elbow ligament that caused him to miss two months last season is providing any discomfort or is in some way responsible for a slight dip in his pitching velocity during spring training.

headline: Janet Norwood Dies at 91; Led Labor Statistics Bureau
text: Janet L. Norwood, who ran the Bureau of Labor Statistics throughout the 1980s and maintained objectivity when politicians wanted her to interpret jobs data in a way that furthered their parties’ agendas, died on March 27 in Austin, Tex. She was 91.

headline: Knicks Will Set New Low; Only Question Is How Low
text: Some milestones await the Knicks in coming days, and none of them are good. As their awful season staggers to a merciful conclusion over the next two weeks, they are certain to set franchise records for the fewest victories in a season and for the worst winning percentage.

headline: Loopholes Seen in New Ethics Disclosure Rules for New York Legislators
text: ALBANY — Lawmakers who are convicted of public corruption may have to forfeit their pensions. Those who are lawyers will be forced to reveal, with some exceptions, the names of their clients. And all legislators will have to verify their whereabouts to collect their daily travel stipend.

headline: Nets, Hitting Their Stride When It Counts, Hold Off the Pacers
text: Less than a minute remained in the Nets’ game Tuesday night, and they were hounding the Indiana Pacers around the Barclays Center floor, their sneakers squeaking in a frantic rhythm as they tried to guard a 5-point lead. The desperation was palpable, and the doggedness paid off.

headline: New York City Comptroller Cites Flaws in Hurricane Sandy Recovery Program
text: A company hired by New York City to help homeowners rebuild after Hurricane Sandy had a “financial disincentive” to act more quickly because it had already been paid millions of dollars upfront, according to an audit released on Tuesday by Scott M. Stringer, the city comptroller.

headline: Cuomo Gets Deals on Tenure and Evaluations of Teachers

Cuomo and teachers’ unions ended in compromise on a variety of fronts, with the governor winning some changes in the way teachers are evaluated and granted tenure, and in how the state deals with chronically struggling schools.

headline: Context for the Debate on ‘Religious Freedom’ Measures in Indiana and Arkansas
text: Gov. Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas appeared set to join Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana in the national debate over religious rights and gay people on Tuesday as the Arkansas legislature passed its own Religious Freedom Restoration Act just a few days after Indiana passed a similar law that has drawn criticism for having the potential to abet discrimination against gay and lesbian couples.

headline: Recipes from Loosie Rouge, a New Brooklyn Bar With a New Orleans Accent
text: “In a place you call home, you can see what’s missing,” says Damien del Rio, a co-owner of the new Brooklyn bar Loosie Rouge. For del Rio and his associates, that home was Williamsburg, and the missing element was a bar that stayed true to the borough’s eclectic and creative spirit. “It’s not only Williamsburg, but what I’ve seen in Brooklyn growing up — the cultural aspects, the things that have been missing from New York for quite a while,” says del Rio, who was born and raised in Bed-Stuy, just a few miles from his watering hole, which opens today.

headline: A Tree-Scented Trio of Fragrances
text: “The tree is the origin of the most beautiful tales and legends, which lends itself perfectly to the values of Liquides Imaginaires,” says Philippe di Méo, the creative director and co-founder of the French perfumery whose ethos is to transport an individual through sensory experience. And with his company’s newest fragrance trilogy, Les Eaux Arborantes, available stateside for the first time today and designed to represent three elements of the tree, he hopes to propel the wearer into spring: “The tree symbolizes the rebirth of nature,” he says.

headline: Jerry Blevins Is ‘Happy to Be a New York Met’
text: VIERA, Fla. — Jerry Blevins was waiting in the Washington Nationals’ bullpen Monday afternoon when he first noticed something unusual. He was scheduled to pitch against the St. Louis Cardinals, but as the game went on, he was not summoned. Then he saw his manager walking toward the bullpen.

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
text: 8 P.M. (Starz Cinema) CAPOTE (2005) Philip Seymour Hoffman, above, won an Oscar for his embodiment of Truman Capote as he uncovers the story that became “In Cold Blood,” the novel about the 1959 murder of the Clutter family in Holcomb, Kan., in this drama directed by Bennett Miller from a script by Dan Futterman. Catherine Keener plays Nelle Harper Lee, Capote’s research assistant; Chris Cooper is Alvin Dewey, the lead investigator on the case; and Clifton Collins Jr. is the murderer Perry Smith. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called the film “a fascinating and fine-grained reconstruction of that period in its subject’s life, a time when he pursued literary glory and flirted with moral ruin.”

headline: After Horror in Libya, Christians’ Grief in an Egyptian Village

The day after watching it, the photographer Jonathan Rashad gathered his equipment for a trip south from Cairo, miles from the scene — but closer to those who felt it.

headline: Tell Me How This Ends Well
text: HONG KONG — I’ve been in China for the last week. It’s always instructive to see how the world looks from the Middle Kingdom. Sometimes the best insights come from just reading the local papers. On March 25, The China Daily published an essay detailing how “Beijing authorities” had “launched inspection tours of kindergartens this week to ensure that children are not overburdened with schoolwork. Although Chinese, mathematics and English are supposed to be taught to primary school students, it is not uncommon to see pre-school-age children across China being forced to study these subjects.” The essay went on to explain why it wasn’t healthy to “begin preparing for the college entrance exam” in preschool.

Specifically, how much should be granted to the outside world?

headline: ‘ISIS: Inside the Army of Terror,’ and More
text: A masked militant with a drawn knife, preparing to slaughter a helpless captive: This is how the group that was to become the Islamic State, more commonly known as ISIS, grabbed the world’s attention in 2004. The Islamic State has renamed and reinvented itself many times since then, but it still makes such scenes a staple of its propaganda.

headline: Ayaan Hirsi Ali’s ‘Heretic’
text: Following the events of the Arab Spring, Ayaan Hirsi Ali writes in her latest book, “Heretic,” she came to the conclusion that “ordinary Muslims are ready for change.” Hirsi Ali has strong thoughts on what form that change should take for Muslims: a major overhaul of their religion. “Without fundamental alterations to some of Islam’s core concepts,” she says, “we shall not solve the burning and increasingly global problem of political violence carried out in the name of religion.”

headline: Barefoot Running May Be Harder for Older Runners
text: Experienced older runners who switch to barefoot running may not adjust as naturally to the process as younger runners do, a new study suggests, which could increase their risk of sustaining an injury while running without shoes.

headline: Daily Report: Tech Leaders Come Together to Oppose Indiana Law

The heads of Apple, Salesforce.com, Yelp and Square have all publicly criticized the law, as have some leaders from other industries.

headline: Has American Business Lost Its Mojo?
text: Over the past three decades, the American economy has become less vigorous. An extensive body of evidence shows that the public focus on the success of high-tech companies like Apple and Google masks an overall downward trend in key measures of business vitality.

headline: Camping According to Your Taste
text: For many people, camping evokes visions of fishing, tents and swatting mosquitoes, in areas where outside communication ranges from difficult to impossible. Jim Rogers, the chairman and chief executive of Kampgrounds of America, would like to dispel the one-size-fits-all perception that camping often receives. The company, often referred to as KOA, is the largest privately owned system of campgrounds in the world, with more than 485 locations in the United States and Canada. “The campground is an oasis for genuine engagement,” Mr. Rogers said. “We’ve redefined camping, as we now have zip lines, horseback rides and pools at many properties.”

headline: Restaurant Report: 430 Duval in Key West, Fla.
text: The historic Crowne Plaza Key West La Concha, in the heart of the ever boisterous Duval Street corridor of Key West, has several claims to fame, including its prominence as the tallest building downtown.

headline: The Common Man’s Crown
text: The 1903 World Series was the first of baseball’s modern era. Boston and Pittsburgh were adhering to newly codified rules of play — and also initiating a new code of dress, as no one could have known, least of all the men in the stands, uniformly obedient to the laws of Edwardian haberdashery. The spectators wore “derbies, boaters, checkered caps and porkpie hats,” wrote Beverly Chico in her book, “Hats and Headwear Around the World.” Each style signaled a distinct social identity. All are now regarded largely as museum pieces, having fallen away in favor of a hat that offers casual comfort and a comforting image of classlessness. Given our cult of youth, our populist preference for informality and our native inclination toward sportiness, its emergence as the common man’s crown was inevitable.

headline: Stranger Still
text: I first heard about the writer Kamel Daoud a few years ago, when an Algerian friend of mine told me I should read him if I wanted to understand how her country had changed in recent years. “If Algeria can produce a Kamel Daoud,” she said, “I still have hope for Algeria.” Reading his columns in Le Quotidien d’Oran, a French-language newspaper, I saw what she meant. Daoud had an original, epigrammatic style: playful, lyrical, brash. I could also see why he’d been accused of racism, even “self-hatred.” After Sept. 11, for example, he wrote that the Arabs had been “crashing” for centuries and that they would continue crashing so long as they were better known for hijacking planes than for making them. But this struck me as the glib provocation of an otherwise intelligent writer carried away by his metaphors.

headline: Sydney Leroux and Alex Morgan: Peas in an Exacting Pod
text: Here is a story about the time Sydney Leroux wanted to jump off a cliff.

headline: Can I Profit From Accidentally Obtained Information?
text: At a previous job, I was responsible for complex negotiations that frequently involved email exchanges of draft transaction documents. One party would do a “redline” of the draft submitted by the other party, so that the receiver could see what changes the sender required. On one occasion, our counterparty mistakenly sent back its redline so that I was able to see text not intended for me: comment boxes and other evidence of what that company’s employees were saying to one another about their negotiating positions. This unintended transparency presumably occurred because the writers did not understand how to use Microsoft Word’s track-­changes functions. I was pretty certain that it was a genuine mistake and not a clever ruse. Using this knowledge, I was able to strike a better deal for my employer. Was it unethical to do so? NAME WITHHELD, NEW YORK

headline: The Editor Who Went to War
text: On the afternoon of April 1, 1865, over 10,000 Union cavalry soldiers were poised to attack the crossroads at Five Forks, Va. If Five Forks fell, so would the South Side Railroad, the last supply line to Richmond. Gen. Phil Sheridan hoped to end the nine-month stalemate along 20 miles of fortified trenches running between Richmond and Petersburg, Va.

headline: Transforming Nursing Home Care

headline: 1940: Army of 120,000 Starts Census
text: WASHINGTON — Tomorrow morning [April 2] 120,000 inquisitive persons, whose curiosity is defined and limited by law, will start on the seemingly gigantic task of taking a census of the population of the United States, the abode in 1930, year of the last complication, of 122,775,046 persons, of whom 2,190,791 were babies growing toward their first birthday and 3,964 were 100 years old or more. Experts anticipate that the census for the first time in the history of the United States will reveal a decline in the foreign-born population due to the quota system limiting immigration. In the 1930-38 period, emigration exceeded immigration by 130,000. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 2, 1940

headline: Cellphones for Women in Developing Nations Aid Ascent From Poverty

She may even worry about her husband taking cash she has budgeted for their children’s needs. Sending money to a family member in another village is risky and can take days. Obtaining a loan in an emergency is often impossible.

headline: 1965: Nonlethal Gas Use Examined
text: LONDON — Colonial Secretary Anthony Greenwood told Parliament today [April 1] that Britain had used nonlethal gas 124 times in the last five years. Some members of Parliament were shocked. The left wing of Prime Minister Harold Wilson’s governing Labor party has bitterly protested U.S. gas warfare in South Vietnam. Mr. Greenwood said British colonial police had used the gas to disarm and disperse rioters and to quell jail breaks. He said it was used 97 times in British Guiana. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 2, 1965.

text: It seems that everyone loves the country of Georgia. You can barely mention it without people piping up to say how startlingly beautiful the Caucasus mountain villages are, or raving about meats grilled over grapevines, the generous use of walnuts and pomegranates, or internationally beloved acharuli khachapuri, fresh baked cheesebread with a raw egg on top. But what they may leave out is how cheap it is — especially true since the lari has lost 20 percent of its value since last summer.

headline: Finding the Farce in Hitchcock, Again, ‘The 39 Steps’
text: The modest double digits in its title don’t begin to capture the exponentially increasing numbers conjured by “39 Steps,” in previews at the Union Square Theater. Since its British debut a decade ago, this delightfully dizzy little play — adapted from “The 39 Steps,” the 1935 Alfred Hitchcock film about love (and espionage) on the run — has divided and multiplied itself in ways that would shame an amoeba. It features a cast of four playing 150 characters, who pursue, run from and deceive one another on a basically bare stage that somehow feels incredibly crowded.

headline: Dolce & Gabbana Earrings Fit for a Queen (Bee)
text: Where flowers bloom, bees follow. And so they do in Dolce & Gabbana’s one-of-a-kind sculptural earrings that evoke summer in Sicily, Domenico Dolce’s birthplace. Each handcrafted pendant, part of the Italian house’s rarefied Alta Gioielleria, or high jewelry, collection, begins with a daisy of faceted aquamarine petals, its center cut from golden beryl — a pure yellow gem known for its brilliant hue. A two-inch gold drone, a symbol of royalty and nature’s industriousness, dangles from the edge, seemingly sipping nectar. The bee’s head, legs and thorax are diamond-encrusted; its eyes are emeralds and its wings are fashioned of painstakingly formed filigree. Alternating bands of curved black jade and citrine create the stripes on the insect’s abdomen and a large, baroque South Sea pearl hangs from the bottom. They may not make honey, but they will turn heads.

headline: Auto Sales Slow After Months of Healthy Growth

headline: 36 Hours in Lisbon
text: Throughout this hilly city on the Tagus River, structures and spaces are being stylishly reborn, harboring chic boutiques, galleries and new spots for eating and drinking.

headline: 36 Hours in Lisbon
text: Everything old is new again in the Portuguese capital. Throughout the hilly metropolis on the Tagus River, fading structures and spaces are being stylishly reborn. Once-forlorn neighborhood markets have undergone ambitious renovations and currently form the city’s newest hot spots for dining and drinking. Formerly decrepit townhouses now harbor Lisbon’s chicest indie shopping centers, and the once-dodgy docklands boom with emergent night life in multiple guises. Even the city’s dowdy, underused central square and adjacent waterfront have been spruced up for lounging and strolling. At the same time, the city’s classic historical charms, from art museums to industrialists’ mansions, remain beautifully intact, complementing their rejuvenated neighbors.

text: One of the world’s great coding libraries is safe, for now.

headline: Finding Respite on Basketball Court
text: Amid Kurdistan’s battle against ISIS, women’s basketball at the American University of Iraq, Sulaimaniya, has provided a sense of continuity.

headline: If an Expert in Day Care Can’t Find a Good One, Can Anyone?
text: I am a professor of early childhood education and a former preschool teacher. My primary research interest is preschool and child care quality, and how families select preschool for their children. As a parent, though, I have been unsuccessful at finding a good preschool for my own child.

headline: Adam Crapser’s Bizarre Deportation Odyssey
text: This past February, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers knocked on an apartment door in Vancouver, Wash., looking for a man named Adam Crapser. A 39-year-old former barbershop owner and auto-insurance claims estimator, Crapser was now the married stay-at-home father of three children, with another baby on the way. He lived a mostly quiet life, playing the guitar and ukulele, looking after a rescue dog and taking his children to the park and the science museum. But the ICE agents at the door were there to inform him that the agency was opening deportation proceedings that could send him to South Korea.

headline: Harry Kane, Globalization and the Push to Limit Foreign Players in the Premier League
text: Last week, a 21-year-old soccer player named Harry Kane made a spectacular debut for England’s national team, scoring against Lithuania just 79 seconds after entering the game and then wheeling away with a look of joyous disbelief as a crowd of roughly 80,000 countrymen roared approval.

headline: Russian Artists Face a Choice: Censor Themselves, or Else
text: MOSCOW — After a law went into effect last summer banning obscenities in public performances, the playwright and director Ivan Vyrypaev excised the curse words from one of his plays, “The Drunks,” for its Russian debut at the prestigious Moscow Art Theater. Some actors played the new version straight, he said, while others winked to make clear what was cut.

headline: Norway Reverts to Cold War Mode as Russian Air Patrols Spike
text: BODO, Norway — From his command post burrowed deep into a mountain of quartz and slate north of the Arctic Circle, the 54-year-old commander of the Norwegian military’s operations headquarters watches time flowing backward, pushed into reverse by surging Russian military activity redolent of East-West sparring during the Cold War.

headline: The Limits of Tylenol for Pain Relief
text: Acetaminophen (Tylenol) is widely recommended for the relief of back pain and the pain of knee and hip arthritis. But a systematic review of randomized trials has found that it works no better than a placebo.

headline: Buying Apartment Buildings in New York and Beyond in a Strategic Bet
text: When Luis Rinaldini, co-founder of Groton Merchant Bankers, wanted to add New York apartment buildings to the firm’s investment portfolio in 2010, he took a chance on two young college graduates to make it happen.

headline: Bunny Business
text: The beguiling beauty and arduous hair-care regimen of the Angora rabbit.

headline: Dutch Royal Family Acts Quickly After Looted Painting Is Found
text: Tracking down art looted during World War II usually takes decades. But the Dutch royal family achieved the feat in relatively record time: A 16-month investigation of the palace art collection identified a 17th-century painting that the family pledges will be returned to the descendants of the Jewish owner.

headline: To Catch a Hacker
text: One reason American businesses and the government remain vulnerable to foreign hackers is that it is incredibly hard to arrest and prosecute those criminals. Responding to that difficulty, President Obama is giving the Treasury Department the power to issue financial sanctions against hackers and the people and businesses that hire them to conduct cyber attacks.

headline: ‘Ready for Hillary’ Workers Are Ready to Join Campaign
text: Since Hillary Rodham Clinton left the State Department in early 2013, the main group pushing for her to make a second presidential run has been Ready for Hillary, a “super PAC” that signed up more than four million supporters and — through regular reports about such grass-roots fervor for Mrs. Clinton — helped freeze the Democratic field.

headline: Atlanta Educators Convicted in School Cheating Scandal
text: ATLANTA — In a dramatic conclusion to what has been described as the largest cheating scandal in the nation’s history, a jury here on Wednesday convicted 11 educators for their roles in a standardized test cheating scandal that tarnished a major school district’s reputation and raised broader questions about the role of high-stakes testing in American schools.

headline: The PayPal Mafia’s Golden Touch
text: The ride-hailing app Uber, the apartment rental site Airbnb and other darlings of the next generation of Silicon Valley start-ups are reshaping the way people use the web. They are also changing expectations about just how much money private companies can raise while still staying out of the public markets.

Editors on the News Desk coordinate with editors running the coverage to decide when to send the alert and what it will say. Speed is key, but accuracy is even more important.

headline: At the Jewish Museum of Vienna, Enduring Images of Europe
text: Erich Lessing is one of the foremost chroniclers of 20th-century Europe, known equally well for photographing politicians like Charles de Gaulle, Eastern Bloc beauty queens, and daily life — a bar mitzvah boy in postwar Poland, a tailor in front of his war-damaged store.

text: Venture capitalists invest in companies in search of breakout hits. These rarities, called unicorns, have grown in size and number as investors chasing returns have bid up their value.

text: With “Furious 7,” the director James Wan takes a break from the horror films for which he’s known (“Insidious” “The Conjuring”) to try pure action. In this video, he discussed an exhilarating, slightly crazy scene. Mr. Wan also touched on working with Paul Walker and finishing the film after Mr. Walker’s death in 2013. Here are excerpts from that conversation.

headline: California Imposes First Mandatory Water Restrictions to Deal With Drought
text: PHILLIPS, Calif. — Gov. Jerry Brown on Wednesday ordered mandatory water use reductions for the first time in California’s history, saying the state’s four-year drought had reached near-crisis proportions after a winter of record-low snowfalls.

headline: John D. States Dies at 89; Doctor Helped Create New York’s Seatbelt Law
text: Dr. John D. States, whose research and advocacy persuaded New York in 1984 to enact the nation’s first state law requiring drivers and front-seat passengers to use automobile seatbelts, died on March 26 in the Rochester hospital where he was born. He was 89.

headline: Review: In ‘Furious 7,’ a Franchise Continues to Roar
text: In a recent interview in Variety, Vin Diesel predicted that “Furious 7” would win the best picture Oscar at next year’s Academy Awards. “Unless the Oscars don’t want to be relevant ever,” he added, though that issue may already be settled. If Mr. Diesel’s prophecy doesn’t come true, it won’t necessarily be a matter of merit. Movies much worse than this lucky-number episode of an overachieving franchise — movies far less sure of their intentions, sincere in their themes or kind to their audiences — have snapped up statuettes. There will no doubt be better movies released in 2015, but “Furious 7” is an early favorite to win the prize for most picture.

headline: Political Thunder Over the Iran Deal
text: With a preliminary deal limiting Iran’s nuclear program apparently in the endgame, opponents are using political thunder to substitute for real information about what’s going on inside the closed-door negotiations.

headline: Russia Shuts Down TV Station Serving Crimean Tatars
text: MOSCOW — Russia pulled the plug on the last independent television station serving Crimean Tatars on Wednesday, continuing what members of the Tatar minority called a pattern of discrimination because of their opposition to Russia’s annexation of the Black Sea peninsula.

headline: Yes, Your Time as a Parent Does Make a Difference
text: The latest salvo in the mommy wars is that all that time you spend parenting just doesn’t matter. But it’s a claim that, despite the enthusiastic and widespread coverage by news media outlets that include The Washington Post, Vox, The Guardian, The Independent, The Globe and Mail, NBC News, The Chicago Tribune and The New York Times’s Motherlode, does not hold water.

headline: A Quick Point Guard’s Unconventional Path to UConn

headline: The Scrambled States of Immigration
text: A country that has abandoned all efforts at creating a saner immigration policy has gotten the result it deserves: not one policy but lots of little ones, acting at cross purposes and nullifying one another. Not unity but cacophony, a national incoherence — one well illustrated in a recent report in The Times on the various ways the states, forsaken by Congress, are adjusting to the millions of unauthorized immigrants living outside the law.

headline: A Haven Between the Hoops in Kurdistan
text: The invasion by the Islamic State, or ISIS, last summer brought tremendous heartache to Kurdistan, the autonomous region in northern Iraq. Thousands of members of the pesh merga, the Kurdish security forces, have been killed and injured, and government employees and teachers have not been paid in months. The future is uncertain. But in Sulaimaniya, a city of about 1.5 million near the Iranian border, things might be looking up for young women.

headline: Oil Glut Is a Boon to Shippers, as Buyers Stock Up at Low Prices
text: LONDON — Jonathan Lee has spent 30 years in the shipping business. But he was as excited as a rookie over the scene on his screen one recent day here at the international nerve center of his oil tanker chartering and dispatching company.

headline: 13 Weeks at No. 1 for ‘Uptown Funk’
text: Mark Ronson’s “Uptown Funk” has dominated the Billboard singles chart since the beginning of 2015, and this week it notches a remarkable 13th time at No. 1. That is the longest run for any song since 2009, when Black Eyed Peas’ “I Gotta Feeling” was tops for 14 weeks straight.

headline: Religious Freedom vs. Individual Equality
text: Indiana’s governor is now vowing to “clarify” a religious freedom law he recently signed in that state, because of what he calls a “perception problem” about whether the legislation would allow open discrimination against people whose sexual identities defy the heteronormative construct.

headline: Purvi Patel Could Be Just the Beginning
text: The prosecution of Purvi Patel began in sorrow and ended in more sadness this week. Patel, a 33-year-old woman who lives in Indiana, was accused of feticide — specifically, illegally inducing her own abortion — and accused of having a baby whom she allowed to die. The facts supporting each count are murky, but a jury convicted Patel in February, and on Monday she was sentenced to 20 years in prison.

At 38, Vince Carter Drifts to the 3-Point Line and Reinvents Himself
text: MEMPHIS — Vince Carter began to lose his hair when he was about 23, but he still goes to the barber with specific instructions. Last week, he wanted his beard trimmed.

headline: Review: Dennis Lehane’s ‘World Gone By’ Completes a Loose Trio of Novels
text: When “The Given Day” arrived in 2008, Dennis Lehane described his 704-page magnum opus as the beginning of a possible trilogy. That’s not exactly how things worked out. Instead of sequels, he wound up producing a very loosely linked trio, adding on “Live by Night” (2012) and now “World Gone By.” Each is written very differently: first, a research-filled epic; then a lean, classic Edgar-winning specimen of 1930s crime noir; and now a suspenseful but reflective accumulation of all the wisdom these books have offered.

headline: Filing on HSBC Compliance
text: The British bank that reached a $1.9 billion settlement to resolve accusations of money laundering still has a long way to go to root out the problems, federal prosecutors say.

headline: Klaus Tschira, Business Software Trailblazer, Dies at 74
text: Klaus E. Tschira, whose pioneering role in the business software revolution made him one of Germany’s richest men, died on Tuesday in Heidelberg. He was 74.

headline: Hongdae Style in Seoul
text: “When I come to Hongdae, I get inspired just by seeing people on the street,” Mina Kwon, an illustrator, said of the hip neighborhood in Seoul, South Korea. “It’s kind of like Harajuku in Japan.” Wearing a Vivienne Westwood jacket, stacked bracelets, a snapback from D9 (a label she designs for) and Timberland boots, Ms. Kwon also gets style ideas from Pharrell Williams. Recently she also did a collection for Forever 21 that includes her street-style take on SpongeBob. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: Review: Alexi Kenney at Weill Recital Hall
text: Some musicians take extra care preparing the first bars of a concert’s opening piece, to ensure a flawless start to the evening. It certainly sounded as if the violinist Alexi Kenney had done so at Weill Recital Hall on Tuesday evening, immediately drawing listeners in with his beautifully phrased and delicate playing in the first-movement Allemande of Johann Paul von Westhoff’s Suite No. 2 in A for solo violin.

headline: Winning Defense at the Spring Nationals
text: There were two particularly meritorious defensive plays during the Spring Nationals in New Orleans last month.

headline: For Players, Tournament Excitement Gives Way to Morning Classes

headline: ClassPass: Deep Discounts, but Some Discontent
text: ClassPass — the two-year-old service that for $99 a month grants members access to a slew of boutique fitness studios — is wildly popular, with class reservations booked in New York City increasing threefold in the last six months.

headline: Review: ‘Sinatra,’ Alex Gibney’s New HBO Documentary, Explores a Legend
text: Few people have led a more examined life than Frank Sinatra did, so a documentarian taking on the subject needs a distinctive approach. Alex Gibney (who also directed the recently-aired Scientology documentary “Going Clear”) finds at least a somewhat successful one for “Sinatra: All or Nothing at All,” which has its premiere Sunday and Monday nights on HBO. Still, there’s no disguising that the story is awfully familiar.

headline: Verbatim: Booker Stands With Menendez
text: Senator Cory Booker, Democrat of New Jersey, on the indictment of his colleague, Senator Robert Menendez.

headline: Play Reimagining ‘Three’s Company’ Wins Case
text: A federal judge in New York ruled on Tuesday that the Off Broadway play “3C,” a darkly comic reimagining of the TV hit “Three’s Company,” did not infringe the copyright of that decades-old sitcom. In the ruling, Judge Loretta A. Preska of the United States District Court wrote that the play represented a “drastic departure” from the TV show, which ran from 1977 to 1984 and remains in syndication.

headline: Subrosa, a Latin Beat in the Meatpacking District
text: Before the trendy hotels moved in, the meatpacking district was a curious place, with hidden spots behind its battered industrial visage. Sebastian Nicolas, 35, an original partner from the Box, the burlesque club on the Lower East Side, hopes to bring a little of that mystery back with a live music “listening room” called Subrosa.

headline: The Beard Goes Technicolor
text: Has the beard become such a hipster cliché that some wearers now need an embellishment to set them apart from every other 20-something with scruffy facial hair?

headline: Review: Liz Gerring’s ‘Glacier’ Has Its New York Premiere
text: The eight dancers in Liz Gerring’s “Glacier” keep changing its temperature. At first, the mood is clinical. Dancers walk, run, balance, fall; they’re often on the cusp of pedestrianism. Since much of the movement is big — and some of it is sports-related — that’s already arresting. But a kinesthetic impetus soon develops, and this becomes full-bodied dancing that changes my breathing.

headline: Staten Island Ferry to Add More Early Morning Trips
text: The Staten Island Ferry is a step closer to running every half-hour around the clock, easing travel for early morning riders.

headline: British Challenger Bank Shawbrook Valued at $1 Billion in I.P.O.
text: The Shawbrook Group, the latest challenger to Britain’s traditional banks to go public, said on Wednesday that it has priced its initial public offering, valuing the company at 725 million pounds, or about $1 billion.

headline: Lucy Lawless Brings a Defiant Edge to ‘Salem’
text: For its first scripted series last year, WGN America went all in on out-there with “Salem,” a witchy tale that rivaled “American Horror Story” in its willingness to be audacious. Few who saw the pilot will forget the scene in which a naked Mary Sibley helped her husband vomit up a frog. With Season 2 beginning on Sunday, how does the channel plan on upping the ante?

headline: A New Exhibition Celebrates Le Corbusier, Through the Eyes of Those He Influenced
text: “Re-Corbusier,” a new exhibition in Paris featuring international artists, explores the influence of the Modernist Swiss architect through others’ creations. The show, which coincides with the 50th anniversary of Le Corbusier’s death, serves as an imaginative counterpoint to the career survey of the architect’s work that will begin at the Centre Pompidou later this month. “There’s a variety in medium, and in generation,” the curator Marjolaine Lévy says of the selection. “Most pieces are part of a series; these aren’t one-off works,” the co-curator Catherine de Smet adds, “which corroborates the artists’ attraction to Le Corbusier’s work.”

headline: The Indictment of Senator Robert Menendez
text: Mr. Menendez was charged with eight counts of bribery, which carry up to 15 years in prison on each charge.

headline: Brunello Cucinelli Clothes Can Make You a Better Man. Provided You’re Very, Very Rich.
text: You never quite know when manhood will arrive, but most certainly, it happens to you before you’re aware of it. There are the demands that need to be met, the hands that need to be held, the wisdom that needs to be imparted.

headline: ‘Scrapbooking’ Our Children Into Facebook
text: It’s official — or at least, you can now make it official: Your baby can have her own Facebook page.

headline: Love and Loss on the Road to Arkansas
text: Nina Robinson’s plans for a fun Southern road trip took a detour when her grandmother died. She ended up delving deep into the rituals and routines of her family.

headline: A Friendly Pillow Fight, Worldwide
text: It might be the world’s largest flash mob. On Saturday, April 4, tens of thousands of people in more than 100 cities worldwide will take to the streets, feathers flying, for the seventh annual International Pillow Fight Day. This year’s event includes cities across four continents, from Shanghai to Seattle, Buenos Aires to Budapest.

headline: Axwell and Ingrosso at Terminal 5
text: The Swedish electronic dance music maestros played a sold-out show on March 30.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Officials on Iran Nuclear Negotiations
text: Mohammad Javad Zarif, Iran’s foreign minister, and Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, discussed the status of talks on Iranian’s nuclear program.

headline: Yukos Investors Settle With Rosneft, Russia’s State Oil Company
text: Yukos, the defunct Russian oil giant whose dismantling a decade ago came to define a country’s flawed property rights system, announced on Wednesday that it had reached a final legal settlement with Rosneft, the state oil company that prospered from the breakup.

headline: The D.J. Maestros Axwell and Ingrosso Aim to Shake the Rafters
text: The Swedish D.J.s and producers Axwell and Sebastian Ingrosso, known lately as the duo Axwell and Ingrosso, hid in the immaculate bowels of the Apple Store in SoHo earlier this week, plotting their escape.

headline: Liquidity Traps, Local and Global (Somewhat Wonkish)
text: There’s been a really interesting back and forth between Ben Bernanke and Larry Summers over secular stagnation. I agree with most of what both have to say. But there’s a substantive difference in views, in which Bernanke correctly, I’d argue, criticizes Summers for insufficient attention to international capital flows – but then argues that once you do allow for international capital movement it obviates many of the secular stagnation concerns, which I believe is wrong.

headline: Reviewing Sound Bars: An Alternative to TV Home Theater Systems
text: WHEN it comes to great television sound, thin is definitely not in.

headline: In a Nod to Past and Future, Clinton Pushes Child Development in Brooklyn
text: For one of her final events before she makes her 2016 presidential campaign official, Hillary Rodham Clinton returned to the cause that started her career in public service: children.

headline: A Closer Look at the Details
text: Carlos Quirarte’s two-room apartment is filled with light and found items.

headline: Former I.R.S. Official Won’t Be Charged for Refusing to Testify
text: WASHINGTON — Federal prosecutors have concluded that Lois Lerner, a former Internal Revenue Service official, should not be charged for refusing to answer questions before a congressional committee about the agency’s improper treatment of conservative groups seeking tax-exempt status, the Justice Department said on Wednesday.

headline: Concord Music Group Buys Vanguard and Sugar Hill
text: In an expansion of one of the world’s largest independent music companies, the Concord Music Group — home to Paul McCartney, Paul Simon and a catalog of classic jazz and soul recordings — announced Wednesday that it had acquired two record labels, Vanguard and Sugar Hill.

headline: Denim Jackets That Are Far From Old-Fashioned and More
text: The classic jean jacket gets a makeover; post-winter fur; mixing girlish frills with tougher edges; and a fun way to wear summer platforms now.

headline: Review: Death Cab for Cutie’s ‘Kintsugi’
text: Desertion — inseparable from its aftermath of recovery — haunts “Kintsugi” (Atlantic), the eighth album by Death Cab for Cutie. Titled after the Japanese art of mending cracked ceramics with precious metals, it’s a smartly shaped response to two recent disentanglements, at least one of which seems to have left a residue of trauma.

headline: Trevor Noah Learns Twitter Just Can’t Take a Joke
text: IN 2002, at a coffee shop in one of San Francisco’s less-charming neighborhoods, I stood in front of 10 or 12 people and told a joke about AIDS. It got a laugh. After I delivered it, as I segued into a searing analysis of Destiny’s Child, I noticed a guy at a table with a Kaposi’s sarcoma on his forehead. When I was writing that AIDS joke, I figured since I was gay, it was fine for me to talk about AIDS, but in context, looking at the joke through the eyes of my audience, I realized it wasn’t something I wanted to do again.

headline: California Governor Imposes Water Order
text: Gov. Jerry Brown announced a sweeping executive order that imposes California’s first mandatory water restrictions as the state’s drought has reached near-crisis proportions.

headline: Turkish Police Foil Attack on Police Station
text: ISTANBUL — A day after a Turkish prosecutor was taken hostage and killed in an attack on Istanbul’s main courthouse by leftist extremists, the police on Wednesday thwarted another attack, killing a woman in a shootout near the city’s central police station.

headline: Looking for Cheaper Skin-Care Products? Borrow From the Men
text: Jennifer Quinn, 25, a digital marketing specialist who lives on the Upper East Side with her boyfriend, Ramine Bigdeliazari, was in the shower about six months ago when she ran out of her L’Occitane Aromachologie Revitalizing Body Scrub. So she tried her boyfriend’s Blue Sea Kelp Body Scrub, by the men’s brand Anthony.

headline: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York
text: Bummed about the lingering chill? Stop into the new shopping mall Brookfield Place, where the first 14 stores — including Diane von Furstenberg, Michael Kors, Tory Burch, Paul Smith and Vince — are now open, to stock up on pieces for when the weather finally turns. At 230 Vesey Street. ... The luxury watch brand IWC Schaffhausen is auctioning an IWC Portofino Monopusher Tribeca Film Festival white gold timepiece through Christie’s, along with a “Money-Can’t-Buy Tribeca Film Festival Experience” that includes V.I.P. access to the festival and hotel accommodation. At christies.com/iwctribeca.

text: Zachary Catazaro and Joshua Thew, both New York City Ballet dancers, donned a few of the freest-wheeling suits.

headline: In Four Loops, Marathon Conveys Palestinian Constraints
text: BETHLEHEM, West Bank — The runners looped four times through this city, following a route that took them from the Church of the Nativity, traditionally considered Christ’s birthplace, down Bethlehem’s main avenue and alongside Israel’s looming separation barrier, scrawled with graffiti and blackened from hurled projectiles.

headline: Cruz, in Iowa, Commends Indiana for ‘Doing the Right Thing’
text: SIOUX CITY, Iowa – The more than 100 people who showed up for a town-hall-style event at Morningside College here on Wednesday heard Senator’s Ted Cruz’s thoughts on the battle over a law in Indiana billed as a religious freedom measure.

headline: C.F.T.C. Accuses Kraft and Mondelez of Manipulating Wheat Prices
text: Less than a week after agreeing to sell itself to H. J. Heinz in a blockbuster deal, the Kraft Foods Group has found itself the target of a government lawsuit over wheat prices.

headline: Backlash Against Indiana Religious Exceptions
text: The Indiana law has touched off a storm of protests from businesses, local governments and college athletics.

headline: Verbatim: Menendez Repeats, ‘I’m Not Going Anywhere’
text: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey saying at a press conference on Wednesday what he said earlier this month when it was learned that criminal corruption charges were likely: He began his career fighting corruption and he is “not going anywhere.”

headline: How Has the California Drought Affected You?
text: Gov. Jerry Brown ordered mandatory water restrictions for the first time in California history. How will water rationing affect you?

headline: S.E.C. Fires Warning Shot About Confidentiality Agreements
text: A sound that delights regulators and strikes fear in corporations — employees’ blowing the whistle on wrongdoing — is poised to become louder.

headline: Nigerian President-Elect Muhammadu Buhari Sets Out His Agenda
text: KANO, Nigeria — Nigeria’s president-elect, Muhammadu Buhari, did not smile while making his acceptance speech on Wednesday — understandably, as terrorism and corruption were his main talking points.

headline: Cynthia Lennon, the First Beatles Wife, Dies at 75
text: Cynthia Lennon, the first wife of the Beatles’ John Lennon, who chronicled their troubled marriage in two memoirs, died on Wednesday at her home in Mallorca, Spain. She was 75.

headline: 560,000-Acre Swath of Florida Land Going on the Market
text: The largest contiguous parcel of undeveloped private land east of the Mississippi River, a vast swath of forest in northern Florida, is going on the market and is expected to bring $1 billion or more when it is sold this year.

headline: EBay Begins Streaming Live Sotheby’s Auctions
text: The buildup was intense. Since July, when Sotheby’s struck a deal with eBay to have its auctions carried live, the marriage of the blue-blood auction house to the blue-collar online retailer had generated tingles of anticipation. But on Wednesday, when eBay streamed Sotheby’s auctions for the first time, the event could not have been more sedate, more like a day at the library than a cut-and-thrust bidding war over Cameoware dishes.

headline: Tom Koch, 89, Dies; Comedy Writer Invented a 43-Man Game
text: Tom Koch, a creator of the vexingly convoluted game 43-man Squamish for Mad magazine and unheralded author of thousands of comedy scripts for Bob and Ray radio programs that in his words parodied “pompous versions of real people,” died on March 22 at his home in Laguna Woods, Calif. He was 89.

headline: New Stumble in Trial of Former Goldman Programmer
text: The long-running case against Sergey Aleynikov — a former Goldman Sachs programmer criminally convicted, and then acquitted, only to be charged again — has rarely seemed to bring out the best in his government accusers. Take Wednesday, which was set to be the first day of Mr. Aleynikov’s new trial.

headline: California Drought Is Worsened by Global Warming, Scientists Say
text: The severe California drought that has led the state to order cutbacks in water use may not have been set off by climate change, scientists say, but global warming is making the situation worse.

headline: Chris Mullin, Back Where He Starred, Basks in the Glow of a St. John’s Reunion
text: After talking for nearly two hours — at a formal news conference in front of 1,000 fans, during interviews carried on a dozen television stations and while being photographed with trustees, boosters and the St. John’s mascot — Chris Mullin walked alone through a corridor of Carnesecca Arena and found one of the few faces he did not know.

headline: Doubts Intensify About Reports of a Video Made During Germanwings Flight’s Final Moments
text: It has been described as the chilling final seconds of blurry pandemonium before the crash, with metallic banging and passengers screaming, “My God!” in multiple languages, captured on a cellphone video shot from the rear of the cabin.

headline: New York Detective Put on Desk Duty After Tirade With Uber Driver
text: A veteran New York police detective has been placed on desk duty for an angry, profanity-laced tirade he delivered Monday to an Uber driver he confronted while driving on-duty in Manhattan.

headline: 4 Killed in Explosion and Fire on Pemex Mexican Oil Platform
text: Huge fireballs illuminated the early dawn skies of the Gulf of Mexico on Wednesday as an explosion and fire killed four people and injured as many as 16 others on a large oil platform in the southeastern Bay of Campeche, Mexican officials said.

headline: Walmart Emerges as Unlikely Social Force
text: Walmart, which has deployed its financial might to squeeze extra gallons of gas out of its trucks and shave pennies off the price of laundry detergent, did something unexpected this week: It muscled its way into a divisive social debate.

headline: Mets Have Strange Feeling: Confidence
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets were trailing by three runs in the bottom of the ninth inning in a meaningless exhibition game Wednesday when the reserve players began a rally and the starters began shouting in excitement at the clubhouse televisions, urging them on.

headline: Hillary Clinton Joins Chirlane McCray to Promote Child Care Effort in New York
text: The guests spoke of early motherhood, recalling the songs they once sang to their children, and asked others at the education center in Brownsville, Brooklyn, to do the same.

headline: A Nuclear Deal With Iran Isn’t Just About Bombs
text: To prove that Americans can be every bit as crazy as Iranians, I took my daughter along on my last trip to Iran, in 2012, for a road trip across the country.

headline: Arkansas Moves to Revise Legislation as Concerns of Religion and Gay Rights Intensify
text: LITTLE ROCK, Ark. — Facing a backlash from businesses and gay rights advocates, Gov. Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas on Wednesday urged lawmakers to rework legislation billed as a religious freedom measure to ensure that it mirrors federal law.

headline: Jeb Bush Seems to Shift Tone in His Praise of Indiana Law
text: Jeb Bush appeared to modify his public comments about Indiana’s “religious freedom” law on Wednesday in a closed-door Silicon Valley fund-raiser, telling a small group of potential supporters that a “consensus-oriented” approach would have been better at the outset.

headline: As Lydia Ko Turns 18, She Hopes to Celebrate With a Major Title
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — Before the world No. 1 women’s golfer, Lydia Ko, got to work Wednesday on the range, she settled a piece of business. Ko took a $10 bill out of her wallet and approached the caddie Mardi Lunn, a native Australian. Using a black permanent marker, Ko, a Korean-born New Zealander, neatly wrote “Go NZ” on the back of the bill, signed her name and drew a kiwi, the bird that is a symbol of New Zealand.

headline: The Netherlands: New Details on Date of Anne Frank’s Death
text: The young Holocaust diarist Anne Frank most likely died a month earlier than previously believed, the Frank museum in Amsterdam has concluded. Tuesday was 70 years since March 31, 1945, when she was thought to have died at the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp in Germany. The timing of her death, from typhus, was established by the Dutch Red Cross, which visited the camp after it was liberated by British soldiers on April 15, 1945. Using new witness testimony and documentation related to Anne and her sister, Margot, including a transport list from Feb. 7, 1945, the museum now believes the two sisters died in February, Erika Prins, a researcher at the museum, said Wednesday.

headline: Another Arrangement
text: THURSDAY PUZZLE — I truly hope you’re not sick of hearing about the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, because we’re not done yet. Yes, the big boards have been put away, and I’m still working on another photo feature called “Humans of A.C.P.T.,” but in the meantime, above are some highlights from Puzzle 7.

headline: Agent Was Secretly Investigated During Silk Road Trial
text: The trial of Ross W. Ulbricht on charges he ran Silk Road, a website that allowed people to engage anonymously in drug dealing and other illicit activities, was widely watched in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Mr. Ulbricht was convicted in February and now faces a potential life sentence.

headline: What Is Morgellons? Singer Joni Mitchell’s Disputed Diagnosis
text: Joni Mitchell, 71, was taken to a hospital in Los Angeles on Tuesday after she was found unconscious at her Los Angeles home. In recent years, the singer has complained of a number of health problems, including one particularly unusual ailment: Morgellons disease.

headline: Gettys Again Made to Cope With Grief in Public Eye
text: LOS ANGELES — The curious death of Andrew R. Getty on Tuesday at his gated hillside mansion here has once again thrust one of America’s wealthiest and most-troubled families into an unwanted spotlight.

headline: Injuries Spur Unplanned Infield Shift for Yankees
text: TAMPA, Fla. — As shortstop Brendan Ryan slid toward second base to field a grounder during the Yankees’ exhibition game Wednesday against the Rays, second baseman Stephen Drew heard Ryan shout. So by the time the ball bounced off Ryan’s bare hand, Drew knew something was wrong.

headline: Is Yemen America's Fight?
text: Should the United States avoid getting involved — even indirectly — in regional efforts to fight the Houthis in Yemen?

headline: How Has the Drought Affected California’s Water Use?
text: An interactive map shows how much water California residents conserved in April and how much daily consumption they are being forced to cut under new mandatory restrictions.

headline: Rights Measures Expose Divisions in G.O.P.’s Ranks
text: WASHINGTON — In Indiana, the Republican mayor of Indianapolis argued against the law the Republican governor had signed. In Ohio, a group called the Young Conservatives for the Freedom to Marry tried to remove antigay language from the party platform. In Arkansas, the Republican governor faced a backlash from business and asked the Republican-led legislature to recall a bill seen as discriminatory to same-sex couples.

headline: Mets Among Major League Leaders in at Least One Category
text: The Mets’ off-season was essentially devoid of splashy moves, as the front office chose to make judicious upgrades in the outfield while looking to an existing core of players — some veterans, some fairly new to the majors — to improve on a 79-83 record.

headline: Luxury Public Golf Course, Run by Trump, Opens on Former Bronx Dump
text: After decades of debate, false starts and cost overruns, luxury golf finally arrived in the Bronx on Wednesday, as the Trump Golf Links at Ferry Point opened in the shadow of the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge.

headline: Damion Hardy’s Murder Trial Begins, After 10 Years of Sanity Arguments
text: In the decade since federal authorities arrested Damion Hardy and charged him with leading a Brooklyn drug crew and ordering six murders, lawyers have argued over one main issue: Is Mr. Hardy mentally competent to stand trial?

headline: Nets Keep Surging Toward Playoffs; Knicks Keep Sinking to Bottom
text: On the Nets’ second possession Wednesday night, Markel Brown went up high after a lob pass and came down hard, after the Knicks’ Langston Galloway nudged him midflight. Brown writhed on the court for several minutes, through a timeout. It looked bad. The Madison Square Garden crowd was even quieter than usual.

headline: Kentucky’s Big Blue Machine Is Ready to Refuel
text: Isaiah Briscoe did not have to be there. His Roselle Catholic High School team had just won the New Jersey high school boys’ championship less than 48 hours earlier. The season was officially over. He had a busy travel schedule of all-star tournaments and events coming up over the next week, so it was a natural time to finally relax — to not touch a basketball for a week or so.

headline: With Playoffs in Sight, Islanders Correct Their Course
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — From coach to captain, the Islanders are a relieved group, after a comeback victory over the Detroit Red Wings on Sunday ended a monthlong home losing streak.

headline: Landlord’s Lawyer Blames Con Ed in East Village Explosion
text: A lawyer for the owner of two of the buildings in Manhattan’s East Village that were destroyed by a deadly explosion last week tried to deflect blame away from the landlord on Wednesday and toward Consolidated Edison, the utility company that provided gas to the buildings.

headline: In Monaco, Alain Ducasse Gives His Favorite Restaurant a Massive Makeover
text: Today, the restaurant where chef Alain Ducasse won three Michelin stars for the first time, Le Louis XV, reopens with a new look, a new menu and a new name. Even in Monaco, the glittery Mediterranean principality where cosmetic surgery is a casual form of art, it rates as a dazzling makeover.

headline: Amuse-Bouche
text: ON A WINTRY DAY in March, a pair of French expats could be seen shrieking in front of a small storefront on Eighth Avenue in New York. The picture window was filled with varicolored confections that, to the uninformed passerby, looked sort of like elegant Hostess Sno Balls: some bite-size, others large enough to share. But to pastry aficionados and French visitors, the implication was unmistakable: The cult of the merveilleux had finally reached America.

headline: Photographic Notes From Underground
text: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

text: fallible • \ˈfa-lə-bəl\ • adjective

headline: James Wood Dies at 85; Revived A.&P. Supermarket Chain
text: James Wood, a British-born executive who prevented one of America’s best-known supermarket chains from, in his words, “slipping into oblivion” in the 1980s, died on March 26 at his home in New York City. He was 85.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
text: 1:15 P.M. (Starz Cinema) IN AMERICA (2003) With their entire lives packed into a groaning station wagon, Johnny (Paddy Considine), an Irish actor, and his wife, Sarah (Samantha Morton), enter the United States from Canada illegally and try to start over in a battered walk-up apartment in New York after the death of their young son. In this drama, directed by Jim Sheridan, Djimon Hounsou is Mateo, a reclusive painter dying of what seems to be AIDS and is befriended one Halloween by Johnny and Sarah’s daughters. Mr. Sheridan (“My Left Foot”) wrote the film with his own two daughters, Naomi and Kirsten Sheridan, and all three received Oscar nominations, as did Ms. Morton and Mr. Hounsou. “This movie, from moment to moment, feels small, almost anecdotal,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “It is only afterward that, like Mr. Sheridan’s other films, it starts to grow into something at once unassuming and in its own way grand.”

headline: Q. and A.: Michael Schuman on the Return of Confucianism in China
text: As a veteran correspondent and resident of Beijing, Michael Schuman has witnessed the growing use of the Confucius “brand” by the Chinese Communist Party in recent years. And he has seen Confucian values manifested in a variety of ways across Asia, where he has reported widely for Time magazine and The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “People should realize we are in a new era. The idea of your nice little green lawn getting watered every day, those days are past.”

headline: Love and Loss on the Road to Arkansas

headline: President Obama’s Letter to 22 Prisoners
text: On Tuesday, 22 people serving sentences of decades or life for nonviolent drug crimes in federal prisons across the country received a personal letter from President Obama, commuting their sentences and ordering their release in late July.

headline: Indiana Loses Its Game
text: Last year Indiana chose “Honest to Goodness Indiana” as its new tourism slogan. Not everyone was charmed. Some critics said they’d have preferred something more cosmopolitan. Although it doesn’t seem likely they’d be happier with the runners-up, one of which was “Seasoned Just Right.”

headline: Religious Freedom vs. Discrimination
Students and Parents in the Dark
text: The Department of Education took a step toward transparency this week when it released a partial list of nearly 560 colleges and universities — the majority of them for-profit institutions — that have been placed under student-aid restrictions because of concerns about their finances and their compliance with federal law. But its failure to release all the names is a clear disservice to students who may end up applying to colleges that might be on the verge of shutting down.

headline: Our Land, Up for Grabs
text: San FRANCISCO — A BATTLE is looming over America’s public lands.

headline: Test Yourself | Here Comes Generation Z
