headline: Explosion at Protest in Afghanistan Kills Over a Dozen, Authorities Say
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — An explosion during a political protest in southeastern Afghanistan killed at least 16 people on Thursday and left many others wounded, including a member of Parliament, according to the authorities.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | California Imposes First-Ever Water Restrictions to Deal With Drought
text: In “California Imposes First-Ever Water Restrictions to Deal With Drought,” Adam Nagourney reports on the water crisis facing the nation’s most populous state.

headline: Somali Militants Kill 147 at Kenyan University
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Somali militants burst into a university in eastern Kenya on Thursday and killed nearly 150 students in the worst terrorist attack since the 1998 bombing of the United States Embassy here, laying bare the nation’s continuing vulnerability after years of battling Islamist extremism.

headline: Cold Spring Harbor Lab, Seeking Human Subjects, Teams Up With Hospital System
text: COLD SPRING HARBOR, N.Y. — Some of the world’s finest scientists live in a former whaling village on the North Shore of Long Island, in a compound reminiscent of an army post.

headline: In Tunisia, One Brother Studied Philosophy, Another Gunned Down Tourists
text: IBRAHIM ZAHAR, Tunisia — The same day that Jabeur Khachnaoui was gunning down foreign tourists at the National Bardo Museum in Tunis last month, one of his older brothers was on the other side of town, attending a rally against terrorism.

headline: Harry Reid Hopes to Ensure Democrats’ Success as Tenure Winds Down
text: LAS VEGAS — Senator Harry Reid, the Senate Democratic leader who announced his retirement last week, settled into a corner booth at the Triple George Grill here, his faced masked by dark sunglasses, evidence of lingering injuries from a workout accident that left him blind in one eye. For the next hour, in a conversation that veered from Washington to Nevada and back again, Mr. Reid made clear that he would deploy all of his resources to make sure Democrats hold on to his seat — critical to any hopes his party has of winning back the Senate in 2016.

headline: Do You Experience FOMO When You Unplug?
text: With Twitter, Facebook and other social media, we can know what’s going on seemingly everywhere all the time. But what happens when we unplug?

headline: A Flying V to Clean the Ice
text: The Flyers’ ice crew, like others around the N.H.L., must repeatedly clear the entire 200-foot-by-85-foot ice surface of the ice shavings that accumulate during a game.

headline: As the Zamboni Idles, N.H.L. Ice Crews Do the Heavy Clearing
text: Chris Jennings glanced up at the video board at Wells Fargo Center in Philadelphia during a Flyers game last month, then at the players slicing along his ice and back up at the video board. Standing by the Zamboni gate, Jennings turned and called out to the eight men and four women behind him.

headline: Cindi Leive | Glamour’s Confidence Chief
text: There are valid confidence lessons for women in “Lean In,” says Cindi Leive, the editor in chief of Glamour magazine. But she cautions women not to measure themselves against a singular model of success.

headline: ‘Eye on the Struggle,’ James McGrath Morris’s Biography of Ethel Payne
text: In our uncertain news media landscape, the black press is not what it used to be. At their height during the Great Migration decades between 1915 and 1970, dozens of weeklies — including The New York Amsterdam News, The Pittsburgh Courier and The Los Angeles Sentinel — reported the news of black America. The Chicago Defender, unofficial organ of the migration, had a national circulation of 130,000. Everything that was fit to print, from the latest racial pogroms to Negro League baseball box scores, filled its ­pages, giving voice to the voiceless along the color line of American political and social life. In 2000, Vernon Jarrett, a longtime Chicago Defender reporter and a syndicated columnist at The Chicago Tribune, described black newspapers as “the most predominant media influence on black people. . . . They were our Internet.”

headline: Air Pollution Takes Early Toll on Children
text: Air pollution can be bad for children – starting even before birth, a new study suggests.

headline: Cindi Leive of Glamour on Harnessing the Power of Praise
text: This interview with Cindi Leive, editor in chief of Glamour magazine, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Using Patient Data to Democratize Medical Discovery
text: Steven Keating, a graduate student at the MIT Media Lab and a brain cancer survivor, was the subject of an article this week, presented as a super data cruncher of his own patient information.

headline: Saudi Leaders Have High Hopes for Yemen Airstrikes, but Houthi Attacks Continue
text: CAIRO — Two months after ascending to the throne, King Salman of Saudi Arabia bet his prestige as a new leader on rallying his Arab allies for a military campaign to save Yemen from an Iranian takeover — all under the direction of his son, the new defense minister and chief of the royal court.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: The Chinese Billionaire Zhang Lei Spins Research Into Investment Gold
text: HONG KONG — With an $18 billion war chest, he is one of China’s richest investors. Yet on a recent trip to San Francisco, Zhang Lei and his entourage crammed into a three-bedroom house in the Mission District, rented through Airbnb.

headline: Militants Carry Out Deadly Attacks on Army Checkpoints in North Sinai
text: CAIRO — Militants in North Sinai simultaneously attacked two army checkpoints before dawn on Thursday, killing at least 13 Egyptian soldiers and two civilians, security officials said. The attacks ended a lull in such violence that had lasted several weeks.

headline: Daily Report: Post-PayPal, and Still Making Waves
text: The ride-hailing app Uber, the apartment rental site Airbnb and other darlings of the next generation of Silicon Valley start-ups are reshaping the way people use the web, David Gelles reports. They are also changing expectations about just how much money private companies can raise while still staying out of the public markets.

headline: New York Today: Old-Fashioned Sports
text: Good morning on this fine Thursday.

headline: Tinder While I Taper
text: This is the sixth installment of Going Off, a series of Anxiety posts chronicling the author’s attempt to wean off the medications she takes for depression, anxiety and insomnia.

headline: When ‘Moneyball’ Meets Medicine
text: What’s worse: Ebola or AIDS? Measles or malnutrition? Lung cancer or low back pain? As individuals, as a nation, and as a global community, where should we focus our time and money to improve lives the most?

headline: In Dubai, Swinging Clubs Under the Stars
text: The shadows covered my ball like giant trash bags, and the subtle breaks in the green blended together as if coated in paint. I didn’t care — how could I? I was playing golf at night.

headline: The Cuddly, Fluffy, Surreal World of Angora Show Bunnies
text: They are basically already sweaters. Not just because they’re mostly wool, with that ludicrous shag frothing out of their nonphysiques; it’s their total passivity, the way they allow themselves to be handled or arranged on a table, just so, like those sea creatures that, incapable of self-propulsion, get joggled along by the tides. Ask about Angora rabbits, and a word you hear a lot is “docile.” “They’re generally a pretty mellow rabbit,” says one Angora fancier. I heard about one that supposedly fell out of its cage overnight, landed on the back of a dog and stayed there until morning.

headline: Via, a Ride-Sharing App, Raises $27 Million for Car-Pooling
text: Be it by land, air or sea, there is no shortage of ways to get around New York.

headline: The Many Faces of Tatiana Maslany
text: The grand adventure of a set visit is entering a universe where everyone — absolutely everyone — is a pro at playing pretend. They’re admirably adult about it. They drink coffee and sit in chairs and operate machines, as if there weren’t lights so hot that they banish the winter outside, as if it’s perfectly normal for a sweltering interior to look like a dusty, sun­baked facade. Insides become outsides here, as gravel underfoot transforms a soundstage floor into a sandy desert.

headline: Saying ‘I Love You’ With Baseball
text: WASHINGTON, N. J. — Football may be America’s most popular sport, but baseball is still where our hearts lie, especially this weekend when the season starts anew. Back in 1985, my own heart was firmly with the New York Mets. Most of my friends were Yankees fans, which was precisely why this immigrant teenager fell for the Mets: They needed my help. They won my loyalty when they lost the division to the St. Louis Cardinals that year, proving once again that misery loves company.

headline: Today in Politics: Indiana Law Deepens Strain Between Republicans and Business
text: Good Thursday morning from Washington, where Senator Robert Menendez’s corruption charges are already becoming a political problem for Democrats. President Obama is heading to Kentucky to talk about the economy, while Speaker John A. Boehner wraps up his big international trip. Jeb Bush seems to have modified his response to an Indiana law seen as both a protection of religious freedom and an invitation for discrimination, while the law has become a thorn for Republicans, especially in their dealings with business leaders.

headline: Iran Agrees to Detailed Nuclear Outline, First Step Toward a Wider Deal
text: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — Iran and the United States, along with five other world powers, announced on Thursday a surprisingly specific and comprehensive understanding on limiting Tehran’s nuclear program for the next 15 years, though they left several specific issues to a final agreement in June.

headline: European Commission Asks Companies to Go Public With Google Complaints
text: LONDON — Europe’s five-year antitrust investigation against Google could soon be heating up again.

headline: Morning Agenda: HSBC Criticized Over Compliance
text: HSBC CRITICIZED OVER COMPLIANCE | When United States prosecutors found HSBC had facilitated money laundering on behalf of Mexican drug cartels and blacklisted nations like Iran, the British bank avoided criminal prosecution in 2012 by agreeing to overhaul its money-laundering controls. In their latest update, filed in court Wednesday, federal prosecutors say HSBC still has a long way to go, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess write in DealBook. Progress has been “too slow” in some areas, the filing said, which was based on a report by Michael Cherkasky, the independent monitor installed at HSBC. The filing criticized the bank for weaknesses in spotting suspicious transactions and for enabling a corporate culture resistant to change.

headline: Lydia Davis: By the Book
text: The author, most recently, of “Can’t and Won’t” abandoned reading Harry Potter alongside her son: “I found the writing flat and shallow, and the characters less than interesting.”

headline: Lesley Manville as the Unhappy Heroine of Ibsen’s ‘Ghosts’
text: LONDON — Her son was dying in her arms, and she held the bottle that contained the means to kill him. Would she? Could she?

headline: Karen, an App That Knows You All Too Well
text: LONDON — Thinking about a life coach but not ready to commit to the real thing? App stores offer lots of electronic alternatives that can be downloaded to your iPhone or Android device. There’s Success Wizard, which promises to “help you plan, focus and achieve real and lasting results.” LiveHappy, brim-full of exercises from the California psychologist who wrote “The How of Happiness.” Niggle, for people who want “a pocket sized coaching buddy on call 24/7.” And soon, from the British art group Blast Theory, an entirely different approach: Karen, a mock life-coach app that develops boundary issues and leaves its users feeling distinctly uncomfortable.

headline: Tommy Tune to Receive Lifetime Achievement Tony
text: Tommy Tune, who has collected nine Tony awards as a dancer, choreographer and director, will need to make room on his shelf for a 10th: He will be honored in June with a special Tony Award for lifetime achievement.

headline: The Middle-Class Lure of This Rural Nebraska Hospital
text: The draw for many people near Beatrice, Neb., today isn’t main street shopping and manufacturing jobs, but the hospital — a symbol of what being in the American middle class now can mean.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘The Sun Rising’
text: We celebrate National Poetry Month with a Poetry Pairing that features John Donne’s poem “The Sun Rising” and the article “New Wing at Corning Museum of Glass Invites the Light” by Alexandra Lange.

headline: Two Ailey Dancers to Leave for New Roles in St. Louis
text: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater is losing two of its most treasured members this summer. Antonio Douthit-Boyd and Kirven Douthit-Boyd — who were married in 2013 — have been named the co-artistic directors of the Center of Creative Arts, the St. Louis organization where Antonio Douthit-Boyd trained. Before they take up their new jobs, on Aug. 15, they will perform their final New York season with the Ailey company at the David H. Koch Theater in June, followed by an engagement in Paris in July.

headline: F.B.I. Says Terrorist Was Killed in Botched January Raid in Philippines
text: MANILA — A botched police raid in the Philippines in January that led to a public outcry and jeopardized a peace deal with rebels was successful in killing one of Southeast Asia’s most notorious militants, according to the F.B.I., which said it had removed the man from its list of most-wanted terrorists.

headline: It’s Not as if We’re Strangers
text: Dear Diary:

headline: James Corden Is Fashion’s New Darling
text: Look out, Seth Meyers. Fashion has a new favorite comedian/host: James Corden, a.k.a. the newish portly British host of “The Late Late Show” on CBS and baker/star of the movie “Into the Woods.” After a leading role at the 2014 Glamour Women of the Year Awards, Mr. Corden has been named host of the Council of Fashion Designers of America awards, to be held in June. It’s the big industry seal of approval.

headline: The Upper East Side Bats Its Eyelashes
text: Nearly two years ago, Mario R. García was invited to lecture and teach at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.

headline: A Limited-Edition Tiffany Timepiece That Honors Its Namesake
text: In honor of Charles Lewis Tiffany, who in 1837 founded the famed jewelry house that bears his name, Tiffany & Co. has created the new CT60 calendar watch, which carries his initials. The number references the phrase “a New York minute,” which he believed contained 60 seconds of possibility. Based on a design made famous by President Roosevelt when he wore it to the Yalta Conference, this model is pure, sleek elegance. Gold numerals made from shimmering metallic powder are set into an 18-karat rose-gold case and attached to a black alligator strap lined in calfskin. The sapphire crystal back reveals the mechanics, decorated with Art Deco motifs borrowed from the 1939 steel store doors. In a numbered edition of 60, this is part of a collection of four new timepieces, the company’s first in more than 20 years. It pays homage to the opportunities embedded in time.

headline: In West Hollywood, a Hotel With a Westwood Touch
text: The British fashion designer Vivienne Westwood makes a detour from the runway to make her debut as a hotel suite designer at the London West Hollywood in California.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Breathless
text: The Challenge: Can you figure out what’s wrong with a 64-year-old woman whose breathing becomes rapid and erratic at times?

headline: Is Cubs’ Kris Bryant a Can’t-Miss Prospect? Fans Can’t Be Sure
text: Kris Bryant, the consensus top baseball prospect in the country, had a scintillating spring training for the Chicago Cubs. In 44 plate appearances, he hit .425 with nine home runs and three doubles, slugging an improbable 1.175.

headline: Musical? Play? All That’s Sure Is David Bowie Is Involved
text: Four decades after his star turn as an alcoholic alien in the film “The Man Who Fell to Earth,” David Bowie is now co-writing a new stage work based on the same story.

headline: Throwback Thursday | Elite College Admissions
text: It’s college admissions season, and high school seniors all over clicked links in the last few weeks telling them if they were — or, in the case of elite institutions like Stanford, more likely were not — admitted.

headline: Lux Capital Raises $350 Million Fund to Back Science Start-Ups
text: SAN FRANCISCO — So much of the money pouring into venture capital nowadays has come from investors hoping to get a piece of the next Uber or Dropbox.

headline: Bernanke Says Global Imbalances Bedevil the World Economy. Discuss.
text: Ben Bernanke and Larry Summers are in the midst of a vigorous blog debate about why the world’s economy is so messed up and how it can be fixed.

headline: 1890: Children Hired to Beg
text: M. Georges Berry, the Paris municipal councilor, has broken many a lance in tilting against old, and in some cases, time honored, abuses, and for his pains has not infrequently heard it suggested that there was a dash of Quixotism in his composition. Nothing daunted, he is ready to break a few more lances. In the campaign he has now started he can receive nothing but commendation.

headline: In ‘Life at the Limits,’ Extreme Creatures at American Museum of Natural History
text: ONE of the great pleasures of science is learning how strange the world is.

headline: Bunny Business
text: The beguiling beauty and arduous hair-care regimen of the Angora rabbit.

headline: Stampede to Join China’s Development Bank Stuns Even Its Founder
text: BEIJING — The sudden rush to join China’s new Asian development bank by this week’s deadline, including last-minute applications by countries hardly considered Beijing’s best friends, astonished even the Chinese.

headline: Indiana and Arkansas Revise Rights Bills, Seeking to Remove Divisive Parts
text: INDIANAPOLIS — After a national uproar over bills promoted as religious freedom measures and criticized as anti-gay, lawmakers in Indiana and in Arkansas approved new legislation on Thursday to remove the most contentious language, though in significantly different ways.

headline: The Magazine Talks Sex, and Readers React
text: Lela Moore is a news assistant and comment moderator.

headline: Stunning Views of Earth From Space
text: The International Space Station is as far as humans go in space these days, but it is at just the right distance to capture astonishing images of Earth.

headline: Muslims Projected to Outnumber Christians by 2100
text: Christianity has long been the world’s largest religion by far, but the population of Muslims is growing so fast that they will match Christians by the year 2070 and outnumber them by the end of the century, according to a report released Thursday that projects the global religious future.

headline: Earth, the Marvelous Blue Orb
text: Sometimes, you have to leave a place to appreciate it.

headline: Germanwings Pilot Searched Web About Suicide and Cockpit Doors, Officials Say
text: DÜSSELDORF, Germany — The co-pilot at the controls of the Germanwings airliner that crashed into the French Alps last week had been searching the Internet in the days immediately before for information about how to commit suicide and the security measures for cockpit doors, prosecutors said Thursday.

headline: Educators Found Guilty in Sexual Assault of Kindergartners in Indonesia
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — An Indonesian court on Thursday found a Canadian educator and an Indonesian teaching assistant at one of the country’s most prestigious international schools guilty of sexually assaulting three kindergarten students, after a high-profile trial in which defense lawyers and the school asserted that the entire case had been fabricated.

headline: Students Describe Attack at Kenya School
text: Students who escaped an attack by gunmen on a Kenyan university described the scene on Thursday.

headline: Video Captures Bombing in Afghanistan
text: Footage obtained by Reuters appears to show the moment a suicide bomber attacked an anti-corruption demonstration in Khost, Afghanistan.

headline: James Harden Scores 51 and Makes Case for M.V.P. in Big Night for N.B.A. Stars
text: It was a big night for box scores in the N.B.A., and a big night for James Harden in his battle with Stephen Curry for the Most Valuable Player Award.

headline: Which Andres Serrano Bunny Are You?
text: A curious fact about this week’s photo essay on Angora rabbits, cut from the text for reasons of space, was that the bunnies we featured — in sumptuous photographs by the artist Andres Serrano — turned out to embody four distinct but equally valid paradigms for ethical reasoning in 21st-century life. Take the following quiz, which consists of questions posed to our Ethicists column in recent weeks, to determine which of these longhair rabbits best represents your intuitive approach to moral quandaries.

headline: New Neighbors Revitalize Battery Park City
text: A wave of food halls and boutiques is transforming this quiet Manhattan neighborhood along the Hudson River.

headline: Cruz Champions a Democrat: President Kennedy
text: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas is a fervent fan of President Ronald Reagan. Mr. Reagan is a constant in Mr. Cruz’s stump speech, whether it’s the conservative coalition he built or his record as president.

headline: ‘The Sympathizer,’ by Viet Thanh Nguyen
text: The more powerful a country is, the more disposed its people will be to see it as the lead actor in the sometimes farcical, often tragic pageant of history. So it is that we, citizens of a superpower, have viewed the Vietnam War as a solely American drama in which the febrile land of tigers and elephants was mere backdrop and the Vietnamese mere extras.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Planet of the Apes’
text: A scene from “Planet of the Apes,” with Charlton Heston.

headline: G.M. Bets Big on a Resurgent Cadillac
text: I learned to drive in my father’s black 1967 Cadillac, which my friends and I called the “Batmobile.” With its fins, 130-inch wheelbase and 4,675 pounds, there was no mistaking it for a Mercedes, not that any of us back then had ever seen one.

headline: SpaHa Soul
text: Informal, improvised cooking in East Harlem.

headline: At SpaHa Soul in Spanish Harlem, Camaraderie on a Plate
text: Artist Thornton wore a red apron as he greeted guests at SpaHa Soul, but when asked if he was the chef, he paused. “I’m the ‘chef,’ ” he said with a laugh, fingers pinching the air.

headline: Making Religion the Problem
text: One of the issues that I didn’t get around to in the last two weeks, while writing way too many words on the question of whether economics or culture explains the decline of marriage and the two-parent family in America, is the question of what, if anything, conservatives actually think we should do about the problem if it is primarily a cultural one. This is the question raised, for instance, by this Damon Linker column, which argues that “scolds” of the right don’t have a plan, beyond pointless hectoring, to build the kind of familial-communal order we’d prefer.

headline: Herod the Great’s Israel
text: I traveled to Israel last May to search for Herod the Great and I found him, or at least his ghost, at his tomb at Herodium. Halfway up an artificial mountain that the king had conjured from the desert for his final resting place, I stood gazing at what was left of the royal mausoleum: a couple of courses of limestone blocks as exquisitely faceted as jewels. Below, the arcing rows of a Roman theater descended in diminishing semicircles to the disc of the stage. Everything around me, even the contours of the earth itself, had been altered at the decree of this ancient ruler. Time has toppled the columns and blurred the carvings, but the majesty (and hubris) of this place remain intact.

headline: U.N. Rights Chief Criticizes ‘Draconian’ Powers Given to Thai Military
text: GENEVA — The United Nations human rights chief, Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein, criticized the “draconian” powers adopted by Thailand’s ruling generals this week, saying on Thursday that they opened the door to abuses and made the junta’s parallel move to lift martial law “meaningless.”

headline: Text to Text | ‘To Kill a Mockingbird’ and ‘History of Lynchings in the South Documents Nearly 4,000 Names’
text: On Feb. 3, 2015, a Times News Alert announced the stunning headline: “Harper Lee, Author of ‘To Kill a Mockingbird,’ Is to Publish a Second Novel.”

headline: Viewfinder: Nick Frank
text: Nick Frank’s images of empty subway stations are imbued with a sense of surreal beauty.

headline: Trevor Noah Sees Childhood Under Apartheid as License to Speak His Mind
text: JOHANNESBURG — Years before he was chosen to succeed Jon Stewart on “The Daily Show,” before he made his debut on that Comedy Central news satire or appeared on any American television program, a rising stand-up named Trevor Noah explained why his racial background was both empowering and confining.

headline: Rev. Robert Schuller, 88, Dies; Built an Empire Preaching Self-Belief
text: The Rev. Robert H. Schuller, a California clergyman who started his ministry by preaching in a drive-in movie theater and transformed it into an empire, building the landmark megachurch the Crystal Cathedral, writing best sellers and, through television, exhorting millions to believe in themselves, died on Thursday in Artesia, Calif. He was 88.

headline: In a Short Time, Ted Cruz Has Raised Big Money From Small Donors
text: Ted Cruz, the Texas Republican senator, raised nearly $4 million in the eight days after he announced his presidential campaign, according to The Wall Street Journal. What’s important about that number is that almost all of it came in amounts of less than $100.

headline: The Last Ice Merchant of Ecuador
text: For over half a century, Baltazar Ushca has hiked up the slopes of Mount Chimborazo, Ecuador’s tallest mountain, to harvest the glacial ice that covers this dormant volcano. In the past, up to 40 ice merchants made the journey up the mountain at a time; today, however, Baltazar works alone.

headline: Two Women in Queens Are Charged With a Bomb Plot
text: Two women living in Queens have been charged with planning to build a bomb, in a plot revealed by a monthslong undercover investigation that found the women had discussed the merits of various types of bombs and had obtained four propane gas tanks.

headline: One Title Mike Trout Hopes to Shed: Strikeout King
text: Mike Trout led the American League in four traditional categories last season. Three — runs, runs batted in and total bases — helped him win his first Most Valuable Player Award. The other reflected the reality that, in this era, even the game’s best player can be a leader of the strikeout parade.

headline: Iowa Operative Will Run Mike Huckabee Super PAC
text: The Mike Huckabee “super PAC” has arrived.

headline: Robert Askins Brings ‘Hand to God’ to Broadway
text: The conceit is zany: In a church basement, a group of adolescents gathers (mostly at the insistence of their parents) to make puppets that will spread the Christian message, but one of the puppets turns out to be more demonic than divine.

headline: Michael Fabiano’s 7 Hours From Call to Stage at the Metropolitan Opera
text: The hot young tenor Michael Fabiano was out running errands near his home in Philadelphia around 1 p.m. on Wednesday when the Metropolitan Opera called, wondering if he could step in for an ailing tenor in its production of Donizetti’s “Lucia di Lammermoor.” The curtain would rise in six and a half hours. In New York.

headline: No Runs, No Hits, New Era: Baseball Ponders Legal Ways to Increase Offense
text: The old catcher smiled wryly. The topic was offense, and what could be done to revive it. When John Buck entered professional baseball, in 1998, fans were swooning for sluggers. All these years later, the landscape has tilted. Runs and homers are falling. Strikeouts and infield shifts are soaring. Pitchers rule.

headline: On World Autism Awareness Day, Gratitude — and a Wish List
text: It is so delightful when your child tries to make you laugh. Lately, my 4-year-old son, Heath, has been recreating a moment when he almost fell in the toilet, which seems about right on the 4-year-old development scale when it comes to a sense of humor. He picks up the seat of the toilet, balances on the edge and looks at my husband and me. He says a mock-concerned “Heath!” and we all laugh.

headline: Manoel de Oliveira, Pensive Filmmaker Who Made Up for Lost Time, Dies at 106
text: Manoel de Oliveira, the acclaimed Portuguese filmmaker whose career began in the silent era, flowered in the 1970s with the end of authoritarian rule in his country and ended with a surge of productivity extending into his 11th decade, died on Thursday at his home in Oporto, Portugal. He was 106.

headline: Prosecutor on Co-Pilot’s Search History
text: Christoph Kumpa, a German prosecutor, said investigators found a tablet computer in the home of Andreas Lubitz, on which the Germanwings co-pilot had researched the safety features of cockpit doors.

headline: Antitrust and Other Inquiries in Europe Target U.S. Tech Giants
text: LONDON — It is not a good week to be a giant American tech company in Europe.

headline: Breaking Free of Steakhouse Wine List Tradition
text: From the rudimentary masculine places of old, contemporary steakhouses have mutated into higher forms of restaurant life. The menus still touch all the steakhouse basics but augment them with far more interesting options than the proverbial icy shrimp cocktails and prefab Caesar salads. Along with a reinvented menu, the steakhouse wine list has also evolved into a more intelligent, diverse and satisfying set of selections.

headline: Hominid Species May Have Coexisted
text: An ancient hominid known as Little Foot may have lived at roughly the same time as Lucy, another famous human forebear, a new study has found.

headline: Awaiting Iran News, Obama Delays Travel Plans
text: President Obama has delayed departure for his scheduled trip to Kentucky while waiting for news on the Iranian nuclear talks.

headline: Indiana To Make Changes to Religious Law
text: Two republican members of the Indiana legislature, Representative Brian C. Bosma and Senator David C. Long, said changes will be made to the state’s Religious Freedom Restoration Act.

headline: In ‘Felix & Meira,’ Luzer Twersky Revisits the Hasidic World He Left
text: A decade ago, Luzer Twersky was a member of a Hasidic community in Brooklyn. Now, having left that world entirely, he’s only Orthodox in the movies. In “Felix & Meira,” due out on April 17, he plays Shulem, the husband of a Hasidic woman (Hadas Yaron) who questions her faith and develops a relationship with a secular man.

headline: If 2024 Olympic Bid Is a Hot Potato, Boston Has No Appetite
text: After completing its long, complicated and anything but transparent process of choosing a city as its candidate to host the 2024 Summer Games, the United States Olympic Committee has found itself in an awkward position.

headline: First Draft Focus: Robert Menendez Goes to Court
text: Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, arrived in Newark on Thursday to be arraigned on federal bribery charges.

headline: Mayweather-Pacquiao Will Have Record Pay-Per-View Pricetag
text: The long-anticipated title fight between Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Manny Pacquiao on May 2 in Las Vegas will cost boxing fans a record price on pay per view: $89.95 to watch in standard definition and, in some cases, $99.95 for the high definition version, two executives familiar with the terms said. The prices were also reported by The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Iraq Forces, Pushing ISIS Out of Tikrit, Give Few Thanks for U.S. Airstrikes
text: TIKRIT, Iraq — One week after the start of intensive American airstrikes against Islamic State hide-outs, most of the key parts of central Tikrit have finally fallen to the government’s forces — although significant pockets remained contested on Thursday.

headline: Uber Hires a Security Chief From Facebook
text: Silicon Valley is home to some of the world’s brightest technical minds. And from Apple to Google, every big company covets the talent of its competitors. Now add Uber, the ride-hailing company, to that group.

headline: Juliette Binoche and Kristen Stewart in ‘Clouds of Sils Maria’
text: A few years ago the actress Juliette Binoche got in touch with her old friend Olivier Assayas, the French director who had co-written the film “Rendez-Vous,” which slingshot her to fame three decades ago.

headline: Tom Cotton: Opponents of Anti-Gay Law Need ‘Perspective’
text: I’m starting to long for the good old days, just weeks ago, when nobody had to think about Senator Tom Cotton, Republican of Arkansas.

headline: When the Politics of ‘Religious Freedom’ Divides Families
text: The religious exception bill pending in Arkansas hasn’t just added to the growing debate over what proponents call “religious freedom bills,” which grant people, and businesses, the right to avoid a fine or lawsuit for refusing to obey a state mandate that violates their religious beliefs. It’s brought our attention squarely back to one of the big divides in politics: When it comes to things like gay rights (and education spending, immigration, and the environment), the generation gap is back.

headline: Criminal Complaint Filed Against Queens Women
text: Details of the charges against two women who are accused in a bomb detonation plot.

headline: ‘Mad Men,’ the Beginning
text: Matthew Weiner shot the pilot for “Mad Men” in 2006. The show debuted on AMC in 2007.

headline: After Nuclear Agreement, Analysts Weigh Deal’s Effects on Iranian Politics
text: WASHINGTON — For Iran watchers, a possible deal to rein in the country’s nuclear program raises questions about its impact not only on arms control in the region but also on Tehran’s complex internal politics.

headline: Clip: ‘Ex Machina’
text: In this scene from Alex Garland’s film, Caleb (Domhnall Gleeson) meets Ava (Alicia Vikander) for the first time.

headline: Robert Durst’s Lawyers Want to Call the Agents Who Arrested Him as Witnesses
text: NEW ORLEANS — In a bid to keep the millionaire Robert A. Durst from having to face felony weapons and drug charges in New Orleans, his lawyers on Thursday sought to call the agents who arrested him as witnesses, part of their effort to prove that evidence collected at the time of the arrest was obtained illegally and cannot be used against him.

headline: ‘Ex Machina’ Features a New Robot for the Screen
text: They’ve been giant and deadly; they’ve been chatty and contemplative; they’ve been acrobatic and futuristic. Robots in movies have served all kinds of functions in becoming an important part of the cinema landscape. So when filmmakers place a robot at the center of their work, the way it looks and behaves compared with those that have come before must be considered.

headline: ‘Mad Men': How The New York Times Covered the First Season
text: “Mad Men” starts the final half of its seventh season on Sunday, and it’s been quite a run for the critically acclaimed AMC drama. But before the show’s pilot premiered on July 19, 2007, it was impossible to predict how influential “Mad Men” would eventually become. Here is a brief look back at how The New York Times first covered the show.

headline: Marco Pierre White
text: A look back at the British chef’s first cookbook, “White Heat,” 25 years after its publication.

headline: Marco Pierre White’s ‘White Heat’: A Game Changer, Revisited
text: In his heyday in the late 1980s and early 1990s, when he was the tantrum-throwing enfant terrible of the London food world, Marco Pierre White had a method for dealing with rude or obnoxious customers in his restaurants. It was called the Whoosh.

headline: Finding ‘Neverland’
text: Behind the scenes at the new Broadway musical.

headline: N.I.T. Winners Seldom Follow Up With N.C.A.A. Tournament Success
text: When Stanford and Miami meet on Thursday night in the final of the N.I.T., they will be competing for a consolation prize. Most N.I.T. winners would have much preferred even a short run in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: After Turbulent Flight, ‘Finding Neverland’ Alights on Broadway
text: In making the leap from movie mogul to lead theater producer with his musical, “Finding Neverland,” Harvey Weinstein has fired or lost more actors, artists and executives than most impresarios do on their shows. He has overseen spending of roughly $20 million (before tax writeoffs) on a world premiere run in Britain and then on an entirely new version of the musical, which opens April 15 on Broadway. He has thrown himself into the role of script doctor, huddling over a laptop the other week with the show’s book writer, James Graham, trying to punch up jokes. He has even fussed over the dog in the cast, pushing for a real-live version instead of an actor.

headline: Nasher Sculpture Center Announces New $100,000 Prize
text: There is no shortage of prizes in the art world, but few specifically recognize sculpture.

headline: ‘Space Is the Place’ Offers Otherworldly Takes on Identity
text: “Being black in America is a science-fiction experience,” the culture critic and musician Greg Tate once asserted in an interview, articulating the premise for what has come to be called Afrofuturism.

headline: Eddie LeBaron, a Star in the N.F.L. at 5-Foot-7, Dies at 85
text: Eddie LeBaron, an undersize quarterback who was a college Hall of Famer, became a Marine Corps hero during the Korean War and then played in the National Football League for 11 seasons, died on Wednesday in Stockton, Calif. He was 85.

headline: Details Given of Iran Nuclear Agreement
text: Federica Mogherini, left, the European Union’s foreign policy chief, and Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif of Iran announced the details of the agreement.

headline: Senator Menendez Pleads Not Guilty to Bribery Accusations
text: Joined by a mutual fondness for good cigars and a round of golf, they spent holidays together in the Dominican Republic, unwinding at a gated oceanfront resort where houses cost as much as $20 million.

headline: Kenyan Minister Announces End of Siege
text: Joseph Nkaissery, Kenya’s interior minister, said many students were killed during the siege of a university.

headline: Across the Creek Is the Other Side of the River
text: Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.

headline: Happy Passover, or Not: Gefilte Fish Is Back
text: The wacky weather of the past few years has wreaked havoc across the nation, from droughts in California to record snowfall in Boston — and Seder tables everywhere in between. Extended freezing on the Great Lakes saw the whitefish haul sink last year, and the supply of gefilte fish fell along with it.

headline: Behind Each Breath, an Underappreciated Muscle
text: Some muscles get all the glory. Bodybuilders show off their swollen triceps; sprinters flash their sharp-edged calves. But deep inside all of us, a sheet of muscle does heroic work in obscurity.

headline: Obama Comments on Nuclear Deal With Iran
text: President Obama spoke from the White House on Thursday after a nuclear deal was announced with Iran.

headline: Senator Kirk Adds Another Republican Vote for Lynch for Attorney General
text: Senator Mark Kirk, Republican of Illinois, announced Thursday that he would vote to confirm Loretta E. Lynch as the next attorney general, meaning she almost certainly has the votes needed for confirmation.

headline: Dortmund, Leading Derby Contender, Is Horse Discoverer’s Latest Star
text: On the first Saturday in May 1996, Donato Lanni, amid final exams to complete a business degree at Concordia University in Montreal, watched the unheralded California thoroughbred trainer Bob Baffert come within a nose of winning the Kentucky Derby with a gelding named Cavonnier.

headline: Step Down, Senator Robert Menendez
text: For high-profile politicians who are indicted by federal prosecutors, there’s something akin to stages of grief. First comes shock, then anger, defiance and, sometimes, after juries convict and judges are ready to impose a sentence, a bit of contrition.

headline: Swiss Votes on Pay Bode Ill for Star Bankers
text: Switzerland’s new “say on pay” rules could make it harder for investment banking stars at UBS and Credit Suisse to outpace their bosses in compensation. All the country’s listed companies face binding shareholder votes on executive compensation this year. But the Swiss public’s hostility toward its banks means they could be first in the firing line.

headline: Details of Agreement to Limit Iran’s Nuclear Program
text: Iran and six world powers agreed on key parameters for an accord regarding Tehran’s nuclear program, with the details to be negotiated by June 30.

headline: Death Toll in Sinking of Russian Ship Rises to at Least 56
text: MOSCOW — Russian emergency workers frantically plucked bodies from the freezing Sea of Okhotsk on Thursday after a refrigerated trawling ship sank in Russia’s Far East, killing at least 56 of a crew of 132.

headline: Verbatim: Trust, but Verify
text: — President Obama, announcing a deal with Iran over its nuclear program.

headline: With Menendez Out, Cardin Rises on Senate Foreign Relations Commitee
text: The corruption charges facing Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey is creating a shift on the powerful Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

headline: Letters: ‘The Age of Acquiescence’
text: To the Editor:

headline: 1962 | Non Scholae Sed Vitae Discimus
text: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

headline: Your Pet, the Art World Insider
text: The ancient Egyptians depicted gods with the heads of dogs and cats. Balthus’s 1935 self-portrait “The King of Cats” includes his alter ego, a cat, rubbing against his leg. The Miser’s own Instagram account recently was exclusively made up of photos of a beagle he was fostering.

headline: The Problem With Math Problems: We’re Solving Them Wrong
text: The following question, from a mother concerned about her daughter’s math education, landed in my email box recently:

headline: ‘Lambert and Stamp,’ a Documentary, Looks at the Who
text: When Kit Lambert and Chris Stamp, two on-the-make British filmmakers, first approached the Who — then a scrappy mod band known as the High Numbers — it was as potential fodder for a movie they’d been planning to shoot. Instead, Mr. Lambert and Mr. Stamp became the band’s managers and, in Roger Daltrey’s words, the “fifth and sixth members of the Who,” steering the group through its heady ascent from arty street kids to worshiped arena rockers.

headline: Weekend Entertainments From the Archives of The New York Times
text: 68 YEARS AGO

headline: Cubs’ Futility Can Be Traced to a Promise, Not a Curse
text: I gave up on superstition long ago, so I do not believe in curses of goats or omens like a black cat running in front of a dugout. That said, I am reasonably certain — or as certain as one can be about these things — that the Chicago Cubs will be playing in the World Series this October.

headline: An Easygoing Trip of a Track From the Stylish Musical Project Tennis
text: To hear her tell it, performing at a runway show was one of the hardest things Alaina Moore, the frontwoman of the duo Tennis, has ever done. “I had never been to one before, but I think it went super well,” she says of hitting the stage at Rebecca Minkoff’s spring/summer 2013 show with her Tennis bandmate and husband, Patrick Riley. “Rebecca wanted us to play live, but she also wanted a D.J. to spin a playlist of all of the songs that were important to her. So we did this mashup where the D.J. would play 30 seconds of a track and then we’d drop in on the same beat. It was such a crazy experience. I’m glad Rebecca didn’t doubt us, because the whole time I was very nervous.” She had no reason to be, as the band’s fashion and culture bona fides are well established: Their music has also been picked as a soundtrack for ads for Marc Jacobs and Tory Burch and, last month, a scene on “Girls.” Moore has also recently begun contributing to the British style magazine Port — a welcome extracurricular break from her daily routine. “Since I’m constantly on the road which a bunch of guys, I usually have such an unglamorous lifestyle,” she says.

headline: Report of Missing Israeli in West Bank Proves to Be Hoax
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli military called off extensive searches in the Hebron area of the West Bank late Thursday night after initial reports that an Israeli man had been abducted by Palestinians proved to be a hoax.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Writer George R.R. Martin Posts ‘Winds of Winter’ Novel Excerpt
text: Winter is coming, slowly.

headline: Ted Cruz Takes a Jab at Rand Paul Over a Senate Vote
text: CEDAR FALLS, Iowa – Senator Ted Cruz of Texas has said he will not run a negative campaign in his bid for the Republican nomination for the White House.

headline: Disarmament Groups Welcome Iran Framework; Israel Is Mistrustful
text: Advocates of disarmament and reconciliation with Iran embraced the framework agreement announced Thursday that would limit Iran’s nuclear capabilities, calling it a welcome alternative to war, while the Israeli government and its supporters voiced deep criticism and said the opposite outcome was more likely.

headline: Why a Claim About the Irrelevance of Parenting Time Doesn’t Add Up
text: In an article Wednesday, I criticized a study that found no link between children’s outcomes and the amount of time that parents spent with their children. Several readers told me that they thought I had drawn the wrong conclusion. Here at The Upshot we want to show you not just what we think, but how we’re thinking, and so I want to explain my statistical argument in more detail. It’s a subtle but interesting issue, and if you get to the end, you’ll earn an extra notch on your wonk belt.

headline: Puerto Rico, Old and New
text: Exploring the archipelago, from Old San Juan to beachfront resorts.

headline: Men’s Street Style for New York Fashion Week
text: Men showed off their style outside the shows during this February’s New York Fashion Week.

headline: A Three-Pronged Front to Limit Shareholder Litigation
text: Delaware is going to war over shareholder litigation, but will shareholders or corporations emerge victorious?

headline: With a New Exhibition, Ari Marcopoulos Keeps His Distance
text: Images in the photographer’s latest series, “L1032015,” include far-away landscapes and urban scenes that are almost abstract.

headline: Jose da Silva Lopes RIP
text: Sad news: Jose da Silva Lopes, a Portuguese economist and government official who played a crucial role shepherding his country into the community of democratic Europe, has just died.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Iraq, Kenya, Syria and Japan

headline: In an Upset, the N.C.A.A. Claims the Moral High Ground
text: INDIANAPOLIS — During his annual pre-Final Four news conference on Thursday, the N.C.A.A.’s president, Mark Emmert, reflected on the coincidental confluence of the Final Four being held at Lucas Oil Stadium this weekend and the contentious law passed last week just a few blocks up Capitol Avenue.

headline: Carmen Cicero: ‘Early Works: 1970-1980s’
text: Carmen Cicero, now in his late 80s, has worked in several styles, none his own, but always with enough panache to establish proprietary claims. In the 1950s, he was a promising second-generation Abstract Expressionist who exhibited regularly, pursuing thatches of autonomist lines on paper and canvas, examples of which are owned by all New York’s major museums.

headline: Alex Da Corte: ‘Die Hexe’
text: Alex Da Corte’s “Die Hexe” (“The Witch”) is a labor of love. That probably describes most works of art, but when expressed with an elaborate environment that takes over interior surfaces of a brownstone gallery — that’s walls, ceiling and floors on two and a half floors, including stairs and hallways — and dazzles at every turn, it gains force.

headline: A Transgender Bangladeshi Changes Perceptions After Catching Murder Suspects
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — In an alleyway off a marketplace specializing in meat and live chickens, up a few narrow, precipitous flights of cement stairs, can be found the most sought-after transgender crime fighter in Bangladesh.

headline: Alice Neel: ‘Drawings and Watercolors 1927-1978’
text: Alice Neel is best known for her portraits which, with their controlled painterly drama and psychological nuance, are complete and polished formal statements in a classical genre. Her drawings and watercolors, or at least the 62 in this absorbing show, are closer to diary entries. Ruminative, confiding, sometimes startlingly unguarded in emotion, they add up to a self-portrait sketched in private over some 50 years.

headline: April 2, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Iraq, Kenya, Syria and Japan.

headline: Steve DiBenedetto: ‘Mile High Psychiatry’
text: Steve DiBenedetto has been showing in New York since the 1980s, but like many painters working on the slow-burn development plan, he’s flourishing midcareer. Expertly constructed but aggressively psychedelic and curiously weird, this is a phenomenal group of canvases.

headline: Robert Menendez Indictment Points to Corrupting Potential of Super PACs
text: It seemed like a typical corruption case: A Florida doctor, seeking official favors with a United States senator, plies him with gifts while raising all the money he can for the senator’s campaign, and for his fellow senators and party.

headline: Young and Zazeela’s ‘Dream House’ Is Getting a New Lease at Dia
text: For decades, La Monte Young, a father of Minimalist music, has preached that sound needs duration — far more than a long evening’s duration — for certain kinds of meaning to accrue. “A one-hour composition,” as Mr. Young said the other day, “is nothing like a six-year composition.”

headline: Review: ‘ISIS: The State of Terror,’ by Jessica Stern and J. M. Berger, and ‘ISIS: Inside the Army of Terror,’ by Michael Weiss and Hassan Hassan
text: The Islamic State and its atrocities — beheadings, mass executions, the enslavement of women and children, and the destruction of cultural antiquities — are in the headlines every day now. The terror group not only continues to roll through the Middle East, expanding from Iraq and Syria into Libya and Yemen, but has also gained dangerous new affiliates in Egypt and Nigeria and continues to recruit foreign fighters through its sophisticated use of social media.

headline: Review: ‘Gustav Klimt and Adele Bloch-Bauer’ Focuses on Portrait Rich in History
text: In 2006, the art collector Ronald S. Lauder purchased Gustav Klimt’s “Adele Bloch-Bauer I” (1907) for $135 million, then the highest price paid for a painting, and made it the crown jewel of the Neue Galerie, the museum he founded in 2001. Since then other paintings have sold for considerably higher sums, adjusted for inflation, including those by Paul Cézanne and Paul Gauguin.

headline: Review: ‘Cheatin’ ’ Conjures a Lusty Film-Noir Dreamscape
text: “Cheatin,’ ” the latest feature from the feverishly crosshatched imagination of the animator Bill Plympton, is a pulpy, sex-addled opera rendered in fleet penciled lines and watercolor washes. Mr. Plympton’s unmistakable style — the scrunched-up faces and elongated bodies, the figures that mutate as well as move, the volatile blending of the sensual and the grotesque — is pressed into the service of a lurid, lusty story that takes place in a colorful film-noir dreamscape.

headline: A Forbidden Relationship, From the Other Side of the World
text: I was free to make as many mistakes as I wanted. She lived within the confines of countless restrictions.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Antiquarian Book Fair Offers Victorian Children’s Peep Shows
text: Victorian children peered into mass-produced accordion boxes of paper prints called peep shows, which gave the illusion of depth and motion. The layers of scenes, pierced with viewing holes, represented parks, gardens, battlefields, theaters and engineering feats like canals, tunnels and bridges.

headline: Jacob Lawrence’s Migration Series
text: Works from the new show at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Review: ‘One-Way Ticket’ at MoMA Reunites Jacob Lawrence’s Migration Paintings
text: On Easter 1939, Marian Anderson stood on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial in Washington and sang: “The gospel train is coming; I hear it just at hand; I hear the car wheels rumbling, and rolling through the land. Get on board.” By then, hundreds of thousands of African-Americans had already heard the call, leaving the rural South for the industrial North in search of jobs, homes and respect.

headline: For Billie Holiday’s 100th Birthday, Tributes and New Releases
text: In Billie Holiday’s “I Cried for You,” recorded at Clark Monroe’s Uptown House in Harlem in 1941, time feels unimportant. She’s flooding the entire thing, doing a long yell, a game of phrasing and pitch, with words delayed and shaken and skywritten.

headline: Why Does She Like Offensive Music? Try Asking
text: My sister is 26. She has a good job, is working toward her master’s degree and has a nice boyfriend. The problem: They listen to this awful music they call “hood rap.” It is filled with obscenities and derogatory comments about women and African-Americans. When our mother heard it, she decided she had failed as a parent. Can we tell her we think this music is hate speech?

headline: NYRA Bars Official and Jockeys’ Agents During Investigation
text: A clocker for the New York Racing Association and two jockey agents were taken away from Aqueduct on Thursday by security agents and told their privileges were revoked until an investigation by the Queens district attorney, into allegations of unlawful access to a computer system, is concluded.

headline: Manhattan Prosecutors Say New York Art Dealer Played Role in Sale of Stolen Artifacts
text: Prosecutors, in court papers, have accused a New York art dealer of selling three ancient sculptures that were stolen from temples in India and Nepal.

text: When Janette Beckman came to 1980s New York from Britain, she soon found herself photographing key figures in hip-hop’s early years.

headline: Review: ‘Cut Bank,’ Looking to Escape a Small Town and Its Eccentrics
text: The comic neo-noir “Cut Bank” is a far cry from the TV series “Fargo,” whose mixture of the zany and surreal this film strains to recapture right down to featuring two of that show’s stars, Billy Bob Thornton and Oliver Platt. The previous credits of its director, Matt Shakman, include the last two episodes of “Fargo.”

text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: Jean-Michel Basquiat’s ‘Unknown Notebooks’ at the Brooklyn Museum
text: Language was Jean-Michel Basquiat’s first artistic language. The words he deftly spray-painted on the walls and buildings of downtown New York in the late 1970s and early ’80s — signing them “SAMO©” — were unlike any other graffiti of the time. They had an arresting presence, a combination of graphic refinement, aural strangeness and compressed meaning that made you stop and ponder. Their themes, rhythms and even their letters also formed the foundation for the paintings that would soon fix Basquiat prominently in the still understudied history of the medium in 1980s New York.

headline: Review: ‘Effie Gray’ Stars Dakota Fanning as a Rejected Wife
text: Bad marriages don’t get much stranger than that of the 19th-century British art critic John Ruskin to Effie Gray, his first and (unsurprisingly) only wife. History and Mike Leigh’s movie “Mr. Turner” remember Ruskin as an advocate for the painter J.M.W. Turner. Others remember Ruskin as the Victorian who, on his wedding night, was so appalled by the sight of his wife’s pubic hair that he refused to sleep with her (ever). What really turned Ruskin off? Who knows? Certainly not the makers of “Effie Gray,” a serviceable British costume drama about the pathetic affair.

headline: An Idea Hits the Beach
text: Blackadore Caye, Belize, is the site of an eco-conscious resort planned by a partnership including Leonardo DiCaprio and Delos, the New York developer.
