They flew past one after another: regional jets and jumbos, airliners and cargo planes, all rumbling above this city’s Northwest Side on their final approach to O’Hare International Airport.

headline: ‘Lumière! Inventing Cinema’
text: A look at a new exhibition celebrating the French pioneers of cinema, Louis and Auguste Lumière.

headline: The Snake That’s Eating Florida
text: Ever since a serpent enticed Eve to munch on that forbidden fruit in the Garden of Eden, relations between humans and snakes have been at best strained. But at least the gullible Eve and her mate had to cope with just the one snake. In South Florida, wildlife officials have struggled for years with tens of thousands of the creatures: specifically, a species known as the Burmese python, an interloper from Southeast Asia that has taken up what looks like permanent residence in Everglades National Park and other areas of the state.

headline: Old Haunt of U.S. Spies Becomes a Playground for Istanbul’s Elite
text: ISTANBUL — For more than a century, the grand Italianate mansion that serves as an anchor of this city’s European quarter was a beehive of American diplomacy and espionage. Spies toiled within and met their agents at the bar across the street, reporters dropped by for after-work drinks, and any Turk could walk in off the street to see the latest art exhibition or browse the library. There seemed to be a celebration every night.

headline: Notre Dame Stifles South Carolina’s Gritty Rally to Reach Second Straight Final
text: TAMPA, Fla. — South Carolina, which entered Sunday’s national semifinals with the 11th-ranked scoring defense in Division I, forced Notre Dame to play in the mud, slowing the game with gritty defense and stifling ball pressure.

headline: RadioShack’s Blueprint for a Rebirth, Planned by a Hedge Fund
text: A day after RadioShack’s narrow escape from liquidation in bankruptcy court, Soohyung Kim, the financier who led the contentious rescue, retreated to a back office to make a conference call with the chain’s almost 2,700 workers, vendors and landlords.

headline: Battling Crime and Calories at F.B.I. (Fit Bureau of Investigation)
text: WASHINGTON — F.B.I. agents are on the front lines of the fight to protect the United States from Islamic terrorists, Russian hackers and Chinese spies.

headline: One of Libya’s Rival Governments Moves to Control Oil Revenue
text: CAIRO — One of the two factions battling for control of Libya took steps on Sunday to divert incoming oil revenue away from the central bank and into its own new account, a steep escalation in the contest over the country’s vast wealth.

headline: Wisconsin Supreme Court Election Raises Concerns About Partisanship
text: The Wisconsin Supreme Court, defined in recent years by polarization and reports of dysfunction, could be profoundly reshaped by an election on Tuesday. The outcome hinges on two choices — whether voters re-elect a justice who is seen as part of the court’s liberal minority and whether they approve a constitutional amendment that seems likely to lead to the installation of a conservative chief justice.

headline: Online Test-Takers Feel Anti-Cheating Software’s Uneasy Glare
text: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — Before Betsy Chao, a senior here at Rutgers University, could take midterm exams in her online courses this semester, her instructors sent emails directing students to download Proctortrack, a new anti-cheating technology.

headline: Timely Resurrection of an Iron Man Bolsters Wisconsin’s Rise
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Shortly after midnight, Traevon Jackson sat in a Wisconsin locker room that was neither euphoric nor delirious but rather filled with a calm. Less than an hour earlier, the Badgers had ended Kentucky’s 38-game winning streak and avenged a heartbreaking loss to the Wildcats in a national semifinal last year.

headline: Evelyn Starks Hardy, Founder of the Gospel Harmonettes, Dies at 92
text: Evelyn Starks Hardy, who founded the Original Gospel Harmonettes, a pioneering all-female black singing group that performed at Carnegie Hall and the Apollo and made its voice heard in the civil rights movement, died on Thursday at her home in Birmingham, Ala. She was 92.

headline: India Tries Evacuating Citizens in Yemen
text: NEW DELHI — India used small boats this weekend to ferry some of its citizens to a naval destroyer anchored near Aden, Yemen, as an operation to evacuate about 4,000 Indians from Yemen’s war zone entered a difficult phase.

headline: Phyllis R. Klotman, Archivist of African-American Cinema, Dies at 90
text: Phyllis R. Klotman, a film scholar who helped unearth lost treasures of African-American cinema and established a major archive devoted to their preservation and study, died on March 30 at her home in Manhattan. She was 90.

headline: 70 Years On, Crowd Gets Close to the Birthplace of the Atomic Bomb
text: WHITE SANDS MISSILE RANGE, N.M. — The stretch of New Mexico desert would seem endless if not for the mountain range looming high in the distance. It is the kind of place where drivers keep an extra close watch on their fuel gauge, and the closest neighbors are small towns, tiny specks of civilization, dozens of miles away.

headline: After Years on the Outside at the Masters, Europeans May Be Poised to Win
text: The last time a European triumphed at the Masters was shortly after Northern Ireland’s Rory McIlroy won his first tournament in the United States.

headline: Coast Guard Swaps Buoys on the Hudson, a Sure Sign of Spring
text: The Katherine Walker, a hulking Coast Guard workboat, was set to grapple a hefty buoy on the Hudson River when an approaching oil barge radioed in, asking, “You guys switching the winter buoys out?”

headline: Yankees Have a Hole and Plenty of Hope to Fill It
text: WASHINGTON — It was 59 degrees and sunny in the Bronx when Tony Fernandez jogged out to shortstop on April 26, 1995, for the Yankees’ season opener. Fernandez, who was 32, was just a fill-in, someone to hold the position until the team could promote Derek Jeter from the minor leagues and usher in another great period in its history.

headline: Shakespeare’s Sonnets, All 154, Reimagined Through a New York Lens
text: Billy Magnussen climbed slowly and silently up an outdoor stairway in northern Manhattan on a blustery afternoon. He stopped briefly to wave to the woman draped in a shawl awaiting him two landings above. But once he reached her, he returned to the bottom of the John T. Brush Stairway, an obscure spot near where the Polo Grounds once stood, named for the long-ago owner of the New York Giants baseball team. Then, with a camera rolling, he climbed the stairs again and again.

headline: A New Wall Rises in Bulgaria
text: Two decades after the removal of a fence designed to keep people in, Bulgaria is building a new one on the Turkish border to keep people out.

headline: Bulgaria Puts Up a New Wall, but This One Keeps People Out
text: LESOVO, Bulgaria — Less than two decades after the painstaking removal of a massive border fence designed to keep people in, Bulgarian authorities are just as painstakingly building a new fence along the rugged Turkish border, this time to keep people out.

headline: Beneath California Crops, Groundwater Crisis Grows
text: Even as the worst drought in decades ravages California, and its cities face mandatory cuts in water use, millions of pounds of thirsty crops like oranges, tomatoes and almonds continue to stream out of the state and onto the nation’s grocery shelves.

headline: Biding His Time, Duke Reserve Delivers the Boom
text: INDIANAPOLIS — He spent hours dunking outside at the hoop in his driveway, with the rim low at first, then raising it just a tad, higher and higher, until no height seemed insurmountable.

headline: Popular Demand
text: Advertisers spent an estimated $870 million on TV commercials during the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, not including the final game.

headline: Robert K. Boyce, Detectives’ Chief, Gains Fame as Gruff Voice of New York Police
text: For more than a decade, whoever occupied the role of chief of detectives in the New York Police Department was a man seen but rarely heard, a silent presence in the flinty-eyed rows of pressed suits or dress blues who stood as ornaments behind elected and appointed officials at city briefings.

headline: The Parched West
text: Articles in this series will explore the effects of the drought that has hit states from the Pacific Coast to the Great Plains.

headline: Track’s Heartbeat Is Fast as Ever in Jamaica
text: KINGSTON, Jamaica — Sound rises like a cliff wall — drums, trombones, trumpets, the ubiquitous vuvuzela, the odd French horn and 10,000 fans screaming.

headline: Gunther Schuller Awarded MacDowell Medal
text: The MacDowell Colony, a prestigious artists’ residency program in New Hampshire, has awarded its 2015 lifetime achievement medal to Gunther Schuller, a composer and educator who has worked to bridge the gap between classical and jazz music.

text: Season 6, Episode 18: Loser Edit

headline: For Derek Jeter, Retirement Is a Job
text: Derek Jeter’s first spring training as a retired Yankee has taken him far from George M. Steinbrenner Field in Tampa. First, he joined his former teammate Hideki Matsui for a charity exhibition game in Japan to raise money for survivors of the 2011 earthquake and tsunami. Then he traveled to Australia, where he attended the Cricket World Cup final in Melbourne.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of April 6
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Optimism Rings at Wrigley, Despite Loss in Opener
text: CHICAGO — In its more than 100 years of hosting Chicago Cubs openers, Wrigley Field had assuredly never seen one quite like this: Outfield bleachers were missing; a new and huge video board loomed in left field; a celebrity manager was in the dugout; and a bona fide ace was on the mound. It was wacky and weird, but this being the long-suffering Cubs, it was all imbued with something familiar: hope.

headline: Before His Vows, Andy Murray Again Plays Bridesmaid to Novak Djokovic
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — It was not much of a wedding present.

headline: Transgender Woman Cites Attacks and Abuse in Men’s Prison
text: ROME, Ga. — Before she fell on hard times and got into trouble with the law, Ashley Diamond had a wardrobe of wigs named after her favorite divas. “Darling, hand me Aretha” or Mariah or Madonna, she would say to her younger sister when they glammed up to go out on the town.

headline: Victor Gotbaum, 93, Dies; Labor Leader Helped Rescue New York City in 1970s
text: Victor H. Gotbaum, a shrewd and combative Brooklyn native who headed the nation’s largest municipal employees’ union for two decades and played a pivotal role in saving New York City from bankruptcy in 1975, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: UConn Too Big, Too Savvy and Too Much for Upstart Maryland
text: TAMPA, Fla. — If there was one sequence of athletic precision that best illustrated the often cruel challenge of dealing with the Connecticut women’s basketball team, it came early in the second half of its national semifinal against Maryland on Sunday night.

headline: California Seeks to Make Way for Statue of Sally Ride in U.S. Capitol
text: SAN FRANCISCO — If California legislators succeed, a statue of Sally Ride, astronaut, physicist and educator, will be enshrined in the nation’s Capitol. But first they will have to remove an impediment: the statue of the Rev. Junipero Serra, an 18th-century Catholic priest who established California missions and is about to be canonized by Pope Francis. In the Capitol’s National Statuary Hall Collection, there is not room for both.

text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — A week that began with many people in golf dissecting Tiger Woods’s preparedness for the Masters and debating the future of the men’s game ended with the world’s best women showcasing a product that has never been more hale or less predictable.

headline: Wisconsin Has Avoided Arms Race in Recruiting
text: INDIANAPOLIS — On Monday night, Wisconsin will face a team with at least eight former McDonald’s all-Americans for the second consecutive game.

headline: A Mascot With a Fuzzy Future
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Sparky the Dragon, the toothy yet friendly Islanders mascot, was poised for interaction as the Anaheim Ducks took the ice for pregame warm-ups recently at Nassau Coliseum.

headline: Wynn Resorts’ Board, Its Nominees and Elaine Wynn Are All Denounced in Shareholder Report
text: A hotly awaited report that was expected to provide guidance for shareholders and institutional investors as to whom to support in Elaine P. Wynn’s battle to stay on the Wynn Resorts board instead suggested all board nominees be rejected and denounced the company’s “manifest failures of governance.”

headline: ‘Twin Peaks’ Return in Doubt as Director Lynch Backs Out
text: The future of Showtime’s revival of “Twin Peaks” was thrown into doubt Sunday evening after the show’s co-creator, David Lynch, announced that he would not direct any episodes after a disagreement about the show’s budget.

headline: Big Names, and Big Money, Remain After Wildcats’ Exit
text: INDIANAPOLIS — The Kentucky Wildcats, college hoops’ pro-ready squad, came to a baffling end Saturday night, as their potent offense became cement-footed.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 6, 2015
text: Climate conditions have exposed our house of cards. The withdrawals far outstrip the replenishment.

headline: Paul George’s Long-Awaited Return Electrifies Pacers’ Push
text: INDIANAPOLIS — With 6 minutes 7 seconds remaining in the first quarter of the Indiana Pacers’ game against Miami on Sunday, Coach Frank Vogel looked down his bench and said only one word: “Paul.”

headline: The Luxury of Leftovers
text: Waste is becoming a dirty word in the world of high-end food. During Expo Milano 2015, the Michelin-starred chef Massimo Bottura will oversee — with help from Mario Batali, Alain Ducasse and René Redzepi — the Ambrosian Refectory, a pop-up dining hall in a disused theater, where meals will be made using surplus from the estimated 400 tons of food that arrive at the culinary fair each day. Batali and Ducasse also recently worked at New York’s wastED, a temporary restaurant at Dan Barber’s Blue Hill in Greenwich Village, which involved a cast of rotating chefs addressing food waste in their menus. In England, Thomasina Miers of the popular Mexican chain Wahaca is championing the Pig Idea, which proposes to change European law to allow for the leftover food of restaurants and catering companies to be used as pig and chicken feed.

headline: Some Time on My Hands, a Little Hope in My Heart for the Mets
text: This is the best time of the year for Mets fans. Sure, the Mets haven’t won any regular-season games yet, but they haven’t lost any, either.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
text: 8:10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE LUNCHBOX (2014) When a delivery service sends a lunch intended for her husband astray, a neglected Mumbai housewife (Nimrat Kaur, above left, with Yashvi Puneet Nagar) finds herself communicating through handwritten letters and home-cooked meals with a widowed office worker (Irrfan Khan) nearing retirement in this debut feature from Ritesh Batra. “This is not a new conceit,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, citing “You’ve Got Mail” and “The Shop Around the Corner.” But, he wrote, “the idea of two lonely souls connecting in a vast, modern metropolis, and remaining strangers even as their intimacy grows, has a durable charm. As do Mr. Khan and Ms. Kaur, islands of melancholy calm surrounded by silliness and noise. Their performances are not exactly subtle — nothing in ‘The Lunchbox’ is exactly subtle — but they are graceful and dignified in the manner of movie stars in an earlier, less aggressive age, ennobling the ordinary lives they explore. And Mr. Batra makes their story touching and credible, an urban fable of hope in the face of disappointment.”

headline: Taking a Few Swings as the Season Begins
text: Just in time for opening day, a half-dozen current and former New York Times writers weigh in with thoughts on the Mets and the Yankees. There seems to be a consensus of sorts: The Mets may actually outdo the Yankees this year.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Spurs at Rockets
text: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

text: The competition, known as Champs, draws students from around the country who record times that are often only a few ticks off world records.

text: The dragon mascot, whose future with the Islanders is uncertain, entertained fans of various ages during a recent game at Nassau Coliseum.

headline: The Kentucky Derby Dartboard: Week 2
text: Top contenders for the 141st running of the Kentucky Derby are listed in order of preference, with comments provided by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. Churchill Downs recently adopted a point system to determine the Derby field, with points being earned by the top four finishers in designated prep races. The odds are from the Churchill Downs futures pool, and the records are starts-win-place-show. An article on Saturday’s Wood Memorial, Blue Grass Stakes and Santa Anita Derby can be found here.

text: SNEAK PEEK: This week Lens is featuring a selection of photographers attending the New York Portfolio Review.

headline: Economics and Elections
text: Britain’s economic performance since the financial crisis struck has been startlingly bad. A tentative recovery began in 2009, but it stalled in 2010. Although growth resumed in 2013, real income per capita is only now reaching its level on the eve of the crisis — which means that Britain has had a much worse track record since 2007 than it had during the Great Depression.

headline: When She Is Pregnant and Obese
Nuclear Fears in South Asia
text: The world’s attention has rightly been riveted on negotiations aimed at curbing Iran’s nuclear program. If and when that deal is made final, America and the other major powers that worked on it — China, Russia, Britain, France and Germany — should turn their attention to South Asia, a troubled region with growing nuclear risks of its own.

headline: The Glitch in Colorado’s Weed Experiment
text: After Colorado voters legalized marijuana, they also approved heavily taxing it and using the money for school construction, law enforcement, drug education and other useful things. The arrangement made perfect sense.

headline: Operator, Get Me the Magic Area Code 212!
text: To the Editor:

headline: Meet the 5 Women’s Rights Activists China Detained
text: Overnight beginning on April 13, the police in China released five women’s rights activists who had been detained in March as they planned a public awareness campaign against sexual harassment on public transportation. Their detention set off an international campaign for their release.

headline: Alcoholics Anonymous and the Challenge of Evidence-Based Medicine
text: Do Alcoholics Anonymous participants do better at abstinence than nonparticipants because they are more motivated? Or is it because of something inherent in the A.A. program?

headline: Still the New Jersey Nets. Sort Of.
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Three years ago, the Nets first said, “Hello, Brooklyn” — and then they stuck around New Jersey.

headline: Boston Marathon Bombing Trial Wraps Up With Clashing Portraits of Naïveté and Extremism
text: BOSTON — The courtroom filled with a swelling chorus of Islamic chants as television screens showed the battlefield carnage on Boylston Street, with severed limbs, an 11-year-old boy with bone fragments from someone else lodged in his body, and bright red blood splashed on the pavement like so many buckets of paint.

headline: For Barbara Comstock of Virginia, a Switch From Left to Right
text: WASHINGTON — Barbara Comstock was an intern for Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts when she realized she might be a Republican. But Ms. Comstock, a freshman member of the House from Virginia’s 10th District, did not simply switch sides; she eventually became one of the Republican Party’s fiercest partisans.

headline: Supreme Court Asked to Look Abroad for Guidance on Same-Sex Marriage
text: WASHINGTON — The world will be watching when the Supreme Court hears arguments this month about same-sex marriage. But will the court be watching the world?

headline: A Dental Hub With Central Park Views May Go on the Market
text: “This is heaven,” Dr. Marc Schneider said, standing in front of his floor-to-ceiling windows on the 14th floor of 30 Central Park South.

headline: The Hackathon Fast Track, From Campus to Silicon Valley
text: Shariq Hashme squints at his laptop screen as he scrolls through hundreds of lines of computer code. “I can’t even make sense of it right now,” he says with a grimace. The long string of numbers, symbols and letters would usually be intelligible to Mr. Hashme, a 21-year-old computer science major at the University of Maryland, College Park, but at this moment, he’s having trouble even keeping his eyes open. In the last 27 hours, he has slept just two.

headline: ‘Better Than Before,’ by Gretchen Rubin
text: For a few months, Gretchen Rubin’s first book, the longstanding best seller “The Happiness Project,” perched on my bathroom radiator, its cartoonish yellow font in conversation with a stray rubber ducky. I read it in small ­doses, convinced with each sitting that I could go to sleep earlier, or discover a ­hobby, or make three new friends. I often forgot the specific advice shortly after reading it, but the sight of the little bluebird on the cover floating across the perpetually cloudless sky was frequently enough to give me a lift.

headline: ‘Selfish, Shallow, and Self-Absorbed: Sixteen Writers on the Decision Not to Have Kids’
text: Today 19 percent of American women reach their mid-40s without ever having a child — a figure that has nearly doubled in four decades, a truly staggering statistic. The sheer velocity of its emergence suggests a unity of intent, as if an army of Gen Xers came of age razing day care centers and burning diapers, and continues to march steadily into the future, attracting new recruits by the minute.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: For Older Adults, a Rising Risk of Subdural Hematoma
text: You don’t have to hit your head to develop an insidious bleed between the soft covering of your brain and the brain itself that in days, weeks or months can threaten your health or life.

headline: New York Today: A New Season
text: Good morning on this very springy Monday.

headline: Daily Report: As Students Take Tests, Software Keeps Watch
text: Before Betsy Chao, a senior at Rutgers University, could take midterm exams in her online courses this semester, her instructors sent emails directing students to download Proctortrack, a new anti-cheating technology. “You have to put your face up to it and you put your knuckles up to it,” Ms. Chao said, explaining how the program uses webcams to scan students’ features and verify their identities before the test, Natasha Singer reports.

headline: United States Embassy, Tehran
text: LONDON — The nuclear deal with Iran is still only preliminary but if concluded it will represent the most important American diplomatic achievement since the Dayton Accords ended the Bosnian war two decades ago. That agreement was imperfect. Still, not another shot was fired in anger after the loss of more than 100,000 lives. This accord, too, reflects harsh realities — Iran has mastered the nuclear fuel cycle — yet represents the best possibility by far of holding Iran short of a bomb, ring-fencing its nuclear capacities, coaxing change in the Islamic Republic, and ushering a hopeful society closer to the world. If the yardstick is effectiveness, and it must be, no conceivable alternative even comes close. Perfection is not part of diplomacy’s repertoire.

headline: Asian, American, Woman, Philosopher
text: This is the ninth in a series of interviews with philosophers on race that I am conducting for The Stone. This week’s conversation is with Emily S. Lee, an associate professor of philosophy at the California State University, Fullerton. She is the editor of “Living Alterities: Phenomenology, Embodiment, and Race.” — George Yancy

headline: Letting My Autistic Son Go Where the Wild Things Are
text: I had heard about the bear. It had been sighted near two corners of our property, 18 acres of mostly wetlands in Massachusetts. For months I had been anxiously scanning the woods, watching.

headline: The Civil War’s 11th-Hour Soldiers
text: Deadly fireworks lit the predawn sky over Petersburg, Va., on April 2, 1865. Shells screeched and exploded all around the thousands of Union troops crouched in assault formation between the rival armies’ entrenchments. A captain approached Col. Bradley Winslow of the 186th New York Infantry and announced, “The general directs you now to advance.” He shook Winslow’s hand, adding: “It will be hot. God bless you!”

headline: Jeb Bush’s 2009 Voter-Registration Application
text: Florida state law requires signatures, social security numbers and driver’s license numbers to be redacted from voter-registration applications before being released. The New York Times separately redacted Mr. Bush’s telephone number and address information as a courtesy.

text: How will U.S. allies joining the China-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank affect world politics and the global economy?

headline: Today in Politics: A Nuclear Scientist From M.I.T. Takes the Bully Pulpit on Iran
text: Good Monday morning from Washington where President Obama and Michelle Obama will host the annual Easter egg roll, and the nation celebrates baseball’s opening day. An effort to repeal a law signed by former Gov. Rick Perry brings the immigration debate back to Texas, and former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida seems to have taken his Hispanic ties a step too far on one occasion. As Sunday talk shows discussed the tentative nuclear agreement with Iran, the White House dispatched an unconventional spokesman to defend it: an M.I.T.-trained nuclear physicist with nearly shoulder-length hair.

headline: Jeb Bush Listed Himself as ‘Hispanic’ on Voter Form
text: There is little doubt that Jeb Bush possesses strong credentials for appealing to Hispanic voters.

headline: ZenPayroll Start-Up Raises $60 Million From Group Led by Google Investment Arm
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Processing companies’ payrolls may not seem like the hottest business opportunity around. But ZenPayroll, a start-up just over two years old, has drawn a number of big backers to do just that.

headline: Kenyan Fighter Jets Bomb Shabab Training Camps in Somalia
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Kenyan fighter jets bombed two training camps of the Shabab militant group in Somalia, defense officials said on Monday, the first military response to the attack on a university last week that killed nearly 150 students.

headline: Morning Agenda: Challenge to Insider Trading Ruling Fails
text: CHALLENGE TO INSIDER TRADING RULING FAILS | On Friday, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit denied Preet Bharara’s request to reconsider a decision in December that sharply narrowed the definition of insider trading. Now left with few legal options, the United States attorney for Manhattan may need to rely on Congress to protect the legacy of his crackdown on insider trading, Matthew Goldstein and Ben Protess write in DealBook.

headline: Do Women Take Body Image Cues From Models?
text: France’s proposed law barring ultrathin models, which is more of an anti-anorexia campaign or an anorexia-prevention bill, if we are being optimistic, has gotten meaningfully closer to realization, winning a majority vote in the lower house of Parliament and moving on to the Senate.

headline: Israel’s Military Faces Delicate Balance in West Bank
text: JERUSALEM — For Israel’s military, maintaining control of the occupied West Bank has been fraught with contradictions in recent months, creating a tension that senior military officials say does not bode well for stability.

headline: At Success Academy Charter Schools, High Scores and Polarizing Tactics
text: At most schools, if a child is flailing academically, it is treated as a private matter.

headline: If Algorithms Know All, How Much Should Humans Help?
text: Armies of the finest minds in computer science have dedicated themselves to improving the odds of making a sale. The Internet-era abundance of data and clever software has opened the door to tailored marketing, targeted advertising and personalized product recommendations.

headline: Who’s Coming to Dinner? Explorers, Astronauts and Spelunkers
text: The annual Explorers Club dinner takes place in one of New York City’s most dramatic settings: beneath the gigantic blue whale at the American Museum of Natural History.

headline: Ancient Chinese Community Celebrates Its Jewish Roots, and Passover
text: Over the remains of the Chinese-style Passover banquet – soups with bamboo and huge chunks of fresh tofu, steamed fish and platters of crisp greens in mustard sauce – Li Penglin, 16, lifted a glass of Israeli wine from his place at the head table. Quietly but without faltering, he read out a Chinese translation of a Hebrew prayer.

headline: 1915: German Ships Reported Sunk
text: LONDON — A dispatch to the ‘‘Daily Mail’’ from Copenhagen reports that the German naval activity in the Baltic, which began with the attack on Libau, when some non-combatants and neutral seamen were killed, came to a dramatic climax on Sunday [April 4]. The German fleet was returning from its Russian expedition when it suddenly found itself caught in its own minefield, which had gone adrift. It is supposed that the mines got loose and floated into neutral waters. As a result of these drifting mines, all maritime traffic has been stopped, and it is reported that no fewer than six German steamers have been sunk by them. — The New York Herald, European Edition, April 7, 1915

headline: Skeptical of Iran Nuclear Deal, Israel Calls for Changes
text: JERUSALEM — Clearly unsatisfied with assurances from President Obama about the provisions of the Iran nuclear deal, Israel on Monday listed specific requirements that it declared were necessary in any final agreement.

headline: Duke vs. Wisconsin Is a Tossup, but the Experts Mostly See It One Way
text: The final of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament Monday night is freshmen versus seniors, traditional power versus upstart, Jahlil Okafor versus Frank Kaminsky, Mike Krzyzewski versus Bo Ryan.

headline: Art for the Knowing Nose
text: Peter De Cupere works in sewage and urinal cakes, candy and flowers — anything to inspire a visceral response of personal memories.

headline: With State Control, North Carolina Republicans Pursue Smaller Prizes
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — In 2011, soon after Republicans won control of the North Carolina General Assembly for the first time since Reconstruction, they set about redrawing congressional and state legislative districts to maximize their advantage, setting off legal challenges and bitter complaints from their rivals.

headline: Virtu, a High-Frequency Trader, Resumes Its I.P.O.
text: After shelving plans to go public last year amid uproar over Michael Lewis’s book about high-frequency trading, one of the biggest firms in that field is restarting its initial public offering.

headline: Turkey Blocks YouTube and, Briefly, Twitter Over Hostage Photo
text: ISTANBUL — As a hostage crisis at the central courthouse gripped this city last week, a photograph coursing through social media conveyed the situation more concisely than any words: a beret-wearing militant, face obscured by a red scarf, holding a gun to the head of a well-known prosecutor.

headline: 1965: Pope Looks at Mixed Marriage
text: VATICAN CITY — Pope Paul VI was reported today preparing a document extensively altering Roman Catholic Church law on mixed marriages, doing away with written promises from the non-Catholic and guaranteeing his or her religious liberty. Italian newspapers speculated that the Pope would shortly issue a ‘‘motu proprio,’’ or a personal administrative decree, altering the marriage section of the code of canon law. A Vatican official said, however, that the Pope would not publish such a document for some time. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 7, 1965.

headline: The Mind of Those Who Kill, and Kill Themselves

headline: Planes Without Pilots
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Mounting evidence that the co-pilot crashed a Germanwings plane into a French mountain has prompted a global debate about how to better screen crewmembers for mental illness and how to ensure that no one is left alone in the cockpit.

headline: Boeing and Delta Spend Millions in Fight Over Export-Import Bank’s Existence
text: WASHINGTON — Last week, with little notice, a federal judge here tossed out Delta Air Lines’ longstanding claim that the government’s export credit agency — which, among other things, provides loan guarantees to overseas airlines for the purchase of Boeing jets — was helping international competitors at the airline’s expense.

headline: Tracy K. Smith’s Most Treasured Cooking Tool
text: The poundcake sitting on the counter in Tracy K. Smith’s kitchen is no mere loaf: Tall and wide, it looks like a great golden gong tipped on its back but still ready at any moment to resound.

headline: For Blackpoll Warbler, a Lot of Flying for a Lightweight
text: Every autumn, tiny forest songbirds known as blackpoll warblers fly 1,500 miles nonstop from New England and Canada to Puerto Rico, Cuba and the Greater Antilles. The journey, long suspected but only now documented, is one of the longest overwater flights made by a songbird. Recording the migration was a challenge because of the tiny size of the birds, which typically weigh about half an ounce. In a study published in the journal Biology Letters, researchers attached miniature geolocators about the size of a dime to the backs of 40 warblers to confirm the migration route.

headline: The Party Is King in Presidential Voting, but a Person Can Make the Difference
text: Over the next several weeks, candidates will begin to announce they are running for president. You may find yourself asking: How much does it matter whether the Republicans nominate Ted Cruz or Jeb Bush? Or whether the Democrats choose Hillary Clinton or Joe Biden? Won’t people just vote for the candidate from their party anyway?

headline: Going to the Derby? What to Do in Louisville, Ky.

headline: How Is Scott Walker Like Reagan? He’ll Tell You

Scott Walker of Wisconsin went on Twitter to wish a happy 22nd anniversary to “my lovely bride Tonette,” and included a wedding photo of the couple in gown and tails. An hour later on Twitter, Mr. Walker posted a photo of another object of his affection: “Today,” he wrote, “is the 104th anniversary of President Ronald Reagan’s birth!”

headline: Why ‘Pro-Gay’ Makes No Sense

headline: James Koukios Leaves Justice Department for Morrison & Foerster

headline: Rev. Gardner C. Taylor, Powerful Voice for Civil Rights, Dies at 96
text: The Rev. Gardner C. Taylor, a grandson of slaves who took over a Baptist pulpit in Brooklyn in 1948, when overt racism defined much of American life, and became an influential voice for civil rights and one of the nation’s most eloquent churchmen, died on Sunday in Durham, N.C. He was 96.

headline: The Fiscal Future I: The Hyperbolic Case for Bigger Government
text: Brad DeLong has posted a draft statement on fiscal policy for the IMF conference on “rethinking macroeconomics” — and I’m shocked, in a good way. As regular readers may have noticed, Brad and I share many views, so I expected something along lines I have also been thinking. Instead, however, Brad has come up with what I believe are seriously new ideas — enough so that I want to do two posts, following different lines of thought he suggests.

headline: Bank of America Merrill Lynch Hires Banker for Equity Capital Markets

headline: Call for Activism at IBM Is Likely to Go Unheard
text: Requests from some big shareholders for activism at IBM are likely to go nowhere. There’s no question that the company’s investors have reason to be dissatisfied. Big Blue’s top line has shrunk for 11 consecutive quarters, shares have fallen about 25 percent from their high, and there’s no hint that the company has discovered a way to reverse course. The snag is that activists don’t have an obvious playbook for IBM’s recovery either.

headline: Creatures of the Wind and Tavi Gevinson’s Southern Spring Trip
text: Last September at Creatures of the Wind’s spring/summer 2015 fashion show, the 18-year-old multihyphenate wonder Tavi Gevinson sat front row and said to John Kobin for The New York Times, “It’s really nice to see it and also to drop in as an observer.” And late last week, she saw it again — this time, in North Carolina, where she co-hosted a dinner with the design duo, Shane Gabier and Christopher Peters, to celebrate the collection’s arrival at the Capitol boutique there. “Tavi has been a friend of ours since the Chicago days; she’s one of the coolest people we know,” Gabier says. “We hadn’t been able to hang out much this year, so it was great to have a few days together in Charlotte to catch up.” During their stay down South, the three amigos ate top-notch Carolina BBQ and shared a screened-in sleeping porch at the hundred-year-old mansion they called home for a few days. Here, Gabier and Peters recount highlights from their trip.

headline: U.S. Weighs Whether to Act or Wait on Insider Trading
text: Last week’s decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit to reject the Justice Department’s request to reconsider its ruling in United States v. Newman, which makes insider trading harder to prove, leaves the government with three choices. It can ask the Supreme Court to review the decision, push Congress to adopt a law to define insider trading or live with the outcome and figure out how to minimize its effect.

headline: Forest Fires Threaten New Fallout From Chernobyl
text: On April 26, 1986, the Chernobyl nuclear plant in Ukraine released a plume of radiation that eventually blanketed an estimated 77,000 square miles of Europe and Eurasia. While the worst of the contamination occurred near the plant — an area still closed to human habitation, now referred to as the exclusion zone — the effects are still seen further afield as well. Radioactive wild boars roam German forests, and radioactive mushrooms grow in Bulgaria.

headline: How Brian Grazer Got Curiouser and Curiouser
text: Brian Grazer, the Academy Award-winning producer behind films including “Frost/Nixon,” “A Beautiful Mind” and “Friday Night Lights,” credits his grandmother Sonia with validating his persistent curiosity. “All the disappointments I had, she acted like they didn’t exist,” he recalls, “and said, ‘You’re going to be special in life. Asking questions is what life is all about, and you’re asking the best questions.’”

headline: Review: ‘R&J&Z’ Is ‘Romeo and Juliet’ for the Zombie Age
text: At the end of most productions of “Romeo and Juliet,” six characters are dead. Well, five if you cut the scene when Romeo skewers Paris, which some directors do. But “R&J&Z,” a gory riff on the tragedy by the writer-performer Melody Bates at the New Ohio Theater, is a little more homicidal.

headline: Review: Noche Flamenca, With Soledad Barrio, at Joe’s Pub
text: If you can’t make it to Spain this week, Joe’s Pub will do. On Saturday, Noche Flamenca returned to that club, where you can experience the troupe’s celebrated take on traditional flamenco up close and in a congenial atmosphere. A guitarist, a singer, a handful of dancers: that’s all this stage can fit, and that’s all this party needs. And when one of those dancers is Soledad Barrio, this company’s burning star, the experience is pretty much guaranteed to be memorable.

headline: Review: Stacy Sullivan, Guided by History and Weather, at the Metropolitan Room
text: Growing up in the part of Oklahoma nicknamed Tornado Alley, the singer Stacy Sullivan waited for 22 years without seeing a funnel cloud, she recalled on Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Room. The combination of fear and excitement that the anticipation of heavy weather can stir up was the driving force behind her audacious, often thrilling new show, her second in less than six months.

headline: Review: In ‘The Dance Apocalypse/Solos,’ the End is Full of Questions
text: What is the Dance Apocalypse and should you fear it? Least ambiguously, it is the name under which Nicole Bindler and Gabrielle Revlock, Philadelphia performers, work together. But what was “The Dance Apocalypse/Solos,” the show they presented on Friday at Jack, in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn?

headline: ‘Louie’ Is Back. His Issues Are, Too.
text: Season 4 of “Louie” was Louis C.K.’s art house phase. One moment he seemed to be channeling David Lynch, the next Woody Allen, the next Paul Mazursky. His half-hour comedy, always on the dark and fantastical side, took on a whole new weight — a seriousness that was simultaneously impressive and a little wearing. At times the only laughter it inspired was the nervous kind. That felt funny, you thought — is that where I was supposed to laugh?

headline: Review: LoftOpera’s ‘Lucrezia Borgia,’ With Flying Bottles of Beer and Poison
text: The final aria in Donizetti’s “Lucrezia Borgia,” an Oedipally charged melodrama about this most infamous of Renaissance power players, is notoriously difficult to sing. In “Era desso il figlio mio” Lucrezia, who has unwittingly poisoned her secret son, flips wildly between expressions of private heartbreak and fiery coloratura-spiked outbursts. The virtuosity of the vocal part can overwhelm the poignancy of the moment, especially in staged performances.

headline: JetBlue to Fly Between Albany and 2 Florida Destinations
text: JetBlue Airways plans to begin daily service between Albany International Airport and two Florida destinations late this year. Flights will begin Dec. 10 with nonstop service to Fort Lauderdale and Orlando. JetBlue already services Buffalo, Rochester, Syracuse, Newburgh, Westchester and both New York City airports. To introduce the flights, JetBlue offered limited one-way promotional fares on Monday of $16.86 — a figure picked to honor Albany’s incorporation in 1686.

headline: Georgia: Judge Sets Hearing on Request by Transgender Inmate for Transfer
text: A federal district judge on Monday set a hearing for Thursday on an emergency motion in the case of a transgender woman, Ashley Diamond, who is seeking an immediate transfer to a lower-security prison or “transitional center” so that she can be safer from sexual assault. Judge Marc T. Treadwell also asked Georgia corrections officials to produce all communications — “emails, correspondence, messages, etc.” — regarding Ms. Diamond’s transfer several weeks ago to Georgia State Prison. Ms. Diamond alleges that the transfer, to a prison with a relatively high prevalence of sexual violence, was “apparently retaliatory” for her lawsuit against corrections officials. Ms. Diamond, 36, is a nonviolent offender and first-time inmate who has lived as a transgender woman since adolescence, but has been held in prisons for men, most of them high-security, for the last three years. She claims in her lawsuit to have suffered at least seven sexual assaults as well as routine sexual coercion and harassment. In addition to safer housing, her lawsuit, filed in February, seeks access to the hormone therapy that is essential medical care for her gender dysphoria. She had been taking hormones for 17 years, she says, until the prison system denied her access. A Georgia corrections spokeswoman said on Monday that Ms. Diamond “has been receiving the appropriate treatment assessed by Georgia Correction Health medical staff” since March. This is apparently a reference to a hormone patch given to her in response to her lawsuit.

text: ROME — Inside the Cinecittà film studios, originally built by Mussolini in part to produce fascist propaganda, a catapult is parked beside Soundstage 13. Not far away, craftsmen touch up chariots. The props are for the remake of the 1959 swords-and-sandals epic, “Ben-Hur,” which is consuming much of the vast studio lot, if not all of it.

headline: Chris Gibson, an Upstate Republican, Starts Early on a Possible Run for Governor
text: Inside a Knights of Columbus post, far from his Hudson Valley district, Representative Chris Gibson spoke insistently to the Brooklyn Young Republican Club, urging the sparse crowd to get to work rebuilding New York’s depleted Republican Party before the next campaign for governor in 2018.

headline: University of Virginia Fraternity to Go After Rolling Stone for Rape Article

Mr. Obama worked for him at Harvard Law School, where Mr. Tribe has taught for four decades.

headline: Body of a Rebel Leader Is Identified in Uganda

headline: Argentina: Ex-Economy Minister Gets Suspended Sentence for Hidden Cash
text: A former Argentine economy minister wept Monday in court as federal judges gave her a suspended prison sentence related to the discovery of thousands of dollars in cash in her office bathroom. Felisa Miceli, the economy minister from 2005 to 2007, had been convicted of corruption-related charges, but last year that sentence was ordered to be reviewed. Ms. Miceli had been unable to prove that she legally obtained the money — cash in dollars and pesos worth more than $64,000 when it was turned up in 2007. Ms. Miceli said Monday in court in Buenos Aires, “It would be a terrible injustice if I went to prison,” adding, “I regret taking the money.” The judges also prohibited Ms. Miceli from holding public office for six years and ordered her to repay 100,000 pesos, or almost $11,400.

headline: Sports Groups in Indianapolis Fight to Keep Their City Welcoming
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Stand next to the obelisk in the middle of Monument Circle here, and you are within one mile of an N.F.L. stadium, an N.B.A. arena and a minor league ballpark; the American College of Sports Medicine; the offices of U.S.A. Gymnastics, U.S.A. Track & Field and U.S.A. Synchronized Swimming; and the headquarters of the Black Coaches Association, the National Federation of State High School Associations and the N.C.A.A.

headline: Complete Without a Break
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — The English language is a funny thing, and I say this not just because I habitually misread the word “pedestrian.” People who come to the United States from other countries are often BEDEVILED by the weird turns our American English takes, from our colloquialisms to our pronunciation.

headline: India: Officers Die in Kashmir Attack
text: Three unarmed Indian policemen were killed Monday by militants in Indian-administered Kashmir, another in a string of recent attacks. The police officers, who were investigating a land dispute in the Shopian district, died when militants shot at them with Kalashnikov rifles and then escaped into woods. In separate extremist attacks, a former militant who was suspected of being a police informer was seriously injured and a police officer in another district was shot in the neck from close range. “If you see all the three incidents, they have resorted to attack on soft targets where people were unarmed,” S. J. M. Gillani, inspector general of police in Kashmir, told the NDTV news channel. Among other recent violence in the area, a police officer and a soldier were killed Thursday by militants who escaped and last month an attack on a police station and army camp left three police officers, four militants and a civilian dead.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
text: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE PAINTED VEIL (2006) An unhappily married 1920s British couple, Kitty and Walter Fane (Naomi Watts and Edward Norton, above), move to Shanghai, where they drift into a steamy state of liberated coexistence in this third screen adaptation of the W. Somerset Maugham novel. Liev Schreiber plays Charles Townsend, the married charmer who brings Kitty to life — and then close to death when Walter, a doctor, discovers their affair and hustles her into the countryside during a cholera epidemic. “As nicely directed by John Curran and adapted to the screen by Ron Nyswaner, this version of the story lulls you by turning Maugham’s distaff bildungsroman into a fine romance,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Even better, the new film gives us ample opportunity to spend time with Ms. Watts, whose remarkable talent helps keep movie faith and love alive, even in the tinniest, tiniest vehicles.” Mr. Norton, she added, “is very fine here, especially early on, before his billing gets the better of the story.”

headline: How to Be Emotionally Intelligent
text: What makes a great leader? Knowledge, smarts and vision, to be sure. To that, Daniel Goleman, author of “Leadership: The Power of Emotional Intelligence,” would add the ability to identify and monitor emotions — your own and others’ — and to manage relationships. Qualities associated with such “emotional intelligence” distinguish the best leaders in the corporate world, according to Mr. Goleman, a former New York Times science reporter, a psychologist and co-director of a consortium at Rutgers University to foster research on the role emotional intelligence plays in excellence. He shares his short list of the competencies.

headline: What It Really Means to Call Hillary Clinton ‘Polarizing’
text: Late in George W. Bush’s first term, the conservative commentator Charles Krauthammer coined the term “Bush Derangement Syndrome,” which he defined as “the acute onset of paranoia in otherwise normal people in reaction to the policies, the presidency — nay — the very existence of George W. Bush.” In other words, there were a whole bunch of people, presumably on the left, who not only didn’t like George W. Bush, but also disliked him to an irrational and perhaps unhinged degree. By coining a “syndrome” to describe the state, Krauthammer, a formerly practicing psychiatrist with an M.D. from Harvard, was injecting a clever bit of gas-lighting into the debate. (Are you sure there’s not something else going on with you, Bush haters? Have you considered getting help?)

headline: The Living Beauty of Wicken Fen
text: On a foggy morning last spring, I took my brother and 11-year-old niece for a long walk in one of Britain’s oldest nature reserves, Wicken Fen, a tiny fragment of a lost marshland ecosystem that once covered around 2,500 square miles of eastern England. We spent hours walking through a mosaic of grassland and sedge, past wet fields cut with scrub-shadow and flashes of open water. Everywhere was bursting with life: singing nightingales, snipe winnowing through the upper air, cuckoos tilting from the tips of willows and rails squealing and grunting in reeds. As we walked on wet grass by one of the fen’s ancient waterways, a barn owl floated past us, its mothy wings shining through particulate mist; at our feet a drinker moth caterpillar inched furrily across the path like a cautiously mobile mustache. We knelt to watch its progress. Then my niece turned to me and asked: “When they made this place, where did they bring the animals from? Did they come from a zoo?”

headline: Lincoln’s Triumphant Visit to Richmond
text: Shortly before noon on April 3, 1865, a telegraph operator on duty at the War Department in Washington, D.C., received an electrifying message over the wires. “Here is the first message for you in four years from Richmond,” it read.

headline: Today in Politics: Some Hiccups Await Rand Paul’s Big Day

Former Gov. Jeb Bush responds to mistakenly calling himself Hispanic, and in Chicago, the polls open in the runoff election for mayor between Rahm Emanuel and Jesus G. Garcia. Though Mr. Paul’s efforts to control the rollout of his presidential campaign — oh, that’s what the announcement will be — may be hindered by the near-simultaneous release of an ad criticizing his statements on Iran, he will be only the second official entrant in what is expected to be a crowded Republican field.

headline: ‘Ravensbrück,’ by Sarah Helm
text: When we hear the phrase “concentration camp,” we usually envision the huge extermination centers the Germans built in Poland as part of their “final solution to the Jewish question,” their effort to murder every Jew they could find. But though it was relatively small, and though it wasn’t primarily an extermination center, Ravensbrück helps us understand how thoroughgoing an onslaught on humanity Nazi Germany perpetrated, and how central to its identity was its implacable urge to enslave and kill those it considered ­undesirable.

text: In a new spin on the chef-driven food festival, the coming Bottega Gran Fondo pairs food enthusiasts and cycling fans for a bike-ride-cum-progressive-feast in California’s Napa Valley.

headline: Indian Police Shoot and Kill 20 Said to Be Illegally Cutting Down Trees
text: NEW DELHI — The Indian police and forestry officials on Tuesday fatally shot 20 loggers whom they suspected of illegally cutting down endangered red sandalwood trees, whose wood can be sold in China and Japan for hundreds of thousands of dollars a ton.

headline: The Fiscal Future II: Not Enough Debt?
text: Continuing my meditation on Brad DeLong’s meditation on the fiscal future. Brad doesn’t just argue that governments should be bigger in the future; he also argues that governments have historically not had enough debt, and should have more.

headline: Economics of Love
text: Not love as in romance; love as in tennis, meaning zero. Cecchetti & Schoenholtz argue that “zero matters” in macroeconomics; specifically, both the zero almost-lower bound on interest rates and downward wage rigidity make the case that deflation or for that matter very low inflation is a bad thing.

headline: The Auto Show Is in New York, and Cadillac Is Too
text: When Cadillac announced last year that it was moving its headquarters to Soho in Manhattan, it caught my attention. Plenty of tech and digital media companies have set up operations in Lower Manhattan, but no auto companies, let alone an old-economy stalwart like Cadillac.

headline: Deployments: Costly. Remembering Why We Do It: Priceless.
text: There is a vintage poster I saw years ago touting the slogan “Join the Navy, See the World.” Early in our marriage, we fulfilled it, hiking the jungles of Saipan where my grandfather fought during World War II, watching the sunrise at Angkor Wat in Cambodia, exploring the castle grounds in Kumamoto and jumping from waterfalls in the Northern Territory in Australia. Over his first deployment, I met his ship in exotic ports at every chance.

headline: 1940: Decree Bans Heat Till Oct. 15
text: From now on the ‘‘eau chaude’’ label on French faucets will be a mockery on four consecutive days a week, winter and summer, under a fuel conservation decree appearing yesterday in the ‘‘Journal Office’’ cutting down hot water supply. The same decree stops all central heating, no matter what type of fuel is used, from April 1 to October 15. It will be neither clever nor useful to seek out a Turkish bath or pool, unless you feel like a member of the ‘‘Polar Bear’’ club. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 8, 1940

headline: ABC’s ‘World News Tonight’ Tops NBC’s Newscast
text: For the first time in five and a half years, ABC’s “World News Tonight” defeated the “NBC Nightly News” in total viewers last week. ABC’s evening newscast averaged 7.99 million viewers a night compared with NBC’s 7.91 million for the week beginning March 30, according to Nielsen.

headline: Atticus Lish Wins PEN/Faulkner Prize

headline: Silicon Valley: Perks for Some Workers, Struggles for Parents

headline: In Deal for TNT Express, FedEx Bets on European Recovery
text: FedEx is making a big opportunistic bet on Europe. The shipping firm has agreed to buy its ailing Dutch rival TNT Express for 4.4 billion euros ($4.8 billion) in a friendly, all-cash deal. That seems a full price for a troubled target. But cost savings, cheap debt and a strong dollar could help FedEx realize good returns.

text: Four construction workers were injured on Tuesday in Manhattan when they fell while doing interior demolition work and were struck by debris, the authorities said.

headline: As Europe’s Political Landscape Shifts, Two-Party System Fades

Bush’s defeat by Bill Clinton, the Republican Party has made a display of talking about expanding its appeal beyond a base of voters that has steadily grown whiter, richer, more intolerant and more right wing.

headline: The New Wave of Cabana Shirts
text: The season of Cabana shirts — also known as Cuban collar shirts, which call to mind mojitos and cigars, and are often emblazoned with kitschy symbols of tropical vacations (palm trees, flamingos, hibiscuses) — has arrived. This summer ushers in a more urbane approach to the classic warm-weather staple: quieter prints and subtler colors that could have been worn by the hip wandering youth in Jim Jarmusch’s 1980 gritty New York film “Permanent Vacation” instead of by a tourist on a beach holiday.

headline: A New Cookbook Imparts the Art of the Swedish Coffee Break
text: Last year, when the Swedish cafe chain Fika opened a new location near T’s offices, its minimalist interiors, heady aroma of fresh-brewed coffee and toppling towers of baked goods drew in a steady crowd — none of whom seemed to know, however, just what “Fika” meant. It’s a cultural gap the Swedish authors of a new cookbook, “Fika: The Art of the Swedish Coffee Break” ($18, Ten Speed Press), are hoping to bridge.

headline: Review: Judith Miller’s ‘The Story: A Reporter’s Journey’
text: In late 2002 and through 2003, Judith Miller, an investigative reporter at The New York Times, wrote a series of articles about the presumed presence of chemical and biological weapons and possible nuclear matériel in Iraq. Critics thought the articles too bellicose and in lock step with the George W. Bush administration’s march to war. They all included careful qualifiers, but their overwhelming message was that Saddam Hussein posed a threat.

headline: Michael Bloomberg, Mayor of London?

text: NEWARK — Schools, sports arenas and apartment buildings have sprouted in recent years in this troubled city as part of efforts to revitalize it. Now, it’s kale’s turn to take root in a most unusual spot.

headline: Russian Nuclear Submarine Catches Fire During Repairs
text: MOSCOW — A Russian nuclear submarine caught fire while undergoing repairs in a dry dock outside the city of Arkhangelsk and smoke billowed from it through the day on Tuesday. But emergency officials told Russian news agencies that the submarine posed no risk of leaking radiation because its nuclear fuel and armaments had been removed before the work began.

headline: Review: Berio to Cage to Mozart at Baryshnikov Arts Center

headline: Review: In ‘About Elly,’ a Middle Class Enjoying Itself Is Engulfed in Change

headline: Museums Begin Returning Artifacts to India in Response to Investigation

headline: Kansas Limits Abortion Method, Opening a New Line of Attack
text: Kansas on Tuesday became the first state to sharply restrict or alter the most common technique used for second-trimester abortions, opening a new, emotionally charged line of attack by anti-abortion forces who hope to take it swiftly to other states.

headline: Another ‘Serial’ Chapter, From Group of Lawyers
text: The story behind the hit podcast “Serial” is not over. The podcast focused on the 1999 death of Hae Min Lee, a Maryland teenager, and the subsequent conviction of her former boyfriend, Adnan Syed, who is serving a life sentence for murder. It became the fastest podcast to reach five million downloads, according to Apple. Starting Monday a group of lawyers and advocates connected to Mr. Syed will debut another podcast, “Undisclosed: The State v. Adnan Syed,” which will “examine and explore the case in greater detail, from an investigatory perspective instead of a narrative one,” according to a statement. “Undisclosed” is being presented by Rabia Chaudry, a lawyer who has been a longtime advocate of Mr. Syed — as “Serial” fans know, she was the one who suggested that Sarah Koenig, the host of “Serial” and a longtime producer for “This American Life,” look into the case — along with two other lawyers, Susan Simpson and Colin Miller. None of them represent Mr. Syed but each has been investigating the case, Ms. Chaudry said in an interview Tuesday. New episodes of “Undisclosed” are to be released every two weeks. The podcast is sponsored by the Adnan Syed Legal Trust, which, according to a page on the crowdfunding site LaunchGood, is dedicated to Mr. Syed’s defense and has raised $93,000. In November the producers of “Serial” said that a second season was coming. In February a Maryland court agreed to hear an appeal from Mr. Syed, who has said that he is not guilty of Ms. Lee’s murder and that he received ineffective legal counsel at trial.

headline: Pakistani Court Orders Ex-C.I.A. Officials Charged Over 2009 Drone Strike
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A Pakistani court on Tuesday ordered criminal charges to be filed against a former C.I.A. station chief and a former C.I.A. lawyer over a 2009 drone strike that killed two people.

headline: Rand Paul and the Empty Box
text: Nate Cohn tells us that Rand Paul can’t win as a libertarian, because there basically aren’t any libertarians. And that’s true. I wish I could say that Rand Paul can’t win because he believes in crank monetary economics, etc. But the truth is that these things matter much less than the fact that not many Americans consider themselves libertarian, and even those who do are deluding themselves.

headline: Video Shows Fatal Police Shooting
text: In video provided to The New York Times, a police officer in North Charleston, S.C., is seen shooting an apparently unarmed man after a scuffle following a traffic stop.

headline: Carried Interest Should Be Disclosed on Tax Forms, and to Private Equity Investors
text: Writing in The Hill, the economist Eileen Appelbaum argues that private equity funds should be required to disclose on the tax return the partnership files for informational purposes the amount of carried interest paid to the general partner. Carried interest is the percentage of an investment fund’s profits — typically 20 percent — paid to the fund’s managers as incentive compensation.

headline: Q. and A.: Cao Fei on Art, Motherhood and Walking the Political ‘Red Line’
text: Cao Fei was still a student at the Guangzhou Academy of Fine Arts in 2000 when she was discovered by the curator Hou Hanru, who introduced her to the international art world. Since then, Ms. Cao, 36, who is best known for her multimedia and video work, has exhibited widely, including at the Venice Biennale, the Serpentine Galleries in London, and the Guggenheim Museum and Museum of Modern Art in New York. She was a finalist for the Hugo Boss Prize in 2010 and won the 2006 Chinese Contemporary Art Award in the best young artist category.

headline: Funeral Masses Held for 2 Killed in East Village Explosion
text: They were four years apart, but death came for them in the same instant: in an explosion in the East Village on March 26, engulfing a block in smoke and destroying three buildings on Second Avenue. Moises Ismael Locón Yac, 27, was busing tables in the midafternoon lull at Sushi Park, a restaurant on the first floor of 121 Second Avenue. headline: Ralph Sharon, Jazz Pianist Who Accompanied Tony Bennett, Dies at 91
text: Ralph Sharon, Tony Bennett’s longtime accompanist, who in the early 1960s persuaded Mr. Bennett to sing a song originally written for a Wagnerian contralto — about the fond intersection of a large muscle in the chest with a Northern California city — and in so doing created a Grammy-winning standard, died on March 31 at his home in Boulder, Colo. headline: Signs of Trouble Before New Jersey Centenarian Killed Wife With Ax and Took His Own Life
text: ELMWOOD PARK, N.J. — Three months ago, Rosalia Juskin dialed 911 from behind a locked basement door. She said her husband, Michael, 100, was ignoring her pleas, so she asked the police for help opening the door. When they arrived, Ms. Juskin, 88, described the episode as an accident.

headline: Director of Voice of America Is Planning to Step Down

headline: Massachusetts: Boston Marathon Bombing Jury Continues Talks
text: A federal jury on Tuesday began deliberations in the case of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, 21, who faces 30 federal charges for his role in the deadly bombing at the 2013 Boston Marathon. Mr. Tsarnaev has pleaded not guilty to the charges, 17 of which carry the death penalty, even though his lawyers have admitted in court that he and his older brother, Tamerlan, set off the bombs and, several days later, led police officers on a fiery chase in which the older brother was killed. If Mr. Tsarnaev is convicted on any of the capital charges, as is expected, there will be a second phase of the trial to determine his sentence. The jurors deliberated all day Tuesday and passed two notes with questions to the court; deliberations are set to resume on Wednesday.

headline: Pearl River, Chinese Emporium in Manhattan, Will Close at Year-End
