text: James Best, who played the oafish sheriff Rosco P. Coltrane on the hit television comedy “The Dukes of Hazzard,” died on Monday near his home in Hickory, N.C. He was 88.

headline: More South Sudanese Seek Shelter at U.N. Bases
text: In a sign of worsening problems in South Sudan, convulsed by civil war and intensifying hunger for more than a year, the United Nations said Tuesday that an increasing number of displaced South Sudanese are seeking shelter and protection at its peacekeeping outposts.

headline: ‘American Epic’ TV Series Examines 1920s Recordings
text: The 1920s are an almost mythical time for the American recording industry, when record labels scoured the map and recorded a huge variety of folk, blues, country and ethnic songs by now-legendary acts like the Carter Family. But who were the people involved, and how did the technology work?

headline: Mexico: Gunmen Kill 15 Police Officers
text: Gunmen ambushed a Jalisco State police convoy, killing 15 officers in one of the deadliest attacks on security forces in eight years of the drug war, state officials said Tuesday. The convoy was attacked as the police units were traveling through the remote western mountains of Jalisco toward Guadalajara. The gunmen are believed to belong to a powerful gang called the New Generation Jalisco Cartel, Jalisco’s security commissioner, Alejandro Solorio Aréchiga, said Tuesday in a radio interview. A man suspected of being one of the gang’s leaders, Heriberto Acevedo Cárdenas, was killed in a shootout with security forces on March 23. Four days earlier, 11 people were killed when a federal police convoy was attacked in Jalisco.

headline: At Masters, Tiger Woods Savors Sharing the Augusta Experience
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — As he makes his 20th appearance at the Masters this week, Tiger Woods has begun to recognize which tournaments have been landmark moments in his life.

headline: Stan Freberg, Madcap Adman and Satirist, Dies at 88
text: Stan Freberg, a humorist whose sprawling imagination fueled a multifaceted career that included pretty much inventing the idea of using satire in commercials, died on Tuesday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 88.

headline: Tiger Woods on His Return to Competition
text: The golfer spoke on Tuesday before the Masters tournament, saying he was happy to again be playing at the highest level.

headline: With Details of Iran Deal Still in Flux, White House Opens Sales Effort
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama has compared the preliminary accord on limiting Iran’s nuclear program to signing a contract to buy a house, emphasizing that the deal is not done until it closes. But a more accurate analogy might be that the administration bought a house under construction and is still haggling over where the windows and doors should go.

headline: Israel’s Unworkable Demands on Iran
text: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has gone into overdrive against a nuclear agreement with Iran. On Monday, his government made new demands that it claimed would ensure a better deal than the preliminary one that Iran, President Obama and other leaders of major powers announced last week. The new demands are unrealistic and, if pursued, would not mean a better deal but no deal at all.

headline: Rahm Emanuel Wins Runoff Election to Secure 2nd Term as Chicago Mayor
text: CHICAGO — Mayor Rahm Emanuel, the former White House chief of staff whose cutting personality and centrist policies earned him the nickname “Mayor 1 Percent” among his critics, was re-elected mayor of Chicago on Tuesday, surviving a challenge from Jesus G. Garcia, a county commissioner who was seeking to become the city’s first Latino mayor.

headline: ‘New Girl’ Star Lamorne Morris on Writing This Week’s Story Line About Race and the Police
text: The Fox comedy “New Girl” isn’t known for its commentary on world affairs — in fact, its stories are largely confined to the apartment its four main characters share. But on Tuesday’s episode, “Par 5,” the plot took an unexpected dive into a conversation about race relations.

headline: Study Warns of Diet Supplement Dangers Kept Quiet by F.D.A.
text: Popular weight-loss and workout supplements on sale in hundreds of vitamin shops across the nation contain a chemical nearly identical to amphetamine, the powerful stimulant, and pose dangers to the health of those who take them, according to a new study. The Canadian health authorities in December called the chemical, BMPEA, “a serious health risk,” and pulled supplements that contain it from store shelves.

headline: Golfing Analyst Knows the Thrill and Agony of Wisconsin’s Season
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Across the street from the hotel where the Wisconsin men’s basketball team was staying, Andy North stood next to his wife, Sue, staring blankly into the distance. It was the same look he had 70 minutes earlier while shoulder to shoulder with Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers in the Badgers’ section at Lucas Oil Stadium.

headline: Jenrry Mejia’s Arm Injury Highlights Sore Spot for Mets’ Staff
text: WASHINGTON — Last year, as the Mets converted the right-handed starter Jenrry Mejia to a reliever, he would become anxious about not having a set schedule, about not knowing exactly when he would throw or enter games. He feared he would get hurt — again.

headline: Review: ‘Cry, Trojans!’ Is the Wooster Group’s Take on ‘Troilus and Cressida’
text: There’s smoke rising from the tepee that occupies upstage-center at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn. But as hard as you may look, you won’t find the fire — dramatic, emotional or intellectual — in “Cry, Trojans!,” the befuddled and befuddling work in which the mighty Wooster Group lays siege to Shakespeare’s “Troilus and Cressida.”

headline: Review: ‘Hand to God’ Features a Foul-Talking Puppet
text: Stand down, Inspector Javert, vengeful foe of bread-snatchers. A more formidable villain now stalks the Broadway boards, one who makes you seem about as frightening as a French pastry. His name, Tyrone, is not the scariest handle, but he’s as ruthless as any dedicated evildoer, with a spectacularly foul mouth and a thirst for young flesh.

headline: Sound of an Air Kiss
text: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — I’m torn about my feelings for this puzzle theme. On the one hand, I’m an animal lover and am therefore anti-TRAP. On the other hand, I’m also an inveterate New Yorker, and can see the utility of having someone develop a TOURIST TRAP, especially in the summer months, when it is apparently tourist mating season and they seem to multiply like rabbits. [Ha ha! She’s just kidding. Please don’t sue us. — Ed.] [Fine. What if we just lure them into nice, air-conditioned movie theaters, so they stop walking the wrong way down the sidewalk? — D.A.]

headline: New Criticism After New Jersey Posts Text of Exxon Settlement
text: Environmental groups and some New Jersey lawmakers issued new criticism on Tuesday of the state’s proposed $225 million pollution settlement with Exxon Mobil Corporation, one day after the state made the text of the deal public.

headline: A Removed Snowden Sculpture Inspires a Hologram in Its Place
text: Having presided briefly over Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn on Monday morning atop a column, a 100-pound bust of Edward J. Snowden was shrouded by parks workers, removed  and stashed in a city storage facility somewhere.

headline: Long an Unfinished Puzzle, the Nets Find the Missing Pieces
text: The Nets were fresh off their 11th victory in their past 14 games, and their locker room at Barclays Center on Monday night was just a few notches short of festive. Bojan Bogdanovic fielded questions about the team’s strong bench play. Brook Lopez reminisced about the team’s defunct mascot, BrooklyKnight, and his old pals, Sly Fox and Mini Sly.

headline: UConn’s Win Isn’t Pretty, but Title Is a Perfect 10th for Geno Auriemma
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Connecticut’s third straight N.C.A.A. women’s basketball championship was impassioned, not pretty. But in the end, it was perfect.

headline: Judge Cites Prison Guard’s Letter in Granting New Trial in Death of Nashville Inmate
text: A federal judge in Tennessee has granted a new civil trial in a lawsuit over the 2010 death of an inmate at a prison in Nashville, citing the emergence of new evidence.

headline: More Teens Using Long-Term Contraception
text: The use of long-acting, reversible birth control like intrauterine devices and implants has risen sharply among teenagers in the last decade, new federal data show. Researchers from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention studied the use of such contraceptives at clinics that receive federal money under the Title X program, which focuses on low-income adults and teenagers. About eight million young women ages 15 to 19 sought birth control at the clinics from 2005 to 2013. At the beginning of the study period, just 0.4 percent, or about 4,000, were using long-term birth control. By 2013, the researchers reported, that had risen to 7 percent, or about 40,000 teenagers. Federal officials say that although long-acting birth control is by far the most effective method, its use among women over all still lags, and they are encouraging providers to take steps to increase the numbers.

headline: Lawsuit Challenges U.S.D.A. Rule Change on Organic Farming
text: A coalition of grocers, seed growers and consumer and environmental advocates filed suit on Tuesday against the Department of Agriculture over a change it made to the process used to determine which substances may be used in organic farming.

headline: Tumblr 497 — 505
text: Tumblr 497 — 505

headline: ‘Justified’ Recap: Then I Have Already Won
text: Season 6, Episode 12: “Collateral”

headline: No Charges for Officer Who Killed Pace University Student in 2010
text: The Justice Department will not bring civil rights charges against a white police officer who fatally shot a black Pace University football player outside a Westchester County bar in 2010, the United States attorney in Manhattan announced on Tuesday.

headline: As Rangers Return to Playoffs, Devils Again Exit Early
text: NEWARK — The Rangers and the Islanders are gearing up for the playoffs again. The Rangers, who clinched the Presidents’ Trophy for the best regular-season record on Tuesday, are intent on defending their crown as Eastern Conference champions. The Islanders are nearing their second postseason trip in three seasons.

headline: Ferguson Elects 2 Blacks to City Council, but Rejects Activist Candidates
text: FERGUSON, Mo. — In the first municipal election here since a black teenager was shot to death by a white police officer last year, voters elected two black candidates to the City Council on Tuesday, increasing the number of African-Americans on the governing body to three.

headline: Can I Hire Someone to Write My Résumé and Cover Letter?
text: The ethicists answer reader questions about job applications and whether hospitals should admit to making fatal mistakes.

headline: SummerStage Expands Its Schedule, Beginning With a Concert by Tedeschi Trucks Band
text: SummerStage, the annual free concert series organized by the City Parks Foundation, will celebrate its 30th season this year with an expanded schedule, hosting more than 140 music, film, dance and theater events across the city’s parks from May through October.

headline: Visually Arresting Graphic Rugs That Value Asymmetry (So as Not to Compete With God)
text: The art director Alex Proba (of StudioProba, A Poster A Day and Kickstarter) and the rug and textile designer Aelfie Oudghiri (of Aelfie) are two of a kind — both create colorful, arrestingly graphic work; originally studied to be doctors in Europe; and are pillars of the collab-happy Brooklyn design community. And so one thing led to another, and a new series of limited-edition rugs and other decorative items, debuting Monday at Shop Cooper Hewitt, was born. The five rug styles ($1,675 each) and three pillow designs ($105 each), hand-dyed and -loomed in the Uttar Pradesh region of northern India, take cues from Kurdish weaving motifs and early Internet graphics, and feature hand-knotting techniques that make them look, Proba says, “more 3D than they actually are.” Many are asymmetrical, like the designs in Proba’s poster series: “That’s one of the reasons I was excited about her work, because you have to work at looking at it,” Oudghiri explains. “That’s a huge tenet of rug weaving; you keep things asymmetrical as a form of humility because you don’t want to compete with God.” And for those who might be, as Proba puts it, “afraid to commit” to the high-impact textiles, the shop will also be selling posters ($155) of the original flat designs.

headline: Iris van Herpen’s Intelligent Design
text: At a time when Silicon Valley is trying (and failing) to be fashionable, the Dutch designer is taking a different route — borrowing the discoveries of scientists, architects and even the military to create artistic pieces of great beauty.

headline: Giving Out Private Data for Discount in Insurance
text: Andrew Thomas’s life insurer knows exactly when he arrives at his local gym. The company is notified when he swipes his membership card, and 30 minutes later, it checks that he is still there, tracking his location through his smartphone.

headline: Wisconsin Re-elects Liberal Judge, but Opens Door for Conservative Chief Justice
text: In a result befitting politically polarized Wisconsin, voters on Tuesday re-elected a State Supreme Court justice seen as liberal, but passed a constitutional amendment that will most likely lead to the installation of a conservative chief justice.

headline: How Chicagoans Voted and Why
text: An exit poll was conducted by Edison Research in 30 randomly selected Chicago electoral precincts. There were no supplemental interviews with early or absentee voters.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The exit poll was based on questionnaires completed by 1,497 voters on Tuesday as they left polling places throughout Chicago.

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
text: 8 P.M. (13, 49) ANIMAL HOMES In this three-part “Nature” special, the ecologist Chris Morgan evaluates and deconstructs various animal dwellings, from their materials and aesthetics to their neighborhoods and locations — and tries to build a few himself. He begins with the nest, works of art constructed — with just a beak — from fur, grasses, twigs, bones and spider silk as well as colorful twine, bits of wire and even plastic bags. After examining nests at the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History, Mr. Morgan tours Connecticut, visiting ospreys in Greenwich and salt marsh sparrows in Madison, before returning to New Haven, where he subjects his own nest to a stress test. (A blueprint is above.)

headline: Duke Welcomes Home Its Latest Champions
text: DURHAM, N.C. — About halfway through the 11-mile drive along Route 15-501 from Chapel Hill to Durham stands a green sign that welcomes drivers to Durham, or as it says, “the city of champions.” The sign, which features the Duke logo, bears reminders of national championships the Blue Devils have won, including the 2010 men’s basketball title.

headline: A Writer Whose Fan Mail Came From the Famous
text: Herbert Warren Wind turned some of the most iconic sportsmen and entertainers of the 20th century into writers, and many of their letters to him are at the Yale University Library.

headline: Corrections: April 8, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “When you’re wrong, you’re wrong. And if you make a bad decision, don’t care if you’re behind the shield or just a citizen on the street, you have to live by that decision.”

headline: Economic Disparity Is Seen in California Driver’s License Suspensions
text: Drivers in California who are unable to pay traffic fines for minor infractions are frequently having their licenses suspended by traffic courts — a policy that has had a disproportionate impact on poor and working-class people, according to a study released Wednesday.

headline: Elvis Is Everywhere
text: SNEAK PEEK: This week Lens is featuring a selection of photographers attending the New York Portfolio Review.

headline: Royal Dutch Shell to Buy BG Group for Nearly $70 Billion
text: LONDON — Energy companies have spent months in a state of strategic paralysis, wary of making big moves with oil prices plunging.

headline: U.S. Coal Leasing Program
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Lawyer’s Personal Beliefs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Better Health Coverage
text: To the Editor:

headline: A View From Monsanto on Herbicide Safety
text: To the Editor:

headline: McDonald’s Turns ‘Progressive’
text: You could almost feel sorry for McDonald’s. That’s an odd sentiment when you consider that the company’s revenues in 2014 were $27.4 billion and its stock price makes it worth something like $92 billion. It’s among the world’s most valuable brands and has three times the United States market share of Subway, its nearest competitor.

headline: Don’t Let Statistics Ruin Baseball
text: ONE of the charms of baseball, which started up again this week, is the exhilarating departure it offers from the noisy bustle of daily life. Come early for batting practice, have a scoring book ready to capture the game in pencil and lean back to take in the crisp musicality of a ball hit on the screws or track the near-perfect route a fleet outfielder takes to run down a fly ball in the gap. Baseball is a language unto itself, a language to be enjoyed and understood by any fan — at least until the talk turns to Babip, FIP and WAR.

headline: Successful Investing for the Long Haul
text: For more than a month now, the White House has been vetting a proposal by the Labor Department that would require financial advisers to act solely in the interests of clients when giving advice on retirement accounts.

headline: The California Drought: How to Adapt
Al Qaeda Is Capitalizing on Yemen’s Disorder, U.S. Warns
text: TOKYO — The new American defense secretary acknowledged Wednesday that Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Yemen had exploited the tumult partly created by the Saudi-led airstrikes there to capture territory, in what has become a broad expansion by the Sunni extremist group.

headline: Ivy League Trailblazers
text: What is it like to be the first member of your family to go to college? First-generation college students must learn to deal with the privilege and the challenges.

headline: To Become a Bridge
text: In 2013, Travis Reginal wrote an essay in Education Life about making his way from Jackson, Miss., to Yale, as a first-generation student. In his admissions essay, he had examined his love of writing poetry. He updates his journey, in his favorite format.

headline: First-Generation Students Unite
text: Ana Barros grew up in a two-family house built by Habitat for Humanity, hard by the boarded-up buildings and vacant lots of Newark. Neither parent attended college, but she was a star student. With a 2200 on her SATs, she expected to fit in at Harvard.

headline: Chicago Is Waiting to See if Runoff Battle Has Humbled Rahm Emanuel
text: CHICAGO — By some measure, everything ended just as it had begun. After an unexpected and unprecedented runoff election in the nation’s third-largest city, Chicago’s brash mayor, Rahm Emanuel, was still Chicago’s mayor.

headline: Obama Takes His Hopes for Cuba to Summit Meeting
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s push for a historic opening with Cuba faces its first major test this week as he travels to a summit meeting in Latin America, where he hopes to highlight momentum toward ending a half-century of isolation from the island nation.

headline: A Golf Writer’s Term, Forever: Amen
text: The whorl of wind will be easier to negotiate than the swirl of memories this week when Ben Crenshaw plays the 11th, 12th and 13th holes at the Masters for the final time in his fabled career.

headline: A Section of the Berlin Wall Will Again Stand in Manhattan
text: A generation ago, in Berlin, citizens attacked the wall with sledgehammers. Today, in a New Jersey warehouse, conservators are reattaching flakes of paint to the wall with daubs of adhesive so tiny they must be applied by syringe.

headline: For Eager Cubans, Big Opening in U.S. Relations Is More Like a Crack
text: HAVANA — With a castoff pizza oven churning out pies, Marialena Perez aspires to be the Domino’s of Havana one day, with lofty dreams of a chain of stores, maybe even a branch in the United States.

headline: T. C. Boyle’s ‘The Harder They Come’
text: “The Harder They Come,” T. C. Boyle’s 15th novel, takes on the paranoia of the far-right sovereign citizen movement and off-the-grid/mountain-man survivalism, as well as more mainstream American notions of independence. This could easily have been an opportunity for a writer of Boyle’s comic gifts to go full-tilt satirical, but Boyle takes a darker and more ­restrained approach. He has written a compelling, complex and intimate novel about three particular people in a specific time and place, a novel that tells us something unnerving about certain precincts of the American Now.

headline: ‘The Children’s Crusade,’ by Ann Packer
text: How do we become who we are? There are many ways of approaching this slipperiest of questions, from the experimental rigor of cognitive neuroscience to the teasing excavations of psychoanalysis. It is, of course, natural territory for the novel, and though Ann Packer’s “The Children’s Crusade” follows one nuclear family, its scope is broadened by its attempts at an answer.

headline: Mothers’ Exercise May Lower Heart Risks in Newborns
text: Exercise in mice substantially lessens the risk that a pregnant mother-to-be will give birth to offspring with serious heart defects, according to a new study that could have implications for women who are or hope to become pregnant.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: For Male Politicians, Dieting Is a Campaign Issue
text: Is fat really an electoral issue?

headline: New York Today: Who’s That Tapping?
text: Good morning on this blustering Wednesday.

headline: Palestinian Stabs 2 Israeli Soldiers and Is Killed
text: JERUSALEM — A Palestinian man stabbed two Israeli soldiers in the West Bank on Wednesday, seriously injuring one and lightly wounding the other, before being shot to death by security forces at the scene, according to the Israeli military.

headline: Open Sesame
text: We sat eating dinner on a dark, cold night, talking soberly about what could possibly be in season when the soil had been frozen for so many months. My companion looked up in sudden knowledge.

headline: Restaurant Report: Museum of Spirits in Stockholm
text: For seven years Petter Nilsson ran one of the most celebrated creative neo-bistros in Paris, La Gazzetta, tucked behind the Gare de Lyon. This Swedish expat brought “the country to the city,” as he put it recently, cooking in clay and hay before everyone else did, celebrating vegetables over proteins before that became a global trend, too. In late 2013, after more than a decade in France, he returned to Sweden.

headline: A Warm Welcome in the Caucasus Mountains
text: The clotheslines that extended from balconies in Stepanakert showed an extraordinary degree of precision, if not obsession. In this city of 50,000, families had ordered the clothes from smallest to biggest: pink toddler socks gave way to slightly larger red and black ones for children and adults, then underwear (sorted by color), and finally a sequence of ever-larger shirts, hung upside down with sleeves outstretched, like an army of invisible superheroes swooping down from the sky.

headline: Overruling My Father
text: When it came to offering medical interventions to severely ill patients with no hope of recovery, my father had a fiercely strong opinion: They were inappropriate. For decades as an infectious diseases specialist, he had been asked to treat infections in dying patients. Whenever possible, he said no.

headline: Can I Hire Someone to Write My Résumé and Cover Letter?
text: I’m looking for a new job in the nonprofit sector and am considering using a résumé service to write my résumé and cover letter. Part of me feels morally conflicted about this process. Is it fair to have someone else write the two materials that show the quality of my writing skills to my future employer? NAME WITHHELD, WASHINGTON

headline: Will Infighting Help the Republicans in 2016?
text: For the first time in recent memory, key members of the corporate establishment, including businesses with close ties to the Republican Party, have publicly defied social conservatives in nationally publicized confrontations.

headline: Hotel Review: Mitsui Garden Hotel Osaka Premier
text: From 11,500 Japanese yen (or $96 at 119 yen to the dollar).

headline: Toni Morrison: ‘I Know How to Write Forever’
text: The Nobel laureate Toni Morrison, known for “Song of Solomon” and “Beloved,” died at 88. We interviewed her in 2015. Watch as she reads from her novel, “God Help the Child.”

headline: The Radical Vision of Toni Morrison
text: Not too long ago, Toni Morrison sat in the small kitchen attached to the studio where she was recording the audiobook for her newest novel, “God Help the Child,” telling a roomful of strangers stories that I will never forget. The studio, a small, refurbished barn in Katonah, N.Y., was more than a hundred years old, but only a few rustic touches remained, like a sliding barn door and knotty pine floors. A solid kitchen table had been laid with fresh fruits, muffins and tins of jam. Beams of sunlight reflected off the blindingly white snow outside the glass window. A young woman from Random House kept mentioning her sunglasses, how it was bright enough to wear them inside. Everyone giggled at her nervous chatter, but they seemed to be mostly laughing at her brave attempt to make small talk in the presence of Toni Morrison.

headline: Today in Politics: Obama’s Trip to Panama Includes a Cuban Subplot
text: Good Wednesday morning from Washington, where a short-lived power failure briefly shut down the government. Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago gets to keep his job after a runoff, while Secretary of State John Kerry will meet with Jewish leaders to try and ease their concerns over a possible nuclear agreement with Iran. Representative Charles B. Rangel has recipe suggestions, and Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky hit the ground running after announcing his candidacy. President Obama begins a trip to Panama where he may or may not have a much-watched meeting with President Raúl Castro of Cuba.

headline: ‘The Bull Rider’
text: Growing up in the Netherlands, I was fascinated by the iconic Western movie cowboys, who lived an understated yet high-stakes existence against a spartan, other-worldly backdrop. Sure, much of this was a Hollywood fantasy, but the West truly was once the land of cowboys and Indians. Things changed pretty quickly. Instead of sprawling ranches dotted with quiet loner types, the landscape is now largely populated by homogeneous residential communities and big-box retailers.

headline: The Bull Rider
text: This short documentary profiles the champion bull rider Gary Leffew, whose insights on rodeos apply far beyond the sport.

headline: Private Profit, Public Gain?
text: Can private investors play a role in modernizing our infrastructure?

headline: Morning Agenda: Shell to Buy BG Group for Nearly $70 Billion
text: SHELL TO BUY BG GROUP FOR NEARLY $70 BILLION | Royal Dutch Shell said Wednesday that it had agreed to buy BG Group for nearly $70 billion,  Stanley Reed and Michael J. de la Merced write in DealBook. Shell said that it would pay for the acquisition with a mix of cash and stock and that its offer represented a 50 percent premium to BG’s closing share price on Tuesday.

headline: Rescue Mission in Yemen Proves to Be Boon for Chinese Military’s Image
text: Chinese military experts are engaging in a bit of exuberant backslapping over the naval evacuation not just of more than 600 Chinese citizens in Yemen, but of hundreds of other foreigners. It was the first time China had deployed warships to carry out such an evacuation, and the fact that so many people from other countries were welcomed on board and ferried to safety was seen as polishing the country’s image as a helpful hand in an international crisis.

headline: Our Push for ‘Passion,’ and Why It Harms Kids
text: Standing on the sidelines of my son’s soccer game I chatted with the younger sibling of one of his teammates. “I don’t really have a passion like my brother yet,” he explained, glancing over at the field. “But my parents are helping me look for one.” I waited for the note of irony that never came.

headline: Peter Sarsgaard as Hamlet at Classic Stage
text: Shakespeare wrote many great roles, but few, if any, rival Hamlet and King Lear in terms of complexity (and potential glory). Both roles offer meaty challenges for actors, and it is practically a rite of passage to assay at least one of them in the course of a career that includes the classics.

headline: Apple Watch Review: Bliss, but Only After a Steep Learning Curve
text: It took three days — three long, often confusing and frustrating days — for me to fall for the Apple Watch. But once I fell, I fell hard.

headline: Dear Diary: My Week Wearing an Apple Watch
text: I picked up my Apple Watch last Wednesday at Apple headquarters in Cupertino, Calif. After interviewing some of the designers and engineers who worked on the device, I was given a guided tour of the watch, similar to what customers will receive when they buy one at an Apple Store.

headline: Can the Apple Watch Free Us From Phones?
text: The technology columnist Farhad Manjoo asks whether the Apple Watch’s new “taptic engine” will give us an alternative to constantly checking our phones.

headline: Labco, French Medical Diagnostics Firm, Files for I.P.O.
text: LONDON — Labco, a French medical diagnostics firm, said on Wednesday that it had filed to pursue an initial public offering in Paris in the first half of this year.

headline: Oyster to Sell E-Books Alongside Its Subscription Service
text: The e-book subscription service Oyster is starting its own digital bookstore, taking aim at major retailers like Amazon, Apple and Barnes & Noble as well as rival subscription services.

headline: Daily Report: Apple Watch Bliss Comes With Steep Learning Curve
text: It took three days — three long, often confusing and frustrating days — for him to fall for the Apple Watch. But once he fell, he fell hard, Farhad Manjoo writes.

headline: BB and the Permahawks
text: Ben Bernanke comes down firmly against the idea that concerns about financial instability should lead central banks to raise interest rates even in a depressed economy. Good — and I was especially pleased to see him citing the Swedish example and the Ignoring of Lars Svensson as a case study.

headline: Putin Meets With Alexis Tsipras of Greece, Raising Eyebrows in Europe
text: MOSCOW — With Russia and Greece at odds with Europe, this week’s visit from the Greek prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, “could not have come at a better time,” President Vladimir V. Putin said Wednesday.

headline: Pacers’ Chris Copeland and 2 Women Are Stabbed Outside Manhattan Club
text: A former New York Knicks forward who now plays for the Indiana Pacers was stabbed in the abdomen during an argument early Wednesday outside a club in Manhattan, the authorities said.

headline: Eye to Eye With a Hawk
text: Dear Diary:

headline: 5 Women’s Rights Activists in China Are Being Held Illegally, Lawyers Say
text: BEIJING — Five women’s rights activists are being held illegally in Beijing because the police have failed to ask prosecutors to formally arrest them, the lawyers for three of them said on Wednesday.

headline: C.I.A. Director Says Iran’s Economic Peril Helped Drive Nuclear Deal
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — The director of the Central Intelligence Agency has provided the first public glimpse of American intelligence assessments about why Iran’s leadership agreed to the tentative nuclear accord last week, saying that Iran’s president persuaded its supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, that their country’s economy was “destined to go down” unless he reached an understanding with the West.

headline: Fashion World Mourns Maria Luisa Poumaillou
text: Before there was Colette or Kirna Zabete, before Fivestory or Merci, before most of the other so-called concept stores became shopping destinations from New York to Shanghai, there was Maria Luisa, a boutique on the Rue Cambon in Paris whose concept was simple: buy and showcase “whatever is different and attracts my eye, by talent that is out of the ordinary and by what is long lasting,” its co-founder, Maria Luisa Poumaillou, told The Business of Fashion in 2013.

headline: Sugar Hill, Rich in Culture, and Affordable
text: The section of Upper Manhattan known as Sugar Hill, poised on a bluff overlooking the Harlem Plain and distinguished by graceful rowhouses and elegant apartment buildings, achieved renown in the 1930s and 1940s, when it was home to prominent African-American professionals, political leaders, artists, musicians and writers. The song “Take the ‘A’ Train,” written by Billy Strayhorn and popularized by Duke Ellington, commemorated the neighborhood, where both lived. Nowadays, though, some newcomers say they had not heard the name Sugar Hill before they arrived.

headline: Quotas Not the Best Way to Add and Retain Women for Corporate Boards, Study Finds
text: It has been an age-old question: Are quotas the best way of getting more women on boards and keeping them there?

headline: Slovakia to Sell Stake in Slovak Telecom Through I.P.O.

I attended its meetings and grew increasingly interested in the club’s discussions, as I come from Serbia, a country where democracy was relatively new.

headline: Love and Loss
text: In children’s books, parental love can be a surprisingly hot-potato subject. If a parent’s emotions seem somehow too enormous and complex, a book about endless devotion can end up striking many as unsettling rather than reassuring. Take the latest round of debate over Shel Silverstein’s classic “The Giving Tree.” Is the book’s depiction of all-in maternal self-sacrifice beautiful, or disturbing and patriarchal? Impassioned arguments persist on both sides. That split recalls similar objections to Robert Munsch’s “Love You Forever,” first published in 1986, which features a new mother rocking her baby and singing a little song that ends, “As long as I’m living / my baby you’ll be.” She repeats the song as she snuggles up to her child through his childhood and teenage years, and even when he is a grown man. Some see in the tale a straightforward, reassuring depiction of the boundlessness of a parent’s love. Others think it’s just too smothering and creepy, especially the way the woman crawls into her adult son’s bed.

headline: 1940: Five Red Leaders Arrested in Paris
text: Details of the methods used in tracking down and arresting the ‘‘general staff’’ of the Communist party in north Paris were revealed by the Prefecture of Police in Paris last night [April 7].Four men and a woman, described as the propaganda and organization leaders of the Communist organization, were trapped Friday night while meeting in a café in the rue de Maubeuge, police reported. To obtain conclusive evidence of the exchange of funds earmarked for Communist work and to link the group with the communist International, police allowed the unsuspecting group to discuss its plans at length before making the arrest, the Prefecture said. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 9, 1940

headline: 36 Hours in Antigua, Guatemala
text: Less than an hour away from the concrete sprawl of Guatemala City, Antigua feels like a portal to another century. The nearly 500-year-old city is cradled by three volcanoes and filled with colonial-era mansions, churches and convents, many with orange and yellow facades. In the evening, residents gather in the jacaranda-lined plazas to listen to musicians tapping mallets on marimbas, or wander between lively night spots. Once the capital of this Central American country (before a series of devastating earthquakes forced the colonial government to move to Guatemala City in the late 1700s), Antigua, population 41,000, is a Unesco World Heritage site. Yet in addition to the striking 17th- and 18th-century ruins right in the center of town, the city offers an array of restaurants, boutiques and bars with live music. Visitors can browse the craft markets or sip an espresso at a working coffee farm, while those with a more adventurous streak can hike up one of the looming volcanoes, or strap on a helmet, lock in a carabiner and hurtle through the rain forest on a zip wire.

headline: In South Carolina, Shot in the Back as He Ran
text: I am truly weary, deep in my bones, of writing these columns about the killings of unarmed people of color by the police. Indeed, you may be weary of reading them. Still, our weariness is but a dim shadow that falls near the darkness of despair that a family is thrust into when a child or parent or sibling is lost, and that family must wonder if the use of deadly force was appropriate and whether justice will be served.

It’s one in a recent spate of horror movies playing out on computer screens that might be likened to the found-footage horror genre that “The Blair Witch Project” started in 1999. But now the frights rely on an active Skype account and a strong Wi-Fi signal.

headline: Behind the Poster: ‘Switzerland’
text: In Joanna Murray-Smith’s play “Switzerland,” the American writer Patricia Highsmith (played by Laura Linney) is near the end of her life. She’s living in self-imposed exile in the Locarno district of Switzerland, having already achieved acclaim for her novels “Strangers on a Train” and “The Talented Mr. Ripley.” One day an assistant (Seth Numrich) from the office of her New York publisher shows up at her front door and tries to persuade her to write another Ripley book. She being an eccentric novelist obsessed by tales of sociopaths and murder, and he being a stranger with possibly shady intentions, tension builds fast in the weapon-filled room where the show is set.

headline: In Paris, Revisiting the ‘Aesthetic Shock’ of Antonioni
text: “Antonioni Was Here,” announces a Julian Schnabel painting at the entrance of the exhibition “Antonioni: Aux Origines du Pop,” which runs tomorrow through July 19 at La Cinémathèque Française. Indeed, the iconic filmmaker left an indelible mark. “He was an explorer, an inventor, a man in perpetual inquiétude regarding the cinematographic form,” remarks Serge Toubiana, the director of the Cinémathèque, which is also hosting a complete filmic retrospective running through May 31. Toubiana cites the sense of “narrative shock, aesthetic shock” Antonioni brought to cinema — whether featuring a fashion photographer modeled on David Bailey in the swinging London of “Blow Up” or casting the exquisite Monica Vitti in a trio of films (“L’Avventura,” “La Notte,” “L’Eclisse”) about indefinable human malaise. Although never quite celebrated or completely understood in his native Italy, he won accolades internationally, some of which are displayed in the exhibition, including a Palme d’Or from 1967, and an honorary Oscar from 1995 (represented by a mislabeled replica, as the original was stolen during a burglary).

Recorded in São Paulo, this appealing album is her first made in Brazil since moving to the States, though seven cuts include strings that were recorded in London. A mixture of aural dreaminess and percussive drive gives Ms. Elias’s natural friskiness a soft focus. It might be described as make-out music with a beat.

headline: Review: Stephen Petronio’s ‘Bloodlines’
text: The history of the leading figures of American modern dance can sound like lines from the Book of Genesis. Senior choreographers nurtured company dancers who in due course became choreographers in their own right. To adapt the King James Version, Ruth St. Denis and Ted Shawn begat Doris Humphrey and Martha Graham; Humphrey begat José Limón while Graham begat Merce Cunningham and Paul Taylor; Mr. Taylor begat Twyla Tharp. ...

headline: How Amal Clooney Took New York
text: At 10:30 a.m. on Monday, Amal Clooney walked into Classroom 103 in William and June Warren Hall at Columbia Law School. The human rights lawyer and wife of the actor George Clooney was dressed in a cream textured coat and floral Oscar de la Renta slingbacks and carried a tangerine bag the size of a large toaster.

headline: ‘International Pop’
text: A look at the exhibition opening on Saturday at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis.

headline: When the World Went Pop
text: MINNEAPOLIS — For art lovers, and certainly for the collectors now paying tens of millions of dollars per painting at auction, Pop art and its trademark images — Marilyns, Ben-Day dots, Coca-Cola bottles, lipsticked lips — have become 20th century classicism, as canonical as Cubism and as appealing as candy.

headline: Portraits of People and Paper
text: Fascinated by a classmate’s braid, Patricia Voulgaris started doing pictures that were a mix of body parts, folded paper and collage.

headline: Review: In ‘Daredevil,’ a Superhero Is Sightless but Not Blind to Crime
text: I admit the possibility that I have unfair expectations for the new Netflix series “Marvel’s Daredevil,” 13 episodes of which will be available to stream on Friday.

headline: Outerwear for Spring, Dresses for an Evolving Day and More Style News
text: Semitransparent raincoats, effortless designs, an eyewear line from Acne and a crocheted bag.

headline: In China, a Climate of Mistrust in Medicine
text: Chinese patients are fed up with their doctors, and doctors are fed up with their patients.

headline: At the New Whitney Museum, the Party Has Already Begun
text: Scaffolding was everywhere, the art had not fully been hung, and opening night was a month away. But that didn’t stop more than 100 guests, including artists, socialites and fashion designers, from walking past construction materials stacked under blankets and orange cones to attend a private “preopening” dinner at the Whitney Museum of American Art last Thursday.

headline: On Waxahatchee’s ‘Ivy Tripp,’ Katie Crutchfield Sings of Emotional Debris
text: Not all wounds scab. Sometimes they remain red, raw, gaping. Sometimes, after a while, the wound is the thing. If it healed, it wouldn’t feel real.

headline: Courtney Love, Devendra Banhart, Amy Poehler and More Celebrate Allen Ginsberg’s ‘Howl’ in L.A.
text: As the man who produced one of Allen Ginsberg’s last recorded works — and who virtually invented the tribute album as standalone art form — the record producer (and current music producer of “Saturday Night Live”) Hal Willner was truly the only person who could have put together last night’s celebration of the Beat poet’s masterpiece, “Howl,” at the Ace in Downtown Los Angeles. Willner assembled a glittering line-up for the event, a three-hour-plus evening of “music, verse and funny people” to benefit the David Lynch Foundation: those featured included Nick Cave (the first person he called), Beth Orton and her husband Sam Amidon, Courtney Love, Macy Gray, Lucinda Williams, Tim Robbins, Van Dyke Parks and a handful of “SNL” alums. “In the ’60s, this was called a ‘Happening’ — a bunch of people in the same room that you would never see in the same room,” Willner said. “We’re just missing a plate spinner!”

headline: For Manolo Blahnik, a Career-Crowning Award
text: There comes a time in a young man’s life when the parties in Tangiers don’t beckon the way they used to, the young-broke-and-fabulous friends of yore grow older and richer (if no less fabulous), and the accolades come thick and fast — but now they are of the “lifetime achievement” variety.

headline: Clinton and Bush Are Already in Hollywood’s Sights
text: LOS ANGELES — Hillary Clinton should keep an eye on George Clooney: Behind that smile, he is producing a movie satire inspired by the antics of some former Clinton advisers whose wildest war stories might best be forgotten.

headline: International Criminal Court Says ISIS Is Out of Its Jurisdiction
text: PARIS — Fatou Bensouda, chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court, said on Wednesday that her office had received ample reports of “crimes of unspeakable cruelty” by the extremists of the Islamic State but that the court had no jurisdiction over Iraq and Syria where the acts occurred or over the group’s leaders.

headline: A.I.G. Receives Approval From F.A.A. to Use Drones
text: The American International Group said on Wednesday that the Federal Aviation Administration had approved its request to use drones to conduct inspections.

headline: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York
text: On Thursday, L.K. Bennett will open a Madison Avenue flagship, the British accessible-luxury label’s first free-standing New York City retail space, where you’ll find store exclusives like canvas block heels ($425). At 655 Madison Avenue.

headline: The Walter Scott Murder
text: The horrifying video of a white police officer in North Charleston, S.C., shooting and killing an unarmed black man — while the man is running away — may still come as a shock to many Americans. But this heinous act, which the officer tried to explain away by claiming that he feared for his life, strikes a familiar chord in communities of color all across the United States.

headline: Phone Cameras and Apps Help Speed Calls for Police Reform
text: The video of the fatal shooting of an unarmed black man by a white police officer in South Carolina is seen by some advocates of police reform as evidence of the rising power of technological weapons in their fight.

headline: Want That ‘Game of Thrones’ Glow? Beauty Tips From Natalie Dormer
text: The English actress Natalie Dormer, 33, knows her way around a corset. She has played pivotal roles on “The Tudors” and as the clever Margaery Tyrell on “Game of Thrones,” which is back for Season 5 on Sunday. Ms. Dormer has also had screen roles in “Rush,” “The Hunger Games” series and the coming horror film “Patient Zero.” Born in Reading, England, she has lived in London since she was 18.

headline: Paul Jeffrey, Saxophonist Who Played With Monk and Mingus, Dies at 81
text: Paul Jeffrey, a saxophonist who was a mainstay of the great pianist and composer Thelonious Monk’s last working group and later a prominent jazz educator, died on March 20 at his home in Durham, N.C. He was 81.

headline: Network of ‘Super PACs’ Says That It Has Raised $31 Million for Ted Cruz Bid
text: A network of new “super PACs” said Wednesday that it had raised $31 million to support Senator Ted Cruz’s presidential campaign, a sum that could upend expectations in the race for the Republican nomination and rewrite the political rule book for outside spending.

headline: Clip: ‘Don’t Think I’ve Forgotten’
text: A scene from the documentary about the rock music scene in Cambodia in the 1960s and ’70s.

headline: At Goyard and Valextra, Leather Goods That Are Durable, Versatile — and Invisible
text: Four years into its life span, my Bottega Veneta purse has assumed the shape of a jellyfish. It is so comfortable resting on my shoulder that it registers as less of an accessory than a utensil, even when jammed with small objects.

headline: Amazon Web Services Takes Fuller Aim at Enterprise Computing
text: Competition for the corporate dollar didn’t take long to heat up.

headline: Prosper Marketplace Raises $165 Million in Latest Funding Round
text: SAN FRANCISCO — To keep propelling its growth, Prosper Marketplace is turning to a new round of investors — including several banks that once could be seen as competitors.

headline: Rand Paul Gets the TV Spotlight and Turns It on Interviewers in Testy Encounters
text: NASHUA, N.H. — Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky is spending the week trying to introduce himself to Americans as the sensitive, softer-edged face of the Republican Party. He talks about how helping his grandmother as she lost her sight inspired him to become an eye surgeon — and how on a volunteer mission in Guatemala, he enabled a husband and wife to see each other clearly for the first time in years.

headline: ‘The Adventures of Alice Laselles,’ Story by 10-Year-Old Queen Victoria, to Be Published
text: Queen Victoria was one of the most notable graphomaniacs of the 19th century, penning an estimated 60 million words of diaries and letters over her lifetime.

headline: In the Gritty New York of the ’70s and ’80s, Not Exactly a Model Life
text: Snow was swirling early last month, and Brad Gooch was sipping coffee in his new Chelsea office, a Zen-like studio of pale wood and orderly book-filled shelves.

headline: Playing Nice at the Premiere of ‘Veep’
text: On HBO’s “Veep,” politicos skewer one another with insults, but things were all smiles Monday night when the cast gathered to premiere the show’s fourth season at the SVA Theater in Chelsea.

headline: I.R.S. Shortcut to Tax-Exempt Status Is Under Fire
text: Battered by a scandal over delays in approving groups for tax-exempt status and plagued by a backlog tens of thousands of cases long, the Internal Revenue Service unveiled a strikingly stripped-down online application last year to speed the process.

headline: In the Boston Marathon Bombing, a Verdict, but Few Answers
text: It took more than three months from start to verdict in the Boston Marathon bombing trial. It will most likely take another couple of months for the government and the defense to lay out, respectively, the aggravating and mitigating circumstances, and for the jury to determine whether Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, convicted of all 30 charges on Wednesday, gets the death penalty, or life without parole. The trial has been an astoundingly time-consuming and expensive undertaking, but it has not given the public what it needs and wants most: the fullest possible understanding of what happened.

headline: Italian Artisans’ Revival After Economic Crisis Reflects Resilience of Small Industry
text: PADUA, Italy — High-end printing is an artisans’ job in Italy. For those books, the gluing and the binding of the pages is predominantly done by hand.

headline: John E. Walsh, Who Distilled the Bible, Dies at 87
text: In the beginning, there were 850,000 words. Three years later, John E. Walsh and his team of editors had condensed the Bible by 40 percent, to 510,000.

headline: Obama Calls for End to ‘Conversion’ Therapies for Gay and Transgender Youth
text: WASHINGTON — A 17-year-old transgender youth, Leelah Alcorn, stunned her friends and a vast Internet audience in December when she threw herself in front of a tractor-trailer after writing in an online suicide note that religious therapists had tried to convert her back to being a boy.

headline: 10-Year Treasury Notes
text: High yield in monthly refunding auction.

headline: The Dow Minute by Minute
text: Position of the Dow Jones industrial average at 1-minute intervals.

headline: Wisconsin Chief Justice Files a Lawsuit to Avoid Demotion
text: The liberal-leaning chief justice of the Wisconsin Supreme Court, Shirley S. Abrahamson, filed a federal lawsuit Wednesday seeking to keep her position, a day after voters approved a constitutional amendment likely to result in her demotion.

headline: Kenya Struggles Over Best Response to University Attack
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Opposition leaders demanded Wednesday that Kenya pull its troops out of Somalia as soon as possible and accused the president of trying to emasculate the judiciary, one of Kenya’s few public institutions that are not considered hopelessly corrupt, in the wake of a terrorist attack last week that killed 142 students.

headline: Snapchat Video on the Apple Watch
text: Farhad Manjoo answers users’ questions about the smartwatch.

headline: Council Vote in Ferguson Brings Promise and Pause
text: FERGUSON, Mo. — As he began his legal career as a public defender and then worked for about a decade in private practice, Wesley Bell said he grew frustrated by some of the shortcomings he saw in St. Louis County’s municipal court system. There were judges who would show little leniency when he felt it was deserved. There were defendants making decisions that did not seem to fit their best interests.

headline: Anne-Claude Leflaive, Vintner in Burgundy, Dies at 59
text: Anne-Claude Leflaive, who presided over one of Burgundy’s most storied white wine estates and was a fervent, influential advocate for environmentally sensitive forms of farming, died on Monday at her home in Gilly-lès-Cîteaux, France. She was 59.

headline: In California, Cities Braced to Cut Water by 10 to 35%
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Among the California water officials who were left reeling on Wednesday by the magnitude of the drought-related cutbacks they will have to make was Tom Gray, the general manager of the Fair Oaks Water District, outside Sacramento. He had been prepared to meet a 25 percent reduction in water use in the district, but the 35 percent recommended by the state? That seemed punitive.

headline: Toronto Orchestra Drops Pianist Over Tweets About Ukraine
text: The Toronto Symphony Orchestra abruptly canceled a performance of Rachmaninoff’s Second Piano Concerto on Wednesday after parting ways with a Ukrainian soloist over concerns that her ribald Twitter commentary had crossed the line into “intolerance.”

headline: Attention Turns to Adam Scott as Anchored Putting Begins a Farewell Tour
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The Masters is viewed as the unofficial start to the consequential golf season, which makes this year’s opening round a first among lasts.

headline: Wall St. Is Told to Tighten Digital Security of Partners
text: Wall Street’s oversight of cybersecurity measures at outside firms it does business with remains a work in progress, according to a review by New York State’s top financial regulator.

headline: Fitting Hugs Into Chipping Practice, Tiger Woods Makes a Cheery Return
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — On the sixth hole of the par-3 contest at Augusta National Golf Club, Tiger Woods called his caddie over to confer on strategy. Woods’s regular caddie, Joe LaCava, held back as the golfer’s son, Charlie Axel, wearing a white pint-size coverall, went over and listened. Woods pointed to where he wanted to land his tee shot.

headline: Video of Walter Scott Shooting Reignites Debate on Police Tactics
text: WASHINGTON — Nothing has done more to fuel the national debate over police tactics than the dramatic, sometimes grisly videos: A man gasping “I can’t breathe” through a police chokehold on Staten Island, a 12-year-old boy shot dead in a park in Cleveland. And now, perhaps the starkest video yet, showing a South Carolina police officer shooting a fleeing man in the back.

headline: Pearl River Mart, a Community Lifeline
text: The Chinese department store’s goods, and jobs, have been supporting Chinese immigrants in New York City for 44 years.

headline: In a Surprise, a Top Kerry Adviser Visits Venezuela
text: MEDELLÍN, Colombia — A top adviser to Secretary of State John Kerry was in Venezuela on Wednesday for a surprise meeting as the United States appeared to be seeking to lower the volume in the rancorous relationship between the countries ahead of a regional meeting of heads of state.

headline: At Pearl River, Four Decades of Helping New Arrivals From Asia
text: Every morning, Ming Yi Chen walks down to the basement of Pearl River Mart, the Chinese department store he opened in 1971, and burns incense. Then he walks back to the first floor to light more incense. He breathes in the sandalwood, to him a calming scent. And the day can begin.

headline: Review: In ‘Buzzer,’ a Relationship Strained on the Urban Frontier
text: The effects of urban gentrification have oft been noted. Bodegas transformed into latte dispensaries. Skyrocketing rents that force out longtime neighborhood dwellers. In the skillful play “Buzzer,” by Tracey Scott Wilson, which opened at the Public Theater on Wednesday, the issue is examined from a more intimate point of view, as the relationship between an interracial couple comes under unexpected strain when they move to the urban frontier.

headline: When Service Isn’t Perfect
Review: Vanessa Hudgens in a Squeaky Clean ‘Gigi’ on Broadway
text: A shower of soap bubbles descends upon the audience at the finale of the pretty and pleasant revival of the musical “Gigi” that opened at the Neil Simon Theater on Wednesday. The gentle downpour is meant to evoke the fizz in a glass of Champagne, the delights of which have been celebrated in one of the bounciest songs from the score by Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe.

headline: Veteran CBS Newscaster Bob Schieffer Announces Plan to Retire
text: Bob Schieffer, a television anchor who has worked at CBS for nearly half a century and interviewed every sitting president since Richard Nixon, announced Wednesday night that he was retiring this summer.

headline: Mrs. Obama’s Wing of White House Is Having Its Share of Transition at Key Time
text: WASHINGTON — The West Wing, where President Obama works, is used to the comings-and-goings of staff members — a never-ending churn that spawns speculation. Now it is the East Wing’s turn.

headline: New York Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Parking Rules Suspended on Thursday
text: Because of Holy Thursday (Orthodox), alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: 4th Brooklyn Man Indicted in Plot to Assist ISIS Pleads Not Guilty
text: A fourth Brooklyn man indicted in a plot to aid the Islamic State pleaded not guilty on Wednesday to charges of attempt and conspiracy to support the terrorist group.

headline: Wall Street Fees Wipe Out $2.5 Billion in New York City Pension Gains
text: The Lenape tribe got a better deal on the sale of Manhattan island than New York City’s pension funds have been getting from Wall Street, according to a new analysis by the city comptroller’s office.

headline: ‘Broadchurch’ Season 2, Episode 6 Recap: Deep Breaths
text: With the season finale looming and a third season on the way, it’s re-evaluation time for “Broadchurch,” a show that seemed destined to be a quiet one-off and then unexpectedly achieved tremendous success.

headline: ‘The Americans’ Recap: Paige the Interrogator
text: Season 3, Episode 11: ‘One Day in the Life of Anton Baklanov’

headline: Stabbing of Chris Copeland Hangs Over Games in New York
text: Just two weeks ago, Wednesday night’s schedule of basketball games in New York held little intrigue. The Nets were one of four teams separated by a half-game for the eighth playoff spot in the Eastern Conference but, at 30-40, had showed that they would probably be little more than an appetizer for the top-seeded Atlanta Hawks if they qualified for the postseason.

headline: Eighth-Inning Rally Chases Chill Out of Yankees’ Second Game
text: The pomp and circumstance of opening day had disappeared — along with the capacity crowd and the warm, sunny skies. Yankee Stadium was a vastly different place Wednesday night from what it had been two days earlier, a mostly vacant ballpark that was occupied by the hearty few who braved temperatures that dipped into the 30s and the wind that accompanied them.

headline: Before Loss, Mets Scoff at Talk of Tension
text: WASHINGTON — Mets Manager Terry Collins was surrounded by members of the news media Wednesday, answering a pregame question, when General Manager Sandy Alderson interrupted him from the back of the room.

headline: Kik Interactive Says It’s Weighing Options, Including Selling Itself
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The messaging app Kik Interactive said on Wednesday that it was exploring its strategic options, including a potential sale of itself, as messaging apps continue to grow in popularity.

headline: Inside Raf Simons’s House
text: The designer talks about a new film detailing the bumpy road to his first couture collection for Dior — and the intimate relationship with the women of his atelier.

headline: A Revived New Orleans Market Champions the Local and Brightens Up the Neighborhood
text: Urban European-style food halls packed with grab-and-go artisanal goods and gourmet groceries from specialty purveyors and local vendors are quickly becoming commonplace across America. A majority of these stateside culinary wonderlands are located, of course, in Manhattan: This spring has already welcomed downtown’s Le District, a vast 30,000-square-foot French market near the World Trade Center (commonly dubbed the “French Eataly”) and a new Times Square multi-vendor called City Kitchen. And modern markets of all sizes are set to open between now and early fall, from Seattle (Market Hall) to Portland (Pine Street Market), Denver (Avanti Food and Beverage) to Atlanta (Ponce City Market) and Charleston (The Cigar Factory). Today, New Orleans joins the trend with the reopening of St. Roch Market — in its original building, which was wrecked by Hurricane Katrina nearly a decade ago.

headline: Kaleidoscopic Images of Jewelry, Flowers and Everyday Objects
text: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: Brooklyn Academy of Music Chooses New President
text: The Brooklyn Academy of Music hasn’t had to search for a new president in a very long time. Since the impresario Harvey Lichtenstein stepped down in 1999, Karen Brooks Hopkins has held the position, becoming a fund-raising powerhouse and building the institution into an anchor for a cultural renaissance in Downtown Brooklyn.

headline: David Laventhol, Publisher on Both Coasts, Dies at 81
text: David A. Laventhol, a former publisher of The Los Angeles Times and Newsday who made a journalistically acclaimed but financially doomed attempt to break into the New York City newspaper market by starting New York Newsday in 1985, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
text: 10 P.M. (FX) THE COMEDIANS Billy Crystal is a comedy legend whose best work may be behind him and Josh Gad is a rising star in this new series, which ventures behind the scenes at “The Billy & Josh Show,” a semifictional late-night sketch series. Stephnie Weir plays the long-suffering producer caught between the men, who agree on almost nothing; Matt Oberg is the show’s head writer; and Megan Ferguson is the no-nonsense production assistant. “Semifake Billy and semifake Josh drop references to these real-life résumés constantly in ‘The Comedians’ as they try to one-up each other while battling over the show they’re supposed to be creating together,” Neil Genzlinger wrote in The New York Times. How meta is it? In Episode 4, Mel Brooks “advises his friend Billy not to try to book a big-name guest on ‘The Billy & Josh Show’ because it would distract the audience from the title characters. Mr. Brooks, of course, steals the episode.” In the Season 5 opener of “Louie,” at 10:30, Louie (Louis C.K.) admits in therapy that he’s not sure “how to live a life anymore” and encounters an angry lesbian at a school potluck. “This time around, as Louis C.K. reinvents the classic sitcom in his own elliptical, cerebral style, he seems to be in his absurdist theater phase, or his surrealist short-story phase — Kafka on the Hudson,” Mike Hale wrote in The Times. “His moments of victory, and redemption, come when he’s alone, onstage, working a funny voice and a dumb joke.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “I knew this family would never get justice, and this guy just hands us justice. He handed us justice.”

text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Looking Ahead to Photos of Old Age
text: SNEAK PEEK: This week Lens is featuring a selection of photographers attending the New York Portfolio Review.
