headline: Rand Paul, Paul Rand Quiz
text: Rand Paul for president! Wow, we’re awash with first-term Republican senators who feel the nation needs their services as leader of the most powerful nation on the planet.

headline: Israel and the Iran Deal
Enjoying the Low Life?
text: The United States is the most powerful colossus in the history of the world: Our nuclear warheads could wipe out the globe, our enemies tweet on iPhones, and kids worldwide bop to Beyoncé.

headline: Footing the College Bill
A Shortage of Funds for Food Safety
text: A farsighted food safety law enacted in 2011 has faced obstacles to meaningful enforcement ever since, including delays in issuing necessary rules and a shortage of money. Now, in what may become the latest shameful chapter, Congress seems unwilling to provide enough money to effectively carry out regulations that are about to be issued. The losers, of course, will continue to be consumers, who live with the hazards of an unsafe food supply.

headline: Explaining Jeb Bush’s ‘Hispanic’ Error
text: EVANSTON, Ill. — AFTER the news broke this week that Jeb Bush erroneously listed himself as Hispanic on a 2009 voter registration application, a familiar cycle of accusations and recriminations set in. The Florida Democratic Party suggested that Mr. Bush might have committed a felony. Cynics contended that for Mr. Bush, a former governor and likely Republican presidential candidate who has long courted Hispanic voters, this was a ploy to further his appeal with that demographic.

headline: Gov. Christie’s Bad Deal With Exxon
text: New Jersey has been fighting for years to get the Exxon Mobil Corporation to clean up and pay up after turning more than 1,500 acres of marshes and waterways into toxic wastelands. But, just as a State Superior Court judge was about to rule on the case earlier this year, Gov. Chris Christie’s administration suddenly and unexpectedly agreed to settle with Exxon for 3 cents on the dollar. The agreement, which became public on Monday, allows Exxon to escape with a payment of $225 million, far less than the estimated $8.9 billion the state had originally asked for a decade ago.

headline: Marijuana Taxes Won’t Save State Budgets
text: Colorado’s marijuana tax collections are not as high as expected.

headline: Chinese Police Seeking Charges Against Detained Women’s Activists, Lawyer Says
text: BEIJING — Police officers in Beijing have asked prosecutors to charge five women’s rights activists who have been detained for more than a month with organizing a crowd to disturb public order, lawyers for two of them said on Thursday.

headline: A Struggle to Secure Iraq’s Shared Past, and Perhaps Its Future
text: BAGHDAD — Looted and shuttered after American troops seized Baghdad a dozen years ago, the National Museum of Iraq has officially reopened its doors — a response to Islamic State thugs’ taking jackhammers to ancient treasures in Mosul.

headline: Mocking Mao Backfires for Chinese TV Host
text: Mao Zedong famously said a revolution is not a dinner party. Nor, it seems, is a dinner party in China an occasion to mock Mao’s revolution.

headline: Why Writers Love to Hate the M.F.A.
text: It was peak reading season, and Lan Samantha Chang, director of the Iowa Writers’ Workshop, was gamely juggling a call from a reporter, interruptions from her 7-year-old as well as a 10 percent surge in applications to the University of Iowa’s Master of Fine Arts program in creative writing. Ms. Chang was in the thick of decisions about who would fill 50 spots evenly divided between the fall fiction and poetry workshops.

headline: North Charleston Police Shooting Not Justified, Experts Say
text: Can a police officer legally shoot a fleeing suspect in the back?

headline: Chile Joins Other Latin American Nations Shaken by Scandal
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — Scandals are shaking one government after another this year in Latin America: the mysterious death of a prosecutor in Argentina, the ouster of Peru’s prime minister over a domestic spying operation, the revelations of a vast bribery scheme at Brazil’s national oil company.

headline: Obama Adviser During Recession Is Given New Challenge: Climate Change
text: Brian Deese’s first job at the White House included churning out economic doomsday scenarios, like how many communities might see unemployment rates hit 25 percent in the event of cascading bankruptcies across the Midwest.

headline: When a Plane Seat Next to a Woman Is Against Orthodox Faith
text: Francesca Hogi, 40, had settled into her aisle seat for the flight from New York to London when the man assigned to the adjoining window seat arrived and refused to sit down. He said his religion prevented him from sitting beside a woman who was not his wife. Irritated but eager to get underway, she eventually agreed to move.

headline: The G.O.P. Presidential Field Looks Chaotic. It’s Not.
text: The Republican primary battle has been called a wide-open contest — the “deepest” and “strongest” field in many cycles. It is full of the party’s rising stars and hopefuls, like Scott Walker, Marco Rubio, Rand Paul, Chris Christie, Ben Carson, Ted Cruz and Bobby Jindal, alongside the most formidable name in Republican politics: Bush.

headline: Lyft Hires Amazon Executive as Chief Operating Officer
text: Amazon has long focused on delivering packages to customers as efficiently as humanly possible. It makes sense, then, that Lyft, a ride-hailing start-up, would want to hire staff from the online retail giant.

headline: Jon Ronson: By the Book
text: The author, most recently, of “So You’ve Been Publicly Shamed” used to find stories about children in peril unbearable. But with his son reaching adulthood, he says, “I nowadays find it impossible to read stories in which dogs are in peril.”

headline: Paul Beatty’s ‘The Sellout’
text: African-American satire has been alive at least since the first black slave made fun of her putative masters and their manners. In that moment of mockery, the cakewalk was born, but this parody had a catch: The slave owners loved it. They mistook the dance for a poor imitation rather than a dark mirror. One of the first homegrown national fads to go global, the cakewalk anticipated the paroxysms of twerking that would follow, whose late adopters like Miley Cyrus might be forgiven for missing the deep irony in the form’s black origins.

headline: Fighting Mental Illness on the Ball Field
text: Mental illness remains highly stigmatized, even after celebrities like Brooke Shields, Mel Gibson and Robin Williams went public with their stories. So it was really a big deal 60 years ago when the Boston Red Sox outfielder Jimmy Piersall wrote two articles in the Saturday Evening Post entitled “They Called Me Crazy—And I Was.” Mr. Piersall’s courageous description of his struggles with manic depression, now called bipolar disorder, helped bring the disease and its treatments out of the shadows.

headline: U.S. Defense Chief Arrives in South Korea Amid News of North’s Missile Launches
text: OSAN AIR BASE, South Korea — Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter’s welcome present was waiting for him when he touched down here on Thursday: confirmed reports that North Korea fired two short-range missiles off its western coast two days before his first visit to South Korea as President Obama’s defense chief.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: New York Today: Spring Break Fever
text: Good morning on this damp Thursday.

headline: Daily Report: Phone Cameras and Apps Capture Interactions With Police
text: The video of the fatal shooting of an unarmed black man by a white police officer in South Carolina is seen by some advocates of police reform as evidence of the rising power of technological weapons in their fight, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac report.

headline: Why Was This Patient Breathing So Strangely?
text: Her doctors thought she was having panic attacks. But she insisted she wasn’t anxious.

headline: The Awkward Romance in ‘Veep’
text: The HBO comedy is a political satire, but its core is the nonromantic romance between Selina Meyer, the vice president played by Julia Louis-Dreyfus, and Gary, her “body man,” played by Tony Hale.

headline: The Grandparent Scam
text: URBANA, ILL. — The crime is known as the grandparent scam. It’s a type of identity theft that many people have been aware of for a while, but my grandfather had not heard about it before he fell prey to it.

headline: Lee Surrendered, But His Lieutenants Kept Fighting
text: “If the programme which our people saw set on foot at Appomattox Court-House had been carried out … we would have no disturbance in the South,” testified the former Confederate general (and future senator) John Brown Gordon in 1871. Speaking before a congressional committee investigating the widespread anti-black violence in the former Confederacy, Gordon was accusing Radical Republicans of bad faith – specifically, of breaking the “Appomattox Compact.”

headline: Today in Politics: A Knighted Bloomberg Decrees Bush and Clinton Worthy Candidates
text: Michael R. Bloomberg offers an opinion on the presidential race, and Gov. Chris Christie sees his approval ratings drop in New Jersey.

headline: Morning Agenda: The $100 Billion Deal Day
text: THE $100 BILLION DEAL DAY  | Two huge offers – one accepted, the other unsolicited – trumpet a potential new frenzy of activity in deal-making. First and foremost, Royal Dutch Shell’s $70 billion acquisition of BG Group of Britain signals that the kinds of behemoth energy mergers that reshaped the industry in the late 1990s may be due for a revival in the face of lower oil and gas prices. In energy, the Brontosaurus is back. Mylan’s $29 billion approach to Perrigo, meanwhile, underscores just how red-hot consolidation in health care continues to be. Both of the generic drug makers had done their own deals in just the last two years.

headline: How Low Can the Philadelphia 76ers Go?
text: There has never been a professional sports team quite like the 2014-15 Philadelphia 76ers, a roster of basketball castoffs and drifters that could be the least capable assemblage of players ever to suit up for an N.B.A. game. The franchise — widely believed by those who follow pro basketball to be deliberately in “tank mode,” in order to lose games and get a top pick in this summer’s N.B.A. draft — has offended sensibilities, provoked curiosity, inspired bizarre mathematical theorems. How low could they go? After they lost 17 games to open the current season, the FiveThirtyEight website published a “dark simulation” that projected their losing streak could reach 54 games. Deadspin declared the Sixers a “godless abomination,” while Slam Magazine, the hip-hop basketball bible, described them as a “flesh-eating bacteria of sorts on the N.B.A.’s collective self-respect.”

headline: Do Police Use Deadly Force Too Often?
text: Have police officers become too willing to use force or are they reacting to the dangers they face every day?

headline: Raising Your Successful 35-Year-Old
text: What do we mean when we say we want to raise “successful” children? Too often, especially around this time of year, that conversation centers on college or the kinds of academics and activities that lead to college. “Success” is hard to measure, and those external markers make for comforting milestones along the way.

headline: Julia Louis-Dreyfus and Tony Hale’s Demented Double Act on ‘Veep’
text: The show begins — the very first scene of the very first episode — with a man helping a woman put on her coat. The man is tall. The woman is small. The man is balding. The woman has the shimmering hair of an extremely convincing shampoo ad. The man wears a nondescript dark suit, a striped tie and some kind of ID badge — the uniform of the bureaucratic functionary. He has a five o’clock shadow and the hint of a double chin. The woman wears a snug red dress with a deep neckline, an elegant gold necklace, understated makeup. She is the vice president of the United States. Getting her coat on is therefore an official matter of state, and the man is clearly treating it as such; he concentrates intently on maneuvering her right arm into the coat’s right sleeve. The woman, meanwhile, pays no attention to the man or to the coat, never even glances back; she stares forward, into the eyes of her chief of staff, with whom she is having a conversation.

headline: Iris Apfel Doesn’t Do Normcore
text: You’ve been a mainstay of the New York fashion scene for years, and you’re now the subject of a documentary, “Iris,” directed by Albert Maysles. Considering how long you’ve been around, are you surprised at all the recent interest in your life? It seems insane to me. I’m doing nothing different than what I’ve done for the last 70-odd years. Maybe I was ahead of the game, and people caught up with me. There aren’t too many 93-year-old cover girls around.

headline: First Draft Focus: Obama at the Bob Marley Museum
text: President Obama visited the Bob Marley Museum in Kingston, Jamaica, on Wednesday night.

headline: Graphic South Carolina Video and Details From a Rap Sheet Distress Some Times Readers
text: The Times gave huge space online and in print Wednesday to the fatal shooting of a black South Carolina man by a white police officer. Given the events last summer in Ferguson, Mo., that decision needs no explanation.

headline: The Indomitable Chita Rivera, Back on Broadway in ‘The Visit’
text: Two hours before any preview performance of “The Visit,” the Kander and Ebb musical that opens this month at the Lyceum Theater, you can find its star, Chita Rivera, in her dressing room. Upside down.

headline: Review: ‘Dior and I,’ a Documentary That Peers Into a Storied Fashion House
text: An elegant and captivating piece of corporate promotion in the guise of a documentary, Frédéric Tcheng’s “Dior and I” unfolds like an episode of “Project Runway” with better clothes and bigger budgets, or perhaps a Christopher Guest movie without a sense of humor. There are some amusing moments, to be sure, and some touching ones as well, but the film is less interested in ideas or emotions than in illusions. It produces an aura of suspense without a sense of real risk, and offers devotees of fashion an appealing, shallow fantasy of inside knowledge.

headline: Some Republicans Seek Status Quo on Iran
text: As Republicans criticize the nuclear deal President Obama and other world leaders struck with Iran last week, some of them say it would be better just to leave the current interim agreement in place instead.

headline: When a Handbag Has a Starring Role
text: “The Audience,” Peter Morgan’s play about Queen Elizabeth II, which stars Helen Mirren on Broadway and which will reopen this month in the West End of London with Kristin Scott Thomas, has had many pleasant repercussions for its much-celebrated leading lady, the director Stephen Daldry and its author. But the name that potentially stands to benefit most from the play’s success is probably less well known: Launer London.

headline: The Gap Between Auto Dealers and Social Media
text: Matt Howell, the general manager of a Hyundai dealership in Huntsville, Tex., has been in the auto business for 18 years. In all that time, he said, “I can think of one deal that originated on Facebook.”

headline: Kerry Says U.S. Knew of Iran’s Military Aid to Houthi Rebels
text: CAIRO — Secretary of State John Kerry has said that the United States knew Iran had been providing military support to the Houthi rebels in Yemen and that Washington “is not going to stand by while the region is destabilized.”

headline: Review: In ‘The Longest Ride,’ the Nicholas Sparks Brand Endures
text: On the Box Office Mojo website, “The Longest Ride” is described in three words: “Brand: Nicholas Sparks.” That may be all you need to know. The film, directed by George Tillman Jr. (“Soul Food,” “The Inevitable Defeat of Mister & Pete”), is the latest screen adaptation of work by an author whose stamp is unmistakable. To those familiar with his novels — and, more relevant to our purposes here, with the seacoast-and-sunlight, white-people-kissing-in-the-rain movies they have inspired — Mr. Sparks’s name evokes a genre, an aesthetic, a swoony, saccharine, weirdly compelling gestalt.

headline: Warner Bros. and Lego Enter Market Where Toys and Gaming Meet
text: BURBANK, Calif. — Warner Bros. and Lego are deploying Batman, Marty McFly, the Wicked Witch of the West and other movie characters in search of profits in the booming area of entertainment known as “toys to life.”

headline: ‘Don’t Think I’ve Forgotten,’ a Documentary, Revives Cambodia’s Silenced Sounds
text: For proof of the universality of rock ’n’ roll, look no further than Cambodia in the 1960s and ’70s. Even there, young people picked up electric guitars and studied Mick Jagger’s moves, melding Eastern melody with Western groove in ways that are still strikingly fresh.

headline: A Penchant for the East Village
text: Before she moved to New York, Jen Dobrovolski lived at home in New Jersey, with an exhausting ferry commute. She caught the boat in Atlantic Highlands, disembarked near Wall Street and took two subway trains to her office in Midtown West. In the evening, it was the other way around.

headline: Peltz’s Attacks on DuPont Threaten America’s Research Edge
text: Since its founding in 1802, DuPont has been at the center of American scientific breakthroughs in chemistry. Among its research triumphs was the black powder that supplied 40 percent of the Allied needs in World War II.

headline: ‘Daily Show’ Successor Trevor Noah Finds Himself Catching Criticism, Not Dealing It Out
text: If an announcement of a presidential candidacy were as rocky as Comedy Central’s introduction of Trevor Noah, “The Daily Show” would have a field day with it.

headline: U.S. Is Closer to Deciding Cuba’s Status on Terror List
text: PANAMA — President Obama is nearing a decision on removing Cuba’s three-decade-old designation as a state sponsor of terrorism, citing progress in his push to normalize relations with the island nation as he arrived here on Thursday night for a summit meeting of Latin American leaders.

headline: How to Verify if That Port Is Indeed a USB 3.0
text: If you do not have the computer’s manual or specifications sheet, there are several ways to check, including looking for a blue light at the jack.

headline: HSBC Facing Criminal Investigation in French Tax Case
text: LONDON — The British bank HSBC said on Thursday that it had been placed under formal criminal investigation by French magistrates examining whether its Swiss private bank assisted wealthy clients to avoid taxes.

headline: French Broadcaster TV5 Monde Recovers After Hacking
text: PARIS — The French television broadcaster TV5 Monde was back on the air Thursday, a day after hackers claiming to support the Islamic State militant group carried out a wide-ranging cyberattack on the network.

headline: Intel Said to End Talks to Buy Chip Designer Altera
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Intel has ended discussions to buy Altera, a designer of specialized computer chips, people briefed on the matter said on Thursday, putting to rest what would have been the company’s biggest-ever takeover.

headline: Malli Mastan Babu, Who Scaled the World’s Tallest Mountains, Dies at 40
text: Malli Mastan Babu, an Indian mountaineer who won fame as the first South Asian to scale the highest peak on each of the seven continents, and who had been missing in the Andes since late March, was found dead on April 3. He was 40.

headline: The Must-Attend Event for Education Technology Investors
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — To observe the major forces at play in the education technology sector, one needed only to stand near the marble fountain in the Phoenician Resort lobby this week.

headline: China Says Construction in Contested Waters Is for Maritime Purposes
text: BEIJING — A Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman on Thursday defended China’s island-building work in contested waters in the South China Sea, saying the infrastructure the nation was constructing around reefs, rocks and shoals was within China’s sovereign rights and would help ships in the event of typhoons.

headline: 1965: Hanoi Rejects Johnson’s Offer
text: SAIGON — North Vietnam today assailed President Johnson’s offer of a peaceful settlement for Vietnam as ‘‘a crude hoax.’’ It also widely distributed a statement by President Ho Chi Minh declaring that the United States must withdraw from South Vietnam before a settlement can be reached. North Vietnam’s response followed Communist China’s rejection of Mr. Johnson’s gesture as an inducement to the Vietnamese insurgents to disarm. Peking also called it a ‘‘hoax.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 10, 1965

headline: In Maastricht, a Taste of Joie de Vivre
text: By the time we were sitting at Café Sjiek, sharing a pot of zoervleis — a Limburgian delicacy that translates to “sour meat” — my husband, Tim, and I were on our third ultra-indulgent restaurant meal of the day and feeling like failed Olympians. The waiter, a rather severe man with a shaved head and the arty eyeglasses of a museum curator, had seemed surprised that I ordered the dish.

headline: Where to Shop in Vienna
text: Neubaugasse Street in Vienna’s seventh district, an enclave near the tourist-frequented Museumsquartier, where both longtime residents and young professionals live, has emerged as a go-to for innovative shopping. Boutiques, housed mostly in three- and four-story 19th-century buildings on this charming and quiet street, sell everything from trendy clothes and accessories to food, and stand out for their personable feel.

headline: Spurs Prepare to Pass the Torch, and Kawhi Leonard Is Ready
text: SAN ANTONIO — With a little over two minutes remaining in the game here on Wednesday night, two fans were ushered onto the court for a contest. They would be racing to make a layup, the catch being that they first had to rest their foreheads on traffic cones and spin around 10 times.

headline: New Hikes in Sonoma
text: A new hiking trail linked to Jack London State Historic Park in Sonoma County, Calif., gives the public access to parts of Sonoma Mountain for the first time.

headline: Iran’s Supreme Leader Says Sanctions Must Lift When Nuclear Deal Is Signed
text: TEHRAN — Iran’s supreme leader on Thursday challenged two of the United States’ bedrock principles in the nuclear negotiations, declaring that all economic sanctions would have to be lifted on the day any final agreement was signed and that military sites would be strictly off limits to foreign inspectors.

headline: Fine Foods Match Vancouver Island’s Spectacular Setting
text: Tofino, an enclave on the western edge of Vancouver Island in Canada, has long been a draw for its spectacular setting between the Pacific Ocean, with its surfer-magnet waves, and the Pacific Rim National Park Reserve. Now, the growing number of restaurants is another reason to visit this British Columbia district, with a population of less than 1,900. The thriving culinary scene here is led by transplants who were attracted to the area’s idyllic surroundings and easygoing way of life.

headline: In Rand Paul Ads, an Appeal to Viewers Before the ‘Skip This’
text: It can be a saving grace. Queue up the latest music video, say, from Taylor Swift on YouTube, and instead of having to wait for an entire car commercial to pass, a “Skip This Ad” button occasionally appears after five seconds.

headline: Keeping Adrian Gonzalez’s Torrid Start in Perspective
text: Adrian Gonzalez of the Los Angeles Dodgers had a home run in each of his first two games this season, then added three on Wednesday night to become the first player in major league history with five home runs in his first three games, according to Elias Sports Bureau.

headline: Anti-Bias Ordinance Falls in Springfield, Missouri, After Push by Christian Conservatives
text: SPRINGFIELD, Mo. — After a successful vote by the City Council here in October to add sexual orientation and gender identity to the list of categories protected from discrimination here, one supporter, David Trippe, thought this Bible Belt city might have turned a page.

headline: Founder of Satyam, Software Outsourcing Company in India, Found Guilty of Fraud
text: NEW DELHI — An Indian court on Thursday sentenced the former head of Satyam Computer Services, a software outsourcing company, and nine others to seven years in prison after a trial centered on one of the largest corporate accounting frauds in India’s history.

headline: Vegetables à la Grecque Shows Its Versatility
text: Despite the name, vegetables à la grecque is French through and through. According to the food writer Roy Andries de Groot, the phrase à la Grecque is attached to many dishes that came to France with refugees (many of them Greek) from the Ottoman Empire in the 15th century and have been absorbed into French cuisine.

headline: Scientists Question Environmental Impact of China’s Winter Olympics Bid
text: JIUZHANBAO, China — A few times a year, rains sprinkle the dry mountains north of Beijing, feeding streams that trickle down to catchments like the Yunzhou Reservoir. From its shores, the water shimmers and sparkles, a mirage that local farmers can see but not touch.

headline: At the Masters, a Cheer for the Old-School Big Three
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Cancer did not prevent Carl Jackson from keeping his annual appointment with Ben Crenshaw on Thursday at the 79th Masters. That was the good news.

headline: 1940: Nazis Enter Nordic States
text: A video report from British Pathé on the occupation of Scandinavian countries by Germany. britishpathe.com.

headline: Toronto Museum Director to Succeed Malcolm Rogers as Leader of Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
text: Succeeding Malcolm Rogers, who served for 19 years, Matthew Teitelbaum will become the next director of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, the museum announced Thursday.

headline: U.N. Rights Chief Criticizes Malaysian Antiterror Measure
text: GENEVA — The United Nations human rights chief on Thursday joined in criticism of the Malaysian government’s planned legislation on sedition and the prevention of terrorism, warning that both bills threatened to severely curtail freedom of opinion and expression and breach the country’s international obligations.

headline: Ahead of World War II Anniversary, Questions Linger Over Stance of Japan’s Premier
text: PELELIU ISLAND, Palau — Visiting the remote Western Pacific site of one of the fiercest battles of World War II, Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko of Japan offered flowers and prayers on Thursday to mark the coming 70th anniversary of the end of a conflict that continues to haunt Japan as it seeks a larger role in the world.

headline: Imported Stars Give Red Sox a Chance at a Worst-to-First Repeat
text: PHILADELPHIA — The last time the Boston Red Sox played the Yankees in the regular season, Derek Jeter retired. On his way off the field for the last time, Jeter paused to shake hands with Clay Buchholz, the Boston pitcher who had been warming in the bullpen when Jeter shook the hands of the other Red Sox before the game.

text: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

headline: Investment Banks Are Within Reach of Adequate Returns
text: Investor redemption may be nearing for investment banks. Most lenders’ wholesale units have destroyed value for seven years. Some may have done so again in the first quarter of this year.

headline: In ‘Living on Love,’ Renée Fleming Takes a Humorous Broadway Turn
text: Renée Fleming has performed at Bayreuth, La Scala and the Super Bowl. She has lent her soprano to the contents of a David Letterman Top 10 list. She has inspired a character in a best-selling novel (Ann Patchett’s “Bel Canto”) and a dessert by the chef Daniel Boulud.

headline: 2016 Ambitions Turn Marco Rubio, Jeb Bush Protégé, Into Rival
text: MIAMI — As Marco Rubio debated whether to run for the United States Senate in 2010, he made a pledge steeped in loyalty and deference: He would never challenge his political mentor, Jeb Bush, if the former Florida governor wanted the job himself.

headline: Amid Political Confrontations in Bangladesh, a Search for a Missing Opposition Official
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — A jittery silence has fallen over the street where Salahuddin Ahmed, a top official of the opposition Bangladesh Nationalist Party, is believed to have been abducted a month ago.

headline: Russian Consumers Reflect the Pinch of Economic Sanctions
text: MOSCOW — The brand-new Avia Park is a glittering testament to the power of the Russian consumer. A panorama of white tile flooring, under a soaring, six story-tall glass roof, it is the largest mall in Europe, with 377,000 square meters of enclosed space, a 17-screen multiplex, even a 70-foot tall aquarium of tropical fish.

headline: Laurie Anderson to Receive Yaddo Artist Medal
text: Laurie Anderson will receive the second annual Artist Medal awarded by Yaddo, the artist colony in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. The ceremony will take place June 1 in New York and will be hosted by Steve Buscemi and Kate Valk.

headline: Ice Cream Sandwiches
text: Born on the Bowery, the ice cream sandwich has come a long way over the last century.

headline: The Ice Cream Sandwich Comes of Age
text: The American ice cream sandwich was born in the Bowery district of Manhattan in the early 1900s, when a pushcart vendor slapped together skinny wafers and vanilla ice cream and handed them for a penny each to shoeshiners and stockbrokers alike.

headline: Robert Durst Pleads Not Guilty to Weapons Charges

headline: Anatomy | ‘Clouds of Sils Maria’

headline: The Right Wine to Drink With a Sandwich
text: Some people with narrow views of the possibilities ask, “Why would you drink wine with a sandwich?” I say, “Why on earth wouldn’t you?”

headline: Taliban Attack in Northern Afghanistan Leaves at Least 10 Dead
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Assailants armed with heavy weapons and suicide vests stormed the provincial prosecutor’s office on Thursday in one of the most peaceful cities in northern Afghanistan, battling security forces for more than six hours and leaving at least 10 people dead and dozens wounded.

headline: Andrew Rashbass, Reuters Chief, Is Moving to Euromoney
text: Andrew Rashbass, the chief executive of Reuters, is leaving the organization this year to join Euromoney Institutional Investor, a British publisher of financial publications, as executive chairman, the companies said on Thursday.

headline: Ana Khouri’s Newest Jewelry Forms — to Accentuate a Woman’s Own
text: The Brazilian designer Ana Khouri’s fine jewelry isn’t defined by carats, cut or color, nor by its high-profile fans, like Madonna and Jennifer Lawrence. Instead, she aims to distinguish her work by highlighting its natural synergy with the human anatomy. In her latest designs (she doesn’t create collections), the former art scholar and sculptor is taking that notion, of connecting the accessory to its wearer, even further. Today at Dover Street Market New York, she debuts collar necklaces, earrings, rings and bracelets made from materials like yellow gold, pavé diamonds and pearls. “I was inspired by a dialogue with the human form,” Khouri says. “The shapes of these pieces follow the lines of the body.” There are cuffs that appear to climb inside the ear and slink their way out of the lobe, and rings that “better frame the curves of the fingers.” Inspired by artists like Louise Bourgeois and Alberto Giacometti, Khouri explains that she aims to “call attention to the lines of the thing — and not the person who is wearing it.” To that effect, the DSMNY installation features live models, veiled and wearing the pieces over their fabric-draped skin — so that viewers only, as Khouri puts it, “focus only on what is essential.”

headline: Latest Score in Cyprus Soccer: Blown-Up Cars 6, Referees 0

headline: ‘Clouds of Sils Maria’ (With Movie Trailer): Olivier Assayas Narrates a Scene
text: The writer and director Olivier Assayas takes a trip to Switzerland, by way of Italy, with his latest film “Clouds of Sils Maria.” It features Juliette Binoche as Maria Enders, a seasoned actress, and Kristen Stewart as her assistant Valentine. Maria agrees to take a role in the revival of a play she performed in 20 years before. In the scene in this video, Maria takes her assistant Valentine to the Swiss Alps to rehearse. During an interview at the New York Film Festival last fall, Mr. Assayas discussed the scene and how Italy stood in for Switzerland. Below are excerpts from that conversation.

headline: Readers Respond: On ‘Can Rand Paul Win With His Principles?’
text: A number of readers responded hopefully to an editorial about Senator Rand Paul’s presidential candidacy, saying it’s time for the Republican Party to listen to a broader range of voices.

headline: The Many Looks of Amal Clooney, New York’s New Fashion Darling
text: Some of the human rights lawyer’s stylish looks, spotted around town.

headline: Neil Young’s ‘Human Highway’ Finally Hits Theaters Decades Later
text: Neil Young’s image, circa 1982, was that of a dark, brooding, introspective rock star who couldn’t get along with Crosby, Stills or Nash, and seemed intent on alienating his fans and his record label with Kraftwerk-inspired electropop. He was certainly not perceived as someone inclined to do a 90-minute Jerry Lewis impersonation in a movie designed as a drug-addled “Wizard of Oz” — one that ends in nuclear conflagration, rather than Kansas.

headline: G.E. Seen Close to Selling Its Real Estate Portfolio
text: General Electric is poised to sell its enormous real estate portfolio in a sale that could fetch about $30 billion, according to people with knowledge of the matter who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

headline: Kansas Tries to Stamp Out Abortion
text: During the past four years, the state of Kansas has become ground zero in the war to criminalize all abortions, and in the process to remove a woman’s ability to control what happens in her own body.

headline: If We Can’t Prevent Wrongful Convictions, Can We at Least Pay for Them?
text: A few weeks ago, a former prosecutor in Caddo Parish, La., named A. M. Stroud III wrote a letter to the editor of The Shreveport Times that quickly caught fire on the Internet. Over more than 1,400 anguished words, Stroud apologized for his leading role in the 1984 trial of Glenn Ford, a Louisiana man who was convicted of murder and spent nearly 30 years on death row in Angola, the state’s maximum-security prison, until last year, when his conviction was overturned and he was released.

headline: Heirs to French Art Dealer May Benefit from Sale of Monet Lost During World War II
text: Much of the art collection of René Gimpel, a French art dealer who associated with the intellectual elite of his day, was lost during World War II when the dealer was detained by the Vichy government and shipped off by the Nazis to a German concentration camp.

headline: Ahead of Watch Release, Apple to Allow Customers to Try It On
text: The era of online shopping made “buy before you try” (and ship back if you don’t like it) a typical consumer experience. The Apple Watch, which comes out April 24, is probably something you should actually try before buying.

headline: Portraits of People and Paper
text: SNEAK PEEK: This week Lens is featuring a selection of photographers attending the New York Portfolio Review.

headline: Rand Paul Tells Republican Critics: ‘War Is Not a Game’
text: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C. — Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky was defiant on Thursday as he answered fellow Republicans who have attacked his foreign policy as naïve and misguided, telling them “war is not a game” to be exploited by over-zealous politicians.

headline: Review: ‘Personal Correspondents: Photography and Letter Writing in Civil War Brooklyn’
text: Symbolically, the Civil War ended when Robert E. Lee surrendered to Ulysses S. Grant in a Virginia parlor on April 9, 1865, a century and a half ago this week. Officially, it concluded a year later, when President Andrew Johnson issued a proclamation of peace. For many people who lived through it, the war never ended at all.

headline: Christen Wilson on What to Do in Dallas During Art Week
text: Tonight, the Dallas Art Fair previews its seventh edition at the Fashion Industry Gallery in Downtown’s Arts District, drawing close to 100 galleries to a city more commonly associated with 10-gallon hats than bohemian berets. Few Dallasites are busier this week than collector Christen Wilson. In addition to chairing Dallas’s Nasher Sculpture Center’s program committee and sitting on similar councils for the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York and London’s Tate museum, she and her husband Derek regularly open their museum-like Highland Park home to visitors and local art lovers alike. Last night, they hosted a reception for the Dallas Museum of Art, amid collection highlights from Sterling Ruby to Donald Judd and Eddie Peake on view. Here, Wilson shares her favorite spots around town — for Art Week or anytime.

headline: Viewfinder: Marko Metzinger
text: The photographer Marko Metzinger’s new series finds symmetry and movement in unexpected places.

headline: 11, and Reviewing His Parents’ Credit Card Bills
text: By the time your kids are applying to college, they ought to know how much money you make.

headline: Word of Oil Find Near Gatwick Excites Britain
text: LONDON — Oil fever gripped Britain on Thursday after a small company announced the discovery of what it described as “a possible world-class potential resource” in the Surrey countryside south of London near Gatwick Airport.

headline: Biden Cites Progress in Iraq’s War With ISIS
text: WASHINGTON — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. offered an upbeat assessment of the battle against Islamic extremists in Iraq on Thursday, saying the government in that country was making “significant and growing” progress with help from the United States and its allies in the region.

headline: Matt Harvey Quashes Uncertainty and the Nationals
text: WASHINGTON — When Matt Harvey took the mound Thursday for his first professional baseball game in 593 days, he kicked at the dirt in front of the rubber, paced off four steps toward the plate and drew a straight line. Every time he threw a pitch, his left foot would land on, or somewhere near, the end of the line.

headline: Greek Finance Minister Steers Debt Talk His Way
text: PARIS — You would never know from his demeanor that Yanis Varoufakis, the celebrity Greek finance minister, was carrying the weight of a nation on his shoulders. In fact, you could be forgiven for thinking that it was his country’s uncompromising creditors who were on the defensive.

headline: Natural Selection May Help Account for Dutch Height Advantage
text: Gert Stulp stands 6 feet, 7 inches tall. His height makes him especially self-conscious at scientific conferences when he rises to describe his research as a demographer at the London School of Tropical Medicine. “It’s always quite embarrassing,” he said.

headline: Lincoln Chafee Hits Hillary Clinton on Foundation Donations
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton has faced little dissension from fellow Democrats as she moves closer to running for president, but fresh signs of restlessness are emerging.

headline: A Boyfriend Too Good to Be True
text: Eight years ago, my mother received an unusual call from her mother.

headline: In 2012 Tribute, Rubio Asked ‘What Would Jeb Do?’
text: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida may have written Jeb Bush’s campaign bumper sticker.

headline: Biden Speaks of Progress Against ISIS
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said on Thursday that Iraqis, with help from the United States, have been making progress in the fight against the Islamic State.

headline: Tensions Between Iran and Saudi Arabia Deepen Over Conflict in Yemen
text: CAIRO — Tensions between Iran and Saudi Arabia deepened on Thursday as Iranian leaders lashed out with rare vehemence against the continuing Saudi air campaign in Yemen, even hurling personal insults at the young Saudi prince who is leading the fight.

headline: ‘Disorder’ and ‘Stray Dogs’ Capture the Look of Cities Falling Apart
text: To live in a large city, the German sociologist Georg Simmel observed in 1903, was to experience an “intensification of nervous stimulation.” Made just over a century later, “Disorder” — a found-footage documentary assembled by the Chinese filmmaker Huang Weikai — takes Simmel’s point to the far side of the moon.

headline: Park Avenue Armory to Restore Tiffany-Designed Veterans Room
text: The blue-blooded Park Avenue Armory has announced the next stage of its modernization. The architecture firm Herzog & de Meuron will restore the building’s opulent Veterans Room, which has one of the few surviving interiors designed by Louis C. Tiffany and Company, the firm identified with the American Aesthetic Movement, led by Louis Comfort Tiffany, working with Samuel Colman, Lockwood de Forest, Candace Wheeler and Stanford White.

headline: Deutsche Bank Nears Plea Deal Over Libor Manipulation
text: A long-running investigation into Wall Street’s manipulation of interest rates is heading into a stark final chapter as authorities around the globe push Deutsche Bank to pay a record penalty and accept a criminal guilty plea for the unit at the center of the case.

headline: Review: ‘One of Us,’ by Asne Seierstad, on Anders Breivik’s Rampage in Norway
text: The nonfiction horror story told in “One of Us: The Story of Anders Breivik and the Massacre in Norway” moves slowly, inexorably and with tremendous authority. It’s a sober book that smells like fresh construction, a house built from plain hard facts. You’re forced to bring your own emotion, and it pools beneath the steady sentences.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, April 12 to 18, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: After Bitter Loss, a Bittersweet One: Seven Are Leaving Kentucky Early
text: In October, the Kentucky men’s basketball team held a two-hour open practice expressly designed for N.B.A. scouts who wanted to see the Wildcats’ draft prospects up close.

headline: Wine Study, by Barge, in Burgundy
text: For passengers who want to drink in more than the scenery, three Burgundy-based barges run by the luxury tour operator Belmond will offer a new Wine Academy focused on educating oenophiles.

headline: A Honey Lozenge of a Cocktail for Cold Spring Days
text: The sharp lens of Bill Cunningham revealed that by the end of March, we still hadn’t shaken our winter black-and-whites. And this week, meteorologists predicted rain every day for the Big Apple — and rain it has. With restaurants reluctant to open up their gardens and sidewalk seating, New Yorkers have yet to savor that first al fresco drink of the season. Indoors, the Bowery’s Saxon & Parole is passing the time until warmer weather arrives with the bartender Maxime Belfand’s Laddie Punch, a surprisingly light drink that warms the bones (thanks to bergamot tea) but isn’t too heavy for April attitudes. “Wintertime, we tend to use heavier spices like cinnamon or even anise or nutmeg,” says Belfand, adding that in the summer, we crave a drink “that has light botanicals in it.” The addition of lemon and vermouth puts his Scotch-based summer drink somewhere between a Rob Roy and a honey lozenge, perfect for the rain-soaked bon vivant.

headline: Bill to End Civil Forfeiture in New Mexico Awaits Move by Governor Martinez
text: In March, New Mexico’s divided Legislature voted unanimously to end the contentious practice of civil forfeiture, which lets law enforcement agencies take property suspected of ties to crime even if no charges are ever filed.

headline: Nationals Play D.J. and Try to Make Mets Feel Like Dust in the Wind
text: WASHINGTON — When the Washington Nationals finished batting practice here on Wednesday at Nationals Park and the Mets took the field, the slow, soothing tones of “Rainy Days and Mondays,” by the Carpenters, came over the loudspeakers.

headline: Obama on Cuba’s Terror List Review
text: President Obama, appearing with the Jamaican prime minister, said that the State Department had completed its review of whether to remove Cuba from the list of state sponsors of terrorism.

headline: Review: ‘The Living’ Wades Into Domestic Abuse and Revenge
text: The neo-noir “The Living,” while bearing an impressive sheen for its modest budget, sells short its own potential. The story of a working-class man in rural Pennsylvania who in a drunken fever physically abuses his wife one night — setting into motion events involving a hit man hired by the wife’s brother to avenge her injuries — flirts with a loaded topic but settles for mere genre exercise.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Kenya, South Africa, Syria and Japan

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, April 12 to 18, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: In ‘Lost River,’ by Ryan Gosling, Surreal Scenes of Urban Decline
text: Like “It Follows” and “Buzzard,” “Lost River” uses bleak Michigan scenery as the backdrop for a form of horror film. Although set in a made-up city, the movie — the feature directorial debut of Ryan Gosling, who also wrote the screenplay — was shot in moribund Detroit neighborhoods. Dilapidated houses, overgrown lawns and abandoned buildings give this demented fantasia a surreal charge.

headline: April 9, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Kenya, South Africa, Syria and Japan.

headline: Review: ‘Coypel’s Don Quixote Tapestries’ Weaves a Classic Tale
text: Miguel de Cervantes’s “Don Quixote,” whose first volume was published in 1605, has inspired and challenged illustrators from Goya to Dalí. Few have captured the paradoxical essence of a book in which fantasy and reality collide to farcical effect over and over. It’s a hard problem: How would you picture simultaneously the narrator’s vividly realistic, warts-and-all description of his hapless protagonist’s adventures and Don Quixote’s own delusional view of himself as a knight errant in a simplified world of heroes, villains, giants and damsels in distress? How would you make visible such a contradictory double vision?

headline: Note to Commuter: Make Yourself Heard
text: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio joined more than 60 mayors across the country on Thursday morning for a nationwide rally on behalf of the American commuter.  Mr. de Blasio, Senator Charles Schumer and other bigwigs actually took the city subway (the R train) to make their point. The well-dressed cluster startled veteran subway riders who are usually interrupted by people begging for money, not beseeching them to contact their members of Congress about the highway trust fund.

headline: Retailers to Stop Sales of Controversial Supplements
text: Some leading vitamin stores have announced that they were pulling from their shelves a group of supplements that may contain a dangerous stimulant.

headline: Bucking Trend, Pereira & O’Dell to Break With Its Brazilian Parent
text: Pereira & O’Dell, an advertising agency known for the long-form digital video campaigns it has created for clients like Skype, is breaking away from its holding company, a move that goes against an industry trend toward consolidation.

headline: Listeria in Sabra Hummus Prompts New Wave of Recalls
text: Two food manufacturers have issued nationwide recalls of products because of the discovery of the potentially lethal bacterium listeria, which federal authorities have now linked to three deaths and five illnesses in Texas and Kansas.

headline: New York Detective Is Suspended Amid Inquiry on Theft at Deli
text: A New York police detective has been suspended after a surveillance video appeared to show him taking money from a Brooklyn deli during a sweep of the store for loose cigarettes.

headline: Married, With Roommates
text: Living with roommates is practically a rite of passage in New York City. It often begins with far too many people sharing too little space and ends with a move into an apartment of one’s own, or with that special someone.

headline: Taking Steps to Bridge a Divide
text: I am traveling abroad and staying with relatives who welcomed me into their home. They are Israeli émigrés and have strong opinions on the Middle East. My boyfriend, whom I am also visiting here, is Muslim, but from a country far from the Middle East. One of my relatives said she is uncomfortable having my boyfriend in her home because he is Muslim. I was aghast. My boyfriend is the kindest man in the world. But my parents told me not to address her hurtful comment because she has been so hospitable. Help!

headline: Lena Hall Rocks Out at, Yes, the Reserved Café Carlyle
text: Early in her Café Carlyle show on Wednesday evening, Lena Hall produced a tambourine and remarked that she might be the first performer to shake such an instrument in this staid cabaret, which until recently had avoided booking rock performers. But appearances there by Debbie Harry and Buster Poindexter, who have done good business, have signaled that the walls are crumbling.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Swords, Sleight of Hand and a Speaking Mummy
text: THE Luxor Mummy returns. Last seen onstage in the 1930s, the bogus but brilliant artifact, reputed to be a contemporary of King Tut, takes an encore at the Morbid Anatomy Museum in Brooklyn in the exhibition “Do the Spirits Return?: From Dark Arts to Sleight of Hand in Early 20th Century Stage Magic.” It opens on Saturday.

headline: Review: ‘The Critique of Reason’ Revisits What Romantic Art Means
text: NEW HAVEN — In the popular imagination, the Romantic artist is a dreamy, introverted type. Picture Turner lashing himself to a ship’s mast, Delacroix whipping up feverish harem scenes or Caspar David Friedrich planting his solitary wanderers in misty landscapes.

headline: Review: In ‘Ex Machina,’ a Mogul Fashions the Droid of His Dreams
text: The perfect 21st-century female looks like a million bucks though costs a great deal more. In “Ex Machina,” Alex Garland’s slyly spooky futuristic shocker about old and new desires, the female in question is a robot called Ava, a name suggestive of both Adam and Eve. Ava has a serene humanoid face and the expressive hands and feet of a dancer, but also the transparent figure of a visible woman anatomy model. Beautiful and smart, sleek and stacked, Ava is at once decidedly unsettling and safely under lock and key, which makes her an ideal posthuman female.

text: Museums and Sites

headline: Bushwick Flea Market Is Open for Browsing
text: Anyone who wants to find a flea market in New York doesn’t have to try very hard. Although pop-ups can be found in places like school playgrounds and parking lots, there are also plenty of familiar mainstays like the Brooklyn Flea in Williamsburg and Fort Greene.

text: Dance

headline: Perella Weinberg Poaches Top Telecom Banker From Lazard
text: As the boutique investment bank Perella Weinberg Partners aims to expand, it has poached one of the top telecommunications bankers around — one who helped put together one of last year’s biggest deals.

headline: On ‘Game of Thrones,’ a Change of Scene
text: Winter may always be approaching in “Game of Thrones,” but as Season 5 of this HBO fantasy hit begins on Sunday night, it feels like springtime in the known world.

text: ‘Spring Wings’

headline: An Awkward Exception to Cruz’s Recipe for Winning the White House
text: Since coming to Washington in 2013, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas has frequently used his public appearances to make a case that Republicans win the presidency only when they nominate bold conservatives.

headline: ‘Mamma Mia!’ to Close in September
text: “Mamma Mia!,” the hit musical based on the songs of the Swedish pop group Abba, will end its 14-year run on Sept. 5. The show, which opened at the Winter Garden on Oct. 18, 2001, and moved to the Broadhurst Theater in 2013, will close after 5,765 performances, making it the eighth-longest-running show in Broadway history, seen by more than 7 million people.

headline: New Video Shows Start of South Carolina Police Conflict as Routine
text: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — South Carolina officials investigating the weekend shooting death of a black man by a police officer here released a video Thursday that for the first time showed the early moments of an encounter that would ultimately reignite anger about police misconduct.

headline: Review: ‘Rebels of the Neon God’ Gets a New York Screening
text: In addition to having one of the best titles ever, “Rebels of the Neon God” marks the start of one of modern cinema’s great careers. This film, which in spite of a worldwide cult following has never received a proper United States release, was the first feature directed by Tsai Ming-liang, whose subsequent work would establish him, alongside slightly older contemporaries like Hou Hsiao-hsien and Edward Yang, as a leading figure in the Taiwanese New Wave of the 1990s. (A retrospective of his work starts Friday at the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens.)

headline: Dash Cam Footage of Walter Scott
text: Dashboard camera footage of Walter L. Scott before he was shot.

headline: In New York, Everywhere a Writing Nook
text: WORK and leisure don’t have to be enemies. The writing life is proof of it. New York’s coffee shops would be deserted if it weren’t for people scribbling and typing the day away. But when every seat is taken, the Wi-Fi is down and the only muffin left is bran, there are alternatives to being cooped up in the home office, and the city’s legion of playwrights know them well.

headline: Exiled Children of Tibet
text: Eight years old when he was sent into exile from Tibet, Tsering Topgyal has followed the lives of others who made a similar journey.

headline: Review: ‘Black Souls’ Depicts Crime Families Bound by Blood in Bad Ways
text: Except for one family member, the Carbones, a clan of goat-herding gangsters in Francesco Munzi’s film “Black Souls” belong to the ’Ndrangheta, Calabria’s mafia, based in the rocky climes of extreme southern Italy. In their secretive culture of simmering blood feuds, vendettas and territorial rivalries, which has flourished since the 19th century, not a grudge is forgotten nor an insult overlooked. The peace is fragile, and a pall of suspicion hangs over their hometown, Africo.

headline: Rand Paul Demands TV Stations Pull Iran Ad
text: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky has been a presidential candidate for only three days, but he is already the subject of a blistering ad attacking his position on Iran. In response, he sent television stations showing the commercial a cease-and-desist letter demanding they pull it.

headline: Review: With Bach as a Catalyst, Thierry Escaich’s Lavish Concerto
text: Not many concertos for violin and oboe have entered the standard repertory. The best-known, as Alan Gilbert remarked during a New York Philharmonic concert on Wednesday, is Bach’s splendid Concerto in C Minor for Oboe, Violin and Strings.

headline: Turning to Big, Big Data to See What Ails the World
text: Like many fields, public health is in the midst of a data revolution: randomized control trials, pay-for-performance and value calculations, all based on data, are changing our ideas about what works and how to finance it.

headline: Review: ‘Broken Horses,’ Vidhu Vinod Chopra’s Modern Western
text: In Vidhu Vinod Chopra’s “Broken Horses,” a brave simpleton named Buddy (Christopher Marquette) follows the murderous orders of his boss, Julius Hench (Vincent D’Onofrio), somewhere on the border with Mexico. Years ago, Buddy promised to build a ranch for his little brother, Jakey (Anton Yelchin), whose life took a different turn: He moved to New York, became a professional violinist and acquired an Italian girlfriend. When Jakey comes home to visit, a deeply silly drama of corrupted innocence ensues.

headline: The Wise Words of Maya Angelou. Or Someone, Anyway.
text: THIS week the United States Postal Service celebrated the life and work of Maya Angelou, unveiling a stamp with her portrait and a lyrical quotation. Unfortunately, the words on the stamp do not appear to have originally been uttered by the poet. Instead, they come from the children’s book author Joan Walsh Anglund.

headline: Review: ‘Desert Dancer’ Tells the Story of the Afshin Ghaffarian
text: The fictionalized biopic “Desert Dancer” explores fascinating aspects of present-day Iran but suffers mightily from simplistic and sentimental tendencies. The debut feature of Richard Raymond, the film depicts the life of Afshin Ghaffarian (Reece Ritchie), a dancer who, frustrated by cultural repression, left the country in 2009. We follow him from childhood, when his instinct to perform at school leads to cautionary messages from his mother about government “morality police.” Later he attends the Saba Art and Cultural Institute and then a university in Tehran, where friends (played by Tom Cullen, Marama Corlett and Bamshad Abedi-Amin, among others) and a love interest (Freida Pinto) join him in a kind of secret college dance club.

headline: This Week’s Movies | April 10, 2015
text: The New York Times film critics review “The Longest Ride,” “Ex Machina,” and “Black Souls.”

headline: Oscar Broadcast Set for Feb. 28
text: Who will produce the next Academy Awards broadcast is yet to be announced, but the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and ABC have set the show date: Sunday, Feb. 28. In an announcement on Thursday, the academy and ABC also scheduled the 2017 Oscars, for Feb. 26, and the 2018 show, for March 4. Voting for the 2016 Oscar nominations will begin on Dec. 30 and close on Jan. 8. Final voting will begin Feb. 12 and end at 5 p.m. Pacific time on Feb. 23. Earlier, Craig Zadan and Neil Meron, who produced the last three Oscar shows, said they would not return as producers of the next ceremony. Academy officials have been reviewing the awards process and presentation after a drop in ratings for this year’s ceremony, which was hosted by Neil Patrick Harris.

headline: Review: In ‘The Harvest,’ Love Is Wielded With a Chill
text: Pity little Andy (a wan Charlie Tahan), stuck in a narrow bed in a cramped room, an IV pole and a wheelchair silently standing guard. Pity lonely Maryann (Natasha Calis), recently orphaned and transplanted to the countryside to be cared for by her solicitous grandparents (Peter Fonda and Leslie Lyles). And pity the horror fans who expect “The Harvest” to deliver the extravagant slicing and dicing that the genre commonly promises. Quieter, stealthier — and downright slow in parts — this sly dig at extreme parenting has virtually no blood and no weapon scarier than a hypodermic needle. Unless you count a mother’s love.

headline: A Yankee Fan Admits (Painfully) That Boston Has the Better Team
text: Can you hear it? It’s the sound of a rumble readying in the Bronx. At least it would have been in years past. The Yankees meet the Red Sox on Friday for their first series in the post-Jeter era. There was a time when the teams’ rivalry was considered by many to be the greatest in sports — and a ticket to a game one of the hottest in town. Things have changed. Two reporters for The New York Times, one a die-hard Yankees fan, below, and the other a die-hard Red Sox fan, weigh in on whether the flame can be rekindled. It’s up to you.

headline: For a Sox Fan, Intensity Is Not Yet in Midseason Form
text: Can you hear it? It’s the sound of a rumble readying in the Bronx. At least it would have been in years past. The Yankees meet the Red Sox on Friday for their first series in the post-Jeter era. Two reporters for The New York Times, one a a die-hard Red Sox fan, below, and the other a die-hard Yankees fan, weigh in on whether the flame can be rekindled. It’s up to you.

headline: Review: ‘In Country,’ Young Men Play at Fighting in Vietnam
text: “In Country” is a stingy documentary. It gives you just enough information about its subjects, some Vietnam War re-enactors in Oregon, for you to be irked by them, but not enough to leave you confident that you’ve formed a fair opinion.

headline: Arca, Valued Facilitator, Steps Out Front
text: Crashes, whooshes, sampled screams. Mournful minor chords, dissolving into distortion or receding into single notes and silence. Deep throbs of bass under splintery percussion. Ghostly processionals. Zaps of static, metallic scrapes, hovering insectlike buzzes. Slowed-down, half-melted hip-hop beats. Floating falsetto melodies under siege from stop-and-start chords. A synthesized cumbia mixed as if its tune were being intermittently obscured by clouds. Breakneck drum programming under orchestral strings.

headline: On a Day for Good Scores at the Masters, Jordan Spieth Has a Great One
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Standing over his drive in the middle of the fairway on the par-5 15th hole at Augusta National Golf Club on Thursday, Jordan Spieth was eight under par for the day. Spieth, who is 21 years old, said he had no idea that the record for the lowest 18-hole score in Masters tournament history was nine-under 63.

headline: Cooper Union Inquiry Puts Nonprofits on Notice
text: In what should be a ringing alarm for nonprofit boards across the country long accustomed to minimal scrutiny or accountability, Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman of New York has signaled that the laissez-faire approach to nonprofit governance is over.

headline: SendGrid Account Breach Was Used to Attack Coinbase, a Bitcoin Exchange
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Hackers targeted SendGrid, a mass email service used by 180,000 companies including Uber, Pinterest, Spotify and Foursquare, to infiltrate Coinbase, one of the most popular Bitcoin exchanges.

headline: Booker, Mentored by Menendez, Assumes Role as His Defender During Legal Fight
text: In his days as mayor of Newark, Senator Cory A. Booker built a national image of himself as a model citizen, given to well-publicized acts of valor like helping his neighbors escape a house fire and saving a vulnerable dog from the bitter cold.

headline: Mexican Official Quits Over Helicopter Ride
text: MEXICO CITY — When a helicopter landed on a grassy patch in an exclusive suburb here on a recent Sunday morning, Ignacio Vizcaìno, a mathematician and aircraft enthusiast, snapped a few photos from his window — and set off the latest scandal to rock Mexico’s political class.

headline: Bronx Woman’s 10 Marriages, Not All of Them Over, Lead to Fraud Charges
text: The year 2002 was very busy for a young woman named Liana Kristina Barrientos.

headline: Georgia Says It Will Allow Hormones for Transgender Inmates
text: Less than a week after the Justice Department intervened in support of a transgender inmate’s lawsuit against Georgia, the state said Thursday that it had ended its blanket denial of new hormone therapy to transgender inmates and would provide them “constitutionally appropriate medical and mental health treatment.”

headline: Brought by Wild Neighbors, Deadly Bird Flu Attacks Turkey Flocks
text: A virulent, deadly flu virus has hit the nation’s turkey flock, forcing culling and quarantines that are disrupting trade with various countries.

headline: Black Immigrants Have Quadrupled Since 1980, Study Says
text: The number of black immigrants in the United States has more than quadrupled since 1980, a new study has found, and that group is expected to make up an increasing share of the nation’s black population in the decades ahead.

headline: Rivals Providence and Boston University Will Play for Frozen Four Title
text: BOSTON — They were impossible to miss, decked out in red, white and black Nebraska-Omaha apparel: the last fans standing at a North Station bar, four hours before the first semifinal game of the Frozen Four.

headline: Richard Dysart, 86, of ‘L.A. Law,’ Dies; Familiar as Authority Figure
text: Richard Dysart, a character actor who specialized in lawyers, doctors and other authority figures — most notably Leland McKenzie, the founding partner of the law firm McKenzie, Brackman, Chaney & Kuzak, on the soapy-serious prime-time drama “L.A. Law” — died on Sunday at his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 86.
