headline: Ukraine’s Parliament Moves to Shore Up Battered Economy
text: KIEV, Ukraine — In a blizzard of votes that highlighted Ukraine’s struggles, past and present, the Parliament adopted legislation on Thursday to ban all symbols and “propaganda” of Communism and Nazism and to overhaul the country’s notoriously corrupt and mismanaged natural gas market.

headline: New York Night Life Carries Perks, and Risks, for Athletes
text: It was, if nothing else, a feat of extraordinary endurance.

headline: Italy: Man Kills 3 at Court During Bankruptcy Hearing
text: A man at a hearing in a fraudulent bankruptcy opened fire in a Milan courthouse on Thursday, killing a judge, a lawyer and a co-defendant and wounding at least two others in an act of “cold premeditation,” Italian officials said. After the hearing began, the officials said, the man, Claudio Giardiello, 57, shot two of his co-defendants, killing one of them, and also killed a lawyer. He then went to the office of a bankruptcy judge and killed him, they said. The officials said they believed that the judge, Fernando Ciampi, had been involved in the bankruptcy case. Another man was shot in the leg. In all, Mr. Giardiello fired 13 shots, they said. “He acted with cold premeditation,” said Tommaso Buonanno, a prosecutor. Mr. Giardiello fled on a scooter but was arrested later in Vimercate, about 19 miles from Milan, where, the police said, he had intended to kill at least one other person. It was unclear how Mr. Giardiello managed to carry a gun into the courthouse. He may have entered through a separate entrance for lawyers and court employees using a false ID, officials said.

headline: Tiger Woods’s Driving, Usually a Strength, Deserts Him
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — An ex-Stanford standout carded a one-under 71 at the Masters on Thursday and described his round as “a minor miracle.” It was Tom Watson, not another former Cardinal, Tiger Woods, whose opening-round 73 was a few sleights of hand short of magical.

headline: South Carolina Police Shooting Seen as Crime Strategy Gone Awry
text: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — It was after dark about five years ago, on a downtrodden strip of this city, when Alicia Delesline stopped trusting the police in the place where she had lived her entire life.

headline: Restraint of Pregnant Inmates Is Said to Persist in New York Despite Ban
text: If you go by the official records of the New York State prison system, Tina Tinen’s account of being shackled right before and immediately after the birth of her son is fiction.

headline: In Aftermath of East Village Blast, Business Owners Pledge to Rebuild
text: They knew each other in passing, as customers, as neighbors, linked only by the fact that their businesses shared the same few blocks of the East Village in Manhattan.

headline: With Break-In, Seeking to Change Locks and Leadership at a New York Korean Group
text: The aging Korean rebels made their way up the emergency staircase in an office building in Chelsea and gathered outside the locked door. Power awaited on the other side.

headline: Review: ‘Wolf Hall,’ the Stage Version, Untangles Tudor History With Relish
text: And now let’s settle in for a really, really good gossip.

headline: Raising the Bar
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — A message from the “It’s 5:00 Somewhere” Department: Party hearty, people. T.G.I.F. Get down. Get back up again. This puzzle by David Phillips encourages you to start out by getting your BOOGIE on and promises that, by the end, you’ll be SOTTED.

headline: NATO Caps Size of Russia’s Mission After Internal Reports of Espionage
text: WASHINGTON — For a year after the North Atlantic Treaty Organization cut back its cooperation with Russia as punishment for the country’s incursions into Ukraine, Russia’s NATO mission has seemed curiously impervious to the deteriorating ties.

headline: De Blasio and Schumer Take the Subway. Many Fellow Riders Shrug.
text: The well-dressed visitors had been at it for several minutes now, treating a semicaptive audience at the south end of an R train car to firm handshakes, a stack of fliers and a filibuster on the gas tax from New York’s senior senator.

headline: Re-enacting the Battle of Appomattox Court House
text: American Civil War re-enactors gathered in Virginia to commemorate the 1865 Battle of Appomattox Court House.

headline: Civil War’s Lessons Resound 150 Years Later
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — The park ranger spoke eloquently of “the struggle over the meaning of this country,” a brass band in Civil War uniforms played “Yankee Doodle” and “Dixie,” and a student from China was thrilled to pose for a snapshot between Gen. Ulysses S. Grant and Gen. Robert E. Lee, who had just formally accepted the terms of surrender.

headline: Review: In ‘In the Courtyard,’ a Neurotic Retiree Bonds With the Janitor
text: Depression, dementia, disillusion — they’re all there in “In the Courtyard,” a gently meandering study of two troubled souls who form a cross-generational bond.

headline: Congressional Hearing in Brazil Disrupted by Rodent Invasion
text: A protester in Brazil disrupted a congressional hearing on Thursday by releasing five rodents as an official from the governing party arrived to answer questions about corruption at the state-run oil company, Petrobras.

headline: Suspect’s Mental Ability Is at Fore as Jurors in Patz Trial Prepare to Get Case
text: After 10 weeks of testimony, both sides rested on Thursday in the trial of the former store clerk charged with killing 6-year-old Etan Patz. Closing arguments in the case are set for Monday.

headline: Review: ‘Kill Me Three Times,’ and Then Some, Set in a Murderous Surf Town
text: It’s of course unfair to blame Quentin Tarantino for all the terrible movies he has inspired, but enough already!

headline: New York Plans Upgrades for Housing Projects to Reduce Emissions and Utility Costs
text: New York City’s public housing projects are set to undertake a large-scale energy saving program to try to cut down on both greenhouse gas emissions and a utility bill that now reaches $576 million a year.

headline: Past Drug Charges Derail a Law Student’s Education
text: David Powers came out of a drug rehabilitation program about 15 years ago hungry to swing his life in a significantly different direction. And that he did.

headline: Review: ‘Reset,’ an Elliptical Tale of Breaking With the Past
text: The idea is a bit better than the execution of “Reset,” an opaque and offbeat story of a man who repeatedly returns to his hometown with the intention of avoiding anyone he once knew.

headline: Wisconsin Agency Bans Activism on Climate
text: CHICAGO — A small Wisconsin agency that manages thousands of acres of state land has banned its 10 employees from working on climate change issues while on the job.

headline: Bernice Tannenbaum, Who Fought U.N. Resolution on Zionism, Dies at 101
text: Bernice S. Tannenbaum, a former president of Hadassah who played a leading role in the fight against a United Nations resolution in the 1980s equating Zionism with racism, died on April 6 at her home in Manhattan. She was 101.

headline: Twitter Says It Suspended 10,000 ISIS-Linked Accounts in One Day
text: Activists and experts who monitor the Twitter traffic of the Islamic State and its supporters noticed something odd last week when many accounts suddenly disappeared.

headline: Senators Continue Late Rush Toward Playoffs
text: On Feb. 1, the eighth-seeded Washington Capitals were tied with the Rangers for the Metropolitan Division’s third spot at 60 points — 8 ahead of ninth-place Florida, 9 in front of Philadelphia and 11 on top of Ottawa.

headline: California Deputies Are Taped Beating Man in Chase
text: LOS ANGELES — A group of San Bernardino sheriff’s deputies were captured on videotape Thursday repeatedly pummeling and kicking a suspect after he fell off his horse at the end of a bizarre chase through rough California desert.

headline: Review: ‘The Sisterhood of Night,’ a Dark Tale of Small-Town Hysteria
text: Early on, “The Sisterhood of Night” feels so familiar that it’s quite a feat when the film turns out to be this tense. Even with sections recalling both “The Crucible” and an “Afterschool Special,” it still fashions a story that’s fairly fresh and often absorbing.

headline: In Dominant Return to Mets, Matt Harvey Doesn’t Miss a Beat
text: WASHINGTON — For his first official day back on the mound for the Mets on Thursday, Matt Harvey wanted everything to be just right. So before the game, he played D.J.

headline: Kayahan, Turkish Singer-Songwriter, Dies at 66
text: ISTANBUL — Kayahan, one of Turkey’s most popular singers and songwriters, died here on April 3. He was 66.

headline: Review: In ‘Clouds of Sils Maria,’ a Celebration Turns Into a Memorial
text: For some young performers, blockbusters are where talent and ambition go to die. For others, like Kristen Stewart, the star of that international juggernaut called the “Twilight Saga,” big movies can be a good place to hide out while they’re raking it in. In the superb French film “Clouds of Sils Maria,” Ms. Stewart plays an ordinary American abroad, a new-age, pop-savvy Daisy Miller who, with expressive intelligence that few blockbusters allow, makes a passionate argument for the kinds of movies the actress herself is best known for. Ms. Stewart has rightly won a lot of attention for her performance (the French film industry rewarded her with its highest honor, a César), but it would be a mistake to think of this as some sort of career rescue mission.

headline: Blue Jays’ Early Barrage Sinks Yankees
text: For 2015, C. C. Sabathia has moved into the locker space at the rear of the Yankees’ clubhouse that once belonged to Derek Jeter. With question marks surrounding their starting rotation, the Yankees would welcome it if Sabathia could also fill a role once handled by Jeter — that of a stabilizing force on the field.

headline: Geoffrey Lewis, Actor in Clint Eastwood Films, Dies at 79
text: Geoffrey Lewis, an actor who appeared alongside Clint Eastwood in a string of films in the 1970s and ’80s, died on April 7 near his home in Los Angeles. He was 79.

headline: Review: In ‘Song From the Forest,’ Louis Sarno Links Africa and America
text: “There’s no future here.” That’s what a local tells the ethnomusicologist Louis Sarno as he prepares to bring his son, Samedi, to the United States from the Central African Republic for the first time. That trip is part of “Song From the Forest,” a languorous documentary about Mr. Sarno’s relationship with the Bayaka, a Pygmy group whose music he started documenting decades ago. (A memoir written by Mr. Sarno that has the same title as this movie has already been made into a feature film, “Oka!”)

headline: Maryland: Census Bureau Guard Is Critically Wounded
text: A gunman critically wounded a guard at the Census Bureau headquarters in Suitland, a suburb of Washington, on Thursday before leading the police on a chase that ended with a shootout in the District of Columbia’s busy H Street Northeast corridor, the authorities said. The man kidnapped his wife in Northeast Washington before driving to the Census Bureau, where the guard saw the couple fighting in the car, the authorities said. After shooting the guard, the man drove back to Washington, where he was chased by the police before being shot by an officer, officials said.

headline: The Agony and the Ecstasy of Kanye West
text: For over a decade, the rap superstar has made music that pushes boundaries, courts controversy and divides critics. Now, the man who has compared himself to Jesus and Steve Jobs just wants to make clothes for the masses.

headline: A Chef’s Advice for Preparing His Five Favorite Springtime Ingredients
text: After six years of what he refers to as “passion and patience,” Eric Canino — the chef behind La Voile, the restaurant at La Réserve Ramatuelle, a luxurious hotel overlooking the Mediterranean, situated in the South of France just outside St. Tropez — finally achieved his first Michelin star last February. “I felt a profound happiness,” he says. Today, La Voile opens for its first season since Canino and his team earned their star.

headline: The Very Best of Kanye West
text: In the cover story for T’s Culture issue, Jon Caramanica joins Kanye West on his quest to bring high fashion to the masses, tagging along as his first sportswear collection for Adidas is introduced and getting the lowdown on his now-infamous brush with Ralph Lauren. Here, in anticipation of West’s seventh studio album, reportedly titled “So Help Me God,” Caramanica and T’s editors share their favorite tracks (and some videos) from the rapper’s catalog, a selection of which can be heard in a Spotify playlist.

headline: At Trevor Noah Show, Happy Fans and an Array of Targets
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — Trevor Noah’s first stand-up comedy show since being named the next host of “The Daily Show” was about racism and the trials of coming to America. He talked about everything, audience members said, except for the deluge of criticism that has followed his selection as heir to Jon Stewart’s satirical throne on Comedy Central.

headline: New York Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Parking Rules Suspended Through Saturday
text: Because of Good Friday (Orthodox) and Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Friday and Saturday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Illinois: Tornadoes Kill at Least 1
text: A band of tornadoes swept across northern Illinois on Thursday, killing at least one person, trapping more than a dozen inside a collapsed building and causing significant damage to homes and businesses, according to local news media reports. The National Weather Service confirmed at least one tornado in the region on Twitter, urging people to “seek shelter immediately.” Initial reports suggested that the northwestern corner of DeKalb County was hardest hit by the storm. It was there that one person was killed in the small town of Fairdale, about 65 miles northwest of Chicago, according to ABC 7 Chicago. In the town of Rochelle, a tornado was said to have struck a restaurant called Grubsteakers, trapping 14 people inside the collapsed building, according to The Daily Chronicle, a newspaper in DeKalb. It reported that all 14 were rescued by firefighters, who were conducting house-to-house checks in the town to make sure there were no further injuries. The National Weather Service issued a severe thunderstorm warning for Cook, DuPage and Will Counties in Illinois and Lake County, Ind. It warned residents of possible wind gusts of up to 60 miles per hour.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
text: 7:25 P.M. (HBO Signature) GOOD NIGHT, AND GOOD LUCK (2005) George Clooney, who directed from a script he wrote with Grant Heslov, burnishes the legend of Edward R. Murrow, the CBS newsman known for his journalistic integrity. In an Oscar-nominated performance, David Strathairn portrays Murrow during the political turmoil that journalists coped with in the 1940s and ’50s — particularly Murrow’s war of words and images with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin. Mr. Clooney plays Murrow’s producer and professional partner, Fred Friendly; Frank Langella is his boss, William Paley; and thanks to archival footage, Senator McCarthy plays himself. “ ‘Good Night, and Good Luck’ is a passionate, thoughtful essay on power, truth-telling and responsibility,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “The title evokes Murrow’s trademark signoff, and I can best sum up my own response by recalling the name of his flagship program: See it now.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “They just rolled up and bothered me for no reason and searched me. They serve and protect when they feel like serving and protecting. But when they feel like harassing, they do that.”

headline: Corrections: April 10, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: A Sabres Fan’s Lament: They Can’t Lose Them All
text: As a native Buffalonian, consigned by geographic fate to root for the Bills and the Sabres for four decades and counting, I’ve had more than a few occasions to taste the agony of defeat.

headline: Exiled Children of Tibet
text: SNEAK PEEK: This week Lens is featuring a selection of photographers attending the New York Portfolio Review.

headline: Access to Medical Records
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Revolution Lives!
text: Beyond all the talk of centrifuges and enrichment capacities, President Obama’s deal with Iran is really a giant gamble on the nature of the Iranian regime. The core question is: Are the men who control that country more like Lenin or are they more like Gorbachev? Do they still fervently believe in their revolution and would they use their postsanctions wealth to export it and destabilize their region? Or have they lost faith in their revolution? Will they use a deal as a way to rejoin the community of nations?

headline: Benefits of a Carbon Fee
No Firing Pins, Please, as the N.R.A. Gathers
text: Seventy-thousand people are expected to attend the National Rifle Association’s convention opening on Friday in Tennessee, but they won’t be allowed to carry firearms in one of the main convention venues. This may run counter to the N.R.A.’s ideas about carrying guns everywhere, from elementary schools to workplaces.

headline: Where Government Excels
text: As Republican presidential hopefuls trot out their policy agendas — which always involve cutting taxes on the rich while slashing benefits for the poor and middle class — some real new thinking is happening on the other side of the aisle. Suddenly, it seems, many Democrats have decided to break with Beltway orthodoxy, which always calls for cuts in “entitlements.” Instead, they’re proposing that Social Security benefits actually be expanded.

headline: Improving How College Campuses Handle Rape Cases
text: To the Editor:

headline: Connecting With Iran
Global Threats to Net Neutrality
text: The Federal Communications Commission recently adopted strong net neutrality rules that should prevent cable and phone companies from creating fast and slow lanes on the Internet. But policy makers in other parts of the world, particularly in Europe and India, are considering very different kinds of rules that could hurt consumers and start-up Internet businesses.

headline: Soaring College Tuition: What Is to Blame?
Why Pilots Still Matter
text: SOMERVILLE, Mass. — IN the two weeks since the crash of Germanwings Flight 9525, there has been no lack of commentary about the failures and future of piloted aviation — much of it frustratingly ill informed. Planes are already so automated, consensus has it, that it’s only a matter of time before pilots are engineered out of the picture completely. And isn’t the best way to prevent another Andreas Lubitz to replace him with a computer, or a remote pilot, somewhere on the ground? Cue the aeronautics professor or university scientist who will blithely assert that yes, we are well on our way to a pilotless future.

headline: China’s Statement on Its Construction in the South China Sea
text: During a regularly scheduled news conference in Beijing on Thursday, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokeswoman was asked about the infrastructure China has been constructing around reefs, rocks and shoals in waters of the South China Sea that are claimed by other countries. The question arose in response to a series of satellite photographs released by the Center for Strategic and International Studies, based in Washington, depicting Mischief Reef in the Spratly Islands, which the Chinese call Meiji Reef in the Nansha Islands.

headline: China Blocks Yangtze Dam Project, Activists Say
text: BEIJING — The Chinese Ministry of Environmental Protection has issued an order preventing dam-building on a stretch of the upper Yangtze River, according to environmental activists, that will result in the scrapping of a proposed hydroelectric dam near the western metropolis of Chongqing that had been opposed for years by environmentalists.

headline: Should Students Sit on Sexual Assault Panels?
text: It was a bland bit of guidance from the Department of Education, cast in legal language and tucked into a footnote two-thirds of the way through a 46-page document about how colleges and universities should address sexual assault on campus.

headline: When Work and Sleep Conflict, Work Wins
text: There are a lot of advantages to earning more money, but getting a good night’s sleep may not be one of them.

headline: Amid a Woeful Circus, Basketball’s Lowly Strivers Carry the Knicks
text: Young women in revealing outfits use slingshots to fire cheap novelties into crowds of beckoning spectators. Two fans have a dance-off at center court for the cruise vacation awarded for the less humiliating performance. A D.J. in an orange blazer blasts a pulsing, party-time beat that causes involuntary nods of the head.

headline: For Mentally Ill Inmates at Rikers Island, a Cycle of Jail and Hospitals
text: It was not a particularly violent crime that sent Michael Megginson to Rikers Island. He was arrested for stealing a cellphone.

headline: Schumer Is Squeezed on Various Sides Over Iran Deal
text: WASHINGTON — In an event as rare as garden tomatoes ripening in January, Senator Charles E. Schumer has little to say.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: April 10
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images of a Coast Guard cutter, a Success Academy charter school and mini-golf at the Jewish Children’s Museum in Brooklyn.

headline: Once Trapped Atop Coney Island Cyclone, but Forever Stuck on It
text: Eighty-five feet above the belly of Brooklyn, the very top of the Coney Island Cyclone offers an unmatched view of a place that seems to always teeter on the brink of reinvention. Amusement park operators, roller coaster visionaries, real-estate developers and a hurricane or two have all come and gone, grasping at Coney Island’s down-at-the-heels glory.

headline: Beijing, With an Eye on the South China Sea, Adds Patrol Ships
text: SINGAPORE — China is rapidly building coast guard ships, the vessels that China most commonly uses for patrols in the South China Sea, and in the last three years has increased the number of ships in that category 25 percent, a new report by the United States Navy says.

headline: Her Stinging Critiques Propel Young Adult Best Sellers
text: John Green still vividly recalls the opening line of a stinging critique that his editor, Julie Strauss-Gabel, delivered after reading an early draft of his novel “The Fault in Our Stars.”

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Ask Well: Vigorous Exercise for the Knee-Challenged
text: Question:

headline: China Is Said to Use Powerful New Weapon to Censor Internet
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Late last month, China began flooding American websites with a barrage of Internet traffic in an apparent effort to take out services that allow China’s Internet users to view websites otherwise blocked in the country.

headline: New York Today: Spring, Undersea
text: Good morning on this foggy Friday.

headline: My Unveiling Ceremony
text: CAIRO — I wore the hijab — a form of dress that comprises a head scarf and usually also clothing that covers the whole body except for the face and hands — for nine years. Put more honestly: I wore the hijab for nine years and spent eight of them trying to take it off.

headline: G.E. to Retreat From Finance in Post-Crisis Reorganization
text: For decades, General Electric was happy to reap the enormous profits that arose from its finance arm as it swelled into one of the country’s biggest lenders.

headline: When a General Kills a General
text: The death toll among general officers during the Civil War was staggering. Because the prevalent military thinking often placed a general at the head of the army, they were killed leading hopeless charges (Lewis Armistead), engaging in skirmishes (J.E.B. Stuart), reconnoitering occupied territory (Thomas “Stonewall” Jackson), mounting impossible offenses (Patrick Cleburne) and sometimes simply sitting their horses (John F. Reynolds). The cost was incalculable; here, after all, were the officers who, political favoritism aside, were presumably the best qualified to achieve their respective armies’ objectives. And yet, they fell in alarming profusion. At the Battle of Franklin alone, six Confederate generals were killed and seven were wounded.

headline: On Set | Kanye West
text: The photographer Juergen Teller takes us behind the scenes in London, where he photographed the boundary-pushing artist for the cover of T’s culture issue.

headline: A Federal Judge and a Hunger Strike Take on the Government’s Immigrant Detention Facilities
text: Since a surge of asylum seekers from Central America began to cross the U.S. border last spring, the Obama administration has adopted a policy to house thousands of them in detention centers. This includes the construction of new facilities specifically for women and children, who have been forced to live for months at a time in conditions that closely resemble prison, in some cases surrounded by high fencing and barbed wire, under the supervision of armed guards. They work for as little as $1 a day, with restricted access to the outside world.

headline: On a Gay Cruise, Just One of the Guys
text: Two men in revealing white singlets walked into a piano bar while the cabaret singer Natalie Douglas belted away on stage, accompanied by Brian Nash, a fixture on the New York City piano bar scene. The men were hardly out of place, though — a couple of other men in white shorts and bunny ears were already there.

headline: Literary Louisiana
text: A few months ago, I pulled off I-10 and stopped at a gas station in LaPlace, La. As I gazed at the vodka and meat pies for sale inside, I realized that I was home. Or at least some crucial nugget of what I call “me” was home. Although I haven’t lived in south Louisiana for going on seven years, the time I put in there, soaking up the land and seascape and sky, and, most of all, the spiritual yearning that exists cheek-by-jowl with drive-through daiquiri shops, poverty and Mardi Gras, changed my perceptions profoundly. Louisiana — south Louisiana, in particular — may as well be its own separate country, a place where the residents just happen to speak American English, except when they’re speaking Cajun French or Yat or some other regional dialect.

headline: Remains From Lincoln’s Last Day
text: Imagine him in the last week of his life, 150 years ago this month. Shuffling, clothes hanging loosely on the 6-foot-4-inch frame, that tinny voice, a face much older than someone of 56. “I am a tired man,” he said. “Sometimes I think I am the tiredest man on earth.”

headline: Fan Dashes Across Track During Practice at Chinese Grand Prix
text: Crossing the street in Shanghai traffic can be treacherous. During practice for the Chinese Grand Prix, it is downright lunacy.

headline: Today in Politics: Guns Give Republicans a Reprieve From Discord
text: Good Friday morning from Washington. Former Gov. Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island says he’s considering running for president, and Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia sees Lee’s surrender to Grant as a model for national grace. President Obama continues his trip to Panama, by way of Jamaica and Bob Marley‘s house, and the friendship between Senator Marco Rubio of Florida and Jeb Bush, the state’s former governor, may be tested in a Republican primary. In Tennessee, however, the Republican candidates and potential candidates will have plenty to agree with at the annual National Rifle Association leadership conference.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: The Gnostic Scriptures
text: Have you ever wondered whether this world is wrong for you? A death, a lover’s unabashed indifference, the sufferings of innocents and the absence of definitive answers — don’t these imply some hollowness or deficiency? For my part, the wrongness struck when I was 4 years old. I was at my grandmother’s house, and I saw a cat torture a baby bird.

headline: Re: Prison Planet
text: “Oh, the company we’re keeping!” lamented one commenter, after reading our March 29 issue, which featured two articles on prisons in the United States and abroad. The package, which included a mapped breakdown of international incarceration rates and other relevant data, “gives us a much needed context to understand where we, the U.S., stand in relation to the practices of other nations,” another reader commented.

headline: ‘Child Holding Potato’
text: Rick Barot’s poem reminds me how often I’ve turned to art to contend with difficult knowledge. Here, what stays with the speaker is an image from a single painting, “the raw starch,” “the dirt” — feeling finding its just articulation there. Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.

headline: The Scar Story Nobody Expected to Hear
text: My classmate Tara wanted to introduce me to some of her friends from school, so not long ago she invited me to watch an American football game with them. We were in downtown Denver, watching a game between the Broncos and another team — I don’t remember who. There were lots of TV screens and pool tables and guys in baseball caps. I had never watched American football before. Eight of us sat around the table, having drinks and dinner.

headline: How to Beat a Polygraph Test
text: “A polygraph is nothing more than a psychological billy club used to coerce and intimidate people,” says Doug Williams, a former Oklahoma City police detective and polygraph examiner who for 36 years has trained people to pass the lie-detector test. The first step is not to be intimidated. Most tests include two types of questions: relevant ones about a specific incident (“Did you leak classified information to The New York Times?”) and broader so-called control questions (“Have you ever lied to anyone who trusted you?”). The test assumes that an innocent person telling the truth will have a stronger reaction to the control questions than to the relevant ones. Before your test, practice deciphering between the two question types. “Go to the beach” when you hear a relevant question, Williams says. Calm yourself before answering by imagining gentle waves and warm sand.

headline: The Last Coal Miners of Spain
text: Coal is on the way out in Europe, and it is dying a slow and ugly death. Its decline has been hastened by competition from the renewable-energy industry, cheaper imported coal from Russia and the United States and new air-quality regulations passed by the European Union. The death throes have been especially violent in Spain, where the national coal-mining industry was created by royal order in 1621 to exploit the coal basin at Villanueva del Rio y Minas in Seville. In 1990, 167 coal mines employed about 40,000 workers. Today there are roughly 40 active mines, employing fewer than 4,000 miners. The struggling industry has long been supported by state subsidies, but under a recent E.U. agreement, all subsidies must expire by 2018.

headline: Daily Report: China Is Said to Use Powerful New Weapon to Censor Internet
text: Late last month, China began flooding American websites with a barrage of Internet traffic in an apparent effort to take out services that allow China’s Internet users to view websites otherwise blocked in the country, Nicole Perlroth reports.

headline: Morning Agenda: G.E. to Sell Bulk of Finance Unit
text: G.E. TO SELL BULK OF FINANCE UNIT | General Electric, under Jeffrey Immelt, is taking its most radical step yet in the transformation of the conglomerate: the sale of most of its finance arm, GE Capital, within the next two years.  Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced report in DealBook that the huge asset sales will simplify the company and potentially free it of the regulatory burden that comes with being a financial institution that is too big to fail.

headline: Richie Benaud, Commentator Whose Native Tongue Was Cricket, Dies at 84
text: The path from the cricket field to the commentary box is well trod, but never with greater distinction than by Richie Benaud, known to many as the voice of cricket, who died in Sydney, Australia, on Friday. He was 84.

headline: As a Daughter Becomes a Teenager, a Mother Becomes a Vampire Novelist
text: Why would a Yale professor write nine full-length vampire novels that only one person will ever read? Love? Desperation? There’s not much difference when it comes to children.

headline: Pakistani Lawmakers Urge Diplomacy in Yemen Conflict but Decline Combat Role
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani Parliament voted on Friday to stay out of the conflict in Yemen, but it urged the government led by Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif to play a diplomatic role in defusing the crisis.

headline: ‘Bad Faith,’ by Paul A. Offit
text: On June 17, 1977, Rita and Doug Swan noticed that Matthew, their 15-month-old child, was having difficulty walking. Both parents were raised in the Christian Science faith, and they called a Christian Science practitioner, Jeanne Laitner, to pray for the child. Rita’s prior experience with an illness of her own is relevant to this choice: When repeated prayer “treatments” failed to give her relief from a painful ovarian cyst, she allowed physicians to operate. But she was viewed as having abandoned her faith. She was no longer permitted to lead church meetings or teach Sunday school. To Rita this loss of community was profound, and perhaps explains why, as her baby was getting worse, she did not seek medical care.

headline: Exploring the Fun Side of China’s War on Corruption
text: For officials under scrutiny, China’s corruption crackdown is no laughing matter. But for many others, it is.

headline: David Treuer’s ‘Prudence’
text: The poetics of damage permeates ­David Treuer’s elegantly bitter fourth novel, “Prudence,” which unites a distinctly modern sociopolitical perspective with a more old-fashioned moral rigor about the ­consequences of emotional cowardice, complicity and repression. On the evidence here, Treuer believes in bravery. Moreover, he believes that a lack of bravery isn’t just sad, it’s deeply destructive — and the destruction can’t be undone. Cowardice can kill people. While there’s much hope in this lyrical novel, as evidenced by the freedom with which it examines some of the more transgressive interstices of race, sexual orientation and gender, there’s also an obdurate insistence on taking responsibility, particularly if one is a man. Treuer’s perspective is bracingly tough. This ­author values honor. Who dares to take that kind of stance anymore?

headline: A ‘Darker Narrative’ of Print’s Future From Clay Shirky
text: A column I wrote last month on the enduring importance of the printed newspaper to The Times drew a response from an incisive thinker about media and technology, Clay Shirky. Mr. Shirky, an author and a professor at New York University, wrote a groundbreaking blog post in 2009 that radically changed my thinking about the future of newspapers then; in an email exchange with me this week, he provides a few more challenging ideas.

headline: What’s On This Week Around The World
text: Berlin

headline: ‘The Poser,’ by Jacob Rubin
text: If a novel can be measured by its imaginative precision, the shrewdness of its characterization and the authority of its prose, then “The Poser,” Jacob Rubin’s smart and absorbing debut, claims its power early and rarely surrenders it. Before the first chapter is over, the narrator, the master impressionist Giovanni Bernini, remembers deducing from the “interior mystery” of his mother’s eyes “how much she hated the rules of bodies, that one person could be only one and that certain spaces would always separate us”; in a quiet classroom he hears the “mouse noise of pencils”; of his work selling train tickets, which he experiences as a satisfying daily masquerade, he observes, “It carried on past dinner when I read a popular novel in bed and would live on soon enough, I hoped, in a house of my own populated by a ticket seller’s wife and ticket seller’s children, a family who would kiss and be kissed by me and who would never meet, as long as they lived, the heaps of sleeping strangers inside their man.” Imaginative precision, shrewdness of characterization, authority of prose: check, check and check.

headline: Renovation vs. Relocation in Retirement
text: SHOULD you downsize and move to a new neighborhood? Or renovate the family residence to suit your retirement needs and lock in for the long term? It is one of the most vexing questions older people face as they plan the shift from a working life to retirement.

headline: I.R.S. Is Looking Into Captive Insurance Shelters
text: It’s tax time again, which means many people will be writing checks to the Internal Revenue Service. But not a lawyer in Los Angeles, who last year put all of his earnings, $840,000, into a tax shelter and plans to put $1 million in this year. He doesn’t have to pay any income tax.

headline: Blueprint for a Bag
text: On May 1, the Whitney Museum of American Art in Manhattan will reopen at a new downtown space designed by Renzo Piano. To commemorate the unveiling, the architect and Max Mara have created a limited-edition bag that mirrors the steel ribbing and graphic lines of the building’s bluish-gray facade.

headline: ‘The Island of Dr. Libris’ and ‘Finding Serendipity’
text: It’s a standard beach-read setup: Young Billy Gillfoyle thinks he is going to spend a dull summer at a cabin by a lake, watching his parents’ marriage sink. But in “The Island of Dr. Libris,” Chris Grabenstein has more devious plans in mind for young Billy. Deprived of TV and Internet access, Billy starts working his way through the cabin’s extensive library. As he reads about the trials of Hercules, he hears distant sounds of battle coming from the island in the middle of the lake. As he reads “The Merry Adventures of Robin Hood,” the cries across the water take on a suspiciously Olde English flavor. Rowing out to investigate, he discovers that whatever classic he reads manifests itself on the island. “The Three Musketeers,” “Jack and the Beanstalk,” “Tom Sawyer,” “Journey to the Center of the Earth” — they all spew up their dramatis personae into a chaotic jumble of swashbuckling anachronism. Billy and his asthmatic pal, Walter, have to figure out what’s summoning these fictional foes and heroes before their summer reading list gets deadly.

headline: ‘The Alex Crow,’ by Andrew Smith
text: Andrew Smith was awarded a 2015 Michael L. Printz Honor for “Grasshopper Jungle,” a novel about giant praying mantises with libidos like teenage boys, and a teenage boy with a libido like . . . well, a teenage boy. So it makes perfect sense that he has produced another tale with premises just as ridiculous. Thankfully, “The Alex Crow” proves once again that Smith does ridiculous better than most.

headline: Alice Hoffman’s ‘Nightbird’
text: Alice Hoffman’s latest book comes loaded with enchantments. Some are explicitly fantastical: a curse from a ­brokenhearted witch with real-world consequences, a winged boy who learns the language of birds. But some of the magic is of a subtler kind — hours that seem to mysteriously vanish in shared conversation, loneliness transformed by the ­alchemy of new friendship.

headline: Bespoke Living, With Michael Ian Black
text: When Michael Ian Black and Martha Hagen-Black began planning a new 3,800-square-foot home for their family in Redding, Conn., it wasn’t because they needed more space or wanted to relocate.

headline: Democrats Keep Lead in Party Identification
text: The party identification of American voters was one of the most hotly debated topics among analysts before the 2012 presidential election. Many Republicans thought there were roughly equal numbers of Democrats and Republicans, and so doubted polls showing President Obama with the lead.

headline: Explaining Subway Behavior to a Child
text: Dear Diary:

headline: ISIS Strikes Iraqi Town, Exacting Deadly Toll
text: BAGHDAD — Islamic State fighters launched a heavy attack on government-held territory in Anbar Province late on Thursday and on Friday, killing 25 Iraqi police officers and soldiers, and then 15 family members of local police officers, according to Iraqi officials.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
text: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: British Invasion
text: Hilary Mantel’s novels about Thomas Cromwell and the court of Henry VIII, “Wolf Hall” and “Bring Up the Bodies,” each won the Man Booker Prize. Next up, the Emmy and Tony Awards?

headline: JooHee Yoon’s ‘Beastly Verse,’ and More
text: Poems don’t necessarily need pictures, nor pictures poems. But children — for whom magic is real and logic overrated — love and need both. In three handsome new poetry collections for children, word and image energize and illuminate each other, becoming journeys for the eye and ear.

headline: Pakistani Militant Leader Tied to 2008 Mumbai Attacks Is Freed on Bail
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — In a move that drew furious condemnation from India, a Pakistani high court released on bail on Friday a militant commander accused of orchestrating the 2008 attacks in Mumbai that killed more than 160 people.

headline: Through a Touch-Screen Looking Glass
text: As Hollywood has repeatedly shown, dressing up well-worn stories in shiny packages can gain another generation of fans. App designers are now taking a turn at the reboot game with some of literature’s most beloved characters. Public-domain works have appeal because, with time-tested narratives in place, software makers can focus on creating a fresh storytelling experience aided by technology.

headline: An Extension Sends Tax Season Into Overtime
text: April 15, that dreaded date, is less than a week away. So if you haven’t filed your federal income tax return yet out of simple procrastination, it goes without saying that you should do so as soon as possible.

headline: Islanders Fans Prepare for Brooklyn
text: As the regular season winds down in the N.H.L., Islanders fans are preparing for the team’s move to Barclays Center next season after 43 years at Nassau Coliseum.

headline: The Laffer Swerve
text: Jim Tankersley has a good article on Arthur Laffer’s never-stronger influence on the Republican party, with just one seriously misleading statement:

headline: Transcendent Islanders Moments at the Nassau Coliseum
text: I am working up a rush of nostalgia during the Islanders’ final spring at Nassau Coliseum. The Isles, who clinched a postseason berth Thursday, play their last regular-season game at the Coliseum on Saturday against the Columbus Blue Jackets.

headline: Inside the List
text: The Sara Zone: Every now and then, The New York Times’s T magazine runs a photo essay showing various writers in the spaces where they work. The rooms are mostly what you’d expect: book-lined shelves, appealing clutter, sunny windows throwing light onto spacious desks (or, in Jesmyn Ward’s case, a bed). What they are not, by a long shot, is a “bordello circus tent.” Yet that’s just how Sara Gruen — whose latest novel, “At the Water’s Edge,” hits the hardcover fiction list at No. 6 — recently described the office above her garage to a newspaper in Asheville, N.C., where she lives; the room is lined with red-draped windows and doubles as a home for her parakeets, Troilus and Cressida, who fly free while she’s working. “It’s the Sara zone,” she told her hometown Citizen-Times. “I pull the curtains, and if the house is not on fire or somebody doesn’t have a leg hanging by a piece of skin, don’t bother me. I love it. It’s a little over the top.” So is Gruen herself, she conceded, when she gets deep in a project: Toward the end of the new novel, she went six weeks without leaving the house. “I sleep the book, I live the book, I don’t get my hair cut, I wear pajamas all day, I become agoraphobic,” she told the newspaper.

headline: Is Quincy Jones the Joan Didion of Men’s Wear?
text: The celebration of the older generation is not, it turns out, limited to women’s wear. Céline may have broken the Internet with its Joan Didion ads, Saint Laurent may have Joni Mitchell, and Dolce & Gabbana may have its grandmothers, but Buscemi, the high-end Made in Italy sneaker brand, has … Quincy Jones!

headline: History in Bloom in Bulgaria
text: Bulgaria, which is known for the rose oil used in fragrances, will hold its 112th Rose Festival, from June 5 to 8, in Kazanlak.

headline: Hillary Clinton to Announce 2016 Run for President on Sunday
text: The prolonged prologue to Hillary Rodham Clinton’s second run for the White House will reach its suspenseless conclusion on Sunday: The former secretary of state, senator and first lady is to announce that she will indeed seek the Democratic nomination for president.

text: In a ceremony last year at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, the Beatles’ original manager, Brian Epstein, was inducted  into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

text: New picture books include “The Grasshopper and the Ants” and “We Dig Worms!”

headline: The Power and Limits of Pope Francis’s Climate Change Campaign
text: I encourage you to read “The pope as messenger: making climate change a moral issue,” an essay on The Conversation website by Andy Hoffman, director of the Erb Institute at the University of Michigan, and Jenna White, a graduate student studying the role of religious institutions in shaping humanity’s response to global warming. (The Erb Institute pursues “a sustainable world through the power of business.”)

headline: Jordan Spieth Breaks 36-Hole Record at Masters and Then Shrugs
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — On Thursday, when Jordan Spieth shot a 64 and nearly set the record for the lowest 18-hole score at the Masters, the soft-spoken Spieth conceded he might have taken advantage of favorable conditions and a few lucky breaks.

text: Investors who take the time to wade through corporate reports on what their top executives are paid are all too familiar with the problem of information overload.

headline: 10 Sports Prizes Stranger Than the Masters’ Green Jacket
text: You would not wear one like it to your daughter’s wedding. Or to a job interview. Or probably not even to a backyard barbecue. But the Masters green jacket is one of the most coveted prizes in sports.

headline: How to Follow the Republicans
text: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: 1915: Germany Said to Seek Peace
text: LONDON — A cablegram to the ‘‘Daily Express’’ says that the Chicago ‘‘Tribune’s’’ Washington correspondent says that Germany has informally announced to the American Government her willingness to discuss peace.

headline: A Murderer at 14, Then a Lifer, Now a Man Pondering a Future
text: CHICAGO — Adolfo Davis admits he was a swaggering thug by the age of 14 as he roamed and dealt drugs with a South Side gang.

headline: Handshake for Obama and Raúl Castro of Cuba
text: PANAMA CITY, Panama — President Obama and President Raúl Castro of Cuba shook hands here on Friday night, and American officials said they would hold discussions on Saturday during a gathering of regional leaders, in the first full-fledged meeting between presidents of the United States and Cuba in more than a half-century.

headline: Paperback Row
text: BENDING ADVERSITY: Japan and the Art of Survival, by David Pilling. (Penguin, $18.) A magnitude-9 earthquake hit Japan in 2011, creating a deadly tsunami and triggering a nuclear plant meltdown. Taking these disasters as a starting point, Pilling, The Financial Times’s Tokyo bureau chief from 2002 to 2008, engages with the social, spiritual, financial and political life of contemporary Japan to make sense of this “stubbornly resistant nation with a history of overcoming successive waves of adversity.”

headline: David Krone Leaves Latest Washington Stint, Quietly
text: David Krone used to make a more action-packed exit.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Season 5: Where We Left Off
text: “Game of Thrones” is returning for its fifth season on Sunday, you might have heard, riding a wave of the kind of intense anticipation usually reserved for royal offspring and new Apple products.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE SYMPATHIZER, by Viet Thanh Nguyen. (Grove, $26.) Nguyen’s tragicomic debut novel fills a void in Vietnam War literature, giving a voice to the Vietnamese and compelling the rest of us to look at the events of 40 years ago in a new light.

text: When it comes to attack ads, Republicans are clearly “Ready for Hillary.”

headline: The Meatball Shop’s Daniel Holzman at Home
text: In the kitchen of his tenement apartment in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, the restaurateur Daniel Holzman has an open cupboard with Mason jars of pickled ramps, carrots, trumpet mushrooms and Jerusalem artichokes that he put up himself last year. “My stock is low because I’ve been eating them all winter,” he said.

headline: Videos Show Tornado in Illinois
text: A large tornado touched down on Thursday night near the town of Rochelle in northern Illinois. Several people were trapped and injured, and at least one person was killed.

headline: A Bartender With a Chartreuse Rebellious Streak
text: Jade Brown-Godfrey, a bartender who works at three bars in Manhattan, has a tattoo of a Chartreuse bottle on her left wrist. “Chartreuse and I, we’ve had a very good relationship,” she said. “It’s unique and fascinating.”

text: This week, Masha Gessen discusses “The Brothers”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Gretchen Rubin talks about “Better Than Before”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Overview: The Digital Business Era
text: The Accenture Technology Vision 2015 maps out five key trends: The Internet of Me, Outcome Economy, Platform (R)evolution, Intelligent Enterprise and Workforce Reimagined. How to sum it all up? It’s not just about you — or me, or anyone else in particular. It’s about all of us — The “We Economy”.

headline: Yemen’s Despair on Full Display in ‘Ruined’ City
text: ADEN, Yemen — Rooftop snipers have emptied the streets of this dusty seaside city and swelled its hospitals and morgues.

headline: Questions About Airbnb’s Responsibility After Attack by Dog
text: On Airbnb’s short and startling ride to global ubiquity, it has delighted many people. Hosts can rent rooms or their entire home and use the income to avoid having a day job, to make ends meet or to get into the bed-and-breakfast business without bothering with local licensing rules or all the usual red tape.

headline: Roast Beef Sandwich
text: Melissa Clark seasons a top loin with salt, pepper, garlic and rosemary before roasting to create the beginning of the perfect cold sandwich.

headline: A Roast Beef Sandwich the Way the Deli Makes It
text: A deli roast beef sandwich is a wonderful thing: a succulent tower of paper-thin slivers of rare red meat, perched on sliced seeded rye, slathered with mustard. Properly made, it threatens to be too tall to eat, but anyone with a firm grip will make the tender meat comply, squishing down just enough for that first juicy bite.

headline: Full-Floor at One57 Sells for $47,367,491
text: A full-floor aerie near the apex of the Extell Development Company’s blue-glass bastion of billionaires, One57, which offers nonpareil park, water and cityscape vistas, sold for $47,367,491.39 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: With New York Real Estate, Just $10 Million Starts to Sound Reasonable
text: Talking about the excesses of the New York real estate market can be like marveling over summer weather in Phoenix: The exceptional is so routine that you easily start to sound tedious recounting or obsessing over it. “On Thursday it was a bone-dry 108 degrees — as it was on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. This morning, a deal closed on a $30 million glass high-rise penthouse in Midtown Manhattan. Similar deals were cut three more times before lunch.” Of course $30 million is a fantastical number, arbitrarily deployed as rhetorical device — an enormous penthouse in a new glass high-rise on or around 57th Street would change hands for two or three times that, as we have all repeatedly been made aware.

headline: When Al Qaeda Stormed My City: Reporter’s Notebook
text: Saeed Al-Batati is a Yemeni freelance reporter who has reported for The Times from the city of Al Mukalla since 2014.

headline: Iran Conjures Strong Opinions in Tennessee, but Little Urgency
text: KINGSPORT, Tenn. — On Wednesday, the Arby’s Army, as the half-dozen men camped out in the corner booths styled themselves, was considering Iran. This had not been a regular topic here, particularly during the recent weeks of N.C.A.A. basketball.

headline: Two Apps to Guide You to Good Food
text: I don’t trust Yelp reviewers. I never know what I want to eat. I avoid bad meals at all costs, and I’m a bad cook. It is safe to say that I am a brat when it comes to food in New York City. I’ve spent a long time looking for an app that will help guide me to the best meal possible with the least effort.

headline: Czech Leader Won’t Attend Moscow Parade After Criticism

headline: Simplifying Mortgage Disclosure Forms
text: Mortgage terms will be simpler for home buyers to read and understand come Aug. 1. Borrowers will receive one disclosure, the Loan Estimate, detailing the terms and projected closing costs shortly after application, and another, the Closing Disclosure, just before signing off.

text: ANDORRA — In the clubby world of banking here in this tiny Pyrenees principality, where money comes and goes under only the partial purview of European regulators, there had long been whispers: Was there something fishy about one of Andorra’s five privately held banks, Banca Privada d’Andorra?

text: This is a bittersweet time on campus. Seniors are beginning to find jobs, and while their enthusiasm is infectious, some of their choices give me pause.

headline: 1940: British Cheered by Sea News
text: LONDON — With its fleet of the sea and the air shoving St. George’s sword into the German dragon up to the hilt and good reports coming from the biggest naval engagement since the Jutland fight twenty-five years ago, the British public went to bed feeling a whole lot better about the war, in spite of the Nazi coups in Scandinavia yesterday. Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain gave the House of Commons a short, but well-applauded account this afternoon [April 10] of this morning’s battle between five British and six German destroyers.

headline: Did You Write Your College Application Essay About Money? We’d Like to Hear From You
text: In each of the last two springs, I have put out a call to high school seniors around the world to send me the college application essays they’ve written that year about money, working or social class. I read every one of them and then, with the help of an outside expert, pick a handful to run in The New York Times.

headline: Review: When Jules Verne Met Nellie Bly
text: Do you regard space travel as one of the highest callings in the destiny of our species? If so (and I do), head immediately to BAM Fisher in Brooklyn. The Ensemble for the Romantic Century’s “Jules Verne: From the Earth to the Moon,” a dazzling musical and multimedia paean to human aspiration, will send you into the stratosphere.

headline: ‘Veep,’ ‘Silicon Valley’ and the Intrusion of Real-Life Events

headline: New Philharmonie Complex in Paris to Close Main Space for More Construction

headline: The Best Reason to Take Rand Paul Seriously Has Nothing to Do With His Politics
text: Although Rand Paul — who declared his bid for the presidency on Tuesday — has spent several years now inching toward the Republican mainstream, there is still a tendency among the political classes to view him as a sideshow candidate. The crankiness of his announcement-week interviews certainly suggests that he’s still getting a handle on retail politics. And though his policy views — calls for more rational sentencing guidelines, a less intrusive national-security apparatus and a restrained foreign policy — give him potential appeal with young, minority and libertarian-leaning voters, they also make him an outlier in the field of declared or likely Republican contenders.

headline: This Is the Easiest Quiz You Will Take Today
text: The photos below show members of two persecuted groups who have sought safety and protection in the United States. Republicans in the House want to rewrite the immigration law to make it easier for one group to enter as refugees. At the same time, they want to make entry much more difficult for the other group.

headline: A Victim of Kenyan Attack Is Remembered
text: A funeral was held on Friday for a student who was one among many Christians who were killed during a terrorist attack on a university in Garissa, Kenya, last week.

headline: 2 Kansas Men Charged in Suicide Attack Plot at Fort Riley

headline: How Alicia Glen, a Deputy Mayor of New York, Spends Her Sundays
text: Alicia Glen, the deputy mayor for housing and economic development, lives on 105th Street and West End Avenue, in the same ZIP code where she grew up. She shops at the grocer from her childhood and has gone to the same nail salon since the day before she was married. Before joining the de Blasio administration, Ms. Glen, 48, was the managing director in charge of the Urban Investment Group at Goldman Sachs. She lives with her husband, Daniel, 53, a media and entertainment lawyer, and their daughter Rosa, 14. Their other daughter, Olivia, 19, is a freshman at Carleton College.

headline: Apple and the Self-Surveillance State
text: Like lots of people, I’m paying attention to the Apple Watch buzz, and doing some of my own speculation. Needless to say, I have no special expertise here. But what the heck; I might as well put my own thoughts out there.

headline: Coachella 2015: And So It Begins, With Drake, Jack White and AC/DC
text: INDIO, Calif. — The number is 16. The 16th edition of the annual Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival will start shortly today. The Times has covered it many years (for me, the number is eight) but not every year. At the beginning, when an enormous field festival built around indie-ish discernment seemed novel, we were probably underestimating it, and then as its lineup started to look like the others that grew up around it — or vice versa — I started to wonder if we were overestimating it. I still do.

headline: Strap-Hanging With Schumer and de Blasio
text: As a news photographer, I find myself hurrying up to wait for a flurry of activity. Thursday morning, it was for the arrival of Mayor Bill de Blasio, Senator Charles E. Schumer and their entourages. They were scheduled to hop on the R train to City Hall to talk to riders and hand out fliers to promote national Stand Up for Transportation Day, a program that promotes increased federal funding for public transportation.

headline: A Self-Rising Second Career
text: When she left music, Judith Norell wound up creating Silver Moon Bakery, a Manhattan Valley fixture.

headline: The Young Hopes of Kenya, Laid in the Grave
text: GATUNDU, Kenya — The cars swung out onto Thika Road, one by one.

headline: Abstract Paintings That Combine French Philosophy, 3-D Software and Hieronymus Bosch
text: When Tom LaDuke recounts his artistic process, it can be a challenge to keep up. The L.A.-based painter and sculptor’s thoughts are a rapid-fire game of connect the dots that catapults from the depths of art history to personal memories to various degrees of existentialism.

headline: At Silver Moon Bakery, the Baking Never Stops
text: Some move to Florida; some volunteer at the library. But when Judith Norell decided to retire as a concert harpsichordist at age 60, she thought she would try her hand at baking bread.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: ‘The Feeling of Being at Home’
text: The photographer Gaia Squarci documented the move by Steve Cannon from his Lower East Side artists’ hub to his new apartment.

headline: A Farewell to a Home for Art and Artists
text: It was 1970, a year after Steve Cannon’s novel, “Groove, Bang and Jive Around,” was published, that he used proceeds from its sale to buy a three-story townhouse on East Third Street, just east of Avenue C, with a brick facade and a hospitable stoop.

headline: At Award-Winning Sevilla, There’s Always Room for the Regulars
text: In February, at the start of his 48th consecutive year running Sevilla, an old-timey Spanish restaurant in Greenwich Village, José Lloves got a call from a nice young man at the James Beard Foundation. Having no idea what the James Beard Foundation was, Mr. Lloves had his son, Tony, return the call. That’s when both men learned that Sevilla, which opened on the corner of Charles and West Fourth Streets in 1941, had just won an America’s Classics award honoring its “quality food, local character and lasting appeal.”

headline: G.E.’s Move Is Enticing to Banks, but Hard to Copy
text: Jeffrey R. Immelt, the chief executive of General Electric, has plotted an escape for GE Capital from onerous regulation. He is offloading most of the conglomerate’s finance unit, which should allow it to ditch the tag imposed by watchdogs of being a systemically important financial institution, or SIFI. Big United States banks might fancy similar liberty, but they are more tightly hemmed in.

headline: Bobby Jindal Talks God and Guns at N.R.A. Forum
text: Nearly every potential Republican presidential contender will be speaking today on a single issue: gun rights.

text: A look at one of the most unlikely pop-art phenomena of the 1960s and ’70s.

headline: Kode With Karlie, Iris Apfel’s Eulogy for Loehmann’s and Making Up Hillary Clinton
text: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

headline: What Hillary Clinton Faces in Congress
text: Hillary Clinton, who seems to have been running for president one way or another for many years now, is reported to be planning to announce her candidacy formally on Sunday for the 2016 Democratic presidential nomination.

headline: Wanted: School With Runway
text: The observant “Project Runway” fan may have noticed that the last time the all-star designers returned from foraging for fabric at Mood, something was missing from that boxy iconic building in New York’s garment district: the name of Parsons the New School for Design.

headline: Millennials Rule
text: This year, 75.3 million millennials, born 1981 to 1997, will inch out boomers as the largest generation, according to Pew Research Center calculations. In five years, they’ll be nearly half the work force.

headline: Campus Jargon
text: PrezBo Because President Bollinger is too many syllables for Columbia students.

headline: Quiz Answers
text: For questions from the Great Midwest Trivia Contest, click here.

headline: The Great Midwest Trivia Contest
text: In April 1966, Lawrence University in Appleton, Wis., held its first trivia competition, broadcast by the student radio station, WLFM. Today, the station and the Great Midwest Trivia Contest have moved to an Internet-only format, and thanks to Google, questions have become even more obscure. Jonathan P. Hanrahan, a junior and next year’s grand master, explains: “Participants typically have access to the Internet, phones, libraries, etc. This means we write our questions so that very, very few can be answered off the top of one’s head.” This year’s contest, the 50th, was held in January with some 900 people representing 86 teams trying to answer 408 insignificant questions over 50 consecutive hours (answers are called in to volunteers). The winner: the on-campus team Bucky’s Brood of Burgeoning Butt Brigadiers’ Bizarre Belligerants Bird-Bondage-Base Burlesque Bonanza.

headline: Reshaping Arizona State, and the Public Model
text: Michael M. Crow sees Arizona State as the model of a public research university that measures itself by inclusivity, not exclusivity. In his 13 years as its president, he has profoundly reshaped the institution — hiring faculty stars from across the country, starting a bevy of interdisciplinary programs, growing the student body to some 83,000 and using technology to bring his ideas to scale, whether with web-based introductory math classes or eAdvisor, which monitors students’ progress toward their major. Last year, Dr. Crow made headlines when the university partnered with Starbucks to offer students the chance to complete their degree online for free. His new book, written with the historian William B. Dabars, is called, appropriately, “Designing the New American University.”

headline: Film School, for Profit or Not
text: For a university dedicated to flashy disciplines like film and music recording, Full Sail at first glance has a rather unflashy campus. To find it, you drive north from the Orlando airport to Winter Park on one of those tedious Florida streets lined with telephone poles, drainage ditches and chain restaurants. Eventually you reach a Wendy’s and a Ker’s WingHouse. Behind them sits Full Sail.

headline: Folding Laundry
text: Davidson College students don’t take dirty clothes home to Mom. Why would they? For 95 years, Davidson, a liberal arts school near Charlotte, N.C., has done students’ laundry free. Clothes are cleaned, folded and nicely wrapped, or pressed and placed on hangers. Back in 1920, “our students, all male then, were expected to dress — dress pants, starched collars, ties,” Jan Blodgett, the college archivist, explains.

headline: Butterflies in Your Stomach
text: The nascent entomophagy movement — barbecue-flavored roasted mealworms, cookies baked from cricket flour — has gotten some recent (sorry) buzz on campus.

headline: Jerry Seinfeld on His New Friend, Wale, and ‘The Album About Nothing’
text: The highest-profile guest on Wale’s “The Album About Nothing,” which currently sits at No. 1 on the Billboard chart, is a 60-year-old white man with no experience rhyming. Instead, Jerry Seinfeld serves as a mentor and spirit-guide for Wale, the Washington, D.C., rapper and “Seinfeld” obsessive, who has mined the series for inspiration since his “The Mixtape About Nothing,” featuring Julia Louis-Dreyfuss, in 2008.

headline: Harvey Weinstein Won’t Face Charges After Groping Report
text: The Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein will not face criminal charges in connection with a woman’s claim that he touched her breasts during a business meeting in his office in TriBeCa last month, the Manhattan district attorney’s office announced on Friday.

headline: Scott Walker Attacks President Obama on Foreign Policy
text: Nearly every potential Republican presidential contender will be speaking today on a single issue: gun rights.

headline: All in the Family With Lincoln
text: A new book and documentary present the latest chapter in the Kunhardt family’s role as custodians of Abraham Lincoln’s image.

headline: Building a Contemporary Relationship
text: Tom Stern and Barbara Bestor were married at Silvertop, a modernist house in Los Angeles that the bride is helping to restore.

headline: A Race-Walking Riot in 1879 Manhattan
text: Q. Can you tell me anything about a riot in New York that occurred over a walking race?

headline: Obama Visits Panama Canal
text: The president on Friday toured the Miraflores Locks in Panama, where he traveled for a summit meeting of Latin American leaders.

headline: A Craftsman of Russian Verse Helps Ukraine Find Its New Voice
text: ODESSA, UKRAINE — EVERY morning at 6, Boris Khersonsky turns on the computer in his dacha. Under the gaze of the dusky icons covering the walls, one of Ukraine’s most famous literary bloggers — a 64-year-old psychiatrist, former Soviet dissident and acclaimed poet — logs onto Facebook to conduct what has become something of a daily symposium on the identity of the new Ukraine.

headline: Aahs for the Bride and Oohs for the House
text: Jewish weddings are traditionally punctuated by the sound of breaking glass, but a videographer crashing through a transparent wall at Silvertop, the illustrious house in the Silver Lake section of Los Angeles under renovation by Barbara Bestor, the architect and bride, may have seemed to be cause for distress.

headline: After ‘Interns’ Star Came Out in Russia, a Mix of Fury and Shrugs
text: MOSCOW — In February, Odin Biron, an American actor who plays a naïve American son of two gay fathers in the hugely popular Russian medical sitcom “Interns,” took a calculated risk. He disclosed that he was gay.

headline: A Hotel Where Guests Are Pals With the Pen
text: While email and social media posts have long stolen snail mail traffic, one New York hotel is standing up for old-fashioned communication with a letter-writing campaign.

headline: Sweet Memory
text: In the opening essay for this issue, the novelist and journalist Walter Kirn pens a cautionary note about our reliance on the technology with which we relentlessly record and curate our lives. His concern is that our devices might be hindering our memories, in all their poignant faultiness. I thought about his essay this morning as I dropped my daughter off for a school trip to Nepal and watched as a photographer documented the departing group, every parent standing by him, snapping the exact same picture with their phones. What did that banal image have to do with the sadness and pride I felt sending my child halfway around the world alone, her eyes welling with tears as we said goodbye, or the note that I stuffed into her bag? Would that snapshot form the basis of our future narrative, pushing away those more fragile memories that we would have otherwise tried to recall years later?

text: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Wilton, Conn., and a lake house in North Brunswick, N.J.

headline: Woman Admitted She Married One of 10 Men for Money, Prosecutors Say
text: A woman who has had 10 husbands admitted that she wed one man in return for cash and helping him get citizenship, prosecutors said on Friday in a Bronx courtroom.

headline: A Piece of Harlem History Turns to Dust
text: The Renaissance Theater and Casino in Harlem, where Duke Ellington performed, Joe Louis slugged opponents and the Black Fives basketball team called the Harlem Rens dominated games, is now mostly in piles of brick, metal and dust.

headline: Where to Rent an Elephant
text: Most people could be forgiven for fantasizing about what their weddings may look like. But some weddings just would not be complete without a guest who could consume 200 pounds of food and imbibe 50 gallons of beverage.

headline: Fort Hood Shooting Victims Recognized as War Casualties
text: In an about-face by the Army, the victims of the deadly 2009 shooting at the Fort Hood military base in Texas, some of them still limping, took the stage on Friday and were recognized as casualties of war.

headline: A Love of Surfing Leads to a Proposal
text: Representative Tulsi Gabbard and Abraham Williams were married Thursday in Kahaluu, Hawaii. Pandit Vinod Dave, a Hindu priest, performed a Vedic ceremony.

text: Kenya and More — Pictures of the Day
