headline: Freeman Dyson: By the Book
text: The physicist, mathematician and author, most recently, of “Dreams of Earth and Sky” says the best books he knows about mathematics and physics are nearly a hundred years old.

headline: Review: In Toni Morrison’s ‘God Help the Child,’ Adults Are Hobbled by the Pain of the Past
text: One of the great themes that threads its way through Toni Morrison’s work like a haunting melody is the hold that time past exerts over time present. In larger historical terms, it is the horror of slavery and its echoing legacy that her characters struggle with. In personal terms, it is an emotional wound or loss — and the fear of suffering such pain again — that inhibits her women and men, making them wary of the very sort of love and intimacy that might heal and complete them.

headline: In ‘Something Rotten!,’ if Music Be the Food of Farce, Play On
text: “Something Rotten!,” which opens Wednesday, is about a pair of brothers, Nick and Nigel Bottom, Elizabethan-era playwrights who are more or less learning on the job. Unable to get anywhere in a theatrical world dominated by Shakespeare, they consult a soothsayer, who informs them that the next new thing will be the musical, and with mixed results they set about trying to write one. An early number they drop, for example, is a celebration of the Black Death.

headline: Pakistani Justices Suspend Executions Ordered by Military Courts
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s Supreme Court on Thursday suspended the death sentences issued by recently established military courts in a move that could incite tensions between the country’s powerful military and its judiciary.

headline: A Practice Nook in the Subway
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Will Carine Roitfeld & Uniqlo Be More or Less Than the Sum of Its Parts?
text: On Thursday, the Japanese clothing retailer Uniqlo announced that its next collaboration would be with Carine Roitfeld, the former French Vogue editor and former Tom Ford muse who is now the global fashion director at Harper’s Bazaar International and editor of her own magazine, named after herself (CR Fashion Book). Consisting of 40 pieces from outer wear to inner wear, Ms. Roitfeld’s Uniqlo line will go on sale in October.

headline: Celebrating the Fast-Moving, Bug-Eyed, Wily World of Hip-Hop Mixtape Covers
text: Mixtapes have been around almost since hip-hop’s beginning, but in the last decade, their ubiquity and efficacy have made them perhaps the prime way for new artists to be discovered and for older artists to re-establish their bona fides. At the same time, now that they’re everywhere, it’s tough to stand out and win attention.

headline: N.B.A. Playoffs: Story Lines to Watch
text: It took all 82 games to decide many of the N.B.A. playoff seedings, but the field is set. A look at some matchups reveals several compelling story lines to follow when postseason play begins Saturday.

headline: At Jin Youzhi’s Funeral, a Quiet Farewell to China’s Imperial Past
text: The simple funeral was fitting for a man who was the last surviving sibling of China’s final emperor, but who led a commoner’s life.

headline: Goldman Sachs Reports Robust Earnings as Trading Revives
text: Goldman Sachs used a strong quarter to fire back against recent criticism of its business model and the opportunities on Wall Street.

headline: Encouraging Teenagers to Read, by Choosing Books From the Non-Y.A. Shelves
text: My sons have always been voracious readers. One started early, the other started late, but once they got going, both were hooked. Then, one day this winter, I looked around my teenager’s room and noticed something was missing. Where books once littered his room, I now find guitar picks, running spikes and dirty socks.

headline: Cost-Cutting Helps Citigroup Beat Estimates
text: Citigroup was able to take a rare victory lap on Thursday, reporting first-quarter results that were devoid of the kind of scandal, losses and regulatory missteps that have come to plague the bank.

headline: Favorite Streets in Europe
text: From Lisbon to Milan, 12 quintessential urban byways.

headline: Cycling Start-Up Peloton Raises $30 Million
text: Investors appear enamored of Peloton and its advanced home-cycling stationary bicycles, so much so that the start-up has raised money again to continue its expansion.

headline: Editorial Contest Winner | The N.H.L. Should Do Away With Fighting
text: For the next 10 days we will be honoring each of the Top 10 winners of our Second Annual Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay a day, in the order of submission.

headline: South Korean President on Raising Ferry
text: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea spoke on the anniversary of the ferry sinking that killed more than 300 people, most of them high school students, promising that the sunken ship would be raised.

headline: Anne Hathaway and Julie Taymor Bring ‘Grounded’ to the Public Theater
text: Anne Hathaway vividly remembers the first time she went to Shakespeare in the Park, to see a production of “The Seagull” featuring Meryl Streep, Kevin Kline, Christopher Walken, Natalie Portman and Philip Seymour Hoffman, among others.

headline: The Musical ‘Amazing Grace’ to Open on Broadway This Summer
text: An inspirational musical about the British slave trader who composed “Amazing Grace” will open on Broadway this summer.

headline: PEN Announces Finalists for 2015 Awards
text: The PEN American Center on Thursday announced the shortlists and judges for the 2015 PEN Literary Awards. Taken together, the awards, fellowships and grants from the literary and human rights organization will confer $150,000 on writers, editors and translators.

headline: Cannes Competition Includes Films by Todd Haynes and Gus Van Sant
text: New films by Todd Haynes, Gus Van Sant and Denis Villeneuve are among the entries in the official competition of the 68th annual Cannes Film Festival, organizers announced Thursday. Projects from Yorgos Lanthimos of Greece and three leading Italian directors — Matteo Garrone, Nanni Moretti and Paolo Sorrentino — also made the cut.

headline: Dita Von Teese Brings Burlesque to a Desert Getaway
text: For the past 36 years, Canyon Ranch in Arizona has had reputation as a desert getaway where guests enjoyed deep-tissue massages and seminars about “the power of possibility.”

headline: China Halts New Policy on Tech for Banks
text: HONG KONG — China has suspended a policy that would have effectively pushed foreign technology companies out of the country’s banking sector, according to a note sent by Chinese regulators to banks.

headline: Go Hammerheads! Winning With Autism
text: Children with disabilities often can’t participate in team sports. A new documentary called “Swim Team” chronicles the Jersey Hammerheads, a swim team for kids with autism.

headline: A Swim Team for Teens With Autism
text: Team sports are a rite of passage for many children, but kids with disabilities often can’t participate. A new documentary called “Swim Team” chronicles the Jersey Hammerheads, a swim team for children with autism.

headline: When Old Glory Returned to Fort Sumter
text: On the evening of April 13, 1865, the steamship Oceanus arrived in Charleston, S.C., after a three-day trip from New York City. Passing by Fort Sumter, the island fort where the Civil War had begun, the ship’s nearly 200 passengers, most of whom were members of minister Henry Ward Beecher’s Brooklyn congregation, broke out into song. “Praise God, from whom all blessings flow! / Praise Him, all creatures here below!” they bellowed.

headline: Search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370
text: Officials from Malaysia and Australia said they would double the search area for the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 if its wreckage was not found in the current target area.

headline: Clues to How an Electric Treatment for Parkinson’s Works
text: In 1998, Dr. Philip A. Starr started putting electrodes in people’s brains.

headline: Advanced N.H.L. Statistics Don’t Like the Rangers
text: The Rangers finished the season with the best record in the N.H.L. and are widely touted as the Stanley Cup favorites.

headline: Cristobal Balenciaga’s Lace Legacy
text: A new exhibition at the Museum of Lace and Fashion celebrates the life — the 120th anniversary of his birth — and legacy — particularly, innovative silk silhouettes — of Cristóbal Balenciaga, who founded the Balenciaga fashion house in Spain in 1937. For the show, the curator Catherine Join-Diéterle, with the help of the designer’s namesake foundation, first gathered creations from the museum’s own 18-piece Balenciaga collection in Calais, France. She then brought in vintage Balenciaga from the Cristóbal Balenciaga Museum in Getaria, Spain (which will host the show in 2016), as well as loaned designs from Paris’s Museum of Decorative Arts, Palais Galliera and Maison Lesage. On view will be a total of 75 items, some of which have never been seen before, and many of which feature lace from Calais, a small city known for its manufacturing of the delicate material. (The museum itself was once an old lace factory.)

headline: Tribeca Film Festival Interview: Pamela Romanowsky on ‘The Adderall Diaries’
text: This is one in a series of interviews focusing on New York-centric movies having their premieres at the Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: Colleagues Addicted to Tech
text: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: Contested Artifacts from Internment Camps Withdrawn from Auction
text: Hundreds of artifacts from Japanese-Americans held in internment camps during World War II were withdrawn from auction Wednesday night.

headline: Vatican Ends Battle With U.S. Catholic Nuns’ Group
text: The Vatican has abruptly ended its takeover of the main leadership group of American nuns two years earlier than expected, allowing Pope Francis to put to rest a confrontation started by his predecessor that created an uproar among American Catholics who had rallied to the sisters’ defense.

headline: Tune In to The Times
text: Mary Anne Weaver , a contributor to The New York Times Magazine, joined MSNBC’s “Morning Joe” to discuss her in-depth cover story on why middle-class British Muslims are joining Islamist militant groups so rapidly.

headline: 2 Brooklyn Landlords, Accused of Making Units Unlivable, Are Charged With Fraud
text: One morning in February 2014, Silveria Hormiga, who lived at 324 Central Avenue in Bushwick, a rapidly gentrifying area of Brooklyn, left for a doctor’s appointment.

headline: 1915: Turkish Sultan May Resign
text: A council of the Imperial dynasty has been held at Constantinople, with the Sultan presiding. The council discussed the possibility of the capture of Constantinople by the Allies and the necessity of transferring the capital to the interior of Asia Minor. The Sultan, who was very depressed, said he owed his accession to the throne to the Young Turks and the revolution, but that he would rather never have reigned than see the misfortunes which their inexperienced and rash policy had brought on Turkey. He declared he was determined to abdicate if it became necessary to transfer the capital to Asia Minor. — The New York Herald, European Edition, April 17, 1915

headline: Etsy I.P.O. Tests Pledge to Balance Social Mission and Profit
text: The online craft bazaar Etsy made its debut on the Nasdaq stock market Thursday, signaling the birth of an unusual public corporation — and not just because its employees carry around compost on bicycles, or because its regulatory filings are peppered with phrases like, “We keep it real, always.”

headline: From Michigan to Alabama, a 690-Mile Yard Sale
text: The World’s Longest Yard Sale runs 690 miles along U.S. Highway 127 from “five miles north of Addison, Mich. to Gadsden, Ala.”

headline: Celebrating 50 Years of New York’s Landmarks Law (at a Landmark, of Course)
text: At a party on Wednesday night that was all about landmarks, the where-were-you-then question simply had to be asked: Where were you on April 19, 1965, when Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr. signed New York City’s landmarks law?

headline: Carly Fiorina Makes Case That She Could Offset Hillary Clinton
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s candidacy could make history by bringing the first female president to the White House, but one potential Republican opponent has an idea for neutralizing her power to galvanize women: nominate a woman to run against her.

headline: Viewfinder: Lexie Moreland
text: Lexie Moreland’s photos of Michael C. Hall preparing for his role in “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” document private moments in the actor’s nightly transformation.

headline: Casa Del Chef
text: This restaurant, run by an alum of Blue Hill at Stone Barns, aims for more than just Ecuadorean comforts.

headline: At Casa Del Chef in Woodside, Queens, the Goals Are Lofty
text: At the end of each day as head cook at Academy of the City Charter School in Woodside, Queens, Alfonso Zhicay hops onto his bike and makes his way a mile south to Casa Del Chef, the restaurant he opened last August near the No. 7 train tracks.

headline: Jackpots for Local TV Stations in F.C.C. Auction of Airwaves
text: LAS VEGAS — The pitch to television broadcasters this week was not easy for them to swallow. It is a good time, they were told, to sell their most precious resource.

headline: Prague’s Cool New Crop of Collective Showrooms
text: Once limited to just a few scattered shops and showrooms, Prague’s design scene is currently experiencing a boom with storefronts and studios opening at a striking pace. And a new crop of collective showrooms, inspired spaces that house multiple designers under one roof, increasingly double as studios and local hangouts.

headline: A Generous (and Unwanted) Gift
1965: Mississippi Floods New Areas
text: CHICAGO — Raging waters of the flooding Mississippi and its tributaries spread over new areas today [April 16], causing stepped-up evacuation of lowland residents and creating new destruction. Along a 400-mile stretch of the rampaging river from Minneapolis-St. Paul, Minn., to south of Hannibal, Mo., thousands of volunteers labored to shore up dikes against the worst spring flooding on record. The number of persons already driven from their homes in North Dakota, Minnesota and Wisconsin was estimated at between 30,000 and 35,000. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 17, 1965.

headline: BlackRock Says Assets Grew 8% in Quarter
text: WASHINGTON — As regulators in Washington warn of the risks that large asset management companies may pose to the markets, BlackRock, the largest of them all, continues to rake in heavy investment flows.

headline: Palestinian Women Join Effort to Keep Jews From Contested Holy Site
text: JERUSALEM — The women, covered face-to-toe, surrounded the Jewish group walking through the contested holy site in Jerusalem. “The army of Muhammad is coming!” the women shouted.

headline: Favorite Streets in 12 European Cities
text: Cobbled lanes, broad avenues, streets for gallery-hoppers, food-lovers, shoppers and flâneurs: Contributors in 12 European cities describe the byways (including one river) they love.

headline: Highlights From Putin’s Annual Call-In
text: In his televised call-in with the nation on Thursday, President Vladimir V. Putin discussed the economy and said, “I tell you straight and clearly: There are no Russian troops in Ukraine.”

headline: Ryan Sullivan Scales Up
text: The young artist’s abstract drip paintings for a new show at Miami’s Institute of Contemporary Art are the largest of his career.

headline: Ferran Adrià Serves Up a Bubbly Night in Barcelona
text: The chef celebrated El Bulli Foundation’s partnership with Dom Pérignon with 29 different hors d’oeuvres, paired with a new champagne vintage.

headline: Etsy, Virtu and Party City All Climb in Their Stock Market Debuts
text: Three prominent companies — Etsy, Virtu Financial and Party City — made promising stock debuts on Thursday, potentially providing a jolt to the market for initial public offerings that has been slow so far this year.

headline: More Bills in G.O.P. Senate; Less Democratic Support
text: Eager to show it can function, the new Republican majority in the Senate has cracked open a window for legislation.

headline: Next Round of Nuclear Talks With Iran Set for Next Week
text: TEHRAN — The next round of nuclear talks between world powers and Iran is scheduled for next week in Vienna, as the two sides begin to address the issues they left unresolved earlier this month in Lausanne, Switzerland, and try to conclude a comprehensive agreement by the end of June.

headline: In Debate Around Sally Mann’s Photography, Too Much Is Exposed
text: “What an artist captures, what a mother knows and what the public sees can be dangerously different things.”

headline: ‘Wonder Woman’ Gets a New Female Director
text: LOS ANGELES — Just days after Warner Brothers said Michelle MacLaren had departed as the director of its planned “Wonder Woman” film, the studio replaced her with Patty Jenkins, who had previously been in and out of Marvel Entertainment’s “Thor 2,” Variety and others reported.

headline: War in Yemen Is Allowing Qaeda Group to Expand
text: DOWAAN, Yemen — Al Qaeda’s branch in Yemen took control of a major airport and an oil export terminal in the southern part of the country on Thursday, expanding the resurgent militant group’s reach just two weeks after it seized the  nearby city of Al Mukalla and emptied its bank and prison.

headline: Without Bidding, Eugene, Ore., Is Abruptly Awarded World Track Championships
text: There was surprise in multiple time zones on Thursday when Eugene, Ore., became the first city in the United States to secure the world outdoor track and field championships. It will stage them in 2021 without the usual constraint of having had to win a formal bidding process.

headline: Dealing With Being Dissed by a Disinvite
text: A month ago, I received an Evite to a colleague’s birthday party. I didn’t open it right away because I could see all the details in the message. I also had to ask mutual friends whether spouses were invited and find a babysitter. There was no R.S.V.P. date. Today, I tried responding (the party is still three weeks away), but when I clicked on the link, I got this message: “Sorry, you are not on the guest list for this event.” Was I disinvited? When I see the host, should I pretend this never happened?

headline: Living With Cancer: In and Out of the Closet
text: In a memoir, “The Summer of Her Baldness,” the visual artist and theorist Catherine Lord finds “the cancer closet . . . at least as complicated as the sexuality closet”: “You can never get entirely out and you can never get entirely back in.”

headline: Use of E-Cigarettes Rises Sharply Among Teenagers, Report Says
text: Kenny, a high school senior in Weston, Fla., likes to puff e-cigarettes during study sessions with friends after school. James, a senior in Fauquier County, Va., uses them outside at lunch with friends who do smoke tricks. Tom, a sophomore from Westchester County, uses them while hiking with friends.

headline: Welcome to Your First Year as a Lawyer. Your Salary Is $160,000.
text: Salaries for lawyers starting out at firms have remained flat, with an annual pay of $160,000 continuing to be the top of the market, according to a new survey from the National Association for Law Placement.

headline: Hillary Clinton Re-emerges, by Design (but Also by Surprise)
text: Did you hear the one about the presidential candidate who walks into a Chipotle restaurant in Ohio? She orders a burrito bowl and makes headlines worldwide.

headline: It’s N.B.A. Playoff Time. Pay No Attention to Those Losing Records.
text: The N.B.A. playoffs this year have an exciting cast. There is Stephen Curry and the supercharged Warriors; the veterans on the Spurs; the Pelicans and the playoff debutant Anthony Davis; and LeBron James in his return to Cleveland.

headline: Deal Reached on Fast-Track Authority for Obama on Trade Accord
text: WASHINGTON — Key congressional leaders agreed on Thursday on legislation to give President Obama special authority to finish negotiating one of the world’s largest trade accords, opening a rare battle that aligns the president with Republicans against a broad coalition of Democrats.

headline: Blackstone Reports Sharp Rise in Profit
text: Blackstone, fresh off its real estate deal with General Electric, continues to mint money in its two largest areas of focus: private equity and global real estate.

headline: How Presidential Campaigns Became Two-Year Marathons
text: The comedian John Oliver doesn’t think the length of the American presidential campaign is funny. “I have no interest whatsoever in the 2016 election, at the start of 2015,” he recently told reporters. “There’s a time and a place for that, and it’s in 2016.”

headline: N.Y.U. Labor Guidelines Failed to Protect 10,000 Workers in Abu Dhabi, Report Says
text: About one-third of the migrant construction workers employed at New York University’s campus in Abu Dhabi — or about 10,000 people — were excluded from the protections of the university’s labor guidelines ensuring fair wages, hours and living conditions, according to an investigative report issued on Thursday.

headline: A Yale Graduate Leaves a Trail of Ventures and Debts
text: In many ways, Joshua Bryce Newman fits the part of the young, successful entrepreneur.

headline: With Eye on Mobile, Yahoo Revises Its Search Partnership With Microsoft
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Marissa Mayer has finally gotten what she’s wanted ever since she left Google three years ago to run Yahoo: a chance to build a new experience for searching the web and mobile phones.

headline: Who Votes For Rubio?
text: When Ted Cruz entered the race a few weeks ago I did my best to conjure a scenario in which he somehow emerged as the Republican nominee. With Marco Rubio, officially in earlier this week, the conjuring is easier: I’ve always thought that the Florida Senator is well-positioned as a primary contender, because he’s closer to the G.O.P.’s center of gravity than any nominee since George W. Bush, because he’s been ahead of his rivals in establishing an actual policy vision (its flaws notwithstanding), and because he’s personally appealing (inspiring immigrant background, no Bush-family baggage, gives a great speech) in ways that distinguish him even in a pretty deep field.

headline: Shareholder Litigation That Works
text: Charles Korsmo is an assistant professor at Case Western Reserve School of Law, and Minor Myers is an associate professor at Brooklyn Law School. They provide compensated advice on stockholder appraisal.

headline: Lawsuit Against Yale Graduate
text: The trail of litigation against Joshua Bryce Newman began with Cyan Pictures, an independent movie production company he founded in Manhattan in 2002.

headline: Florida Governor to Sue Obama Administration Over Medicaid Expansion
text: A standoff over expanding Medicaid in Florida escalated on Thursday after Gov. Rick Scott, a Republican, said he planned to sue the Obama administration for using what he called “coercion tactics” to try to pressure the state into adopting the program, a centerpiece of the president’s contentious Affordable Care Act.

headline: Book by Slain Charlie Hebdo Editor Argues Islam Is Not Exempt From Ridicule
text: PARIS — Stéphane Charbonnier, the editorial director of the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo who was assassinated by Islamist gunmen in Paris in January, is proving as defiant in death as he was in life.

headline: ‘Star Wars’ Trailer Is Unveiled for Ecstatic Fans
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. – Most fan conventions are known for high hysterics, but the reaction to the debut of the second “Star Wars: Episode VII – The Force Awakens” teaser trailer here on Thursday was nothing less than bone rattling.

headline: Goldman’s Improved Returns Come at Higher Risk
text: Goldman Sachs is replacing one earnings problem with another.

headline: A Balancing Act for Jeb Bush in 1989
text: A series of diplomatic cables tied to a business trip Jeb Bush made to Nigeria in March 1989 highlighted the tension between his own business interests and the privileges and scrutiny that came with being the son of a president.

headline: For Jeb Bush the Businessman, Some Deals Brought Grief
text: Barely a month after his father’s inauguration as president in 1989, Jeb Bush and his new business partners landed in Nigeria.

headline: Palestinian Driver Suspected of Deliberately Hitting Jerusalem Bus Stop
text: JERUSALEM — A preliminary investigation of a Palestinian driver who crashed into a bus stop in Jerusalem late Wednesday night, killing an Israeli man and injuring an Israeli woman, reinforced suspicions that he had rammed his car into the pedestrians intentionally, the Israeli police said Thursday.

headline: Visiting Auschwitz: Reporter’s Notebook
text: The day I was scheduled to fly from Paris to Krakow, to visit Auschwitz, there was an air traffic control strike in France and hundreds of flights were canceled. Luckily, not mine.

headline: Verbatim: I Believe I Can Fly (With Some Help)
text: — Senator John Cornyn of Texas, the Republican whip, when asked about the gyrocopter that landed on the Capitol lawn on Wednesday.

headline: N.F.L. to Reinstate Vikings’ Adrian Peterson
text: Minnesota Vikings running back Adrian Peterson will be reinstated on Friday, ending one of the N.F.L.’s more complex and embarrassing suspensions.

headline: Generic Version of Copaxone, Multiple Sclerosis Drug, Is Approved
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the first generic substitute for Copaxone, a widely used drug for multiple sclerosis and the biggest-selling product for Teva Pharmaceutical Industries.

headline: Ebola Researchers Take New Look at Risk of Sexual Transmission
text: Concerned about the potential for sexual transmission of Ebola, international health officials are investigating new reports of suspected cases and beginning studies to determine how often and how long the virus remains active in semen. And, for now, they are warning Ebola survivors to practice protected sex indefinitely.

headline: Hillary Clinton Evolves on Gay Rights, While Others Lag Behind
text: Two bits of news today on the civil rights front seemed worthy of comment.

headline: U.S. Investigates Possible Misconduct in Chicago Public Schools
text: CHICAGO — Federal investigators are speaking to public school officials here as part of an inquiry into possible misconduct, the president of the Chicago Board of Education acknowledged this week.

headline: Clinton Is Said to ‘Love’ de Blasio, Despite Lack of Endorsement
text: DES MOINES — Hillary Rodham Clinton has no hard feelings toward Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York for declining to endorse her presidential bid — at least according to Tom Harkin, the former Democratic senator from Iowa.

headline: Teaching the Armenian Genocide With Primary Sources From The New York Times
text: In the spring of 1915, the Young Turk regime of the Ottoman Empire began an organized campaign of violence against its Armenian population under the cover of World War I. A consensus of historians (PDF) consider the massacres, forced deportations and mass starvation that killed more than one million Armenians a genocide.

headline: The Look of Love Is in the Dog’s Eyes
text: Those big brown eyes gaze at you, deeply. Your heart leaps. You caress, murmuring sweet nothings. And as those big browns remain fixed on you, the tail wags.

headline: Putin Takes Questions: More Economy, Less Ukraine
text: MOSCOW — Sounding at times like a mayor promising to fix potholes and close noisy bars, President Vladimir V. Putin used his annual national call-in show on Thursday to try to reassure Russians that the country’s economic troubles were under control and that he shared their concerns on pocketbook issues.

headline: Misty Copeland Makes the Cover of Time Magazine
text: For the first time in a generation a dancer has made the cover of Time magazine: Misty Copeland, the American Ballet Theater soloist, was chosen as one of the magazine’s “100 most influential people,” and is featured on one of the five different covers for its upcoming issue.

headline: Clinton May See Rubio Fund-Raiser From Her House
text: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida is taking his fight to Hillary Rodham Clinton — or at least, very close to her.

headline: Exploring California’s Bold Pinot Noir
text: The most interesting California pinot noir producers today seem to continually push out toward the fringes. In that, they are following in the footsteps of Josh Jensen, the founder of the Calera Wine Company.

headline: American Woman Wounded in Shooting in Karachi, Pakistan
text: KARACHI, Pakistan — An American citizen was critically wounded in what was apparently a militant attack on Thursday in the southern port city of Karachi.

headline: Russia Bans Tom Hardy Thriller From  Theaters
text: In the latest salvo in a broader culture war, Russia’s culture minister, Vladimir Medinsky, has banned the release in Russia of “Child 44,” a Cold War thriller starring Tom Hardy as a policeman investigating a series of child murders in 1953, for “distorting historical facts,” Variety reported.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Lost River’
text: Ryan Gosling narrates a sequence from his film “Lost River.”

headline: Two Museums to Host Pollock ‘Black Pourings’
text: TWO MUSEUMS TO HOST

headline: ‘Lost River’ (With Movie Trailer): Ryan Gosling Narrates a Scene
text: For his directorial debut, the actor Ryan Gosling took to the streets of Detroit to tell the story of a family — Billy, played by Christina Hendricks, and her two sons, Bones and Frankie — in a deserted town, “Lost River.” The film is in theaters and available  on demand. During a recent interview in New York, he answered questions about his film. Below are excerpts from that conversation.

headline: Ohio Man Trained in Syria Is Charged With Planning Terrorism in U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — An Ohio man who trained with a terrorist group in Syria was accused by federal prosecutors on Thursday of returning to the United States with the goal of mounting an attack at home, the first example of a pattern that counterterrorism officials have long feared.

headline: ‘Telephone: An International Arts Experiment’ by Nathan Langston
text: Sometime last winter, Terri St.Arnauld and Frank Yezer, photographers in Austin, Tex., and Maya Ciarrocchi, a video artist in New York, each received an email that contained a song. The tune was by Stelth Ulvang, a musician from Denver, whom they had never met. In a spare recording, on banjo and accordion, Mr. Ulvang sang of a forlorn man and a landscape of smoke and clouds.

headline: N.B.A. to Test Players for H.G.H. Starting Next Season
text: The N.B.A. announced Thursday that it would expand its antidrug program next season to include blood tests for human growth hormone. The league said testing would begin this year in preseason training camp.

headline: Apple Watch Availability Is Clarified
text: Apple’s method of releasing products like the iPhone is straightforward: On the day of release, you buy the phone at a retail store or it is delivered if you ordered online. The process is a lot less clear for the Apple Watch.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Changing Views on Gay Marriage
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s views on same-sex marriage have evolved in the almost 20 years since her husband, Bill Clinton, then the president, signed the 1996 Defense of Marriage Act, saying that he had “long opposed governmental recognition of same-gender marriages.” This week Mrs. Clinton, who is running for president, said she hoped that same-sex marriage became a constitutional right.

headline: Ferran Adrià Serves Up a Bubbly Night in Barcelona
text: Last night in Barcelona, Ferran Adrià, the renowned Catalan chef, worked a dinner service for the first time since he closed El Bulli, the avant-garde, Michelin-three-star table that was repeatedly named best restaurant in the world. Co-hosted with Dom Pérignon’s head oenologist, Richard Geoffroy, the event at the Palo Alto market was titled “This Is Not a Dinner.”

headline: Dodd-Frank’s Hotel California May Have Exit After All
text: General Electric may be the first to find out if it is possible to escape the Hotel California.

headline: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on 3 Leaders of Gang Based in El Salvador
text: MEXICO CITY — The United States government imposed sanctions on three leaders of the Mara Salvatrucha street gang on Thursday as part of a broader effort to crack down on the transnational gang, which is based in El Salvador and runs human trafficking and drug operations into the United States.

headline: Duchovny and Anderson: The Literary Files
text: There must be something about solving paranormal mysteries that sparks literary inspiration.

headline: Review: ‘Child 44,’ a Secret-Police Thriller in Soviet Russia
text: “Child 44,” directed by Daniel Espinosa from a screenplay by Richard Price, is an English-language movie set in Russia, which means that it is above all a festival of accents. Gary Oldman, Paddy Considine and Vincent Cassel measure their vowels and consonants carefully, but the most floridly enjoyable voices belong to Tom Hardy and Noomi Rapace, last seen together speaking Brooklynese in “The Drop.” In that film, Mr. Hardy dropped his r’s like a champ. Here he lands heavily on the aitches and contracts the words “it is” into the letter Z. “Zimpossible,” he says. “Zdifficult.”

headline: Review: ‘Tangerines’ Is a Tale of War and Honor
text: Ivo, a taciturn grandfather with a straight back and a silver beard, makes wooden crates in his workshop. He hopes to make enough to contain the harvest from his neighbor Margus’s tangerine grove. The two men are among the last Estonians remaining in the former Soviet Republic of Georgia during the 1992 war in the Abkhazia region.

headline: House Votes to Repeal Estate Tax
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama and the Republicans in Congress clashed over taxes and wealth on Thursday, a day after many Americans sent checks to the Internal Revenue Service, as the House voted to repeal the federal tax levied on multimillion-dollar estates.

headline: Review: ‘Salad Days’ Revisits Washington’s Punk Moment
text: Yes, Washington is a company town, its labor force often revolving in and out with each presidential administration. But a vigorous underground musical scene has long existed there, and “Salad Days,” an enlightening documentary by the rock journalist Scott Crawford, details its origins.

headline: Review: ‘True Story’ Stars Jonah Hill and James Franco
text: “The Journalist and the Murderer” is the title of a book by Janet Malcolm, but it could just as well be the name of a genre. A small library of searching and sensational stories attests to the strong, often uncomfortable affinity between reporters and killers. Truman Capote’s “In Cold Blood” is perhaps the supreme example, and one that has inspired several movies over the years. Neither Michael Finkel’s book “True Story” nor Rupert Goold’s film adaptation is anywhere near as accomplished as Capote’s book or Bennett Miller’s movie “Capote.” The new film is of interest mainly because it demonstrates just how difficult it can be to map the queasy moral territory where crime and journalism intersect.

headline: Clashes Intensify Over Stalled Nomination of Loretta Lynch
text: WASHINGTON — Senators on Thursday reopened negotiations on a stalled bill to combat human trafficking, while bickering intensified among Democrats and Republicans, and even the White House, over the stalemate that has ensnared the attorney general nomination of Loretta E. Lynch.

headline: Review: In ‘The Human Experiment,’ We’re the Unwitting Guinea Pigs
text: Not long into “The Human Experiment,” a scary if scientifically lightweight documentary about our daily exposure to thousands of synthetic chemicals, you realize that its main targets are women. Proceeding through breast cancer statistics, cosmetics ingredients and the toxic horrors that lurk in our household cleaners, the movie focuses primarily on the ladies. Even its poster — an infant surrounded by cleaning products — seems designed to catch a woman’s eye.

headline: Seaport Museum Picks Interim President to Lead as New Executive Director
text: Jonathan Boulware, who since November 2011 has served as the South Street Seaport Museum’s waterfront director and interim president, has been appointed executive director, the museum is to announce next week.

headline: Some Fear Fallout From Preet Bharara’s Tension With Judges
text: Preet Bharara, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York and one of the most acclaimed prosecutors of his generation, is locked in what seems to be an escalating war of words with the federal judiciary — one that some judges fear could influence important rulings.

headline: Making the Magazine
text: A behind-the-scenes look a The New York Times Magazine in the 1980s.

headline: Review: In ‘Alex of Venice,’ a Career Workaholic Learns to Shoulder Family Burdens
text: An appealing portrait miniature of a woman who loses and finds her bearings, “Alex of Venice” takes place against that messy Los Angeles backdrop of beachside attractions and boardwalk crowds, millionaire mansions and homeless encampments known as Venice. That’s the neighborhood in which the heroine, Alex (Mary Elizabeth Winstead), grew up and that, with her family, she still calls home. She may not notice the carnival anymore, but the director, Chris Messina, takes time to gently point out some of the more picturesque sites, like the Venice sign that serves as a gateway to the Pacific and the arched walkways that Orson Welles immortalized in “Touch of Evil.”

headline: Former JPMorgan Chase Broker Charged in $20 Million Fraud
text: A former JPMorgan Chase broker treated accounts maintained by his clients as his own personal piggy bank — using about $20 million in client money to make unprofitable options trades and even paying down the mortgage on his New Jersey home, according to a federal criminal complaint unsealed on Thursday.

headline: Reading The Times With Andy Borowitz
text: Andy Borowitz is the creator of the news satire column The Borowitz Report and a memoir, “An Unexpected Twist.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
text: South Korea and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Review: ‘Human Highway’ and ‘Muddy Track,’ Whimsical ’80s Artifacts From Neil Young
text: Throughout his protean music career, Neil Young has tried his hand at filmmaking. The movies of Neil Young, auteur, include the rarely seen “Journey Through the Past” (1974), which Paul Thomas Anderson (“Inherent Vice”) has cited as an influence, and “Greendale” (2004), an earnest and political rock opera.

headline: April 16, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from South Korea, Poland, Greece and Brazil.

headline: Something Old (Bridal Wear) Meets the New (3-D Printing)
text: It is only a coincidence that the opening of the 3-D Print Design Show on Thursday at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in New York should coincide with the start of New York International Bridal Week, whose runway shows will be held farther up the Hudson River at Piers 92 and 94 and elsewhere in the city.

headline: Review: ‘Monkey Kingdom’ Invests a Wild Chimp With Girl Power
text: Imposing human motives, emotions and story lines on wild animals is probably never a good idea for a nature documentary, but it’s done to especially annoying effect in “Monkey Kingdom,” a new feature from Disneynature aimed at younger children.

headline: Review: ‘Unfriended,’ in the Scariest Ways You Can Think Of
text: A skinflint’s dream, “Unfriended” either raises or lowers the bar for low-budget, big-studio synergy. More provocative sizzle than bloody-disgusting steak, it features a small cast of whozat young actors and was directed by another question mark, Leo Gabriadze. The most recognizable name is Timur Bekmambetov, the cult filmmaker (“Night Watch”) turned Hollywood name (“Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter”), who cooked up the idea of making a movie that unfolds almost entirely on computer windows. One of Mr. Bekmambetov’s former employees, Nelson Greaves, wrote the script, and they both also helped produce.

headline: Ryan Sullivan Scales Up
text: The young painter Ryan Sullivan makes the type of ethereal drip abstractions one might expect to require a three-page pamphlet for explanation; but in fact, most of his descriptions are simple. That’s not an insult — quite the contrary. Sullivan speaks of his practice with sharp, fine-tuned language. “I’m trying to deal with these parameters that I’ve set in front of me and the event of making this thing,” says the 32-year-old Rhode Island School of Design graduate. “There’s something closely linked between the image that you see, the process of making it and the material. There’s nothing else. There’s no subject matter tacked on top of that, it’s much more about how closely those things can be bound together.” This week, Sullivan opens his first solo and American institutional exhibition at Miami’s Institute of Contemporary Art — the institution founded by former employees of the Museum of Contemporary Art, North Miami, that’s lately been closely watched in the art world after its recent move to the Design District (on the second floor of the charming 1912 Moore building) and appointment of a not-yet-30-year-old deputy director and chief curator (Alex Gartenfeld, a former Art in America editor).

headline: Review: ‘Closer to the Moon’ Recounts a Bizarre Bit of Romanian History
text: “Closer to the Moon,” a fictionalized tale about a weird chapter in Romanian history, tries hard to slap a smiley face on a calamity. In 1959, a group of formerly true-believing Romanian Communists, all Jewish, did the unthinkable when they robbed a branch of the state (and only) bank. They were soon caught, but the story went from curious to crackpot when officials decided that the robbers would portray themselves in a state-produced film titled “Reconstruction,” recreating their gangsta roles with secret meetings, gats and getaway cars. Apparently believing that the state might go easier on them if they cooperated, the robbers played along, all the way through the show-trial end.

headline: Roadblocks to Sharing Medical Records
text: The ability to transfer electronic medical records from one doctor or hospital to another is essential to the smooth functioning of the health care system and to providing the best possible care to patients. Yet all too often these transfers are being blocked by developers of health information technology or greedy medical centers that refuse to send records to rival providers.

headline: Review: ‘Felix and Meira,’ a Portrait of a Tempted Hasidic Wife
text: Unfolding on snowy sidewalks and beneath overcast skies, “Felix and Meira” watches ever so closely as a young Hasidic wife and mother is tempted by the quirky charms of a wayward older man.

headline: The Economy Still Needs More Help Than It’s Getting
text: For economy watchers, more angst than usual has surrounded the release of recent economic reports. The uneasiness began two weeks ago, when data showed an abrupt and unexpected slowdown in job growth in March. That decline upped the importance of subsequent reports. If they were strong, the slump in March could be dismissed as a fluke. If they were weak….

headline: Staten Island Rising
text: This year could mark a turning point for the borough, with major projects starting construction and hundreds of new apartments coming to market.

headline: Review: In ‘The Dead Lands,’ the Maori Fight for Survival
text: The burdens of tribal responsibility weigh heavily on Toa Fraser’s “The Dead Lands” and its Maori warriors, but, inconveniently, so does some ponderous and cluttered filmmaking. Set deep in New Zealand forests long before colonization and performed in the Maori language, Mr. Fraser’s full-dress action drama follows a chieftain’s son surviving after his family is slaughtered by merciless enemies.

headline: Going Interactive at Tribeca With Storyscapes
text: WITHIN a few minutes of entering “Door Into the Dark,” an interactive installation at the Tribeca Film Festival, you are, quite literally, at the end of your rope. The installation, which invites participants to take a visionless, disorienting journey in a big black box, is one of five projects in this year’s Storyscapes, a division of the festival that presents experiments in narrative and storytelling.

headline: WikiLeaks Posts Sony Pictures Documents, Angering the Studio
text: LOS ANGELES — Sony Pictures Entertainment reacted harshly on Thursday to word that WikiLeaks, a web portal devoted to disclosing confidential information from governments, corporations and other large and powerful entities, had posted a searchable archive of emails and other documents stolen from the studio last year by hackers.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: On Holocaust Day in Israel, Strangers Answer the Call to a Funeral
text: JERUSALEM — Most of the mourners had never met Nate Remer, who survived the Holocaust hiding in a Ukrainian forest, built a successful wholesale hardware business in Southern California and had severe dementia for 15 years before dying Tuesday at 82. They did not know his son, Gary, a professor at Tulane University, or his grandson, Moshe Alexander, who moved to Israel five years ago and works in high tech.

headline: Review: In ‘Antarctic Edge,’ a Region of Retreating Ice
text: There aren’t many uncharted areas left on the globe, but “Antarctic Edge: 70° South” takes viewers to a spot where surveying is so scarce that the destinations may diverge from their locations on a map. Exploring that terrain could mean getting caught in ice for a month, as one scientist in the film recounts experiencing.

headline: Carmelo Anthony Says He’s Much Clearer About Knicks’ Future
text: If there was a positive thing that Carmelo Anthony could take from the Knicks’ brutal 2014-15 season, he said, it might be clarity.

headline: Lower East Side Galleries
text: Holland Cotter’s walk through the galleries of the Lower East Side.

headline: Galleries in Brooklyn and Queens
text: Martha Schwendener’s tour through the galleries of the boroughs.

headline: Chelsea Galleries
text: Roberta Smith’s walk through the galleries of Chelsea.

headline: 10 Galleries to Visit in Brooklyn and Queens
text: The difference between Brooklyn and the city’s other art districts is that a huge number of artists actually live here — ask anyone who’s reviewed applications for grants or fellowships for artists.

headline: 10 Galleries to Visit on the Lower East Side
text: THE Lower East Side was once frontier territory, where new immigrants settled alongside poets and artists, punk musicians and anarchists, everyone needing rock-bottom rent. In the 1980s, the neighborhood soaked up some of the limelight trained on the East Village art scene, and began the slow creep toward gentrification. A decade or so ago, when art dealers started to set up shop below East Houston Street, a vague hope beat in the hearts of some observers that the neighborhood might be an alternative, in art and attitude alike, to Chelsea. I doubt anyone harbors that hope today. Mostly, the Lower East Side gallery scene is Chelsea with more storefronts and cheaper retail. Still, it has a certain margin of flexibility, and sometimes it uses it. And that’s good to see.

headline: 10 Galleries to Visit in Chelsea
text: NO gallery scene is static, but lately Chelsea’s has been especially in flux.

headline: Distinct Prisms in an Ever-Shifting Kaleidoscope
text: With female artists more visible than ever, here are five who have put their stamp on the current gallery moment. They work in studios from Sunnyside to Crown Heights to Paris, in paint, porcelain and pixels.

headline: Review: ‘Below Dreams,’ the Human Struggle in the City Below Sea Level
text: Garrett Bradley’s “Below Dreams” hovers around three people in their 20s striving separately in New Orleans. With an impressionistic style and mostly nonprofessional actors, what emerges is a handful of adequate scenes that constitute an assortment of notes toward a film rather than a final draft.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for April 17-23
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Jazz Listings for April 17-23
Movie Listings for April 17-23
text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Ontario Will Loosen Rules to Allow Beer Sales in Largest Supermarkets
text: OTTAWA — Ontario, Canada’s most populous province, said on Thursday that it would partly open its beer retailing system, which is dominated by three of the world’s largest breweries.

headline: Galleries in SoHo and Tribeca
text: Martha Schwendener takes a tour through the galleries of SoHo and Tribeca.

headline: 10 Galleries to Visit in SoHo and TriBeCa
text: IN SoHo, the real estate casualties just keep coming: Last year Pearl Paint, the venerable art supply store on Canal Street, closed. This month Pearl River Mart, the Chinese department store where you can buy everything from paper lanterns to cheap ceramics, announced its departure. Rent on its Broadway space is reported to exceed a heart-stopping $500,000 a month. Yet, amazingly, despite the growing glut of flagship stores, SoHo remains a great place to see art; its nonprofit spaces are thriving. And few things are as satisfying as braving the consumerist hordes, ducking into an art space that is hidden in plain sight, and having your consciousness altered without spending any money at all.

headline: See Art Now: 50 New York Art Galleries to Visit This Weekend
text: THERE is no New York art world; there are only art worlds: a planetary system with no sun at its center.

headline: Civil Lawsuit Against Jameis Winston
text: The former Florida State student Erica Kinsman filed a lawsuit in state court in Florida against Jameis Winston, the former Florida State quarterback, and accused him of “forcible rape.”

headline: Upper East Side Galleries
text: Holland Cotter’s walk through the galleries of the Upper East Side.

headline: 10 Galleries to Visit on the Upper East Side
text: IN terms of New York City gallery history, the Upper East Side, roughly from 57th Street northward, is the establishment, the old regime. Galleries that put the city on the international map in the 1950s started here. Several of our big museums call this turf home. So do several of the elite contemporary galleries that now serve as feeding tubes to those museums.

headline: Gisele Bündchen’s Runway Walks Through the Years
text: A look back at Ms. Bündchen’s runway career.

headline: Review: In ‘Beyond the Reach,’ Michael Douglas as a Greedy Ogre in the Desert
text: How many times can a guy lose his marbles? If the guy is Michael Douglas, apparently as many times as he wants.

headline: Classical & Opera Listings for April 17-23
text: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Gisele Bündchen May Not Be Off the Runway Just Yet
text: “Why would she do this to us?” wailed Anita Bitton, the fashion-industry casting director, when confronted with the news of Gisele Bündchen’s apparent retirement from the runway.

headline: Is Slack Really Worth $2.8 Billion? A Conversation With Stewart Butterfield
text: When I recently wrote about Slack, a corporate messaging app that has aspirations to replace email, investors valued the company at $1 billion. That was a month ago. Today, the start-up announced that it has raised $160 million from a half dozen investors, and that it is now worth $2.8 billion.

headline: Comedy Listings for April 17-23
text: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Jameis Winston Being Sued by Woman Who Accused Him of Rape in 2012
text: The woman who accused the former Florida State quarterback Jameis Winston of sexually assaulting her in 2012 filed a lawsuit against him on Thursday, two weeks before the N.F.L. draft.

headline: This Week’s Movies | April 17, 2015
text: The New York Times film critics review “Child 44,” “Alex of Venice” and “Unfriended.”

headline: Allan McCollum’s One-of-a-Kind Shapes in ‘For the Millions/Just for You’
text: “PEOPLE accuse me of making fun of the art world, of cynically satirizing it,” the artist Allan McCollum once said. “But I only feel I’m trying to dramatize it, to reduce it to its most simple codes.” During an era when the contemporary art world can feel like a planet for the 1 percent — soaring auction prices, private museums, new international art fairs by the week — the codes seem ever more exclusive and cryptic. Yet at the same time, entry to one of the largest contemporary-art collections anywhere in the world — the galleries of New York City — is free. To enjoy it, you don’t need much more than a good pair of walking shoes, a list of addresses and an open mind.

headline: ‘For the Millions/Just for You (One Hundred and Eight Unique Shapes Out of Over Thirty-One Billion)’
text: The New York Times asked the artist Allan McCollum, a pioneering Conceptual artist, to create a work specifically for a newspaper page.

headline: Review: Beth Gill’s ‘Portrait Study,’ Improvised Death at the Live Ideas Festival
text: It was an odd night at New York Live Arts on Wednesday. For one thing, exceptional dancers kept dying. Or that is was it looked like, as one by one they entered, moved around a bit and collapsed on the ground, lying there as more and more dancers succumbed to the same fate.

headline: Pop, Rock & Cabaret Listings for April 17-23
text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: Robert Ashley’s ‘Crash’ Opens at Roulette
text: Robert Ashley, the brilliant, innovative American composer who died in March last year at 83, created a distinctive operatic aesthetic, a surrealist, meditative style instantly recognizable as his own. Operas of all genres often have surrealist elements, whether the fantastical plot lines of Handel or the satirical quirks of Shostakovich. But Mr. Ashley’s engrossing stage works feature ordinary people, taking on a surrealist hue through the imaginative use of voices: singsong patterns of multiple speakers that blend into scores both direct and elusive.

headline: Dance Listings for April 17-23
text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Theater Listings for April 17-23
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: MATA Festival’s Sounds of Play
text: A playground swing, a set of miniature panpipes and a chorus of table lamps were among the instruments in use at the Kitchen on Tuesday and Wednesday during the first two concerts presented by the MATA festival of new music. One trend that emerged early on was the playful experimentation with objects — found, invented and tinkered with — as a conduit for sound.

headline: Spare Times for Children for April 17-23
text: ‘Take the Stage With Broadway Stars’

headline: African-American Life, Double-Exposed
text: “Through the African American Lens,” culled from a Smithsonian collection, shows how photography – and black photographers – reshaped a people’s image.

headline: Vanity Fair Updates Article by NBC Reporter Engel
text: Vanity Fair on Thursday updated the account it had published by the NBC News correspondent Richard Engel about his 2012 kidnapping in Syria, stating that he had misidentified his captors.

headline: Spare Times for April 17-23
text: Around Town

headline: No. 2 Lawyer for New York City, Set to Retire, Looks Back
text: When Jeffrey D. Friedlander went to work as a lawyer for New York City in 1970, he was hired by Norman Redlich, his former law professor at New York University, his salary was $13,300 and John V. Lindsay was mayor. When he retires in June as the Law Department’s second in command, he will have worked for 13 corporation counsels and seven mayors.

headline: David Makol, Known for Pursuit of Insider Trading Cases While at F.B.I., Joins S.E.C.
text: Before David Makol scared insider trading suspects into cooperating with the F.B.I., and long before he helped investigate the Boston Marathon bombing, he was a low-level examiner at the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Review: Ali Akbar Moradi in Concert at Elebash Recital Hall
text: Love, spirituality, intoxication with the divine and the power of music were all channeled through ancient, basic instruments at Ali Akbar Moradi’s concert on Wednesday night at Elebash Recital Hall at the City University of New York Graduate Center. “Instead of bringing a clergyman to direct me toward God,” he sang, “bring me a musician.” The concert was part of Live@365, a world-music series at the center.

headline: Italy Accuses Muslim Migrants of Killing Christians at Sea
text: ROME — The Italian police on Thursday charged 15 Muslim men with homicide aggravated by religious hatred after survivors of a migrant boat rescued in the Mediterranean told investigators that the men had menaced Christians on board and thrown a dozen Christians overboard to their deaths.

headline: Journalists at Gawker Media’s Websites Are Planning to Unionize
text: Employees at Gawker Media, the parent company of websites like Gawker and Deadspin, are planning to unionize.

headline: After $1 Billion Loss, Senior Citadel Manager Derek Kaufman Steps Down
text: A senior manager at the hedge fund Citadel has left after losing $1 billion of investors’ money last year.

headline: Deesha Dyer, a Former Music Writer, Is Named President’s Social Secretary
text: Deesha Dyer, a former music and hip-hop culture writer, has been selected as President Obama’s new social secretary, overseeing the parties and public events held almost daily at the White House.

headline: U.N. Security Council Sees Video Evidence of a Chemical Attack in Syria
text: UNITED NATIONS — A Monday night in March, at 8:30. The sound of helicopters, then a thud, then the smell of bleach, overpowering, followed by a surge of wounded to the local hospital. They were all short of breath. Some vomited. All reeked of bleach.

headline: Iraqi Premier Softens Tone About Saudis
text: WASHINGTON — One day after he sharply criticized Saudi Arabia’s military intervention in Yemen, Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi of Iraq on Thursday said that he still wanted to maintain good ties with the Saudis and hoped that they would open an embassy in Baghdad soon.

headline: A Police Shot to a Boy’s Back in Queens, Echoing Since 1973
text: It was 1973, long before anyone could imagine hashtag declarations of solidarity and protest, the kind of message to the world that today might read, #IamCliffordGloverInTheFourthGrade.

headline: Rahul Gandhi, an Heir Apparent in India, Ends a Secretive Absence
text: NEW DELHI — Fifty-seven days after the Indian National Congress party’s heir apparent, Rahul Gandhi, mysteriously absented himself from New Delhi, leaving word through his office that he needed a few weeks off to “reflect on recent events,” he returned with equally little explanation on Thursday, striding into his house as a scrum of television reporters said things like “He has stepped out of the vehicle!” and “He was wearing dark glasses!”

headline: British Election Photo Ops With Children Go Awry
text: As campaigning intensifies before next month’s general election in Britain, candidates have been forced to respond to the U.K. Independence Party’s calls to restrict immigration, by leaving the European Union.

headline: Trial of Karma al-Khayat, Lebanese Journalist, Begins in Hague Tribunal
text: PARIS — A Lebanese journalist went on trial Thursday before an international tribunal to face charges of obstruction of justice and contempt of court for publishing confidential information from the international investigation into the 2005 assassination of Rafik Hariri, a former Lebanese prime minister.

headline: Amid Dean Skelos Inquiry, Contracting by Nassau County Faces Review
text: A corruption unit of the Nassau County district attorney’s office will open a review of county contracting practices, in response to revelations that a federal investigation into the leader of the New York State Senate is focused in part on a county storm water contract.

headline: Mayor de Blasio, in Iowa, Cites ‘Rampant Inequality’ in U.S.
text: DES MOINES — The tall man from out of town came dressed in the colors of the flag, carrying a message of woe about the nation: Washington, he lamented, was out of touch; working-class people were hurting; and political parties had “a lot of explaining to do.”

headline: In Canada, It’s March Madness in April
text: OTTAWA — The swaggering confidence that fans of the Ottawa Senators displayed Wednesday night is a relatively new phenomenon. Last month, when it looked as if the Senators might defy the odds and make the playoffs, the anxious local conversation was about jinxes, hexes and curses.

headline: Mix of Curiosity and Outrage on the Hill After Pilot Buzzes Capitol
text: WASHINGTON — Some prominent lawmakers raised questions on Thursday about how the pilot of a gyrocopter, eager to deliver a protest message to Congress over campaign finance laws, was able to fly the aircraft apparently undetected through protected airspace and land near the Capitol.

headline: Levi Watkins, 70, Dies; Pioneering Heart Surgeon Pushed Civil Rights
text: Dr. Levi Watkins Jr., the first surgeon to successfully implant an automatic heart defibrillator in a human patient, and a civil rights pioneer who helped fling open medical school doors to hundreds of students who had been excluded — as he had once been — because they were black, died on Saturday in Baltimore. He was 70.

headline: Ira Lewis, Actor and Playwright, Dies at 82
text: Ira Lewis, an actor turned playwright whose comedies, often with star-studded casts, skewered the neuroses and pretensions of writers and artists, died on April 4 in Edison, N.J. He was 82.

headline: Thelma Coyne Long, Australian Tennis Champion, Dies at 96
text: Thelma Coyne Long, an Australian tennis star who won 19 Grand Slam titles at midcentury, died on Tuesday in Narrabeen, near Sydney. She was 96.

headline: Matt McKenna, Bill Clinton’s Spokesman, Is Leaving for Uber
text: Former President Bill Clinton’s longtime spokesman, Matt McKenna, is leaving his current role for a communications job at Uber, the by-order car service that has swelled in size in the last two years.

headline: A Time for Phil Jackson to Raise His Game
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — If Phil Jackson’s first full-season performance as president of the Knicks has fallen woefully short of being commensurate with his $12 million annual salary, payback can begin in the playoffs. His 17-victory team has mercifully gone home. It is time for him to learn as much as he can about those clubs that remain.

headline: New York City Council Votes to Restrict Credit Checks in Hiring
text: The City Council passed a bill on Thursday that will make New York the 12th jurisdiction in the country to prohibit employers from using credit checks to screen job applicants.

headline: Review: ‘The King and I,’ Back on Broadway
text: A big, scrupulously detailed 19th-century ship glides toward the audience in the opening moments of Bartlett Sher’s resplendent production of Rodgers and Hammerstein’s “The King and I,” which opened on Thursday night at the Vivian Beaumont Theater. It’s an impressive sight, worthy of every “oooh” it elicits. But its presence wouldn’t count for nearly as much if it weren’t carrying such precious cargo.

headline: Charge Leader
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — To the average solver, who might not even notice bylines, this might not matter. But as a female constructor, I find a themeless crossword that a woman has constructed as a welcome thing to see.

headline: For Sale: Aging Boat That Had an Unenviable Job
text: Kevin Byrnes stood on the bridge of the Newtown Creek, an aging, 300-foot-long tanker that has served New York City since 1967, and looked admiringly down its length.

headline: Fee to Be Charged for Video of South Carolina Shooting, Publicist Says
text: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — The video of a North Charleston police officer shooting an unarmed man in the back will now cost news outlets that want to run it $10,000, according to a publicist representing the man who shot it.

headline: Rangers Seize Quick Lead and Don’t Let Go
text: The regular season ended, and for the Rangers the days passed by like ellipses, a cliffhanger, a tantalizing pause bridging all that has happened with all that they hope is still to come.

headline: Mexico’s President Rolls Out Plan to Save Endangered Porpoise
text: MEXICO CITY — President Enrique Peña Nieto and his top military commanders flew to a modest fishing village in Mexico’s far northwest on Thursday and made a promise to protect a small porpoise called the vaquita that is on the edge of extinction.

headline: Two Found Dead on Brooklyn Railroad Tracks
text: The bodies of two unidentified men were found on railroad tracks in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn on Thursday.

headline: Ukraine: Gunmen Kill Pro-Russian Journalist in Kiev
text: A Ukrainian journalist with a vocal pro-Russian stance was killed in Kiev, the capital, by unidentified gunmen on Thursday, a day after a pro-Russian lawmaker was killed in a similar attack. The journalist, Oles Buzina, 45, publicly opposed the protests that led to the ouster of President Viktor F. Yanukovych in 2014. The current president, Petro O. Poroshenko, called for a swift investigation and declared that the recent killings were “conscious provocations” intended to “destabilize domestic politics in Ukraine.” President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said Ukraine’s government was allowing a campaign of political violence against supporters of the previous government.

headline: At ‘Politics and Pie’ Event, Jeb Bush Goes Against the Republican Grain
text: Jeb Bush indicated on Thursday night that President Obama’s choice for attorney general, Loretta E. Lynch, ought to be confirmed – putting him at odds with a number of Senate Republicans who’ve said they would try to block the nomination.

headline: Voting Ends in Sudan With a Small Turnout
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — Voting ended Thursday in Sudan’s elections, with a low turnout despite a one-day extension.

headline: New York State Elections Board Retains a Corporate Donation Loophole
text: ALBANY — The State Board of Elections declined on Thursday to change a longstanding ruling that critics say has allowed millions of dollars to flow, virtually unchecked, into campaign coffers across New York.

headline: Chinese Journalist Sentenced to 7 Years on Charges of Leaking State Secrets
text: HONG KONG — Gao Yu, a 71-year-old Chinese journalist who has repeatedly challenged the Communist Party during a decades-long career, was sentenced to seven years in prison on Friday after a court in Beijing found her guilty of leaking state secrets abroad. Ms. Gao said she would appeal, according to her lawyer and her brother, who were in the courtroom.

headline: Jewell Loyd and Amanda Zahui B. Are Top Two Picks in W.N.B.A. Draft
text: UNCASVILLE, Conn. — The Seattle Storm of the W.N.B.A. selected Jewell Loyd first overall in the draft Thursday, the second early entrant to earn the honor after the Los Angeles Sparks took Tennessee’s Candace Parker No. 1 in 2008. Amanda Zahui B. was selected second overall by the Tulsa Shock.

headline: Just Like Mets Imagined It: Clutch Offense, Fifth Straight Win, First Place
text: The Mets talked all winter about winning, about contending, and they dreamed about scenes such as the one at Citi Field on Thursday. Lucas Duda delivered the big hit, sending home the go-ahead run against the Miami Marlins. The crowd was on its feet, chanting “Doo-da! Doo-da!” The Mets won their fifth game in a row and jumped into first place in the National League East.

headline: Under Deal, Living Wage for Workers at a Tower in Hudson Yards
text: New York City officials said on Thursday that all of the workers in a proposed office tower in the Hudson Yards project in Midtown Manhattan will be paid at least $13.30 an hour, the first broad application of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s executive order mandating a living wage.

headline: Unlicensed Dental Work in the Bronx Leads to Arrest

headline: What’s On TV Friday
text: 8:10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) FOOTNOTE (2012) The tension-filled relationship between rival Talmudic scholars — Eliezer (Shlomo Bar Aba, above), who toils in obscurity under the belief that his career was blocked by a nemesis, and Uriel (Lior Ashkenazi), an academic star with a busy schedule of public lectures — becomes more complicated when Eliezer is mistakenly awarded a coveted prize meant for Uriel, who happens to be his son. But how to correct the error? Under the direction of Joseph Cedar, the American-born Israeli director, “the fraught relations between father and son erupt into an intergenerational tsimmes worthy of Shakespeare, Freud or the more melodramatic portions of the Hebrew Bible,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this Oscar nominee for best foreign-language film. “It plays as farce, but the chords of family tragedy resonate underneath the laughter.” Resolution, he added, “is unlikely, which may or may not be cause for optimism. Academic life and family life are both built on love — the love of learning, the love of other people — but they survive on contention, renewing and extending quarrels from one generation to the next.”

headline: At Helsinki Airport, a New Snooze Option
text: The Helsinki Airport hopes to help jet-lagged travelers catch up on their sleep with the introduction of new sleeping pods at two of its international gates.

headline: African-American Life, Double-Exposed
text: The late 1930s image by Eliot Elisofon shows Zack Brown taking a picture of two dapper African-American men on a Harlem street. It challenged the then-dominant view of black urban life, focusing on dignity instead of suffering, self-possession instead of defeat, happiness instead of sorrow. Mr. Elisofon’s picture also reminds us of the powerful role of photography in African-American life, how the medium — and black photographers — helped reshape the image of a people.

headline: Help for Victims of Crooked Schools
text: State attorneys general have long served on the front lines of the struggle to control and discipline predatory for-profit colleges that saddle students with crippling debt while granting them useless degrees, or no degrees at all. On April 9, nine of them who know firsthand how people can be deceived and bled dry sent a letter to the Department of Education, asking it to provide restitution — and help fix the problem — by forgiving the federal student loans of people harmed by crooked schools. The letter makes a strong case for prompt action.

headline: California Groundwater
Racial Terror, Fast and Slow
text: WASHINGTON — IN the past two years, this country has held events commemorating 50 years since the triumphs and key struggles of the civil rights movement: the March on Washington, the Civil Rights Act and, most recently, the “Bloody Sunday” march in Selma, Ala.

headline: That Old-Time Economics
text: BRUSSELS — America has yet to achieve a full recovery from the effects of the 2008 financial crisis. Still, it seems fair to say that we’ve made up much, though by no means all, of the lost ground.

headline: A View From Thailand’s Ambassador
text: To the Editor:

headline: When Cultures Shift
text: In January 1969, two quarterbacks played against each other in Super Bowl III. Johnny Unitas and Joe Namath were both superstars. They were both from Western Pennsylvania, but they came from different cultural universes. Unitas was reticent, workmanlike and deliberately unglamorous. Namath was flashy and a playboy. He turned himself into a marketing brand and wrote a memoir jokingly called, “I Can’t Wait Until Tomorrow ’Cause I Get Better Looking Every Day.”

headline: The Revolt Over Standardized Tests in New York Schools
Want Reform? Principals Matter, Too
text: POLITICIANS and education reformers are fixated on the performance of teachers, but they often overlook another key ingredient for improving student achievement: principals. The problem is that great principals often don’t end up in the schools that need them most — those with poor and minority students. School districts, states and universities need to do much more to get outstanding principals into these schools.

headline: Turkey’s Willful Amnesia
text: Next Friday, April 24, Armenians the world over will commemorate the 100th anniversary of the start of the mass killings of Armenians in Ottoman Turkey, now widely recognized as the first genocide of the 20th century. Widely, that is, outside Turkey, where the government and the majority of Turks continue to furiously attack anyone who speaks of genocide.

headline: Staten Island’s Turning Point?
text: A wide bay may separate Staten Island from the rest of the city. But in terms of real estate, differences between the borough and other enclaves seem to be lifting like a morning fog.

headline: For Lucasfilm, the Way of Its Force Lies in Its ‘Star Wars’ Fans
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Even in the social media age, some movie studios still see fans as zoo animals to be force-fed: We, the cool film people, will tell you, the easily manipulated consumers, what to like. Other Hollywood companies have developed a true appreciation for the geek masses, but they are still learning how to hone a strategy.

headline: Appeals Panel Weighs Fate of Obama’s Immigration Overhaul
text: NEW ORLEANS — The immediate fate of President Obama’s sweeping immigration overhaul now rests with a three-judge appeals panel after an intense legal clash on Friday between lawyers for the federal government and for a 26-state coalition that has challenged the executive actions.

headline: U.N. Calls on Western Nations to Shelter Syrian Refugees
text: UNITED NATIONS — With Syria’s neighbors increasingly shutting their borders to refugees and thousands trying to cross the Mediterranean Sea in search of safety, the war in Syria is creating the worst global refugee crisis in decades, putting new pressure on the United States and other Western countries to open their doors — and in turn, prompting domestic political backlash.

headline: What’s Your Favorite Sandwich?
text: Smoked turkey, hot pastrami or the classic P.B. & J.? Spicy mayo, a drizzle of olive oil or pickled peppers? Sharp Cheddar, pepper jack or Gruyere? Toasted rye, sliced focaccia or a sesame-seed bun?

headline: Q. and A.: Willis Barnstone on Translating Mao and Touring Beijing With Allen Ginsberg
text: Willis Barnstone is a polymath author of more than 70 books — a poet, translator and scholar of Gnosticism and the New Testament. But the 87-year-old also has had a long and colorful relationship with China, translating Mao Zedong’s poetry and befriending numerous Chinese artists and political leaders in the 1980s.
