headline: Reining In Soldiers of Fortune
text: WASHINGTON — Ten years ago, I found myself in Burundi, sipping a Coke with the country’s president, the American ambassador and the president’s 8-year-old daughter. The president’s life was in danger, and the American government sent me in to keep him alive.

headline: Overcoming Poverty’s Damage to Learning
text: In the weeks after 9/11, Pamela Cantor, a child psychiatrist specializing in trauma, was enlisted by the New York City Board of Education to lead a team studying the impact of the attacks on the city’s public school children.

headline: In Ireland, Chasing the Wandering Soul of Yeats
text: Exploring Innisfree, the tiny bristling island in the middle of a lake that William Bulter Yeats immortalized in verse.

headline: Sweet and Salty: Majorca’s Traditional Cuisine
text: Dinner at Ca N’ignasi was a parade of delicious oddities. An empanada that looked liked a tribal crown got its earthen color from cuttlefish ink in the dough. A coca, a type of flat bread normally topped with roasted vegetables, was capped by strands of briny whitebait.

headline: Crossing to Safety
text: My father died when I was only a year old, and my mom had six children to care for. My husband’s family always came around to help my mom out. When I was a toddler and my husband was 13, he used to carry me on his back to escape bombings during the Vietnam War. When I grew up, my family suggested I marry him. They said it would lighten the load and lift us from poverty. I was 19.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Kneipp Herbal Bath Oils
text: Not so long ago, I was given a bottle of jewel-toned Kneipp Herbal Bath Oil as a gift. It was packaged in a pretty glass bottle, like crème liqueur. Also like crème liqueur, it seemed pointless. I ignored it. For two decades, bath-taking was something I filed under the category of Things I Don’t Do, for Reasons of No Moral Significance. Other items in this class include whistling (physically incapable of it), parallel parking (don’t own a car) and twerking (hurts my back).

headline: ‘’N’em’
text: The colloquialism of the title, which means “and them” — as in “Tell your mama ’n’em I said hello” — encompasses a host of people made familiar by the world of the poem. Most of us have known them: elders and distant ancestors whose way of being was rooted in the wisdom of folk knowledge, a generation now all but gone. Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.

headline: How to Negotiate a Ransom
text: “Make sure they’re alive first,” says Leslie Edwards, a top hostage negotiation specialist and former British Army officer. Demand to speak to the captive on the phone, or better still, on video chat. If that is not possible, ask the abductor to answer what Edwards calls a “proof-of-life question,” something only the kidnapped would know, like the name of a pet goldfish. Ransom amounts vary widely. At the high end, Edwards once settled at $10 million to secure the release of 26 crew members aboard an oil tanker held by Somali pirates, but he has also freed a detainee in Afghanistan for less than $10,000. A counteroffer to the first ransom demands should be a result of exhaustive research. “You don’t need to know their names, but you need to know their modus operandi and their track record,” Edwards says. Whether the hostage-takers’ motives are purely mercenary or derive from a more dangerous mix of ideology, politics and greed, this is not the time to be a cheapskate. “Make a decent opening offer that puts value on the life of the hostage,” he says.

headline: Re: Note to Self
text: It is what it is. When Colson Whitehead wrote in the April 5 issue about the use of tautological phrases like “You do you” and “Haters gonna hate” as evidence of an increasingly narcissistic culture, he hit a nerve with readers.

headline: Mona Eltahawy Doesn’t Need to Be Rescued
text: In your new book, “Headscarves and Hymens: Why the Middle East Needs a Sexual Revolution,” you write about your decision to start wearing the hijab as a teenager. What prompted it? My family moved to Saudi Arabia from the U.K. when I was 15. I was groped twice while on pilgrimage to Mecca. It made me feel like I just wanted to hide my body. I struck a deal with God. I said: “They say a good Muslim woman should wear a head scarf. I’ll do it if you save my mind.”

headline: The Man Who Carried Lincoln’s Torch
text: It seemed all of Washington had gone to the theater on April 14, 1865 – Good Friday – to hail the imminent end of the war. Grover’s New National Theater celebrated with a performance of “Aladdin, or the Wonderful Lamp,” along with the reading of an original patriotic poem, the singing of the popular new war song “When Sherman Marched Down to the Sea,” a massive panorama painting of Fort Sumter and a “Magnificent Pyrotechnic Display.” Although President and Mary Lincoln had declined Leonard Grover’s invitation, the audience included Tad Lincoln and his tutor. Also in the packed house was a 21-year-old clerk in the War Department named Jim Tanner, who left a record of his evening in a long letter he wrote to a friend several days later.

headline: Cam Talbot, One of the Most Valuable Rangers, Now Just Sits and Watches
text: About eight hours before Game 1 of their first-round playoff series Thursday against the Penguins, Rangers goaltender Henrik Lundqvist addressed a media scrum around his locker. He discussed an array of topics, describing his approach and the top-seeded team’s position as the favorite in the series.

headline: The Boat to Lift All Tides
text: Out on Lake Washington, you hear them in the predawn murk: coaches barking, rowers gasping, sounds as familiar to the morning as the Canada geese that clack above the boys and girls in the boats. In Seattle’s first light, you see the slender crafts cutting through the chop of the lake, oars dipping in strained union.

headline: Today in Politics: The Republican Dance Card Fills Up in New Hampshire
text: Good Friday morning from Washington, where the relationship between Congress and the Obama administration continues its prickly course. But the primary focus moves from Iowa to New Hampshire, the state of derailed presidencies and second chances, which welcomes 19 Republican presidential hopefuls for a weekend of 30-minute pitches.

headline: Arnaldur Indridason’s ‘Reykjavik Nights,’ and More
text: Arnaldur Indridason isn’t like other authors of Nordic crime fiction. The crimes he writes about aren’t particularly gruesome. His villains aren’t excessively violent, nor are his victims especially remarkable. And his detective hero is so taciturn he’s barely socialized. But the Icelandic author’s latest novel, REYKJAVIK NIGHTS (Thomas Dunne/Minotaur, $25.99), nicely illustrates the qualities that make his books so deeply pleasurable.

headline: Morning Agenda: Bharara’s Tension With Judges
text: BHARARA’S TENSION WITH JUDGES | Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, “is locked in what seems to be an escalating war of words with the federal judiciary,” James B. Stewart writes in the Common Sense column.

headline: We Armenians Shouldn’t Let Genocide Define Us
text: ON April 9, Armenia’s prime minister, Hovik Abrahamyan, welcomed an unusual visitor to his office. His guest might have blended in with the locals were it not for the film crew and bodyguards around her. But she was not just any Armenian, she was the world’s most famous person of Armenian origin: Kim Kardashian.

text: The Welsh journalist and author Jon Ronson joined Twitter on Dec. 10, 2008. He has since published more than 44,000 tweets — almost 20 each day. He has seen some things.

text: The Chicago Cubs have started the season 5-3. Would the addition of a potential superstar slugger perhaps have turned one of those losses into a win? Cubs fans certainly have a right to wonder.

headline: ‘Galileo’s Middle Finger,’ by Alice Dreger
text: “Soon enough,” Alice Dreger writes at the beginning of her romp of a book, “I will get to the death threats, the sex charges, the alleged genocides, the epidemics, the alien abductees, the anti-lesbian drug, the unethical ethicists, the fight with Martina Navratilova and, of course, Galileo’s middle finger. But first I have to tell you a little bit about how I got into this mess.”

headline: Umbrella Delivery in the Rain
text: Dear Diary:

headline: A Ban on Beef in India Is Not the Answer
text: The sacredness of cows in India might be a cliché, but it is deeply felt, rooted in the history of Hinduism. In Mumbai, one often encounters women selling grass to feed the cow they have in tow — for a few rupees, the donation affords not only a blessing, but also a chance to feel connected to the country’s farmland roots. The cow is divinely associated with Krishna, the cowherd, and considered a mother figure because of the milk it gives. One doesn’t go into an Indian branch of McDonald’s expecting to order a Big Mac.

headline: Serving All Your Heroin Needs
text: FATAL heroin overdoses in America have almost tripled in three years. More than 8,250 people a year now die from heroin. At the same time, roughly double that number are dying from prescription opioid painkillers, which are molecularly similar. Heroin has become the fallback dope when an addict can’t afford, or find, pills. Total overdose deaths, most often from pills and heroin, now surpass traffic fatalities.

headline: Ferrari Interiors for a Miami Condo
text: MIAMI — The color of the walls, floors and ceilings is a dead giveaway.

headline: Is Alexander Wang Really the Most Influential Designer in the World?
text: The Time magazine “100 Most Influential People” list is out, and there are four fashion names on it (or two, and two kind-of-fashion names): Alexander Wang, under artists; Diane von Furstenberg, under icons; and Kim Kardashian and Kanye West, under titans.

headline: Former Tullett Prebon Employee Pleads Not Guilty in Libor Case in Britain
text: A former employee of the British brokerage firm Tullett Prebon Group pleaded not guilty on Friday in a criminal inquiry into the manipulation of a global benchmark interest rate.

headline: ‘Rain: A Natural and Cultural History,’ by Cynthia Barnett
text: When I finish Cynthia Barnett’s “Rain,” I toss the book into a more-or-less waterproof pouch and walk five miles in a steady drizzle. I carry the book through a forest of moss-blanketed Sitka spruce, along a soggy gravel beach and over the slippery mud of a coastal marsh. This is the least I can do in homage to Barnett’s work.

headline: ‘Shame and the Captives’ and ‘The Evening Chorus’
text: The dislocations of wartime come in many forms. A major military conflict can destroy cities, ruin economies and inflict calamity and hardship on entire populations. But it can also cause subtler, more personal derangements, and it’s these that are the subject of two new novels, each tracing the complex “arithmetic of war” as it plays out for individuals living far from the wholesale chaos of the front lines. “Shame and the Captives,” by Thomas Keneally, and “The Evening Chorus,” by Helen Humphreys, both tell stories of far-flung P.O.W. camps during World War II, but in each case the principal focus is less on the prisoners themselves than on those living on the other side of the barbed wire.

headline: Clip: ‘The Wannabe’
text: A scene from “The Wannabe,” directed by Nick Sandow.

headline: Foot Fungus Is Better in America
text: Let’s say you have a borderline embarrassing medical condition. Here’s how it goes down in America: You go to Target, walk past the dollar bins (keep walking, your local landfill thanks you), stroll to the pharmacy located near the free restrooms, pick up your over-the-counter medication, amble toward the registers while deciding which one of the many available cashiers will have the pleasure of ringing up your purchase, and finally pick up a pack of gum or the latest Disney princess Band-Aids. A minute later, the cashier asks, “Did you find everything you needed today?”

headline: New York Times Co. Elevates Meredith Kopit Levien to Chief Revenue Officer
text: Meredith Kopit Levien, executive vice president for advertising at The New York Times Company, has been promoted to chief revenue officer and will oversee “the generation of all advertising and subscription revenue,” the company’s chief executive, Mark Thompson, said in a memorandum to employees on Friday.

headline: Taking a Facebook Break, Temporarily or for Good
text: The site lets users deactivate their accounts and then return with all content intact. Permanently deleting an account wipes it, and all the content, out.

headline: ‘Infested,’ About Bedbugs, by Brooke Borel
text: A book about bedbugs is, by necessity, a book about nearly everything: about travel and adventure, about our ­relationship to nature, about how scientists solve problems, about trust and whether we view strangers as friends or foes. It is a book about what people will do under extreme circumstances, and about environmental politics, and art and mental illness. It is even a book about kinky sex.

headline: ‘Rust: The Longest War,’ by Jonathan Waldman
text: I am afraid of the can of haggis in my kitchen cupboard. It is not that I don’t like haggis; I do. No, I am worried about what may have happened to it in the 14 years since I bought it. Now I have an idea, after reading “Rust,” which is one of those books that examine the fabric of our material world and pick at its scabs. It is a book about what is corroding away unseen and unnoticed by most of us. The heroes and antiheroes in this account of cans exploding, bridges collapsing and buildings falling apart are the engineers and corrosion experts who are either saving us all from oblivion or pushing paranoia. Jonathan Waldman, an environmental journalist, is an outsider coolly detached from this debate, although clearly fascinated by the people involved, and this is one of the main strengths of the book.

headline: As THX Gets a New Trailer, an Interview With Its Composer
text: It starts with soft, low, swarming, otherworldly sounds, then steadily builds to high-pitched unified, synthesized bliss.

headline: Verizon to Offer Slimmer TV Channel Packages to Battle Streaming Rivals
text: Verizon Communications is introducing a television offering through FiOS that gives customers more options to pay for the channels they watch and not for those they don’t.

headline: ‘The Triumph of Seeds,’ by Thor Hanson
text: “Oh, no!” I thought as I gazed at Thor Hanson’s book with pictures of seeds all lined up on the jacket in boring, well-spaced symmetry. If “The Triumph of Seeds” had really been about how the little acorn makes the mighty oak, I might have screamed. But the genius of Hanson’s fascinating, inspiring and entertaining book stems from the fact that it is not about how all kinds of things grow from seeds; it is about the seeds themselves.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE BROTHERS: The Road to an American Tragedy, by Masha Gessen. (Riverhead, $27.95.) Gessen traces the roots of the two Chechen immigrants who became the Boston Marathon bombers, and examines the attack’s aftermath.

headline: Inside the List
text: Northern Lights: With a population of 5.1 million people, Norway has fewer residents than New York City — and, by the look of things these days, more writers than Brooklyn. This is their moment in the midnight sun: Our cover next week will feature new books by Karl Ove Knausgaard, Per Petterson and Asne Seierstad, while Jo Nesbo turns up at No. 9 on the hardcover fiction list with his latest crime novel, “Blood on Snow.” Nesbo is of course a regular on the best-­seller pages, thanks to his Harry Hole mystery series, but “Blood on Snow” — about a 1970s hit man who falls in love with his target — is a stand-alone. It was inspired, Nesbo has said, by his desire to do for Oslo what Jim Carroll did for New York in “The Basketball Diaries”: “He makes Manhattan feel dangerous but also small,” Nesbo told The Yorkshire Post earlier this month. “Any big city will have its darker side, it’s inevitable, and Oslo is no different. . . . On the other hand my Oslo is a little bit more twisted and darker, a bit like Gotham City is a darker version of New York.” Nesbo is often grouped with the Swedish writers Stieg Larsson and Henning Mankell as exemplars of a recent wave of Nordic noir, but he told the newspaper he’s at a loss to explain the phenomenon: “People ask me, What is it with Scandinavian crime fiction? And I’ve been trying to come up with a smart answer, but I really don’t know.”

headline: Paperback Row
text: TO RISE AGAIN AT A DECENT HOUR, by Joshua Ferris. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $16.) Ferris’s debut novel, the first-person-plural satire “Then We Came to the End” (2007), traced the decline of an ad agency. His second, “The Unnamed” (2010), concerned a man’s debilitating compulsion to walk. “To Rise Again” follows the undoing of Paul O’Rourke, a misanthropic, Red Sox-loving dentist in midlife crisis, who watches in horror as an online impersonator promotes an obscure religion in his name.

headline: Banking on Apple Watch Will Be Limited, for Now
text: Apps will allow users to peek at their balance and recent activity, but not to pay bills or make deposits.

headline: Stuff We Liked

headline: Germanwings Memorial Service Held at Cologne Cathedral
text: COLOGNE, Germany — The leaders of Germany on Friday joined hundreds of mourning relatives in one of the country’s most hallowed cathedrals to honor the passengers and crew members who died when a jet smashed into a French mountainside last month, a crash that horrified the world after investigators said the co-pilot had deliberately brought down the plane.

headline: Orson Welles’s ‘The Lady From Shanghai’ is Reissued on Blu-ray
text: Film noir was conceived in Weimar Germany, born in wartime Hollywood and named in postwar France — which is where these dark crime films, including two new releases, Orson Welles’s “The Lady From Shanghai” (1948) and Robert Montgomery’s “Ride the Pink Horse” (1947), were most fully appreciated.

headline: 1984 | Behind the Scenes at a Long-Ago Magazine
text: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

headline: Vivendi Chairman Bolloré Wins Battle Over Double Voting Rights
text: PARIS — The chairman and biggest shareholder of Vivendi, the French company that owns Universal Music, withstood a stockholder rebellion at the company’s annual meeting on Friday, winning a battle in what could be an unusually contentious proxy season for corporate France.

headline: 1915: Italo-Austrian Fight Reported
text: Grave incidents have occurred within the last few days on the Austro-Italian frontier, writes the ‘‘Figaro’s’’ Milan correspondent. The Austrians have attacked the Italian Bersaglieri of the 11th Regiment, who repulsed the attack, crossing into Austrian territory for about 200 mètres. It is stated that 100 men were killed on both sides.

headline: How Many Fingers Does Hillary Clinton Have Up? … Five!
text: “Saturday Night Live” spoofs can bedevil politicians, burnishing their quirks in the public’s consciousness for entire campaigns and beyond.

headline: More Married Couples, Same-Sex and Straight, Are Sharing the Job of Pastor
text: HARTFORD — Cathy Rion Starr and Heather Rion Starr, the ministers of the Unitarian Society of Hartford since last summer, were reminiscing recently about a conversation early in their friendship, before they had become either romantic partners or co-workers.

headline: Sarah Jessica Parker Will Return to HBO in ‘Divorce’
text: Sarah Jessica Parker is coming home to the cable network that helped make her one of TV’s biggest stars. She will star in another HBO series set in New York, more than a decade after the series finale of “Sex and the City,” it was reported Thursday.

headline: More Older Adults Are Becoming Inventors
text: LIKE many inventors, Bob Nepper, 82, is a compulsive improver. Mr. Nepper, an electrical engineer who lives in North St. Paul, Minn., has pet projects that have included a self-guided lawn mower and an outside faucet that can run hot and cold. His basement is stocked with tools like a lathe and a milling machine to craft his ideas.

headline: Cast of ‘Hamilton’ Pays Tribute to ‘A Chorus Line’ With a Song
text: The hit Off Broadway musical “Hamilton” closed its Thursday night performance with an unusual number: “What I Did For Love” from “A Chorus Line.”

headline: Top Saddam Hussein Aide Reported Killed in Northern Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — An Iraqi provincial governor said Friday that militiamen had killed Izzat Ibrahim al-Douri, the highest-ranking official from Saddam Hussein’s government who was still on the loose, in clashes in a mountainous region of northern Iraq.

headline: Fred Segal Opens a Store, and a Food Truck, in Japan
text: Just as Japan’s cherry blossom season comes into bloom, the storied Southern California brand Fred Segal sets up shop — and a food truck — in Tokyo. The new store, situated on a recently converted urban railway site called Log Road Daikanyama, opens its doors in the Daikanyama neighborhood, among luxe boutiques (like Saturdays NYC), low-key cafes, residential homes and gleaming skyscrapers.

headline: The Path to ‘Today, I Announce ...’
text: Highlights as the 2016 presidential hopefuls make their way down a familiar path, perhaps to “yes.” There are four loosely defined stages.

headline: Mapo Tofu Goes Vegetarian
text: Mapo tofu, that aromatic dish of braised tofu with minced pork (sometimes beef) in a deeply savory sauce, is a wildly popular menu item in many Chinese restaurants. I gladly order it whenever possible. Just a spoonful or two with steamed rice makes a pleasant beginning to a multicourse meal.

headline: Cooking Techniques: Making Caramel
text: Dissolve sugar in water over heat to make caramel.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz: Exercise, Women and the Love of Dogs
text: Take the Quiz

headline: Video: Getting From ‘Not Interested’ to ‘I’m Running’
text: Back in mid-March, when he was merely an undeclared presidential hopeful, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas acknowledged that he was pretty much already running for the Republican nomination. “I will point out, a week ago, I was in Iowa,” he said to a cheering crowd. “Yesterday, I was in South Carolina. And today, I’m in New Hampshire.”

headline: Exclusive | The San Remo
text: A triplex penthouse owned by Demi Moore in the prized south tower the 1930 Emery Roth landmark is for sale at $75 million.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: This week’s properties include condos in Prospect Heights and Alphabet City and a co-op in the West Village.

headline: Demi Moore Is Seeking $75 Million for Her Central Park West Penthouse
text: The triplex south tower penthouse widely considered the crown jewel of the San Remo, the twin-peaked Emery Roth masterwork and city landmark on Central Park West, is poised to enter the market for the first time in 25 years. The asking price for the residence, PH26C, along with a two-bedroom two-bath lobby level maisonette, No. 1H, included in the sale, is $75 million, an amount that, if met, would set a record for an Upper West Side co-op and shatter the in-house record of $26.4 million achieved at the San Remo last year.

headline: Mike Huckabee Fuels Speculation With Announcement on Fox
text: Mike Huckabee, the former Republican governor of Arkansas and TV talk-show host, has been saying that he will make a decision on whether he will run for president by “sometime in the spring.”

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Spinster’ and Public Shaming
text: This week, Kate Bolick discusses “Spinster”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Jon Ronson talks about “So You’ve Been Publicly Shamed”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Spinster’ and Public Shaming
text: This week, Kate Bolick and Jon Ronson.

headline: 1940: French Canadians Guard Buckingham Palace
text: French-Canadian service members guarded Buckingham Palace in April 1940. (britishpathe.com)

headline: Letter: What We’ve Learned
text: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: How Much Festival Is Too Much Festival?
text: Jon Caramanica, Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss the vicissitudes and artistic value of music festivals.

headline: Humanitarian Crisis Grows as Iraqis Flee ISIS Threat
text: BAGHDAD — In an intensifying humanitarian crisis in Iraq’s embattled Anbar Province, thousands of residents are fleeing a pitched battle between Islamic State militants and pro-government forces around the provincial capital.

headline: Parents of Youngest Boston Marathon Victim Oppose Death Penalty for Tsarnaev
text: BOSTON — For the last few months, the government has used Bill and Denise Richard, and the death of their son Martin, to drive home the heinous and depraved nature of the bombings at the 2013 Boston Marathon.

headline: An Unwanted Dog in China
text: Tibetan mastiffs were once trendy must-have dogs for wealthy Chinese, selling for more than $200,000. But waning interest has left many breeders with unwanted dogs.

headline: No Comment Necessary: ‘Ovary’ Clinton
text: Deanna Alexander, a member of the Milwaukee County Board of Supervisors, has apparently begun calling Hillary Clinton “Ovary.” On Wednesday, she tweeted:

headline: Popcast: How Much Festival Is Too Much Festival?
text: Every summer, they rise: moist, many-tentacled, confused, chaotic, pervasive. They pop up in cities across the country – around the world! – and sprawl out largely unchecked, imposing their will upon tens of thousands of people, who find themselves helpless in their presence.

headline: Once-Prized Tibetan Mastiffs Are Discarded as Fad Ends in China
text: BEIJING — There once was a time, during the frenzied heights of China’s Tibetan mastiff craze, when a droopy-eyed slobbering giant like Nibble might have fetched $200,000 and ended up roaming the landscaped grounds of some coal tycoon’s suburban villa.

headline: Springtime Sheet-Pan Chicken
text: Most sheet-pan chicken suppers are wintry things: long-roasted one-pan meals heavy on the starchy root vegetables. They are satisfying and kitchen-warming, but not a recipe to reach for when the sun finally shines.

headline: Stories From Current and Former Success Academy Parents
text: New York City parents of current and former Success Academy students describe a learning environment that was a godsend for some children and a grind for others.

headline: Review: Cantata Profana’s Indefinable ‘Dreams and Visions’
text: When is a quartet a quintet? One answer to this stump-your-friends trivia question is Schoenberg’s String Quartet No. 2 (1908), whose four players are joined by a singer in the final two movements, intense settings of poems by Stefan George.

headline: Writer Retreats to a Kabul That Lives Only in His Memories and Books
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — FOUR large clocks tick out of sync, puncturing the silence of his Soviet-built apartment. A half-burned candle sits next to a stack of books. A small television is covered in soot.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival Interview: Nick Sandow on ‘The Wannabe’
text: This is one in a series of interviews focusing on New York-centric movies having their premieres at the Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: Why Americans Don’t Want to Soak the Rich
text: With rising income inequality in the United States, you might expect more and more people to conclude that it’s time to soak the rich. Here’s a puzzle, though: Over the last several decades, close to the opposite has happened.

headline: South Africa Moves to Quell Anti-Immigrant Violence
text: JOHANNESBURG — Shops and vehicles owned by foreigners were attacked in downtown Johannesburg on Friday as the South African government tried to quell a wave of anti-immigrant violence that has claimed at least four lives in the country.

headline: Vegetables and Cheese Meet Bread
text: This week Martha Rose Shulman joined Food’s sandwich issue with a roasted pepper and goat cheese sandwich that is ideal for travel. Vegetables and cheese, hot or cold, always make a great sandwich combination. Here are more ideas from Recipes for Health.

headline: What I Love | Sally Hershberger
text: Home is an apartment with a fireplace, sunsets out the window and friends nearby.

headline: The Logistics Behind Mayweather and Pacquiao’s 60-40 Split
text: LOS ANGELES — No matter who wins the richest boxing match in history on May 2, Manny Pacquiao will receive part of his pay the next business day from his promoter, Bob Arum.

headline: Handling Images From Sources Who Aren’t Journalists
text: Some call it “user-generated content.” The authors of a new study prefer the term “eyewitness media.”

headline: Carine Roitfeld + Uniqlo, NYFW’s New Homes and Ryan Gothling
text: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Everything’s Coming Up Daisies
text: I remember a time when a daisy was just a daisy, with its familiar yellow circle at the center, surrounded by that soft ruff of velvety white petals: cheap and lovable. And then those Gerbera daisies seemed ubiquitous in the 1990s, flashy and colorful. Sure, they’re pretty, but they seemed to be trying a little too hard.

headline: Justice Department’s Criminal Chief Pledges More Clarity
text: The Justice Department often bemoans a lack of transparency from companies facing criminal investigations. Now the Justice Department will be providing some clarity of its own.

headline: Colors Pop at Sally Hershberger’s Chelsea Home
text: Bright colors pop in Sally Hershberger’s one-bedroom rental at London Terrace Gardens. The neutrals are limited almost exclusively to the black, gray and white coats of her dogs, Cherry and Foxy.

headline: Clinton’s Stance on Marriage Equality Is Promoted in Video
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s embrace of the gay community continued on Friday with a new advertisement featuring her in a diner being thanked for supporting same-sex marriage as a constitutional right.

headline: Rodrigo Rato, Ex-I.M.F. Chief, Investigated in Spain Over Finances
text: LONDON — The financial affairs of the former International Monetary Fund chief Rodrigo Rato have come under increased scrutiny in Spain after law enforcement officials detained Mr. Rato as part of a tax and money-laundering investigation.

headline: Verbatim: A Yankee Candidate in Red Sox Country
text: — Former Gov. George Pataki of New York, addressing New Hampshire Republicans at a meeting of prospective 2016 presidential candidates on Friday, when asked about his best moment in public life. The roomful of Red Sox fans erupted in loud boos.

headline: Fraud Fed the Mortgage Crisis
text: Expanded mortgage lending in low-income neighborhoods before the foreclosure crisis was helped along by fraud — namely, the overstating of borrower income on loan applications, according to new academic research.

headline: N.B.A. Playoff Preview and Predictions: New Contenders Emerge
text: When the Cleveland Cavaliers announced that they had made a trade for the All-Star forward Kevin Love, pairing him with the returning LeBron James, one of the worst teams in basketball became a championship contender. Amid the “Coming Home” hoopla, someone forgot to tell the Golden State Warriors and the Atlanta Hawks that this was Cleveland’s year.

headline: George Bush’s Letter Cautions Family on Conflicts of Interest
text: In 1988, as George Bush ran for president, he addressed a letter to George W. Bush, urging family members to steer clear of perceived conflicts of interest.

headline: U.S. Army Trainers Arrive in Ukraine
text: MOSCOW — The Kremlin on Friday warned that the arrival of several hundred American military trainers in Ukraine could “destabilize the situation” in the country’s southeast, where a cease-fire between government troops and Russian-backed separatists is barely holding.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Strange Gun Argument
text: Americans who believe the Second Amendment gives them an individual right to own guns (as opposed to a more general right to bear arms, as our editorial board argues) often make cogent arguments for their position. I believe that allowing people to own guns is not incompatible with imposing reasonable restrictions on their ownership, but I have heard sensible people strongly argue the opposite side.

headline: The Power of Starting With ‘Yes’
text: I once served on a committee led by a powerful woman. She had strong views, but what I remember most is that whenever I spoke, she nodded her head vigorously and affirmatively. Over time, I learned that her nodding didn’t mean she necessarily agreed with me. Even so, I always sensed that she was listening closely and carefully considering what I had to say.

headline: The Eiffel Tower Reappears in The Times’s Travel Section
text: Quick, name a structure in Paris besides the Eiffel Tower.

headline: Blackstone’s Latest Results Suggest Its Model Is Finally Working
text: It makes sense for a firm that thinks in blocks of seven to 10 years to take about eight before hitting its stride. The listed units of Blackstone, the buyout shop led by Stephen Schwarzman, finally trade noticeably above their 2007 initial public offering price. Owners of the equity, however, may yet prove more fickle than investors in Blackstone’s funds.

headline: A Drug Trial’s Frayed Promise
text: Last fall, an article in The American Journal of Psychiatry caught the attention of specialists who treat borderline personality disorder, an intractable condition for which no approved drug treatment exists.

headline: Dan Farrell, Photographer Who Captured Kennedy Funeral Salute, Dies at 84
text: Dan Farrell, a photographer for The Daily News in New York known for his image of John F. Kennedy Jr. saluting his father’s coffin, died on Monday in Rockville Centre, N.Y. He was 84.

headline: France Announces Stronger Fight Against Racism and Anti-Semitism
text: PARIS — Deadly attacks on Jews by Muslim extremists in January and a sharp spike in anti-Muslim acts since then have prompted the French government to elevate the fight against racism into “a great national cause,” leading government officials said on Friday.

headline: Identity Theft Poses Extra Troubles for Children
text: The note that arrived in the mail, dated March 25 and addressed to my grade-school-age daughter, said what we had expected and feared: Like tens of millions of other Americans, including untold numbers of children, she may have fallen victim to thieves who gained access to Social Security numbers and other personal data from the health insurance giant Anthem.

headline: Jeb Bush Proposes Requiring Medicare End-of-Life Directives
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Jeb Bush, defending his efforts to keep alive Terri Schiavo, a brain-damaged woman, when he was governor of Florida, suggested on Friday that patients on Medicare should be required to sign advance directives dictating their care if they become incapacitated.

headline: Current and Former Success Academy Parents
text: New York City parents share their experiences with the charter school network.

headline: Verbatim: Rubio Addresses Question of His Age
text: “I know 44 is, which is what I turn in May,”

headline: Another Petrobras Subcontractor Files for Bankruptcy
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Another Brazilian company has fallen to the corruption scandal surrounding Brazil’s petroleum giant, Petrobras: Schahin Group requested on Friday a bankruptcy court’s protection for 28 of its subsidiaries.

headline: First in the Nation Forum: Rick Perry
text: Every major Republican presidential hopeful is in New Hampshire this weekend for the state’s First in the Nation candidate forum. We bring you the highlights, starting with former Texas Gov. Rick Perry.

headline: Carla Fernández Brings T to Mexico to See the Making of Her Designs
text: Last year, the fashion designer and activist Carla Fernández, who collaborates with artisans throughout Mexico to create avant-garde silhouettes rich in hand-worked detail, was the subject of a popular show at the Isabella Stewart Gardner museum in Boston. Now, just in time for Earth Day, the West Coast will have the chance to interact with Fernández’s work up close — and, for the first time in the U.S., to actually buy it. Starting tomorrow, the Boiler Room at Heath Ceramics in San Francisco is hosting “Design Culture Mexico,” a presentation that expands upon the Gardner show. Curated by Renee Zellweger of the San Francisco organization Summer School (no, not that Renée Zellweger), the exhibition also features work from select Mexican artists and functions as the official stateside launch of Fernández’s collection.

headline: Letter on Settlements
text: A letter signed by 16 European foreign ministers urged the E.U.’s foreign policy chief, Federica Mogherini, to clearly distinguish products that are made in Israel from those made in Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank.

headline: Israeli Foreign Minister Denounces E.U. Proposal to Label Settlement Products
text: JERUSALEM — Israel’s foreign minister on Friday angrily denounced a letter signed by more than a dozen of his European counterparts asking that the European Union require products made in Israeli settlements be labeled differently from those made in Israel.

headline: George Bush Letter in 1988 Warned Family of ‘New Friends’ Asking Favors
text: As the 1988 presidential campaign of then Vice President George Bush began, he knew that the “microscopic probing” of his family was about to intensify.

headline: At Global Economic Gathering, U.S. Primacy Is Seen as Ebbing
text: WASHINGTON — As world leaders converge here for their semiannual trek to the capital of what is still the world’s most powerful economy, concern is rising in many quarters that the United States is retreating from global economic leadership just when it is needed most.

headline: Yemeni Army Tries to Safeguard Oil Fields as Qaeda Fighters Advance
text: DOWAAN, Yemen — A Yemeni Army unit handed over control of a group of oil fields to a coalition of armed tribes on Friday in an attempt to keep the fields from falling into the hands of Al Qaeda or other militant groups amid the chaos of a continuing bombing campaign led by Saudi Arabia.

headline: Univision’s ‘Sábado Gigante’ Ends a 53-Year Run
text: The Spanish-language variety show “Sábado Gigante” is ending its run in September after more than 53 years on the air, Univision Networks announced Friday.

headline: Obama Urges ‘Creative’ Talks to Bridge Divide With Iran on Sanctions
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday directed his diplomats to use “creative negotiations” to bridge a sharp divide with Iran over the fate of sanctions if it agrees to curb its nuclear program, signaling flexibility in hopes of keeping a tentative agreement from unraveling.

headline: Participatory Budgeting Opens Up Voting to the Disenfranchised and Denied
text: On Wednesday afternoon. Anthony Marx, the president of the New York Public Library, addressed a roomful of women in pastel bouclé at an annual fund-raising lunch. He told them about a boy he had met on the stoop of a branch library in the Bronx who had a laptop that looked as though it was associated with a sales receipt time-stamped in the early 1990s. Mr. Marx asked him what he was doing, and the boy told him that he was there because his family couldn’t afford Internet access at home.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Child 44,’ ‘Alex of Venice’ and ‘Unfriended’

text: In The New York Times Book Review, Heather Havrilesky reviews Kate Bolick’s “Spinster: Making a Life of One’s Own.” Ms. Havrilesky writes:

headline: Making a Home, in Sickness and Health
text: Winston S. Fisher didn’t have big plans for his 30th birthday in July 2013. “I thought I’d just go home and eat cake, alone,” he said.

headline: Second Wind for Michael Phelps, as a Swimmer and a Person
text: MESA, Ariz. — As his life unraveled, the athlete rued that all he knew how to do was swim. “So I was just this little hole where a man should be,” he said.

headline: For Professor Rubio, Remedial Welding May Be Required
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — On his first day on the campaign trail as an official 2016 presidential hopeful, Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, on Friday embraced the retail tradition of New Hampshire, offering himself up as both teacher and student, eager to learn but comfortable and quippy.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Alex of Venice’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Alex of Venice.”

text: Images from Dodgertown, now Historic Dodgertown, which hosts events like Canadian Football League minicamps, high school soccer games and junior college softball championships.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Unfriended’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Unfriended.”

headline: Turkish Premier Says European Stance on Armenian Genocide Reflects Racism
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s prime minister on Friday accused Europe of showing signs of racism after the European Parliament passed a resolution calling on his government to recognize the mass killings of Armenians in the collapsing Ottoman Empire as genocide.

headline: A Duplex at One57 for $91.5 Million
text: The “Winter Garden” duplex penthouse at One57, Extell Development’s vitreous skyscraper, which has attracted a bevy of billionaire buyers since sales began in 2011, sold for $91,541,053 to a group led by the hedge fund mogul William A. Ackman. It was the second highest price ever paid for a single residence in New York City and the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: After Manhattan Explosion, Family’s Real Estate Business Faces Scrutiny
text: The field of rubble on Second Avenue in Lower Manhattan where three buildings stood before they were destroyed by a gas explosion last month shares a neighborhood with restaurants serving borscht and varenyky, shops that post signs in Cyrillic and a store selling tubs of poppy seed spread. These are the vestiges of a pocket of the East Village neighborhood once so dense with Ukrainian immigrants fleeing Soviet control after World War II that it was known as Little Ukraine.

headline: Promised a Supermarket Five Years Ago, a Housing Project Is Still Waiting
text: Residents of the Farragut Houses, a city housing project in northwest Brooklyn, suffer from at least two forms of isolation. There is the physical kind: the gated Brooklyn Navy Yard to the east, the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway to the south. And there is the economic kind: the luxury apartments of Dumbo to the west, the historic rowhouses of Vinegar Hill to the north.

headline: Serbian President’s Plane Takes Harrowing Plunge
text: WARSAW — An engine on an aging Serbian government plane carrying the president failed on Friday, sending the aircraft into a horrifying 60-second plunge over the Adriatic Sea, according to Serbian officials and news reports.

headline: Obama Calls Senate Delay ‘Embarrassing’
text: President Obama criticized the Senate’s delay in approving the appointment of Loretta E. Lynch as attorney general on Friday, saying there was no reason for it besides ‘political gamesmanship.’

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Africa and Elsewhere
text: South Africa and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: April 17, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from South Africa, Greece, Turkey and Lebanon.

headline: Review: In ‘Tatau,’ a Pacific Idyll for Dodgy Londoners
text: Just to prove that all eight-episode cable drama series are not created equal, even in the golden age of television, BBC America is offering the British import “Tatau” beginning on Saturday night. From the production studio behind the original “Being Human,” “Tatau” is a spring-break thriller translated to TV about a pair of gullible boys from London set loose among the shamans, hallucinogens and maidens of the South Pacific. You get a sense of what you’re in for early on when the grizzled surfer dude who runs the local bar walks into his first scene carrying a chain saw.

headline: A Lively Comment Discussion About Dementia and Sex
text: Elder sex. Nursing home dalliances. The erotic lives of dementia patients.

headline: Stopping Short of Rejection, Clinton Sets Conditions for a Trade Deal
text: After 24 hours of silence, Hillary Rodham Clinton has weighed in on perhaps the most divisive issue before the Democratic Party, setting her conditions for accepting a new trade deal making its way to Congress but not flat out rejecting it.

headline: A New Spring for Old Dodgertown
text: VERO BEACH, Fla. — The Montreal Alouettes football players, dozens of them, jogged out of the Jackie Robinson meeting room to a practice field wearing shorts, cleats and Jackie Robinson T-shirts.

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, April 19 to 25, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Martin Winterkorn to Stay as Volkswagen Chief, Even After Slight
text: PARIS — Just a week after it appeared that Ferdinand K. Piëch, Volkswagen’s powerful chairman, was preparing to throw his hand-picked chief executive and presumed successor under the Microbus, the company announced Friday that the executive, Martin Winterkorn, would have his contract renewed.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, April 19 to 25, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Rubio to New England: Can’t Wait Til ‘That Tom Brady Guy’ Retires
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Senator Marco Rubio on Friday offered a crowded house party in New Hampshire some hard truths — namely, he doesn’t love New England sports teams.

headline: Obama on His Concerns About Congress
text: The president, in an appearance with Prime Minister Matteo Renzi of Italy on Friday, spoke about his concerns that congressional action would derail the nuclear deal with Iran.

headline: First in the Nation Forum: Chris Christie
text: Best Applause Line: Many to choose from, but “I didn’t run for governor of New Jersey to be elected prom king” got the most love.

headline: Nick Cave’s ‘The Sick Bag Song,’ an Epic Poem Composed on Tour
text: If you ever find yourself sitting next to the rock star Nick Cave on a plane, don’t be alarmed if he reaches for an airsick bag. He’s probably just going to jot down some song lyrics or other stray thoughts.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: On TV, Ecological Themes for a Small Planet
text: Earth Day, which this year falls on Wednesday, is an occasion for celebrators, castigators and celebratory castigators. And for television that does all three of those things.

headline: Friday Night Music: Milk Carton Kids
text: I’m in Athens, and should do something location-appropriate, but am just too tired. And I did get to see them in an invitation-only concert last Saturday, which was wonderful; new album coming out next month. Sometimes simple beauty is enough:

headline: The Rapper Heems on Sticking to His Roots, Eschewing Stylists and His Signature Hermès Scarf
text: Heems, né Himanshu Kumar Suri, looks equal parts regal and comfortable holding court in the back of Brooklyn’s Cafe El Beit. Dressed in tailored black separates, his shiny hair slicked up into a high bun, he could be dressed for any one of his many roles: art curator, clothing designer, loving uncle, political activist and, of course, rapper. His first solo album, “Eat Pray Thug,” was released last month to critical accolades. (His former project, the hip-hop group Das Racist, was likewise beloved for its incisive and playful lyrics.) But Suri barely allowed himself time to celebrate, instead diving right back into community politics — specifically, the desperate call for a taxi stand near Manhattan’s beloved Punjabi Deli.

headline: Seller in Canceled Internment-Camp Auction Comes Forward
text: For years, the things sat in storage in John Ryan’s house in Connecticut and in his father’s house before that, a 60-year-old time capsule of a painful period in American history and a looming question mark for the Ryan family members, who did not know what to do with what they had.

headline: Iran’s Foreign Minister Warns of Unlimited Atomic Fuel Enrichment if Talks on Final Agreement Fail
text: Iran’s foreign minister raised the prospect on Friday of unlimited Iranian atomic fuel enrichment if the final phase of talks with the United States and other big powers on Iran’s disputed nuclear program does not achieve an agreement by a June 30 deadline, with all sanctions dropped.

headline: Can You Be a Waitress and a Feminist?
text: LAS VEGAS — THIS week I will be sexually harassed on the job, and like many women in the Las Vegas service industry, I will count my tips at the end of my shift and decide that it is worth it.

headline: Review: ‘Se Llama Cristina,’ a Search for Identity, at the Intar Theater
text: A magical realist fable with a side of fried chicken, Octavio Solis’s “Se Llama Cristina” begins with a Latino man and woman (Gerardo Rodriguez and Carmen Zilles) asleep in a squalid room. On waking, they can’t remember where they are or who they are. Eventually, they notice a crib, with a drumstick stuffed into the swaddling. “Maybe, just maybe, we’re still trippin’,” the man suggests. “You and me and the leg of chicken.”

headline: When a Gun Is Not a Gun
text: THE Justice Department recently analyzed eight years of shootings by Philadelphia police officers. Its report contained two sobering statistics: Fifteen percent of those shot were unarmed; and in half of these cases, an officer reportedly misidentified a “nonthreatening object (e.g., a cellphone) or movement (e.g., tugging at the waistband)” as a weapon.

headline: Penn Station, Then and Now
text: Despite protests, the Midtown railroad mecca was demolished in the mid-1960s, and led to stronger efforts to save landmarks.

headline: Before Coming Together, Separates
text: Two-piece wedding dresses are turning up in the fall 2015 lines of a number of designers.

headline: Puzzling Death of Chicago’s Whirlwind Chef, Homaro Cantu
text: CHICAGO — As people in the restaurant business here remember the chef Homaro Cantu, who took his own life this week, they describe a man who was always willing to take on one more thing.

headline: Dances of India, Rich in Breadth and Addressing the Sublime
text: The dance forms of India — though I began to watch them over 30 years ago in London — became a regular and deepening source of fascination to me only once I began work as chief dance critic of The New York Times in 2007. It’s been a boon, after decades of dancegoing, to investigate them: They’ve extended my idea of dance itself, what it can be and signify.

headline: A ‘Star Wars’-Themed Plane Will Take to the Skies this Fall
text: The 2016 election campaign may have begun, but an even bigger marketing crusade is on the horizon — and the force is strong with this one. Yesterday’s release of a trailer for “Star Wars: The Force Awakens,” the latest film in the famous franchise, has kicked off what will surely be an endless series of product placement partnerships, one of the first of which is with All Nippon Airways, Japan’s largest airline.

headline: Biden to Attend Israeli Event, in Attempt to Cool Tensions
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will attend an Israeli Independence Day event sponsored by the Israeli Embassy in Washington next week as the Obama administration tries to cool its public feud with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

headline: Two-Piece Wedding Dresses Make Their Statement
text: With an intimate May 16 wedding set in Santa Fe, N.M., Tiffany Coletti Titolo began a quest last year for a gown that would fit her hourglass proportions but that also, she said, “didn’t feel off the rack.”

headline: Why Is Spring Being So Passive Aggressive?
text: The springlike weather that — finally! — has begun to arrive, nearly a month after its official start date, with temperatures reliably reaching into the 60s and budding flowers making a sudden appearance in public parks, has not appeared a moment too soon for Nick Guy, 28, of Buffalo.

headline: Review: At Youth America Grand Prix Gala, Young and Older Stars Align
text: A dancer may be born with talent, but it takes more than that to get a body ready for the stage. At “Stars of Today Meet the Stars of Tomorrow,” a Youth America Grand Prix gala in which young dancers shared a program with professionals, Julie Kent, the host along with Jared Angle, spoke of gratitude for the teachers, parents and students who sacrifice much in the “pursuit of bringing more beauty to the world.”

headline: Anna Clyne, a Composer Who Creates With Images
text: When Anna Clyne was working on her first big orchestral piece, she invited one of her composition teachers, Julia Wolfe, to look at her drafts. But when Ms. Wolfe arrived at Ms. Clyne’s studio in Chicago, where she had just begun a residency with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, Ms. Wolfe found no sketches written out on music manuscript paper or drafted with any of the software programs commonly used by composers. Instead, “The wall had a painting across it,” Ms. Wolfe remembers. “It was done in a series of panels that went across her studio, and she said, ‘This is my piece.’ ”

headline: Review: In Third Rail Projects’ ‘Genuine Plastic Reliquaries,’ All the City’s a Stage
text: Public displays of affection are hardly uncommon in Manhattan, where it can often seem as if all the world’s a make-out party. But few such demonstrations are as artfully awkward — or as thoroughly public — as that of a couple recently spotted on West 42nd Street.

headline: The New York City Landmark Law Over the Years
text: Here’s a look back at the law’s impact and some of the thousands of buildings, interiors and entire neighborhoods it has protected.

headline: New York City’s Landmarks Law at 50
text: New York City’s landmarks preservation law turns 50 on Sunday. Any who doubt its continuing significance should head to the West Side of Manhattan, to the building it came too late to save. Pennsylvania Station in 2015 is a monument to civic suffocation, a basement of low, dust-blackened ceilings, confusing corridors, beer-and-popcorn dealers, yowling buskers and trudging commuters.

headline: Don’t Confuse Jeremy Piven With Ari Gold
text: The fast-talking, obnoxiously brazen Hollywood agent played by Jeremy Piven on “Entourage” dogs him wherever he goes. “l have an Apple Store appearance coming up,” the compact 49-year-old Mr. Piven said last month, “and the invitation says, ‘Please join the actor Ari Gold.’ ”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Reviews: Jidenna, Chastity Belt, Sicko Mobb and Mickey Guyton
text: Jidenna

headline: Bill Cunningham | Joy Blooms
text: Signs of spring and summer showed up last week.

headline: Review: Heidi Latsky Dance at Montclair State University
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — For the choreographer Heidi Latsky, there are no unbeautiful bodies and no bodies incapable of dancing. In what some might call disability, she finds possibility. In “Triptych,” which opened at the Alexander Kasser Theater at Montclair State University on Thursday as part of the Peak Performances series, she unleashes some of those possibilities in three complementary dances, one for film and two for the stage.

headline: In Shanghai, a Convincing Win in the Open Pairs
text: In Shanghai last week, there were subsidiary events for those players not continuing in the Yeh Brothers Cup.

headline: Meatyard at Home in Kentucky’s Cultural Scene
text: A new exhibit explores how Ralph Eugene Meatyard, a master of creating a strange and personal reality, was far from a solitary artist, but deeply involved with others in Kentucky’s creative milieu.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Joy Blooms
text: Signs of spring and summer showed up last week. For fashion, it was all about the colorful scarf and the gray flannel suit. Daffodils, tulips, pussy willows, flowering branches and balloons appeared in Union Square. In Central Park, it was almost summer, with flying kites and a new generation of flower children.

headline: Things to Do in Westchester, April 19 to 25, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Tibetan Dies After Setting Himself on Fire in Protest
text: HONG KONG — A man set himself on fire in a heavily Tibetan region of southwest China this week, leaving behind a makeshift shrine that included a photo of the Dalai Lama, international groups reported on Friday. He was the second Tibetan to set himself on fire in a protest in the last two weeks and the 139th within China since the practice began among Tibetans in February 2009.

headline: Hey, Kids, Look at Me When We’re Talking
text: Consider this fair warning: If you’re going to bring your children around me, I’m going to teach them how to shake hands. The process, which I picked up from my dad, involves three simple steps: “firm grip, squeeze, look me in the eye.” When my father started doing this in the 1970s, the hardest step for many children was the first. This was the era when the demure four-finger handshake was still popular among women and girls. More recently, as gender equality has leveled the handshake, I’ve noticed that young people have an almost universal aversion to the final step.

headline: Evening Hours | Highlight of the Season
text: Creative dining at the Brooklyn Museum and other celebrations.

headline: Review: ‘Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2,’ Starring Kevin James, Heads to Las Vegas
text: You won’t find much offensive in Kevin James’s slick, innocuous vehicle “Paul Blart: Mall Cop 2.” You won’t find much prompting an emotional reaction in general, so familiar are the jokes and situations. If Mr. James’s character thinks of safety first, so does this movie, to its extreme detriment.

headline: A New Face at 20 Percent Off? Sign Me Up.
text: I lost a lot of weight a while back, and a few weeks ago I realized my skin was too big for my face.

headline: Anger Management: Why the Genius Founders Turned to Couples Therapy
text: Over breakfast at Cafe Mogador in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, Ilan Zechory couldn’t stop talking about the complicated relationship with his best friend, Tom Lehman.

headline: Under Bombardment in Yemen, Civilians Voice Terror and Despair Online
text: While Saudi Arabia’s ambassador in Washington offered an upbeat assessment this week of the air campaign in Yemen led by his nation, calling it “very, very successful,” civilians living under bombardment for more than three weeks expressed terror and despair in messages posted online.

headline: Christopher Wheeldon’s ‘An American in Paris’ Brings Ballet Values to Broadway
text: The conversion of famous movies into stage musicals is business as usual on Broadway these days. But the adaptation of the 1951 film “An American in Paris” that opened at the Palace Theater on Sunday has attracted unusual attention from the world of ballet because of who is involved.

headline: Khalik Allah’s Movie Captures Harlem Faces and Voices by Moonlight
text: Shot at night, the Harlem subjects of the photographer and filmmaker Khalik Allah have a soulful glow even when their circumstances are dire. In his film “Field Niggas,” Mr. Allah records the struggling denizens of the corner of 125th Street and Lexington Avenue. His rich use of color, chiaroscuro, slow motion and fades seems to suspend faces and bodies against the inky backdrops and twinkling city lights.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, April 19 to 25, 2015
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: ‘Revenge of the Popinjay’ at Dixon Place
text: The curtain speech at “Revenge of the Popinjay,” by Animal Parts at Dixon Place, sounds a bit different than usual. There’s little about cellphones or flash photography or exit routes. Instead, Anthony (Anthony Johnston), with his plaid shirt and ripped jeans and uniquely Canadian friendliness, shares the latest safety guidelines issued by the New York Police Department: “Try to be off the streets by nightfall. Do not go out alone. If you must leave your homes after dark, always travel with a same-sex buddy.”

headline: Colbert and Lucas on ‘Star Wars,’ Late-Night TV and Howard the Duck
text: Just like everyone else, George Lucas checked out the new teaser for “Star Wars: Episode VII – The Force Awakens.” That was one of several tidbits gleaned from a wide-ranging talk between the director and the television host Stephen Colbert at the Tribeca Film Festival on Friday.

headline: Loyalty Extending Beyond the Barber’s Chair
text: Frank Codispoti’s hair salon, Allegria, is in a fancy new hotel in Downtown Brooklyn, but his camaraderie has fostered generations of loyal customers.

headline: A Little Off the Sides, Camaraderie on Top
text: You would have a hard time finding a better representative of Old Brooklyn than Frank Codispoti. A barber who immigrated to New York when he was 18 from the town of Sant’Andrea in the southern Italian region of Calabria, Mr. Codispoti has cut hair in Brooklyn for more than 40 years. So it might seem somewhat jarring to find him in such a fancy spot in the lower lobby of the New York Marriott at the Brooklyn Bridge. But the crossroads of new and old Brooklyn are everywhere, and Allegria Hair Salon is just such an intersection.

headline: Review: Jordi Savall, Plunged in the Emotion of Performance and Life
text: If it is possible for a musician performing publicly at full tilt to be simultaneously lost in thought, the Catalan viola da gamba virtuoso Jordi Savall may have done it in the first half of his solo program at Weill Recital Hall on Monday. One of Mr. Savall’s two appearances in Carnegie Hall’s Before Bach festival, the recital, “The Spirit of the Viol,” focused on music of Marin Marais and the Sainte-Colombes, father and son.

headline: The Week in Political Pictures
text: On the road in Iowa and New Hampshire; a crashed gyrocopter; Booth’s pistol; and cycling for wounder warriors.

headline: 59th Street Bridge Singer
text: For most of its users, the Queensboro Bridge is something to be traversed as quickly as possible, but for Sue Hassel, it is a place to linger.

headline: New York City’s People, Famous and Everyday
text: Two photographers who shared a fascination with the city captured it with very different focuses.

headline: Two Visual Tales of New York
text: The two photographers were born just two years apart and grew up poor in Brooklyn in the 1920s and ’30s. The war awakened them creatively. Their subject was New York.

headline: First in the Nation Forum: Jeb Bush
text: Best Applause Line: It drew both laughter and applause, but the tight-fisted New Hampshire Republicans really enjoyed Mr. Bush’s recounting of how, as Florida governor, he earned the nickname “Veto Corleone” for his efforts to restrict spending.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
text: On the road in Iowa and New Hampshire; a crashed gyrocopter; Booth’s pistol; and cycling for wounder warriors.

headline: Clinton Team to Hit the Road in Search of New Donors
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s finance team will go on a fund-raising road trip next week, holding a series of meetings with hundreds of small donors on the East Coast as a way to engage supporters ahead of larger planned events aimed at those who are expected to bundle donations and collect a larger number of checks.

headline: Stock Markets Fall Around the World
text: Signs of complacency were evident before stock markets around the world tumbled on Friday.

headline: A Challenge to Lumber Liquidators’ Tests
text: A few consumers have filed a lawsuit against Lumber Liquidators, accusing the company of hiring unaccredited laboratories to prove to customers that its flooring is safe and not contaminated with formaldehyde.

headline: Chief Leaves Music Service Taken Over by Jay Z
text: Barely a month after Jay Z took over Tidal, a Swedish streaming music service, the top executive at its parent company has stepped down and about a dozen employees have been laid off.

headline: Gun Maker Colt’s Curious Exchange Offer
text: Colt Defense, maker of the famous pistols used by outlaws and actors, has announced that it may undertake one of  the strangest prepackaged bankruptcy cases ever.

headline: Safety Regulations Issued for Trains Carrying Oil
text: Responding to public pressure to act more quickly after a series of fiery train derailments involving oil shipments, the Transportation Department on Friday issued a series of emergency orders, including a 40-mile-an-hour speed limit for hazardous materials moving through urban areas.

headline: At a Long Island Beach, Human Tempers Flare Over Claws and Feathers
text: JONES BEACH STATE PARK, N.Y. — On a brisk day in early spring, the scene at Jones Beach was quiet.

headline: Free the President
text: LAST week’s news from Washington: A dysfunctional Congress managed to function just long enough to bludgeon President Obama into ceding his prerogative to enter into an executive agreement with Iran regarding its nuclear program.

headline: Why We Let Prison Rape Go On
text: ORANGE, Conn. — IT’S been called “America’s most ‘open’ secret”: According to the Bureau of Justice Statistics, around 80,000 women and men a year are sexually abused in American correctional facilities. That number is almost certainly subject to underreporting, through shame or a victim’s fear of retaliation. Overall, only 35 percent of rapes and sexual assaults were reported to the police in 2010, and the rate of reporting in prisons is undoubtedly lower still.

headline: For a Mother, Many Worries and Few Clues About Her Runaway Daughter
text: In January, a 16-year-old girl named Joannie opened her journal, decorated with glittery stars on the cover, and wrote, “Dear God, Thank you for another day on earth and watching over me and my family.” There was nothing, in hindsight, to remotely suggest she would run away from home again in three months.

headline: Republicans in Quandary Over Vote on Loretta Lynch
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans do not want to be held responsible for rejecting the historic nomination of Loretta E. Lynch, the first African-American woman picked to be attorney general. But they also are in no hurry to see her confirmed because of her defense of President Obama’s immigration policies.

headline: Key Moments in Pilot’s Mental Health History
text: The Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz received certifications allowing him to fly, even though he had exhibited suicidal tendencies and was treated by psychotherapists.

headline: Keep Pilots in the Cockpit
text: To the Editor:

headline: Putin’s Threats: How Should the U.S. React?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Jury in Etan Patz Case Focuses on Confession and Video
text: A Manhattan jury deliberating in the trial of a man accused of murdering 6-year-old Etan Patz in 1979 asked on Friday to review the testimony of a prosecutor who made the decision not to record the daylong interview with the police that led to the man’s confession.

headline: Teenage Pressures and Suicide Risks
Equity and Birthrates
text: To the Editor:

headline: Senator Jeff Sessions Argues for a Cut in Immigration
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Pope and the Nuns
text: To the Editor:

headline: Review of Comcast Deal Is Said to Raise Concerns
text: The staff lawyers at the Justice Department reviewing Comcast’s proposed $45 billion takeover of Time Warner Cable have raised concerns about the merger and are leaning toward recommending that it be blocked, according to a person with knowledge of the deliberations.

headline: Declassify the 9/11 Pages
text: To the Editor:

headline: Marco Rubio Swings Through New Hampshire
text: NASHUA, N.H. — On his first day on the campaign trail as a declared 2016 presidential candidate, Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, embraced New Hampshire’s appetite for retail politics on Friday, offering himself up as both teacher and student, eager to learn but comfortable and full of quips.

headline: Sunny Skies, but N.B.A. Has Eye to the Horizon
text: On the eve of the N.B.A. playoffs, Commissioner Adam Silver relayed the news that business was good in the wake of two days of meetings by the league’s Board of Governors at a Manhattan hotel.

headline: First in the Nation Forum: Marco Rubio
text: Best Applause Line: “This is about the future of America and its very identity.”

headline: Ichiro Suzuki’s Hitting Remains Constant Amid Changes
text: He gently places the silver case on the carpet of the Miami Marlins’ clubhouse, then clicks the fasteners and lifts the lid. You know what is inside, but this is Ichiro Suzuki, still a bit mysterious after all these years. You half expect the contents to glow, like the briefcase in “Pulp Fiction,” a movie released more than two decades ago, in a year Suzuki hit .385.

headline: Referendum Reshapes Scottish Political Terrain
text: PAISLEY, Scotland — Mhairi Black is lively, self-confident and 20, with an exam in politics to take before she graduates from college. But as the Scottish National Party’s candidate for Parliament from a constituency west of Glasgow, Ms. Black is poised to overturn a large Labour Party majority here and defeat one of Labour’s stars, its shadow foreign secretary and campaign manager, Douglas Alexander.

headline: Robert P. Griffin Dies at 91; Michigan Senator Urged Nixon to Quit
text: Robert P. Griffin, a former Republican senator and congressman from Michigan who co-sponsored one of the nation’s most rigorous laws to fight corruption in unions and who delivered a critical blow to Richard M. Nixon’s presidency by withdrawing his support during the Watergate crisis, died on Thursday in Traverse City, Mich. He was 91.

headline: British Prosecutors Drop Charges Against 9 Journalists in Tabloid Inquiry
text: LONDON — After a series of court reversals, prosecutors on Friday dropped charges against nine of the 12 journalists who still faced trial after police investigations into the behavior of Britain’s freewheeling tabloid press.

headline: Hillary Clinton Hiring of C.F.O. Is Called Signal to Possible Donors
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s recruitment of Gary Gensler, a former top federal Wall Street regulator, as her campaign’s chief financial officer was meant to show donors she is serious about avoiding the overspending that plagued her 2008 presidential campaign, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Rules to Make Retirement Investing Safer
text: In a giant step forward for investor protection, the Department of Labor proposed new rules this week to ensure that financial advisers act solely in their clients’ best interests when giving advice and selling products for retirement accounts. The new standard of fiduciary duty would bar stockbrokers, insurance agents and other financial professionals from increasing their pay by steering clients into high-cost products and strategies when comparable lower-cost ones are available.

headline: Pope Stops Investigating the Good Sisters
text: The Vatican’s misguided investigation of American Catholic nuns seemed thoroughly steeped in chauvinism from its inception three years ago by the church’s male-dominated bureaucracy. Rome’s move against widely respected churchwomen was puzzling and provocative in an era of scandal by male priests committing child rape and being repeatedly shielded by their male superiors.

headline: After Walter Scott Shooting, Scrutiny Turns to 2nd Officer
text: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — He did not fire a shot. He is black, not white.

headline: Hope Still Bright for Cubs’ Kris Bryant After Shaky Debut
text: CHICAGO — A few hours before Kris Bryant made his major league debut at Wrigley Field on Friday afternoon, his father, Mike, a onetime minor league outfielder, stood near the Cubs’ dugout, watching his son rip line drives all over the field during batting practice. Gripped by nostalgia, he recalled how 5-year-old Kris had hit the ball with such power he thought his son could have been a big leaguer even then; how Kris had opted for college instead of turning professional after high school; how his son had never had an alcoholic drink; and how he wept a night earlier, after he had learned Kris was on his way to Wrigley.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “The Syrian crisis places the entire humanitarian system at a crossroads. It requires us to radically rethink how we protect and assist such large numbers of displaced people.”

headline: Civil Rights Groups in South Carolina Ask U.S. to Investigate Killings by Police
text: Civil rights groups in North Charleston, S.C., asked the United States Department of Justice on Friday to investigate all fatal shootings by police officers in Charleston County in the last 21 years.

headline: Cardinal Francis E. George, 78, Dies; Urged ‘Zero Tolerance’ in Abuse Scandal
text: Cardinal Francis E. George, who was the Roman Catholic archbishop of Chicago for 17 years and helped shape the American Catholic bishops’ response to the child sexual abuse scandal and their resistance to the Obama health plan’s contraception coverage, died on Friday at his residence in Chicago. He was 78.

headline: Military Deaths in Afghan and ISIS Operations
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,343 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations and three service members who have died supporting the operation to eliminate the Islamic State militant group. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Peering Through the Haze
text: They sure know how to bury the lead at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: Replica of Lafayette’s Frigate to Set Sail From France for a U.S. Visit
text: PARIS — A finely wrought full-size replica of the Hermione, the ship that carried the Marquis de Lafayette to America in 1780 to help the American revolutionaries fight the British, will set sail on Saturday for the United States in a formal launching ceremony in France.

headline: It’s Your Fiction That Interests Me
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — As Damon Gulczynski says in his notes below, it helps to have a knowledge of current pop culture — we’ll use “The Simpsons” as an example in the next paragraph — to gain a toehold in a Saturday puzzle. It also helps to know history, sports, horticulture, older pop culture, music, the capitals of Indian states and intriguing yet seemingly out-of-context quotes from books written in 1950.

headline: Sony Studio Renews Warning After WikiLeaks Posts Stolen Data
text: LOS ANGELES — David Boies, a lawyer for Sony Pictures Entertainment, began warning news media outlets on Friday that WikiLeaks’s posting of emails and documents stolen from Sony does not, in the media giant’s view, make them fair game.

headline: Arrest by F.B.I. Is Tied to $500 Million Art Theft From Boston Museum, Lawyer Says
text: BOSTON — Federal agents trying to solve the biggest art theft in the nation’s history arrested a 79-year-old Hartford man on Friday after conducting their second sting against him in three years to force him to disclose the whereabouts of $500 million in stolen art, the man’s lawyer said.

headline: Review: ‘The Mineralogy of Objects,’ With a Most Flexible Guest Star
text: The star of Laurie Berg’s “The Mineralogy of Objects” is an inflatable sex doll named Tanya. She appears midway through the 55-minute dance, which made its debut on Thursday at Danspace Project, in line with Ms. Berg and the three other female dancers who make up the cast. They toss Tanya around and try to keep her aloft like a beach ball. They engage her in an absurdly acrobatic ballroom duet. They roll with her on the ground as she deflates.

headline: Stanislav Gross, Czech Leader Who Erred on Iraq Link to 9/11, Dies at 45
text: Stanislav Gross, who in 2004, at age 34, became the Czech Republic’s youngest prime minister and who played a small role in the buildup to the Iraq war, died on Thursday in Prague. He was 45.

headline: Bartolo Colon’s Arm and Bat Help Push Mets to 6th Straight Win
text: Michael Cuddyer walked around the Mets clubhouse before Friday night’s game against the Miami Marlins wearing a faded orange T-shirt adorned with a Mets logo and the slogan “The Magic is back.” But Harry Houdini would have had difficulty conjuring some of the plays that led to the 4-1 win against the Marlins a few hours later, the Mets’ sixth straight victory.

headline: Vivian Nicholson, 79, Dies; A Rags-to-Riches Story Left in Tatters
text: She went to London to collect her prize wearing borrowed stockings and cardboard in the soles of her shoes. There, as flashbulbs exploded, she became an international celebrity — the factory worker who had come into a fortune.

headline: Alex Rodriguez, a Maligned Source of Power, Lifts the Anemic Yankees
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Too often in the young season, the Yankees have floundered in the field, flailed at the plate and watched their starting pitchers last as briefly as a June bug.

headline: One Teenager Is Killed and Another Is Injured in Shooting Outside Brooklyn Housing Project
text: One teenage boy was killed and a second was injured in gunfire in the courtyard of a Brooklyn housing project on Friday night, the police said.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
text: 9 P.M. (CUNY) THE CLAY BIRD (2003) City Cinematheque’s tribute to Milestone Films continues with Tareque Masud’s drama, set in Bangladesh in the 1960s, about Anu (Nurul Islam Bablu), a shy young boy from rural East Pakistan who is sent to an Islamic school by his father (Jayanto Chattopadhyay), who doesn’t want his son tainted by the outside world. Anu struggles to conform to the school’s monastic ways, and to be accepted by the cliquish boys. But soon he gravitates to the enthusiastic oddball Roko (Russell Farazi), the one student who refuses to go along with the program. “Mr. Masud’s expansive fluidity is rapturous, inspired equally by the floating equanimity of Satyajit Ray and the work of the Iranian director Abbas Kiarostami, who deftly uses ritual behavior to provide social commentary,” Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times. “It’s also evident that Mr. Masud loves all his characters, even the small-minded ones — the sign of a real director. It’s no small achievement to make a picture that extols the necessity for clear, free thought while dramatizing the barriers that challenge such a capacity.”

headline: Corrections: April 18, 2015
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Afghan President Blames ISIS for a Bombing
