text: JALALABAD, Afghanistan — The Afghan president, Ashraf Ghani, blamed the Islamic State extremist group for a suicide bombing here on Saturday that killed 35 civilians. If responsibility is confirmed, it will suggest a major escalation of the group’s activities in Afghanistan.

headline: Australian Police Arrest 5 Men They Say Were Planning Terror Attacks
text: SYDNEY, Australia — The Australian police arrested five men on Saturday who they said had been planning terrorist attacks to be carried out next weekend, during a national holiday. Prime Minister Tony Abbott said the men had been inspired by the Islamic State extremist group.

headline: At Afghan Weddings, His Side, Her Side and 600 Strangers
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — When Shafiqullah walked into his wedding celebration, he was surprised to find 600 extra people in the room, none of whom he recognized.

headline: The Week on Instagram
text: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took viewers from a Louisiana plantation to a “Star Wars” celebration.

headline: 1947: Édith Piaf’s New York Debut
text: Édith Piaf singing “Non, Je Ne Regrette Rien” in December 1960. It was her comeback show after a year off the stage because of health issues. INAThis year marks the centenary of the birth of the French singer Édith Piaf. In 1947, the New York Herald Tribune reported on her first show in the United States:

headline: Catherine Deneuve Celebrated at IFC Center
text: Imperious, perverse, remote and radiant, Catherine Deneuve is a monument to French poise and pulchritude. François Truffaut, Luis Buñuel and Roman Polanski are among the Continental auteurs who have been captivated by her. Now, the IFC Center honors her with “Deneuve x 8,” a program of her best-known films, playing through June 7 as part of its Weekend Classics series.

headline: Deciding the Fate of a Beloved Tree
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Germanwings Crash Exposes History of Denial on Risk of Pilot Suicide
text: DÜSSELDORF, Germany — When Andreas Lubitz sent an email in 2009 seeking reinstatement to Lufthansa’s flight-training program after a monthslong absence, he appended what in retrospect was a clear warning signal about his fitness to fly passenger jetliners: an acknowledgment that he had suffered from severe depression.

headline: Second Stage Buys Helen Hayes Theater, Ending Dispute
text: A nonprofit theater company on Friday purchased one of the last independently owned Broadway houses, promising to bring more plays by living American playwrights to an industry dominated by musicals, movie adaptations and British imports.

headline: At Republican Gathering, All Talk Is of Hillary Clinton (None of It Is Good)
text: NASHUA, N.H. — They attacked her judgment on resetting American relations with Russia and protecting American diplomats in Libya. They slammed her as secretive for using a personal email account at the State Department and deleting messages in the face of scrutiny. They mocked her recent campaign events in Iowa as inauthentic and her unannounced lunch at Chipotle as antisocial. They even reached back to her husband’s infidelity to disparage her.

headline: Surveying How Their Gardens Grow
text: Deborah Marton spends her workdays toiling over places where others spend their days of rest. Ms. Marton, 52, is the executive director of the New York Restoration Project, a nonprofit group that Bette Midler started in 1995 to reclaim decaying green spaces in the city’s low-income neighborhoods. This means that Ms. Marton sometimes spends her weekends hearing from Ms. Midler. “Right now she’s in L.A., preparing for a tour,” Ms. Marton said. “But she does think about work on the weekends.” After the past winter, and with Earth Day approaching on April 22, the staff, which tends to two parks and 52 community gardens, has had a lot of planting and spiffing up to do. When not overseeing the spiffing, Ms. Marton decamps to her loft in the Flatiron district, which she shares on alternating weeks with her son, Henry, 16, and full time with Lex, a small rescue mutt.

headline: Regulatory Relief for Banks That Rarely Fail
text: Rolling back regulations created after the 2008 crisis has been Job 1 for leaders of many of the nation’s large and powerful banking institutions. So it’s no surprise that recent proposals for regulatory reform in the financial industry have overwhelmingly been the work of big banks or their supporters. The bankers want to return to the days when they could roll the dice, pocket their winnings and rely on the taxpayer if something went wrong.

headline: Variety: A Mind-Boggling Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — And you thought April Fools’ Day had passed.

headline: Moleskine Notebooks Adapt to the Digital World
text: During his travels, the author Bruce Chatwin famously scribbled in small black notebooks with covers made of oilcloth, a tightly woven cotton coated in linseed oil; each was wrapped in an elastic band. He stocked up on them at a Parisian paper store and took them on trips to Brazil, Afghanistan and Australia and to a dinner meeting in New York with Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis.

headline: The Trout Lily’s Brief Spring
text: Despite the warm weather and recent rains, spring was barely evident on a recent walk I took through Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. Not even the tips of the bloodroot were showing, and trout lily leaves were resigned to south-facing slopes. The calls of an Eastern phoebe resonated through the sober woods; it was still winter in most ways.

headline: First in the Nation Forum: Rand Paul
text: Best Applause Line: Holding up former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton’s actions before the attack on American diplomats in Benghazi, Libya, as a “dereliction of duty” that “should forever preclude her from holding high office.”

headline: An Inspirational Interior for a Digital Designer
text: Geoff Dowd is the director of experience design at Adobe Systems in San Francisco.

headline: One Killed in Kashmir Valley Protest
text: NEW DELHI — A young man was killed in the western part of the Kashmir Valley on Saturday when police and security forces fired on stone-throwing protesters, the police said.

headline: Israel and Palestinians Reach Tax Deal
text: JERUSALEM — Israel and the Palestinian Authority have reached an agreement to resolve a monthslong dispute over the transfer of tax revenue Israel collects on behalf of the Palestinians, officials said on Saturday.

headline: Books on a Photographer, the Underground Railroad and Ancestry
text: Back in the 1940s, a boyfriend gave Eve Arnold a $40 Rolleicord camera, and she wandered to New York after work and on weekends, she recalled, capturing in black and white “drunken bums sleeping in the Bowery, sun glinting off rope, texture of paint peeling off walls.”

headline: Drawing a Trout
text: The writer and artist James Prosek makes drawings of the fish he catches in order to enhance his powers of observation.

headline: Beyond Horse-Whispering
text: Sheryl Jordan, 56, is the equestrian director at Salamander Resort and Spa in Middleburg, Va.

headline: The First Film Shot in New York City
text: Q.What was the first movie shot on location in New York City?

headline: Technology That Prods You to Take Action, Not Just Collect Data
text: The bookshelves in Natasha Dow Schüll’s office at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology are punctuated here and there with kitchen timers: a windup orange plastic device, an egg-shaped stainless steel mechanical timer, a digital hourglass with falling pixels in lieu of sand.

headline: Out of Africa, Kuba Fabrics That Dazzle and Teach
text: An intriguing back story enlivens the dazzling designs and astute scholarship on display in “Kuba Textiles: Geometry in Form, Space, and Time,” an exhibition of 19th- and early 20th-century African textiles now at the Neuberger Museum of Art.

headline: The Mine-Sniffing Rats of Africa
text: Nicholas Kristof follows a large rodent as it searches a minefield in northern Angola.

headline: Google’s Steely Foe in Europe
text: Margrethe Vestager, the European Union’s commissioner for competition, who last week took on the colossus that is Google, has a reputation for toughness.

headline: Whooshing Trains and Sweeping Views at Hudson Social in Dobbs Ferry
text: We knew that we were in for a good time at Hudson Social when minutes after we were seated. another patron (a CNN producer, we were told) bought everyone in the restaurant a round of drinks. When we politely refused, our waitress deadpanned: “He insists.” And so, like the other two dozen folks sipping Westchester’s own Captain Lawrence brews and vodka-strong blood-orange martinis, we settled into the good vibes — and great views — at this new Dobbs Ferry eatery.

headline: Faith vs. Facts
text: JERUSALEM — MOST of us find it mind-boggling that some people seem willing to ignore the facts — on climate change, on vaccines, on health care — if the facts conflict with their sense of what someone like them believes. “But those are the facts,” you want to say. “It seems weird to deny them.”

headline: The Machines Are Coming
text: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — THE machine hums along, quietly scanning the slides, generating Pap smear diagnostics, just the way a college-educated, well-compensated lab technician might.

headline: Trout Fishing, a Taut Line to Our Past
text: The ancient communication between angler and fish is a connection to when humans had to hunt and gather to survive.

headline: Responses to David Brooks: The Road to Inner Virtue
text: Readers discuss a column by David Brooks about how “deeply good people got that way.”

headline: The Giant Rats That Save Lives
text: MALANJE, Angola — I’M walking in a minefield here in rural Angola, tailing a monster rat.

headline: Granny Get Your Gun
text: WASHINGTON — THE most famous woman on the planet has a confounding problem. She can’t figure out how to campaign as a woman.

headline: Hillary’s Shelved Crown
text: THE 2016 presidential campaign is only now gathering steam and already I’m confused.

headline: Checking Charlie Hebdo’s Privilege
text: A LIVING cartoonist lecturing his murdered peers makes for a curious spectacle, but that’s what transpired at journalism’s George Polk Awards a week ago. The lecturer was Garry Trudeau, of “Doonesbury” fame; his subject was the cartoonists for Charlie Hebdo, the Parisian satire rag, who were gunned down by fanatics because of their mockery of Muhammad and Islam.

headline: Vance Joy
text: Vance Joy is an Australian singer-songwriter known for the recent breakout hits “Riptide” and “Mess Is Mine.”

headline: I Was an Animal Experimenter
text: How did it happen? How did I go from being a high school student who played in a rock band to a mad scientist conducting cruel animal experiments?

headline: The Strip
text: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: The Other Side of Boredom
text: MY years as a kayak guide coincided exactly with the Great Recession. By 2009, tourists were canceling their trips in droves. I received their cancellation emails in a quiet shop on the water in San Diego, behind a desk stuffed with waivers for the two-hour trips I rarely led, topped with a display rack of sunglasses that were never purchased. Many days went by without any customers. I had nothing, really nothing, to do. The only indicator of time passing was the sun moving across the wall and the click of the mouse as I, alone with my boredom, discovered the Internet.

headline: Voting Rights, by the Numbers
text: When the Supreme Court struck down the heart of the Voting Rights Act in 2013, its main argument was that the law was outdated.

headline: Would You Want to Smell BBQ All the Time?
text: CITY COUNCIL meetings in Austin, Tex., tend to be droning, low-drama affairs, but that wasn’t the case earlier this month when barbecue was on the agenda: specifically, the smell of barbecue and a proposal to control it, in response to some citizen complaints.

headline: Anti-Semitism in the Soccer Stands
text: An ugly vein of soccer fan excess — the chanting of anti-Semitic slurs — recently disgraced a Dutch soccer game, prompting officials of the home team, Utrecht, to apologize for shocking outcries from the stands like “Hamas, Hamas, Jews to the gas” and “Jews burn the best!”

headline: Europe’s Tough Case Against Google
text: The charge in the European Commission’s antitrust complaint against Google may be relatively easy to explain — the company tried to steer people to its own comparison-shopping service. But it won’t be easy to show that Google’s tactic actually hurt its rivals — or hurt consumers by limiting their choices.

headline: First in the Nation Forum: Carly Fiorina
text: Best Applause Line: Ms. Fiorina has organized her campaign around tough attacks on Hillary Rodham Clinton, and has emphasized how much more business experience she has. Ms. Fiorina’s comment that “Hillary Clinton must not be president of the United States,” was met with an enthusiastic ovation.

headline: Hey, Google! Check Out This Column on Headlines
text: THE headline was perfect: “China’s Tensions with the Dalai Lama Spill Into the Afterlife.” Engaging, informative and clever, it sat atop a story about reincarnation and the succession plan for the Tibetan Buddhist leader, accompanied by a photo of the golden-robed monk.

headline: First in the Nation Forum: Bobby Jindal
text: Best Applause Line: Mr. Jindal’s denunciations of the Common Core education standards, with particular hoots and claps for his flat insistence that “We have got to get rid of Common Core.”

headline: Lawsuit in Spain Seeks Recognition of Another Dalí Creation: A Daughter
text: GIRONA, Spain — Salvador Dalí led the kind of eccentric and sensational lifestyle that might have been expected of one of the greatest Surrealist painters.

headline: As Detroit Tigers Evolve, Success Is a Constant
text: The Detroit Tigers have pulled off a trick that only the best teams can do. Their position in the standings never changes, but their roster continues to evolve.

headline: The Art of Music and Conversation
text: Louis K. Meisel, a Manhattan art dealer and music lover, has been presenting concerts by young musicians in his SoHo loft for some 18 years.

headline: At Organico, Where Organic Isn’t Simply Healthy
text: Signs that Long Islanders are interested in healthier eating seem to be everywhere. My favorite supermarket recently doubled the space for organic and whole food; a peek into my son and daughter-in-law’s refrigerator revealed an all-organic lineup of milk, eggs and poultry, and then there’s Organico, an organic Italian restaurant that opened last August in Port Washington.

headline: Nearly 20 Years Later, Another Yankees Replacement Is Struggling
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — For a generation, Don Mattingly embodied the Yankees ideal. He was the team’s best player, its captain and a revered figure for the way he carried himself.

headline: Review: In Tammy Ryan’s Play ‘Tar Beach,’ a Summer Night of Partying, Boys and Regrets
text: Tammy Ryan is a playwright known to New Jersey audiences for her “Lost Boy Found in Whole Foods” and “Soldier’s Heart,” both of which were produced in recent seasons by Premiere Stages in Union. Her latest work, “Tar Beach,” can now be seen in its world premiere at Luna Stage in West Orange.

headline: First in the Nation Forum: Lindsey Graham
text: Best Applause Line: Mr. Graham, a noted quipster, won more laughs than applause, but they were chuckles of approval. One of Mr. Graham’s most resonant one-liners was his criticism of the Obama administration’s negotiations with Iran over that country’s nuclear capacity. “I wouldn’t let John Kerry buy me a car,” he cracked.

headline: Ever-Changing Flavors, With a Hint of Daring at Pairings Palate+Plate
text: As a new father, I rarely find myself in a white-tablecloth, formal restaurant, so I’m almost surprised when I enter such a place. The casual elegance of Pairings Palate+Plate in Cranford, N.J., made me wonder if I was underdressed in my jeans and sweater.

headline: Nets’ Hopes Rest on Deron Williams, if He’s Up to Carrying Them
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Deron Williams was surrounded by a group of reporters Friday as he answered questions about the Nets’ new lease on life.

headline: First in the Nation Forum: John Kasich
text: Best Applause Line: After calling for stronger border security and federal budget changes, especially changes to entitlement programs, Mr. Kasich said, “We need a strong America to send a message to our enemies … that America is back, and this can be done.”

headline: Oh, Baby, What a Playoff Game! Right, Mom and Dad?
text: My parents don’t remember anything about the first hockey game I went to, but they’ve been talking about the second ever since. Probably because it could also count as the third game and part of the fourth one, too.

headline: An American Dreamland, From the Beginning
text: Somehow, she missed “Coney Island Baby,” the 1962 doo-wop hit by the Excellents. But Robin Jaffee Frank, who organized “Coney Island: Visions of an American Dreamland, 1861-2008,” has not missed much. A sprawling evocation of Brooklyn’s most famous — and sometimes infamous — locale installed at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art, this clamorous multimedia exhibition mixes fine art, pop culture and history, juxtaposing shimmering beachscapes and gaudy carousel horses, Sunday comics and classic photographs, surreal paintings and vintage posters.

headline: First in the Nation Forum: Mike Huckabee
text: Best Applause Line: It was not for a lack of trying, but Mr. Huckabee only received modest applause from a crowd that may have been a bit fatigued as the afternoon wore on and the candidates kept coming. His best response may have been when, in criticizing the country’s tax system, he referenced the emails lost by Lois Lerner, the former Internal Revenue Service official. “They can’t even keep their emails for seven days much less seven years,” Mr. Huckabee said of the I.R.S., complaining that the agency requires Americans to retain their income tax records.

headline: An Architect of Hawks’ Success, in Purgatory as Playoffs Begin
text: ATLANTA — Jonathan Walton, a professor of religion and society at Harvard University, received a phone call in September from Danny Ferry, who had recently started a leave of absence as the general manager of the Atlanta Hawks.

headline: La Foresta in Killingworth is a Farmhouse With Big Visions and Big Portions
text: The hulking olive-brown barn set along a barren reach of Route 81 in Killingworth had sat unused for years. Once home to a struggling Christmas-themed gift shop, it had long stood vacant — a looming carapace marooned beside a sparsely traveled rural road. But then, in late 2013, Francesco Lulaj, a local restaurateur, noticed it.

headline: First in the Nation Forum: Ted Cruz
text: Best Applause Line: Take your pick. “We need to abolish the I.R.S.” “We need to repeal every word of Obamacare.” Or, “Twenty months from now, imagine a commander-in-chief who stands up and says with utter clarity, we will destroy radical Islamic terrorism.” And finally, “If only the terrorists attacked a golf course, that might actually get the White House’s attention: ‘Holy cow, this is serious.’” Most of the Republicans ate up all of it and more.

headline: After Collapsing in Game 2, the Islanders Relish the Comforts of Home
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — The Islanders’ almost unfathomable ability to squander two-goal leads rose to the forefront yet again Friday night in Game 2 of their first-round playoff series against Washington.

headline: A Marathoner Outruns a Childhood of Poverty
text: Fernando Cabada — a poor Latino from one of the rougher neighborhoods in Fresno, Calif. — is the first to acknowledge that he will be an unusual front-runner for Monday’s Boston Marathon.

headline: A Free Spirit Prepares to Make an N.F.L. Splash
text: It surely was a sight to behold last year when Leonard Williams, a 6-foot-5, 302-pound defensive end at Southern California, would coast to team workouts across campus on a longboard as his wild hair flapped in the wind.

headline: California Releases Revised Water Consumption Rules
text: LOS ANGELES — In case there was ever any doubt, forcing a 25 percent cut in urban water use by Californians in the fourth year of a searing drought is not going to be easy.

headline: China Cracks Down on Golf, the ‘Sport for Millionaires’
text: HONG KONG — President Xi Jinping’s crackdown on vice and corruption in China has gone after drugs, gambling, prostitution, ill-gotten wealth and overflowing banquet tables. Now it has turned to a less obvious target: golf.

headline: Police Unions, Facing Public Anger, Rethink How to Address Shootings
text: Amid nationwide outrage over a police officer’s shooting eight bullets at the back of an unarmed, fleeing suspect in South Carolina, the statement by the local police union had a half-sentence of regret and contrition: Yes, it said, the fatal shooting was “beyond comprehension.”

headline: Cornell’s Chocolate Milk Fills Refueling Gap
text: ITHACA, N.Y. — Throughout the school year, Cornell’s strength and conditioning center is filled with a chorus of clanging weights and thumping rock music.

headline: Irwin Schatz, 83, Rare Critic of Tuskegee Syphilis Study, Is Dead
text: Nobody knows how many people read the December 1964 issue of the journal Archives of Internal Medicine, but apparently only one, Dr. Irwin Schatz, was so appalled by one of its articles, about a syphilis experiment using uneducated black men in Tuskegee, Ala., that he wrote the study’s author to protest.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: A Positive Perspective

headline: Double Down
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Well, I got myself into a fine mess with this one. I got out of it, eventually, but a fine mess is to be expected when I am faced with a rebus puzzle.

headline: A. Alfred Taubman, 91, Dies; Developer, Sotheby’s Owner and Focus of Scandal
text: A. Alfred Taubman, an art collector and shopping-mall tycoon who sold Renoirs and root beer with equal panache and turned a sleepy Sotheby’s auction house into a global power of art sales, but went to prison in a commission-fixing scandal involving its archrival Christie’s, died on Friday at his home in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. He was 91.

headline: Sale of U.S. Arms Fuels the Wars of Arab States
text: WASHINGTON — To wage war in Yemen, Saudi Arabia is using F-15 fighter jets bought from Boeing. Pilots from the United Arab Emirates are flying Lockheed Martin’s F-16 to bomb both Yemen and Syria. Soon, the Emirates are expected to complete a deal with General Atomics for a fleet of Predator drones to run spying missions in their neighborhood.

headline: Utility vs. Homeowners Over Solar Power
text: In Hawaii, where 12 percent of the homes have solar panels, handling the surplus power is putting pressure on the state’s biggest utility, which is fighting to reduce what it pays for the energy.

headline: Conflict Over Soil and Water Quality Puts ‘Iowa Nice’ to a Test
text: MANSON, Iowa — The flat, endless acres of black dirt here in northern Iowa will soon be filled with corn and soybean seeds. But as farmers tuned up their tractors and waited for the perfect moment to plant, another topic weighed on their minds: a lawsuit filed in federal court by the state’s largest water utility.

headline: Solar Power Battle Puts Hawaii at Forefront of Worldwide Changes
text: HONOLULU — Allan Akamine has looked all around the winding, palm tree-lined cul-de-sacs of his suburban neighborhood in Mililani here on Oahu and, with an equal mix of frustration and bemusement, seen roof after roof bearing solar panels.

headline: Workers Seeking Productivity in a Pill Are Abusing A.D.H.D. Drugs
text: Fading fast at 11 p.m., Elizabeth texted her dealer and waited just 30 minutes for him to reach her third-floor New York apartment. She handed him a wad of twenties and fifties, received a tattered envelope of pills, and returned to her computer.

headline: On This Day, Five Pitches and You’re Done
text: CENTRAL ISLIP, N.Y. — Sean Burroughs of the Bridgeport Bluefish fouled off an 0-2 pitch in the first inning of Saturday’s exhibition game against the host Long Island Ducks. The ball landed beyond first baseman Jon Griffin’s reach, and Burroughs lingered near home plate until the umpire Tony Senia explained to Burroughs that he had struck out.

headline: ‘Outlander’ Recap: The Power of Choice
text: Season 1, Episode 11: “The Devil’s Mark”

headline: Derrick Rose Puts Injuries, and Doubts, Behind Him as Bulls Defeat Bucks
text: CHICAGO — The lights dimmed, and the pump-up songs filled United Center. Fans stood, and spotlights circled the arena. The word “playoffs,” in red lighting, flashed on the floor. The Bulls’ starting lineup for Game 1 of their Eastern Conference series against Milwaukee was introduced, and the public-address announcer had a long-awaited treat for the home crowd.

headline: At Candidate Forum, Scott Walker Discusses Same-Sex Marriage of a Relative
text: NASHUA, N.H. – Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, a likely Republican presidential candidate, addressed an issue on Saturday night that has been roiling his party in recent years: gay marriage. Asked by a reporter if he would attend a gay wedding, Mr. Walker, a conservative and a son of a preacher who prays regularly for guidance, said he had attended a reception for a gay relative who had been married.

headline: First in the Nation Forum: Scott Walker
text: Best Applause Line: “If you want to vote in the state of Wisconsin, you have to carry a photo I.D. to prove who you are,” Mr. Walker said about one of several “conservative” laws he said he enacted as governor.

headline: Jonathan Crombie, Romantic Lead in ‘Anne of Green Gables,’ Dies at 48
text: Jonathan Crombie, a Canadian actor who was known to a generation of fans as Gilbert Blythe in the mini-series “Anne of Green Gables,” died on Wednesday in New York City. He was 48.

headline: Mets, Hottest They’ve Been Since 2010, Extend Their Streak to 7 Wins
text: Sitting atop the National League East, the Mets, winners of six straight, carried a noticeably calm vibe into Saturday’s game against the Miami Marlins.

headline: Masahiro Tanaka Is Stellar as Yankees Blank Rays
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — It took three starts, a cautious protocol and two months of ceaseless questions about the health of his right elbow, but the Masahiro Tanaka the Yankees have anxiously been hoping for was unveiled here Saturday night.

headline: A New Whitney
text: No longer a fortress in an uneasy city, the Whitney Museum of American Art opens itself up to a changed New York, a glittery emblem of new urban capital signaling a definitive shift in the city’s social geography.

headline: Smriti Rajan, Ravi Bhatia
text: Smriti Rajan and Dr. Ravi Bhatia were married Saturday at the Marriott Silicon Valley in Fremont, Calif. Pandit Bhushanji, a Hindu priest, officiated.

headline: Kiara Pesante and  Malik Haughton
text: Kiara Chavon Pesante, the daughter of Aundrea Wearing-Pesante and Wilfredo Pesante Jr., both of Fairburn, Ga., is to be married Sunday to Malik Jelani Haughton, the son of Tina L. Haughton of Orlando, Fla., and the late David H. R. Haughton. The Rev. Dr. Michael E. Dyson, a Baptist minister, is to officiate at the Mayflower hotel in Washington.

headline: Summer Jackson and  Luke Tarbi
text: Summer Rachel Maria Jackson and Luke Davis Tarbi were married Saturday at the Sedona Heritage Museum in Sedona, Ariz. Roland J. Jackson, a brother of the bride and a minister of the American Marriage Ministries, officiated, with their great uncle, the Rev. Joseph S. Simmons, a Baptist minister, taking part.

headline: Daphne Stavropoulos, Robert Papp
text: Daphne Zoe Stavropoulos and Robert Joseph Papp were married Saturday at the Archangels Greek Orthodox Church in Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Harry Pappas, a Greek Orthodox priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Bianca Caban, Justin Gerrard
text: Bianca Marie Caban, a daughter of Donna Acevedo Caban and Osvaldo Caban Jr. of the Bronx, was married Saturday to Justin Robert Gerrard, a son of Melinda R. Gerrard and Robert J. Gerrard, Jr. of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Peter M. Colapietro, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of Saint Monica in Manhattan.

headline: James Fielding and Edison Briones
text: James David Fielding and Edison Briones were married Saturday in Palm Springs, Calif. The Rev. J. Edwin Bacon Jr., an Episcopal priest, officiated at the O’Donnell House, an event space.

headline: Madeleine Fawcett, Adam Atenasio
text: Madeleine Johnston Fawcett and Adam Anthony Atenasio were married Saturday at the Bath and Tennis Club in Palm Beach, Fla. The bride’s half brother, Courtney D. Fawcett, who became a Universal Life Church minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Melissa Paniccioli,  Daniel Linehan
text: Melissa Dawn Paniccioli and Daniel Connor Linehan are to be married Sunday evening at the Liberty House restaurant in Jersey City. The Right Rev. Kenneth J. Reihl, a Lutheran minister, is to officiate.

headline: Danielle Stahl and David Kirsch
text: Danielle Heather Stahl and David Jay Kirsch were married Saturday at the Park Hyatt in New York. Rabbi David Posner officiated.

headline: Ilona Palamarchuk,  David Johansson
text: Ilona Joy Palamarchuk, a daughter of Emiliya S. Palamarchuk and Petr A. Palamarchuk of Everett, Wash., was married Thursday in Seattle to David Douglas Johansson, the son of Barbara Corrigan Johansson and Douglas K. Johansson of Sammamish, Wash. Ed McKenna, a judge at the Seattle Municipal Court, officiated.

headline: Rebecca Savoie,  Christian Patry
text: Rebecca Ann Savoie and Christian Michel Patry were married Saturday by the Rev. George M. Rossi, a Baptist minister, at the River Course at Kiawah Island Club on Kiawah Island, S.C.

headline: Caroline Scheinfeld, Jeremy Leventhal
text: Caroline Patricia Scheinfeld and Jeremy Nathaniel Leventhal were married Saturday night by Rabbi Steven C. Reuben at the Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles.

headline: Jessica Schisano, Kyle Reidy
text: Jessica Martha Schisano, the daughter of Marianna T. Schisano and Richard Schisano of Newburgh, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Kyle Louis Reidy, a son of Valerie J. Reidy and James M. Reidy of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph G. Marina, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of Saint Francis Xavier in Manhattan.

headline: Amanda Niu, Patrick Swieskowski
text: Amanda Pei-Shiang Niu and Patrick David Swieskowski were married Saturday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Their friend Dr. Joseph Dottino, who became a minister of the American Marriage Ministries for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Kristin Meliambro, James Crismale II
text: Dr. Kristin Ann Meliambro and Dr. James Francis Crismale II were married Saturday at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle in Brookville, N.Y. Raymond P. D’Alessio, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony.

headline: Natalie McCormack,  Jonathan Richards
text: Natalie Genecia McCormack and Jonathan Elliot Richards were married Thursday at Ebenezer Wesleyan Methodist Church in Brooklyn. The church’s pastor, the Rev. Edward L. Jenkins Sr., performed the ceremony.

headline: Katherine Lamm,  Nicholas Morales
text: Katherine Elmlinger Lamm and Nicholas James Morales were married Saturday evening at Manhattan Penthouse, an event space in New York. The Rev. Galen Guengerich, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated.

headline: Julie de Neufville, Nick Monier
text: Julie Lyons de Neufville, the daughter of Virginia Lyons de Neufville and Richard de Neufville of Cambridge, Mass., was married Saturday to John Nicholas Monier, a son of Amy Williams Monier and Dr. Jules C. Monier of Dallas. William S. Lyons, the bride’s maternal uncle, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at Stella Plantation, a working plantation and event space in Braithwaite, La.

headline: Antonia Pryor and William Leavitt
text: Antonia Reese Pryor, a daughter of Lindsey Stansfield Pryor and Samuel F. Pryor IV of New York, was married Saturday evening to William Cowles Leavitt, the son of Elizabeth Ballantine and Paul Leavitt of McLean, Va. The Rev. Ted Pardoe, an Episcopal priest and the bride’s godfather, performed the ceremony at Christ Memorial Chapel in Hobe Sound, Fla., with the Rev. David C. L. Prior, an Anglican priest, taking part.

headline: Leah Keim, Bates Parsons
text: Leah Ann Keim, a daughter of Sarah L. Keim and Dr. Michael L. Keim of Fargo, N.D., was married Saturday evening to Charles Bateman Parsons, the son of Kathryn M. Parsons and J. Geddes Parsons of Hobe Sound, Fla. The Rev. Jered Weber-Johnson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. John the Evangelist Episcopal Church in St Paul.

headline: Patricia Peter and Henry Park
text: Dr. Patricia Rose Peter, the daughter of Dr. T. Rose and T. P. Peter of Freehold, N.J., is to be married Sunday to Dr. Henry Soo-Min Park, a son of Hye Kyong Park and Dr. Robert I. Park of Warren, N.J. The Rev. Ian B. Oliver, a minister of the United Church of Christ, will perform the ceremony at Battell Chapel at Yale, where he is a pastor at the University Church.

headline: ‘Booyah’ at the End of This First Date
text: Lisa Cadette Detwiler and Jim Cramer were married Saturday evening at the Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn. Aran Yardeni, an archeologist and friend of the couple who became a Universal Life Minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Crosby Scores Twice as Penguins Tie Series With Rangers
text: Pittsburgh’s Sidney Crosby hunched at center ice for the opening face-off against his Rangers counterpart, Derick Brassard, on Saturday night, and on cue came the boos that greet Crosby every time he touches the puck at Madison Square Garden.

headline: BuzzFeed Says Posts Were Deleted Because of Advertising Pressure
text: An internal review by BuzzFeed last week found three instances when editors deleted posts after an advertiser or employees from the company’s business side complained about their content, according to a memo sent to staff members on Saturday by the news and entertainment website’s editor in chief.

headline: Corrections: April 19, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Finding Fame In the Frame
text: In 1980, the groundbreaking conceptualist photographer Tseng Kwong Chi (1950-1990) infiltrated a $300-a-ticket reception for an exhibition of Ching dynasty costumes at the Metropolitan Museum of Art wearing his own signature outfit, a drab uniform similar to what Chairman Mao regularly wore. Pictures taken by a collaborator show him posing with Paloma Picasso, Henry Kissinger and others who may have taken him for a visiting dignitary rather than an interloper from the downtown art scene.

headline: Party-Rap Tunes, Served Up Light
text: As radio stations that were once straight-ahead hip-hop begin to lower their walls to pop influence, hip-hop won’t necessarily change, but it will morph. That creates room for a whole new class of rappers who have never considered life outside of the club. Take Kid Ink: He’s from Los Angeles, but where he really lives is on the radio, in saccharine party anthems full of dubious gender politics and toothless rapping.

headline: Finally, An Interview
text: “I’ve been waiting all my life for this moment,” Bruce Jenner says in a recent trailer for his hotly anticipated tell-all with Diane Sawyer. (Haven’t we all?) But what “this moment” is, exactly, remained a mystery when the network released a second excruciatingly brief teaser on Thursday for “Bruce Jenner — The Interview,” a two-hour “20/20” special on Friday at 9 p.m. Eastern time.

headline: A Merger of Art and Life
text: For the final section of a trilogy delving into issues including identity, memory and ancestry, the choreographer Emily Johnson has aimed high in her multiday performance installation “Shore in Lenapehoking (New York City).” Each section — four equal parts — relates to her quest to find connections between live performance and life. An Alaska native of Yupik descent now based in Minneapolis, Ms. Johnson looks at those places where, as she puts it, “we meet and merge.”

headline: BuzzFeed Report on Deleted Stories
text: A memo from Ben Smith, the editor in chief of BuzzFeed, that was sent to staff members about the site’s review of deleted posts.

headline: BuzzFeed Editor’s Emails Concerning Ads
text: An email from Ben Smith, the editor in chief of BuzzFeed, about a deleted post.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “The privacy of the pilot cannot be traded for aviation safety.”

headline: What’s On Sunday
text: 5:30 P.M. (FXM) RUBY SPARKS (2012) Zoe Kazan, above, wrote and stars in this variation on the Pygmalion myth as Ruby, a smart, saucy, redheaded young woman from Dayton, Ohio, who magically appears in Los Angeles, seemingly without much control over her emotions. Paul Dano, Ms. Kazan’s real-life partner, is Calvin, a literary whiz kid turned blocked writer who breathes life into this figment of his imagination, and then directs her every move. “ ‘Ruby Sparks,’ directed by Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris, the team behind ‘Little Miss Sunshine,’ has the same zany and sweet tone laced with just enough hardheaded wisdom to keep it grounded in psychological truth,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “The screenplay, by Ms. Kazan, is so polished and witty that it immediately puts her in the same league as Diablo Cody. And Ms. Kazan’s lovely, tart performance is the equal of Ellen Page’s portrayal of the title character in ‘Juno.’ Both are impetuous screwball heroines who could have been created only by women.”

headline: Notes on Greece
text: OK, that was intense. I’ll write more about my visit, but right now (from Frankfurt, where I’m laying over for a couple of hours) I want to make a data point. about just how much adjustment Greece has done.

headline: Crowding In and the Paradox of Thrift
text: As Francesco Saraceno notes, the IMF’s research department, which was always excellent, has become an extraordinary source of information and ideas in this Age of Blanchard. In particular, these days you can pretty much count on the semiannual World Economic Outlook to offer some dramatic new insight into how the world works. And the latest edition is no exception.

headline: Editorial Contest Winner | ‘Chemical Horses’ and the Racing Industry
text: We are honoring each of the Top 10 winners of our Second Annual Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay a day, in the order of submission.

headline: Hundreds of Migrants Are Feared Dead as Ship Capsizes Off Libyan Coast
text: ROME — Hundreds of people were feared dead on Sunday after a ship crowded with migrants capsized and sank in the Mediterranean, as the authorities described a grisly scene of bodies floating and submerging in the warm waters, with the majority of the dead apparently trapped in the ship at the bottom of the sea.

headline: A Mother’s Fight Against Gun Violence
text: It was a phone call that Jean Corbett-Parker had been dreading since the birth of her son. After leaving a nightclub in Harlem in 2001, her son, LaTraun Parker, was fatally shot in the head. When Ms. Corbett-Parker was called to Harlem Hospital to identify his body, she said she almost refused.

headline: ISIS Video Appears to Show Executions of Ethiopian Christians in Libya
text: CAIRO — The Islamic State released a video on Sunday that appears to show fighters from its branches in southern and eastern Libya executing dozens of Ethiopian Christians, some by beheading and others by shooting.

headline: 1915: After Wife’s Death, Baron de Reuter Commits Suicide
text: LONDON — Baron de Reuter, the death of whose wife on Friday [April 16] at Margery House, Lower Kingswood, Reigate, has already been announced in the HERALD, committed suicide last night by shooting himself with a revolver. Since his wife’s death, to whom he had been married for thirty-nine years, the baron had been deeply depressed, and he passed several hours daily beside the body.

headline: At Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Ceremony, a Generational Push and Pull
text: CLEVELAND — Although the show went on for five hours, a few things managed to go unmentioned at the 30th annual Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony on Saturday night here. Among the relevant topics not discussed: the solo catalog of Ringo Starr, who became the fourth and final Beatle to gain entry to the Hall twice over, this time as an individual; disco, rap and dance music, some of the rock-adjacent genres not represented in this year’s class; and the conspicuous decades-long absence of Bill Withers, one of the show’s honorees, from the music industry.

headline: Kenneth Branagh Starting London Theater Company
text: LONDON — Bibbidi-bobbidi-boo. Kenneth Branagh, whose movie “Cinderella” opened last month, has formed his own theater company, and will put on a season of plays at the Garrick Theater in the West End here, starting in October.

headline: Los Angeles County Museum of Art Reveals New Acquisitions
text: Before starting an ambitious capital campaign to finance the creation of a bold new building by Swiss architect Peter Zumthor, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art has been engaged in a 50th-anniversary acquisitions campaign designed to boost a collection that has long been considered uneven.

headline: A Response to Alec Baldwin’s Complaints That a Living Wage Rally Snarled Traffic
text: Dear Alec Baldwin,

headline: 1965: Swiss Try to Curb French Consumption of Snails
text: PARIS — After the lobster war, the chicken war and the artichoke war, France has become embroiled in a ‘‘snail war.’’ The Swiss canton of Neuchâtel, it was disclosed today [April 19], has issued a decree barring the ‘‘capture, transport and sale’’ of snails. Since most Swiss have a pronounced aversion to snails — on the dinner table, anyway — the new law is interpreted here as a riposte against the neighboring French department of the Doubs. Snail, smothered in garlic butter and baked, are a favorite dish of the French, and the people of the Doubs are accused of crossing the border to hunt for the escargots that the Swiss don’t use. Police have been authorized to search cars, suitcases and gamebags for contraband snails. Smugglers run the risk of having not only their booty but also their cars seized. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 20, 1965

headline: ‘Furious 7’ Muscles Out Newcomers
text: LOS ANGELES – Box office analysts have run out of bad car puns — raced laps, zoomed past, revved up, burned rubber, put pedal to the metal – to describe the performance of “Furious 7,” which took in an additional $29.1 million over the weekend in North America, for a three-week global total of $1.15 billion.

headline: Women’s Rights in China
text: Does the shoe fit?

headline: ‘Gone With the Wind’ Dress Sells for Six Figures
text: A dress worn by Vivien Leigh in the 1939 film “Gone With the Wind” sold for $137,000 this weekend. The dress, which was worn in four scenes by Leigh’s Scarlett O’Hara, was sold by Heritage Auctions along with other memorabilia from the film.

headline: Europe's Duty on Migrants
text: The high season of migration from Africa to Europe has begun, bringing with it a new wave of tragic drownings in the Mediterranean. Last year, more than 3,200 people died crossing the Mediterranean. This year, 900 people have already drowned, and on Saturday a boat carrying hundreds more capsized in the Mediterranean north of Libya. Unless Europe acts to reform its policy on migration, 2015 could be the deadliest year yet for the thousands of people who fled to Libya from conflict-torn regions across the Middle East and Africa, only to find Libya equally dangerous.

headline: Library of Congress Begins Posting Its Recorded Poetry Archive
text: To celebrate National Poetry Month, the Library of Congress has posted online some 50 recordings from its Archive of Recorded Poetry and Literature, including readings and lectures by Robert Frost, Elizabeth Bishop, Gwendolyn Brooks, Czeslaw Milosz and Paul Muldoon.

headline: New Blood Test Shows Promise in Cancer Fight
text: In the usual cancer biopsy, a surgeon cuts out a piece of the patient’s tumor, but researchers in labs across the country are now testing a potentially transformative innovation. They call it the liquid biopsy, and it is a blood test that has only recently become feasible with the latest exquisitely sensitive techniques. It is showing promise in finding tiny snippets of cancer DNA in a patient’s blood.

headline: Praise and Skepticism as One Executive Sets Minimum Wage to $70,000 a Year
text: When Dan Price announced last week that he would cut his own pay and profits to make it possible to raise the minimum wage at Gravity Payments, his credit card processing company in Seattle, to a hefty $70,000 a year, he had little idea of the whirlwind it would stir.

headline: With ‘Mad Men’ Shoot, Unwittingly Adding to Atelier’s Colorful Past
text: Adam Van Doren — who has an eye for detail, what with his training as an architect and his career as a painter and art historian — marveled at the attention to detail. To give his atelier more of a 1960s look, the crew that rented it for the pilot of a television series not only took down the track lighting, but also replaced the not-exactly-new faceplates on the electrical outlets with even older-looking ones.

headline: As a Cable Network Dispute Plays Out, Dodgers Fans Scramble to Pull Up a Chair
text: Through the last 66 seasons, Vin Scully’s melodic voice has brought Dodgers baseball to the team’s fans on radio and television.

headline: IBM Venture With China Stirs Concerns
text: HONG KONG — Shen Changxiang, who once supervised the cybersecurity of China’s strategic missile arsenal and spearheaded computer security research for the navy, has warned of the perils of his country’s reliance on American technology.

headline: Bill Clinton Leads Tribute on 20th Anniversary of Oklahoma City Bombing
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — Twenty years to the hour after a homemade bomb gutted this city’s federal office building, killing 168 people and a nation’s complacency about terrorism, a delegation led by former President Bill Clinton gathered here on Sunday to honor the dead and to celebrate the city’s resilience.

headline: China Frees Up $200 Billion for Lending to Stimulate Economy
text: HONG KONG — Chinese policy makers are dealing with a financial conundrum. Overall economic growth is slipping, which argues for looser monetary policy. But the risk is that any new money is diverted to the country’s frothy stock markets.

headline: Greece Flashes Warning Signals About Its Debt
text: WASHINGTON — By the standards of his frenzied schedule here last week, the meeting on Friday between Yanis Varoufakis, the Greek finance minister, and Lee C. Buchheit, the dean of international debt lawyers, was a quiet one.

headline: Tavares’s Overtime Goal Lifts Islanders Over Capitals
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — The chants of “Let’s go, Islanders” that reverberated through the 43-year-old Nassau Coliseum on Sunday before the Islanders took the ice to warm up were merely a preview of the jubilation ahead.

headline: Sunday Talk Show Roundup: The Surrogates Are Loosed
text: The Sunday shows were filled with prospective and declared Republican candidates for president and with surrogates for Hillary Rodham Clinton, who announced her candidacy a week ago.

headline: T.H. Tsien, 105, Dies; Scholar of Chinese Books Rescued 30,000 of Them
text: T. H. Tsien, a scholar of Chinese books and printing who in 1941 risked his life to smuggle tens of thousands of rare volumes to safety amid the Japanese occupation of Shanghai, died on April 9 at his home in Chicago. He was 105.

headline: Mets Win Again, but With 2 Injuries, ‘It’s Not a Good Day’
text: The crowd at Citi Field was doing the wave in the seventh inning. The Mets had scored seven runs in the fourth and eventually defeated the Miami Marlins, 7-6, to win their eighth straight game and complete a four-game sweep on a Sunday afternoon when Matt Harvey pitched.

headline: Trevor Noah, Next ‘Daily Show’ Host,’ Aggressively Sunny in Performance
text: By the way, Trevor Noah can also be pretty funny.

headline: Review: ‘The Mineralogy of Objects,’ With a Most Flexible Guest Star
text: The star of Laurie Berg’s “The Mineralogy of Objects” is an inflatable sex doll named Tanya. She appears midway through the 55-minute dance, which made its debut on Thursday at Danspace Project, in line with Ms. Berg and the three other female dancers who make up the cast. They toss Tanya around and try to keep her aloft like a beach ball. They engage her in an absurdly acrobatic ballroom duet. They roll with her on the ground as she deflates.

headline: Review: ‘David Hallberg Presents: Legacy’ at the Koch Theater
text: David Hallberg is an extraordinary dancer. How did he get there? On Friday at the David H. Koch Theater, he took us through parts of that journey in “David Hallberg Presents: Legacy,” a showcase of companies with which he has danced, supplemented by his own commentary. (Because of an injury, he’s on hiatus from performing.) These included the troupes for which he is a principal dancer — American Ballet Theater, represented by its Studio Company, and the Bolshoi Ballet — as well as the Mariinsky Ballet, Australian Ballet and Tokyo Ballet, in its American debut.

headline: Efforts for Land Mine Removal in Colombia Have Doubters
text: Colombia has one of the highest numbers of land mine victims in the world.

headline: Senator Joe Manchin of West Virginia to Seek Re-election
text: Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia, a Democrat known as a bridge between the parties, said on Sunday that he would run for re-election, quieting speculation that he would abandon his seat to run for governor.

headline: The agreement between FARC and Colombia’s military to work together on land mine removal has its doubters.
text: Colombia has one of the highest numbers of land mine victims in the world.

headline: In Colombia, Land Mines Are Cleared, Inch by Inch
text: COCORNÁ, Colombia — Luvin Mejía kneels on the ground, wearing a heavy Kevlar vest and pants, a thick clear plastic shield over his face.

headline: Venice Cup Women’s Qualifying Unfolds
text: This year’s Bermuda Bowl, Venice Cup and d’Orsi Senior Bowl world championships will take place in Chennai, India, from Sept. 26 to Oct. 10.

headline: Yankees’ Sweep at Tampa Bay Is Their First Since 2005
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — There have been no puffs of white smoke emanating from the office of Yankees Manager Joe Girardi, nor has Girardi issued any proclamations.

headline: Chivalrous Rule
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — When you find out the back story behind this one, you will likely give Tom McCoy a huge “Awww…” He’s dedicated today’s smooth Monday puzzle to his parents. His puzzle is also an excellent example of how to get started solving The New York Times crossword, if you’re a beginner (and I know you’re out there).

headline: Second Stage Buys Helen Hayes Theater and Settles Suit
text: A nonprofit theater company on Friday purchased one of the last independently owned Broadway houses, promising to bring more plays by living American playwrights to an industry dominated by musicals, movie adaptations and British imports.

headline: Review: Andris Nelsons Makes New York Debut as Boston Symphony Leader
text: One would think that by now the Boston Symphony Orchestra, which has been around since 1881, would have nothing to prove. Still, Andris Nelsons, the ensemble’s dynamic new music director, and the players, who are clearly excited over his arrival, seemed eager to show off last week at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Review: Jon Krakauer’s ‘Missoula’ Looks at Date Rape in a College Town
text: Pants on fire are a frequent motif in Jon Krakauer’s “Missoula,” a book about date rapes on a college campus. Mr. Krakauer, who admits to having known or cared virtually nothing about this subject before a personal experience prompted him to explore it, has a lot to say about lying.

headline: Shift of Christie’s Auction Crowds Art Collectors’ Calendars
text: At first glance, it seems a simple thing: This year, Christie’s has decided to hold its Impressionist and Modern art evening auction in the second week of May, not the first, as it usually does.

headline: Sky Pods Show Rise of New York Skyline
text: The elevators to the observatory atop 1 World Trade Center show an animated time lapse that recreates the development of New York City’s skyline, from the 1500s to today.

headline: On Time-Lapse Rocket Ride to Trade Center’s Top, Glimpse of Doomed Tower
text: An imposingly realistic vision of the old 1 World Trade Center, the ultimately doomed north tower, will begin appearing next month in a most unlikely place: the five special elevators servicing the observatory atop the new 1 World Trade Center.

headline: Billboards in Iran Say ‘Death to America,’ but Officials Say ‘Let’s Make a Deal’
text: TEHRAN — Wearing business suits set off with sneakers, the American executives trailed a young guide along the narrow sidewalks of the capital of Iran, once branded by the United States as part of the “Axis of Evil.”

headline: Rangers Lose Ground as Power Play Falters
text: The Pittsburgh Penguins had 1,123 penalty minutes in the regular season — the most in the N.H.L. — and were short-handed 277 times, the fifth-highest total. In Game 1 of their first-round playoff series against the Rangers on Thursday, the Penguins sent a cavalcade to the penalty box, taking four first-period penalties, which led to Ryan McDonagh’s decisive power-play goal in a 2-1 Rangers victory.

headline: Vienna Convention Is Part of Criminal Court Routine in Immigrant-Rich Queens
text: In a windowless fluorescent haze, in the depths of Criminal Court in Queens, a defendant making his first appearance before a judge hears a long, numbing list of forms changing hands.

headline: Xi Jinping Heads to Pakistan, Bearing Billions in Infrastructure Aid
text: BEIJING — China’s president, Xi Jinping, travels to Pakistan on Monday laden with tens of billions of dollars in infrastructure and energy assistance on a scale the United States has never offered in the past decade of a close relationship, a gesture likely to confirm the decline of American influence in that nation.

headline: Meb Keflezighi Is Back at the Boston Marathon as a Superstar
text: BOSTON — One year after capturing the Boston Marathon, when he ran alone for nearly the entire race to become the first American to win since 1983, Meb Keflezighi has come to attract the kind of vocabulary less commonly applied to runners than to gods.

headline: Anatomy of an Interrogation
text: The story of the first and only CIA contractor to be convicted in a torture-related case after an interrogation.

headline: A Singular Conviction Amid the Debate on Torture and Terrorism
text: Agonizing over torture as an antiterrorism tactic — how to define it and how to punish abusers, if at all — has been central to national security debates since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. The issue has received renewed attention in recent months with the release of a Senate committee report describing techniques used by the Central Intelligence Agency against terrorism suspects, practices found by senators to have been high in brutality and low in effectiveness.

headline: Skip Child Support. Go to Jail. Lose Job. Repeat.
text: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — By his own telling, the first time Walter L. Scott went to jail for failure to pay child support, it sent his life into a tailspin.

headline: Airline and Automaker Earnings; Euro Finance Meeting
text: Here are some of the top business stories to pay attention to in the coming week.

headline: Yemen Houthi Leader Is Defiant in Face of Saudi Airstrikes
text: SANA, Yemen — More than three weeks after Saudi Arabia began a bombing campaign aimed at crippling his movement, the leader of Yemen’s Houthi rebels responded with defiance on Sunday in a televised speech, saying that Saudi attempts to “humiliate” his country were doomed.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of April 20
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Netflix Is Betting Its Future on Exclusive Programming
text: LOS GATOS, Calif. — It is April 9 just before midnight in the war room of Netflix’s headquarters here, where the smell of popcorn fills the air and a team of engineers, social media experts and other specialists starts counting down the seconds until the new “Daredevil” superhero series goes live on the streaming service.

headline: Service Members Are Left in Dark on Health Errors
text: FORT WAYNE, Ind. — Lt. Col. Chad Gallagher was T. J. Moore’s squadron leader when the 19-year-old recruit arrived for basic training last spring at Lackland Air Force Base in San Antonio. He was watching at the quarter-mile track nine days later when Mr. Moore, on an easy mile-and-a-half test run, collapsed at the finish line and was rushed to a hospital.

headline: Interpublic to Buy Minority Stake in Samba TV, a Start-Up for TV Analytics
text: The Interpublic Group of Companies is buying a minority stake in Samba TV, a start-up that provides television analytics, part of the advertising giant’s effort to understand how consumers are watching television.

headline: Start-Up Solves ‘Star Wars’ Droid Puzzle
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — This is the story of how Robert A. Iger, chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, solved a technology problem — how to bring the new “Star Wars” droid BB-8 to toy shelves and Disney parks — by playing with a ball on his office carpet.

headline: Signs and Sounds of Spring
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Review: ‘The Tailor of Inverness,’ a Father-Son Tale at Brits Off Broadway
text: The writer and performer Matthew Zajac has a ghost story for you. And an adventure story and a detective story. It’s all the same story, which is apparently a true story and conveniently his own story — well, his and that of his father, Mateusz Zajac, who eventually settled in Inverness, Scotland, supporting his family with his sewing machine. What happens before that and also long after, as Matthew returns to Poland to spool back the lost threads of his father’s life, are the subjects of his impassioned but unfocused solo show, “The Tailor of Inverness,” the first entry in this season’s Brits Off Broadway festival.

headline: New Book, ‘Clinton Cash,’ Questions Foreign Donations to Foundation
text: The book does not hit shelves until May 5, but already the Republican Rand Paul has called its findings “big news” that will “shock people” and make voters “question” the candidacy of Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Small Film Producers Form a Group to Counter Piracy
text: LOS ANGELES — In what they hope will be an aggressive attack on the web-based theft of intellectual property, some of Hollywood’s top foreign sales executives are banding together to fight digital movie pirates.

headline: Familiar Shoals for America’s Cup: A Spat Over Rules
text: The America’s Cup appeared to have regained momentum in San Francisco Bay in September 2013, but 19 months later, it looks in need of a gust of wind.

headline: Mexican Police Capture Leader of Juárez Cartel
text: MEXICO CITY — Mexican officials said Sunday that they had captured a leader of the Juárez Cartel, Jesús Salas Aguayo, the man in charge of the gang’s operations in Ciudad Juárez during a convulsion of violence that made the city one of the world’s most murderous.

headline: Seeking Business, Cuomo Heads to Cuba With a New York Trade Delegation
text: When the United States opened the door for agricultural trade with Cuba more than a decade ago, Ward Dobbins went to Havana to market his Red Delicious apples, fresh from upstate New York. Working out of a tiny trade-show booth, he signed a contract to do business with the Cubans, and even caught a glimpse of Fidel Castro.

headline: Nets Drop Series Opener but Gain Sense of Hope
text: ATLANTA — Since the moment last week, in the waning hours of the N.B.A. regular season, when the Nets somehow slipped into the playoffs, Coach Lionel Hollins had cataloged the ways that the nature of the competition would change.

headline: Side Plots for Hawks as They Navigate Playoffs: Arrests and Injury
text: ATLANTA — As the Hawks, a surprise 60-win team in the regular season, were entering the postseason Sunday as the Eastern Conference’s top-seeded team, one of the few things dampening their spirits was the absence of their teammate Thabo Sefolosha, whose ongoing conflict with the New York Police Department will unfurl as a side plot to the high-octane basketball.

headline: In Arkansas, Gay Rights Ordinance Highlights Clash Between Two Faces of Tourism
text: EUREKA SPRINGS, Ark. — The Rev. Randall Christy was sitting in the amphitheater of “The Great Passion Play“ Friday afternoon, two weeks before opening night. Below him, amid a stage set meant to evoke ancient Jerusalem, a cast member in a baseball cap took Pontius Pilate’s horse-drawn chariot on a practice run.

headline: Laid-Off Walmart Workers Head to Labor Board
text: A group representing Walmart workers laid off after the abrupt closing of five stores last week planned to seek an injunction on Monday from the National Labor Relations Board that would require the retailer to rehire all 2,200 affected workers.

headline: In Arkansas, Gay Rights Ordinance Highlights Clash Between Two Faces of Tourism
text: A measure supporting gay rights in Eureka Springs is on a May 12 ballot, and opponents say the effort to promote the town as gay-friendly has hurt a nearby Christian destination.

headline: Forgiving $38,750 in Child Support, for My Kids’ Sake
text: Earlier this year, I spent three hours sitting on a hard, wooden bench in the Queens County Family Court, waiting for a judge to approve my petition to forgive $38,750 in child support arrears from my ex-husband.

headline: Mets Managing to Overcome Pain, for Now
text: Travis d’Arnaud, the stoic and rapidly improving Mets catcher, lost his cool late Sunday. No one could blame him. The Mets are the hottest team in baseball, and d’Arnaud cannot play for them for a while. He learned that his right hand was broken.

headline: Box, Provider of Cloud-Computing Services, Faces Make-or-Break Moment
text: LOS ALTOS, Calif. — About 10 years ago, Aaron Levie dropped out of college to start a Silicon Valley company called Box. Before long, he was one of those young technology wizards of whom great things were expected.

headline: LeBron James and Cavaliers Smooth Out Kinks, Then Roll Past the Celtics
text: CLEVELAND — It had been 1,802 days since LeBron James last appeared in uniform for a playoff game as a member of the Cleveland Cavaliers, so the energy inside Quicken Loans Arena on Sunday afternoon was almost volcanic during warm-ups. The building practically shook when James’s name was announced before the tip.

headline: Changing Tactics, Apple Promotes Watch as a Luxury Item
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple has scrapped its usual routine for releasing products with its new device, the Apple Watch. The company is instead taking a page from the playbook of another industry: luxury goods makers.

headline: At Small Theaters, a Divide on Actors’ Pay
text: In Los Angeles County, theaters with fewer than 99 seats have been allowed to pay performers just a small stipend.

headline: Review: ‘Fun Home’ at the Circle in the Square Theater
text: “Fun Home” knows where you live. Granted, it’s unlikely that many details of your childhood exactly resemble those of the narrator of this extraordinary musical, which pumps oxygenating fresh air into the cultural recycling center that is Broadway.

headline: At Small Theater, a Big Divide on Actors’ Pay

headline: Popular Demand
text: Three-quarters of owners use their tablets to surf the web “in a typical week,” according to the consumer panel polled by Experian Marketing Services, and more than half send email or visit social media sites.

headline: Animals Put at Risk in New York City’s Shelters, Audit Finds
text: The nonprofit group that cares for New York City’s stray and unwanted animals has administered unsafe drugs and stored vaccines improperly, according to an audit released by the comptroller’s office on Sunday.

headline: Signs Ebola Spreads in Sex Prompt a C.D.C. Warning
text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention revised its guidelines on Ebola transmission on Sunday night, urging survivors to abstain from all forms of sex or use condoms every time “until more information becomes available,” rather than three months as previously recommended.

headline: Actors’ Equity Pushes for Minimum Wage, but Not All Members Want It
text: LOS ANGELES — They rehearse for weeks, often in run down theaters that were once garages or retail stores; perform challenging premieres of new works and imaginative reinterpretations of old ones; and sometimes clean the bathrooms, sell the tickets, or sew the costumes, too.

text: Season 4, Episode 2: “East Wing”

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “We have said too many times ‘Never again.’ Now is time for the European Union as such to tackle these tragedies without delay.”

headline: Sunrise Over Marfa
text: It’s the typical New York predicament: Artists need space. Donald Judd, apparently, needed a lot of it. In 1971, he moved from New York City to Marfa, Tex., over 2,000 miles away. Later that decade, with the help of the Dia Art Foundation, he repurposed 34 buildings across 340 acres of the former military base Fort Russell to host his many large-scale installations — and to exhibit a few of his favorite artists, including John Chamberlain and Dan Flavin. (The permanent collection also includes works by Roni Horn, Claes Oldenburg and Coosje van Bruggen.)

headline: The Top 10 Moments from Salone del Mobile 2015
text: Unlike the fashion world, the furniture world pretty much only has one “season,” and it begins, for most brands, every April — when the Salone del Mobile trade fair takes place in Milan, bringing with it hundreds of satellite exhibitions and tens of thousands of professionals hoping to be excited by what’s new and next in design. Furniture companies set up incredibly elaborate booths at the fairgrounds to showcase their newest products, international designers band together to install their contemporary wares in centuries-old palazzos and villas, and local gallerists like Rossana Orlandi and Nina Yashar become curatorial tours de force, putting on their best and biggest shows of the year. After you’ve spent nearly a week pinballing around Milan, around the clock, attempting to absorb all the objects and ideas on offer, it’s always hard to begin to make sense of what you’ve seen — but here is a quick look at the 10 people, things and exhibitions that stood out most this year.

headline: Word of the Day | infantile
text: infantile • \ˈin-fən-ˌti(-ə)l, -təl, -ˌtel, -(ˌ)til\ • adjective

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Q&A: Maisie Williams on Arya’s New Mission
text: This post contains spoilers about Sunday’s episode, “The House of Black and White.”

headline: What’s on TV Monday
text: 10:15 A.M. (Starz Cinema) MASTER AND COMMANDER: THE FAR SIDE OF THE WORLD (2003) In the first of three Russell Crowe movies, Mr. Crowe stars as Capt. Jack Aubrey, commander of a British frigate whose crew must battle a faster, larger French vessel off the South American coast during the Napoleonic wars. Paul Bettany is the ship’s surgeon — so deft he operates on his own abdomen — and the sensitive foil to Aubrey’s ferocity. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that Peter Weir’s vigorous adaptation of the Patrick O’Brien series, with land-based scenes filmed on the Galápagos Islands, “hums with humor, passion and life.” He added, “It makes you wish Napoleon were still around, so we — that is, I mean, the British Empire — could beat him all over again.” In “Winter’s Tale” (2014), at 12:45 p.m. on HBO Signature, Mr. Crowe plays a gangster in early- 20th-century New York intent on putting asunder the love between a consumptive rich girl (Jessica Brown Findlay) and a thief (Colin Farrell). “A thin line separates the magical from the preposterous, and by insisting so strenuously on its own magic, ‘Winter’s Tale’ pitches helplessly into earnest ridiculousness,” Mr. Scott wrote about this adaptation by Akiva Goldsman of Mark Helprin’s best seller. And in “A Good Year” (2006), at 2:45 on HBO Signature, Mr. Crowe portrays Max Skinner, an aggressive London bond trader who inherits a small vineyard from his Uncle Henry (Albert Finney). Soon enough, Max, soothed by the memories of summers spent amid the grapevines, has morphed into a bon vivant and fallen for a beautiful bistro owner (Marion Cotillard). Then a young Californian (Abbie Cornish) shows up and announces that she is his uncle’s previously unknown daughter — which would make her Henry’s true heir. In his review of this Ridley Scott adaptation of the Peter Mayle novel, Stephen Holden advised viewers “to make a reservation at an upscale French restaurant immediately after seeing the film or risk going home feeling deprived.”

headline: Corrections: April 20, 2015
text: NEW YORK

headline: Meatyard at Home in Kentucky’s Cultural Scene
text: Ralph Eugene Meatyard, a master of photographing the strange and abstract, created his own reality, often casting his family into a hazy, two-dimensional world, where masked boys and specters of motion played against buildings and underbrush. Looking at that work — portraits of a minimal or absurd social landscape, it would be easy to see him as a solitary artist. Meatyard’s pictures are somewhat exclusionary, as if he found a surreal haven somewhere in the hills of Kentucky. Meanwhile, his local contemporaries tackled ambitious themes: Thomas Merton offered passionate counsel against the dangers of a self-centered, soulless society; while Wendell Berry ardently defended the environment.

headline: Trial Postponed for Greek Neo-Fascist Golden Dawn Party Members
text: KORYDALLOS, Greece — In the highest-profile political trial in Greece in decades, members of the neo-fascist Golden Dawn party appeared in court on Monday for a brief hearing as their trial was scheduled to open on charges including membership in a criminal organization and murder.

headline: Regulate the Internet?

headline: Look to the States on Broadband
text: State and local governments are starting to play an important role in getting broadband Internet access to the American public. And that’s highly commendable considering that many people still do not have access to high-speed connections at affordable prices.

headline: Shinzo Abe and Japan’s History
text: The visit by Japan’s prime minister, Shinzo Abe, to the United States next week is important on several levels. He will be the first Japanese leader to address a joint meeting of Congress. He and President Obama are expected to announce progress on a key issue, increased defense cooperation, and possibly on a second, trade. They will also discuss a third challenge, China’s growing influence in Asia.

headline: Greece on the Brink
text: “Don’t you think they want us to fail?” That’s the question I kept hearing during a brief but intense visit to Athens. My answer was that there is no “they” — that Greece does not, in fact, face a solid bloc of implacable creditors who would rather see default and exit from the euro than let a leftist government succeed, that there’s more good will on the other side of the table than many Greeks suppose.

headline: Mohammad Javad Zarif: A Message From Iran
text: TEHRAN — WE made important progress in Switzerland earlier this month. With the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council plus Germany, we agreed on parameters to remove any doubt about the exclusively peaceful nature of Iran’s nuclear program and to lift international sanctions against Iran.

headline: The American Response to Ebola
Farming Sunshine by the Megawatt
text: CALVERTON, N.Y. — Across decades, the great agricultural belt of eastern Long Island has cycled through all manner of crops, from the postwar cornucopia of potato farms to the crazy-quilt of sun-dappled vineyards that blankets the modern farmland. Now the region is farming sunshine itself.

headline: Saving a Plane That Saves Lives
text: WASHINGTON — WHEN American troops find themselves fighting for their lives, there is no better sound than an A-10, a plane officially nicknamed the Thunderbolt II but known affectionately by the troops as the Warthog, firing its enormous 30-millimeter gun at the enemy. It might not be pretty, but the A-10 is our most capable close air-support aircraft, and its arrival on the battlefield signals survival for our troops and annihilation for our enemies.

The federal government even forbids private insurers to use the numbers on insurance cards when they provide medical or drug benefits under contract with Medicare.

headline: 2 Manhattan Aeries With Hearst’s Imprint Are on the Market

headline: How Do You Deal With Boredom?

headline: ‘The Road to Character,’ by David Brooks
text: David Brooks’s gift — as he might put it in his swift, engaging way — is for making obscure but potent social studies research accessible and even startling, for seeing consistency as the hobgoblin of little minds and for ranging as widely across the private domain as the public. There aren’t many writers on politics who will study “emotional intelligence” as closely as they do polls, and fewer still extol failure as enthusiastically as they do success. Brooks’s flaws, as he tells us with typical cheerfulness and ease at the beginning of his new book, are that “I was born with a natural disposition toward shallowness” and “I’m paid to be a narcissistic blowhard” (the admission itself, of course, taking some of the edge off that “narcissistic”). He is, in short, a near-ideal public commentator (for this paper and for many other media outlets) because he is happy to sacrifice complexity and nuance in order to spin a hyper-readable, lucid, often richly detailed human story that sounds far less shrill and ad hominem than most of the polarizing rants of the day.

headline: Asne Seierstad’s ‘One of Us,’ About Rampage in Norway
text: After the Second World War, Scandinavia seemed to create model societies, free of corruption and intolerance, moral, compassionate and fair. The Danish people had bravely defied their Nazi occupiers throughout the war and saved almost all of the nation’s Jews. In 1944, the Swedish economist Gunnar Myrdal published a groundbreaking critique of the racism faced by African-­Americans in the United States. Myrdal’s study, “An American Dilemma,” greatly influenced President Truman’s executive order to integrate the United States military, the Supreme Court’s ruling on behalf of school desegregation, and the creation of the modern civil rights movement. In 1964, Gunnar Jahn, a former leader of the Norwegian resistance to the Nazis, handed Martin Luther King Jr. the Nobel Peace Prize at a ceremony in Oslo. Jahn expressed the hope that “conflicts between races, nations and political systems can be solved, not by fire and sword, but in a spirit of true brotherly love.”

headline: Roadside Bomb in Somalia Kills 4 Unicef Workers
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — At least four Unicef staff members were killed and four others were severely wounded in northeastern Somalia on Monday when a roadside bomb exploded near their minibus, a United Nations statement said.

headline: What, Exactly, Do You Want?
text: Suppose that you value freedom of choice. Are you committed to the mere opportunity to choose, or will you also insist that people actually exercise that opportunity? Is it enough if the government, or a private institution, gives people the option of going their own way? Or is it particularly important to get people to say precisely what they want? In coming decades, these seemingly abstract questions will grow in importance, because they will decide central features of our lives.

headline: 1940: Canadians Honor War Dead
text: Twenty-three years to the month from the day in April when gallant Canadian troops, in the face of withering German fire, began the battle of Vimy Ridge, destined to become one of the most famous pages in the history of the World War, Canadian veterans in Paris and modern Canadian soldiers at Vimy yesterday [April 20] refreshed the memory held by the world of the 11,000 who died at the ridge and the 60,000 Canadians who lost their lives in the war. In Paris the Canadian Legion gathered at the Arc de Triomphe yesterday morning as Colonel Vanier, Minister to France, laid a wreath upon the Unknown Soldier’s grave. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 21, 1940

headline: Sleek Spring Sandals to Complement, and Elevate, Any Look
text: Since its inception four years ago, the L.A.-based brand Building Block has created It bags for the sort of women who don’t do It bags. The line’s Modernist, structured carryalls, accented with cylindrical rubber straps and pared-back tassels, have a pleasing heft and luxe gloss that resonate with the ladies who covet them — many of them from the art world, who prefer that their accessories whisper, not shout. Now, the label’s designers, the sisters Kimberly and Nancy Wu, have turned their talents to footwear with the debut of their first shoe style, a simple but striking summer sandal. Hand-made in Italy of vegetable-tanned leather and encircled by a single strap of the same rubber tubing used in the line’s bags, they’ll gracefully ground even the most far-out spring looks. Nancy says of the design: “Inspiration always stems from the beauty and challenge of editing out excess details to reach a quiet balance of form and function.”

headline: Chelsea Miller’s Most Treasured Cooking Tool

The six-inch blade was once a farrier’s rasp for trimming horses’ hooves, rusted and dulled from use. Ms. Miller carved it with an oxyacetylene torch, ground it down and blasted it smooth in her smithy, down the street from her apartment in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: 1965: U.K. Scolds France on SEATO

French officials said it was pointless to send Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville to be the lone dissenter against U.S. policy in Vietnam.
