headline: Vampire Squid Outlast Their Shallower Peers
text: The mysterious vampire squid live in the deep sea at depths of about 3,000 feet. While squid in shallower waters reproduce only once, vampire squid reproduce throughout their life span, according to a new study in the journal Current Biology. After examining 40 specimens from the Santa Barbara Natural History Museum, the study authors noted that one fertile female appeared to have laid 3,800 eggs over her lifetime, but still retained 6,500 oocytes. The finding suggests vampire squid may live longer than shallow-water squid species.

headline: Inside the Sunrise Tour at the Chinati Foundation
text: How Donald Judd’s untitled, 100-aluminum-box installation in Marfa, Texas looks in the early morning hours.

headline: At Colette, an Art Exhibition and Beyoncé-Approved Headpieces
text: “I definitely didn’t take a ‘normal’ art path,” says the Brooklyn-based multidisciplinary artist Amit Greenberg. Yes, his works have been displayed at institutions like the Whitney Museum of American Art and SFMOMA Artists Gallery — but his debut solo show, “This is a happy thought,” featuring a character called BLU, fills the floors of the Paris shop Colette. Greenberg and a series of collaborators cooked up backpacks, T-shirts and tomato sauce; he asked Laura Wass of WXYZ Jewelry to customize the brand’s caps and headbands, made from metal tubes coated with car paint and hand-woven on rubberized elastic cording. The “dream helmets,” as Greenberg dubbed them, are meant to transform the viewer into a real-life BLU, and include a dose of Beyoncé freshness — the musician wore an upside-down WXYZ visor as a crown in her “7/11″ music video, released late last year.

headline: Vivid Accounts of War’s Horror Stream From Yemen’s Capital
text: Residents of Yemen’s capital, Sana, shared vivid accounts of life during wartime on social networks on Monday, as a huge blast shattered windows and shook buildings miles from the site of an attack in the Faj Attan district of the city.

headline: Cooking Techniques: Roasting Chestnuts
text: Roast chestnuts until fragrant and beginning to split.

headline: Post-Disptach’s Ferguson Coverage Wins Breaking News Photography Pulitzer
text: The St. Louis Post-Dispatch’s coverage of the aftermath of the Michael Brow shooting earned the paper the Pulitzer Prize for Breaking News photography.

headline: Batteries and Renewable Energy Set to Grow Together
text: POMONA, Calif. — The future of American energy, according to one widely held view, will include solar panels and wind turbines continuing to proliferate, churning out ever more electricity and eventually eclipsing fossil fuels to help offset the forces of climate change.

headline: W.H.O. Promises Reform After Criticism Over Ebola Response
text: After criticism that it was slow and ineffective in the crucial early months of the Ebola crisis, the World Health Organization said Monday that it would overhaul the way it deals with epidemics.

headline: Scenes from the Ebola Crisis Earn Photography Pulitzer
text: Daniel Berehulak’s coverage for the New York Times of West Africa’s Ebola crisis has earned him the Pulitzer Prize for Feature Photography.

headline: Morgan Stanley Takes Different Path to Rival Goldman
text: Morgan Stanley’s divergence from Goldman Sachs’ strategy is starting to pay off. James P. Gorman’s firm had its best quarter in years in the three months to March. Its Wall Street arch rival still has the edge on earnings performance. By one important metric, however, investors value Morgan Stanley more highly.

headline: Vaccine Phobia in California
text: California is in the midst of a dispute between parents who want to exempt their children from some or all of the vaccinations required for admission to public and private schools and a medical establishment that believes, with good reason, that vaccines can protect the students from the harm caused by infectious diseases and reduce the risk of transmitting the diseases from schools to the broader community.

headline: Scenes From the Ebola Crisis Earn Photography Pulitzer
text: Daniel Berehulak was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for feature photography on Monday for his coverage of the Ebola outbreak in West Africa for The New York Times. The staff of the St Louis Post-Dispatch won the prize for Breaking News Photography for their coverage of the aftermath of the police shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri.

headline: Times Coverage of Ebola: Pulitzer-Winning Articles and More
text: The Times produced more than 400 articles, including about 50 front-page stories from inside the Ebola-afflicted countries themselves. Here is a sample of work.

headline: 88,000 Applicants and Counting for 55 Units in ‘Poor Door’ Building

headline: 2015 Pulitzer Winners: South Carolina Paper Wins Public Service Prize; New York Times Wins 3
text: The Post and Courier of Charleston, S.C., with a staff of about 80 and a daily circulation of 85,000, won the most prestigious of the Pulitzer Prizes for journalism awarded on Monday, for a series on the high number of deaths resulting from domestic abuse in the state.

headline: Post-Dispatch’s Ferguson Coverage Wins Pulitzer in Breaking News Photography
text: The photography staff of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch won the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography on Monday for its coverage of the aftermath of the police shooting of an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown, in Ferguson, Mo., last summer.

headline: John Kasich of Ohio Takes Step Toward Presidential Run
text: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio unveiled New Day for America on Monday, a tax-exempt nonprofit committee that will allow him to raise money to travel the country as he explores a bid for the White House.

headline: ‘Finding Zero’: A Long Journey for Naught
text: Most tourists who venture to the tiny town of Khajuraho in northern India are drawn there by the thousand-year-old Jain and Hindu temples, especially the scandalously explicit sex depicted in the statues adorning the walls.

headline: What’s Behind the Surge in Refugees Crossing the Mediterranean Sea
text: There were about 17 times as many refugee deaths from January to April this year as there were during the same period last year.

text: There’s a special kind of despair, Thomas Pynchon observed in “The Crying of Lot 49,” that can arrive “when nobody around has any sexual relevance to you.”

headline: Sunrise Over Marfa
text: Donald Judd’s 100 untitled works in mill aluminum, created from 1982-6, was filmed in stop-motion this weekend during a sunrise tour of the Chinati Foundation in Marfa.

headline: David Koch Signals a Favorite: Scott Walker
text: Charles G. and David H. Koch, the influential and big-spending conservative donors, appear to have a favorite in the race for the Republican presidential nomination: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin.

headline: Cuomo Stays Optimistic After Seeing the Challenges of Doing Business in Cuba
text: HAVANA — Those along for the ride on Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s whirlwind trade mission to Cuba got a quick lesson on the challenges of doing business here: They saw abject poverty and a poorly developed infrastructure — and even experienced spotty air-conditioning at a hotel as temperatures soared well above 90 degrees.

headline: Leader of Militant Group in Russia Is Killed, Reports Say
text: MOSCOW — The leader of the Caucasus Emirate, the most active militant group in Russia, has been killed in a counterterrorism operation, the Russian authorities and Islamic militant websites reported Monday.

headline: Heading to Seattle? What’s New in Washington’s Seaside City
text: Advice to visit Seattle’s Pike Place Market may border on cliché — but for a good reason.

headline: Ebola Lying in Wait
text: A growing body of scientific clues — some ambiguous, others substantive — suggests that the Ebola virus may have lurked in the West African rain forest for years, perhaps decades, before igniting the deadly epidemic that swept the region in the past year, taking more than 10,000 lives.

headline: Review: In ‘I Understand Everything Better,’ Ruthless Elemental Forces
text: Hurricane Sandy is a marker for the choreographer David Neumann, whose life around that time underwent serious turbulence. His mother died the summer before the hurricane, his father a few weeks after the storm. (Both were esteemed actors in the experimental theater company Mabou Mines.) Somewhere along the way, Mr. Neumann turned to a quote from Albert Einstein: “Look deep into nature and you will understand everything better.”

text: BEN WILLIAMS

headline: Silicon Valley’s Water Conservation Conundrum
text: Menlo Park, Calif. — Silicon Valley has a richly deserved reputation as the world’s engine of technology innovation, with a track record that includes developing integrated circuits, microprocessors, personal computers and smartphones. This is a culture of confidence and bravado. Ask a bunch of tech leaders about their goals, and it’s a good bet that many of them will utter the words, “To change the world.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Greece, South Africa, Yemen and Iraq.

headline: Dark Matter’s Deep Reach
text: Earlier this year, Dr. Sabine Hossenfelder, a theoretical physicist in Stockholm, made the jarring suggestion that dark matter might cause cancer. She was not talking about the “dark matter” of the genome (another term for junk DNA) but about the hypothetical, lightless particles that cosmologists believe pervade the universe and hold the galaxies together.

headline: Our Ever Green World
text: By all evidence, Nero’s favorite color was green. The Roman emperor dressed in green, collected emeralds, cheered at the chariot races for the “green stable” team, and was particularly fond of eating green leeks.

headline: Rabies Deaths Higher Than Previously Thought
text: Rabies kills 59,000 people a year, or about 160 a day — more than had previously been assumed — according to a study published last week.

headline: Review: In ‘The News,’ a Cacophony of Current Events
text: If you have heard Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo speak and immediately thought “operatic hero,” then Jacob Ter Veldhuis’s “The News” is the music drama for you.

headline: IBM First-Quarter Earnings Top Wall St. Expectations
text: IBM reported earnings on Monday that surpassed Wall Street’s estimates, helped by solid sales of its new mainframe computers, even as its revenue fell.

headline: TV Review: ‘Inside Amy Schumer’ Season 3
text: Comedy Central recently released a teaser for the third season of “Inside Amy Schumer”: a music video parody sending up male obsession with a certain aspect of female anatomy, to the refrain, “Milk, milk, lemonade, round the corner fudge is made.” A few days later “Inside Amy Schumer” won a Peabody Award, television’s seal of middlebrow cultural respectability, alongside dramas like “The Americans” and “The Honorable Woman.” It was all the proof needed that no one has read the current cultural, intellectual and comedic moment better than Ms. Schumer.

headline: Readers Respond: On ‘Serving All Your Heroin Needs’
text: Physicians, counselors, chronic pain patients and family members of people addicted to opiates shared personal stories about America’s growing opiate addiction problem in response to a Sunday Review article, “Serving All Your Heroin Needs.”

headline: Walkabout: The Mystery of Kim Jong-un’s Mountain Climb
text: Kim Jong-un, Explorer? Did the leader of North Korea actually climb the country’s highest peak, at more than 9,000 feet, in leather shoes and a medium-weight coat? (BuzzFeed)

headline: Review: Marilyn Maye’s Tribute to Frank Sinatra
text: It took a while for “Her Way,” Marilyn Maye’s tribute to Frank Sinatra at 54 Below in New York on Friday evening, to achieve liftoff. But once it did, this 42-song anthology became a phenomenal demonstration of one woman’s stamina and musical intelligence.

headline: Review: In ‘Séquence 8’ Acrobats Defy Gravity and Constrictive Words
text: Among the abundant talents possessed by Les 7 Doigts de la Main — the philosophizing acrobats whose delightful new show “Séquence 8” runs through Sunday at City Center — is a gift for subverting metaphors. Many poetic comparisons will probably spring into your mind as you watch this sexy, witty Montreal-based team distort, upend and mock the laws of physics that keep us earthbound.

text: Human Composting

headline: Review: In ‘Emily Climbs (Machine Méchant),’ a Botched Rebirth
text: Put down those probiotics, step away from the treadmill and leave that Lipitor prescription unfilled. You can stop worrying about extending your life via diet and nutrition, because in just a few decades, scientists will perfect the art of regeneration. Well, almost. The titular heroine of “Emily Climbs (Machine Méchant),” at the Brick, undergoes a rebirthing procedure in the year 2090. But she comes back in triplicate.

headline: Here’s Your Pulitzer. Bad News to Come.
text: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

headline: Audiences Flying to ‘Neverland’ and ‘Paris’
text: “Finding Neverland,” despite opening to a barrage of negative reviews, grossed more than $1 million on Broadway last week for the fifth week in a row, and on Monday producers announced a national tour to begin next year.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: In Performance | Kelli Barrett
text: Ms. Barrett, with Ron Melrose on piano, sings “He’s There” from the new Broadway musical “Doctor Zhivago,” an adaptation of Boris Pasternak’s 1957 novel. The show is at the Broadway Theater.

headline: Teachers’ Unions Fight Standardized Testing, and Find Diverse Allies
text: In Florida, the teachers’ union has lobbied to limit the use of standardized tests, and the governor last week signed a bill that limits the number of hours students can spend taking them.

headline: Europe’s Migrant Crisis
text: Humanitarian experts predict the number of migrants who die crossing the Mediterranean Sea in 2015 could reach record levels.

headline: Pulitzer Winner for Music Found Inspiration in Pennsylvania Coal Mines
text: The composer Julia Wolfe’s oratorio “Anthracite Fields,” which won the Pulitzer Prize for music on Monday, had its origins in curiosity about the road not taken.

headline: Online Art Buying Rises in New Market Report
text: Sales of art online rose to $2.64 billion in 2014, from $1.57 billion the previous year, according to a report to be issued on Tuesday by the British insurance company Hiscox. Online art buying, the report found, accounted for 4.8 percent of the value of the global art market, which it estimated at $55.2 billion.

headline: Bird Flu Spreads to a Farm in Iowa With 5.3 Million Chickens
text: WASHINGTON — The Agriculture Department announced Monday that an outbreak of avian flu had been confirmed in what could potentially be millions of chickens at an Iowa egg producer, the largest outbreak yet in an epidemic that has also hit turkey farmers in Minnesota.

headline: Empty Nest? In Slovakia, It May Begin When the Child Is 35
text: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia — Jozef Izso, sitting on a small platform bed beside his desk while his mother busily puttered around in an adjoining room, said that there were definitely pluses and minuses to living with your parents when you are 29 years old.

headline: 2015 Pulitzer Prize Winners in Journalism, Letters, Drama and Music
text: The prizes, which are administered at Columbia University, were announced on Monday.

headline: Marathon Winners’ Jubilation in Boston
text: Lelisa Desisa and Caroline Rotich won the 2015 Boston Marathon, two years after bombs were detonated at the event.

headline: Justices Hear Second Round of Arguments on Case Hinging on Phrase’s Meaning
text: WASHINGTON — For the fifth time since 2007, the Supreme Court on Monday struggled to make sense of a phrase in a federal law that requires longer sentences for some gun crimes based on earlier convictions.

headline: H.I.V. Cases Lead Indiana to Extend Needle Exchanges
text: WASHINGTON — Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana extended a needle exchange program for another 30 days on Monday as the number of H.I.V. cases linked to intravenous drug use in a rural county continued to grow, with new cases being reported almost daily.

headline: Zulu King Tries to Calm Anti-Foreigner Violence in South Africa
text: The influential king of the Zulus, South Africa’s largest ethnic group, sought to distance himself on Monday from anti-foreigner comments he made three weeks ago, which the authorities there have called the catalyst for a wave of deadly xenophobic violence.

headline: Anxiety in Missoula Over Book About Campus Assaults
text: MISSOULA, Mont. — This town is bracing for a book. The local prosecutor wrote an urgent letter to its publishers trying to delay its release. Book sellers are taking orders for copies that wait in sealed boxes, ready to be opened on Tuesday. Some people are dreading its revelations about rape in their football-loving college town. Others are glad: Tell the story, they say, the louder the better.

headline: A Ballet Dancer, Offstage, With a Camera
text: Daniil Simkin, a principal dancer at American Ballet Theater, captures candid moments offstage, revealing the hard work behind the natural, masterly ease shown onstage.

headline: A Mets Newcomer Is Thrown Into the Fire
text: The first time John Flaherty crouched behind the plate in a major league game, the home plate umpire, Rich Garcia, asked how he was feeling.

headline: Dr. Oz to Respond on Show to Criticism by Physicians
text: The celebrity talk show host Dr. Mehmet Oz plans to respond aggressively on Thursday to doctors who have criticized his medical advice and questioned his faculty position at Columbia University, a spokesman for the show said on Monday.

headline: Clinton Calls Republican Criticism Just Partisan Distraction
text: KEENE, N.H. — Questions about her personal use of email at the State Department? Controversy about foreign donors to the Clinton Foundation? Accusations that her campaign events are overly staged?

headline: Google Adds ‘Mobile Friendliness’ to Its Search Criteria
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Many businesses around the world could wake up on Tuesday to discover their search ranking has been downgraded. After a monthslong warning period, Google will add “mobile friendliness” to the 200 or so factors it uses to list websites on its search engine.

headline: Bill Would Give F.D.A. More Muscle on Cosmetics
text: For decades, the Food and Drug Administration has had fewer than a dozen pages of instructions for how to regulate the millions of lipsticks, moisturizers and other cosmetics sold each year.

headline: Judge Denies Transgender Inmate’s Request for Transfer
text: MACON, Ga. — Ashley Diamond, the Georgia inmate whose lawsuit is making her a protagonist in transgender rights history, said in her first federal court appearance on Monday that she had come to blame herself for being a victim of multiple prison rapes, internalizing the guilt placed on her by corrections officials.

headline: Federal Prosecutor Drops Kirchner Conspiracy Case
text: BUENOS AIRES — A criminal case against President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner seemed to dissolve Monday when a federal prosecutor dropped accusations that she and her foreign minister had conspired to shield Iranians suspected of planning the 1994 bombing of a Jewish community center here.

headline: Uber Adds a Low-Tech Twist to Its Modern Business Model in India
text: NEW DELHI — Auto rickshaws are the mangy donkeys of Delhi transport, glorified golf carts that are a cheaper open-air alternative to taxis, and whose drivers enthusiastically embrace Delhi’s perpetual, honking traffic chaos.

headline: Teva to Pay $512 Million to Settle Suit Over Delay of Sleep Disorder Drug
text: The drug maker Teva Pharmaceutical Industries said on Monday that it had agreed to pay $512 million to settle claims that a subsidiary, Cephalon, paid generic manufacturers to keep their own cheaper versions of a drug off the market, a practice that the Supreme Court ruled in 2013 could be illegal in some cases.

headline: New York Subway Use Rose in 2014, Especially in Growing Neighborhoods
text: The number of people riding New York City’s subway system continued to rise last year, with some of the biggest jumps in ridership occurring in Brooklyn and Queens.

headline: Warning Iran, U.S. Sends Two More Ships to Yemen
text: WASHINGTON — The aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt and a guided missile cruiser were headed to the waters off Yemen on Monday to join 10 other American warships as a warning to Iran about its shipments of weapons to rebels there, American officials said.

headline: Ruling Clears Way for Jury Verdict on Former Goldman Sachs Programmer
text: The criminal case against Sergey Aleynikov — the former Goldman Sachs programmer who was convicted in federal court, then acquitted, only to be charged again in state court — will soon head to a jury after Mr. Aleynikov’s last-ditch effort to toss out the case came up short.

headline: A Grizzlies Fan Finds Fame as the Bongo Lady
text: MEMPHIS — The fans who pack FedEx Forum for Grizzlies games never know when it will happen. It could be a timeout late in the second quarter, or a break in the action early in the fourth. It does not even occur every game.

headline: A Veteran of the Financial Crisis Tells China to Be Wary
text: About 340 pages into Henry M. Paulson’s new book on China, a sentence comes almost out of nowhere that stops readers in their tracks.

headline: California Court Rules Water Pricing Plan Violates Law
text: LOS ANGELES — A California appeals court dealt a setback Monday to one of the main tools drought regulators want to use to force reductions in urban water use, saying a tiered pricing plan in the Orange County city of San Juan Capistrano that charged higher rates for big water consumers violated a voter-passed amendment to the State Constitution.

headline: Washington, Though Still Divided, Comes Together on Trade and Other Issues
text: WASHINGTON — Partisan peevishness is alive and well on Capitol Hill. But increasingly, Congress, under Republican control, is pressing forward on broad aspects of President Obama’s end-of-term agenda.

headline: Timing and Publicity Are Right as Pete Rose Looks to Shake Stigma
text: Since Fox Sports announced its hiring of Pete Rose as a studio analyst on Saturday, I’ve wondered, What took so long?

headline: N.J. Transit Proposes Fare Increase and Service Cuts
text: Fares for most riders would increase about 9 percent under a New Jersey Transit proposal announced on Monday in an effort to close a large budget gap at the agency.

headline: Joseph Phelps Dies at 87; Brought Innovation to California Wines
text: Joseph Phelps, a former builder whose passion for wine led him to become an innovative Napa Valley producer and the first to bottle an expensive Bordeaux blend with a fanciful proprietary name, died on April 15 at his home in St. Helena, Calif. He was 87.

headline: Elio Toaff, Spiritual Leader of Italian Jews, Dies at 99
text: Elio Toaff, the chief rabbi of Rome for half a century, who as a leader of Italian Jewry during its revival after World War II helped forge more amicable relations between Jews and the Vatican, died on Sunday in Rome. He was 99.

headline: On One Point Voters Agree: Barcelona Election Has Intrigue
text: BARCELONA, Spain — It is election season in Catalonia, and the most anticipated race will have all of the expected ingredients: charges of corruption, fringe challengers, improbable campaign promises and blatant pandering to voters (free haircuts, anyone?).

headline: Review: Renée Fleming Plays Against Type in ‘Living on Love’
text: Making her Broadway debut in “Living on Love,” the lumpy little comedy that opened on Monday night at the Longacre Theater, Renée Fleming seems like far too nice a woman to be playing a diva. That sounds irrational, I know, since Ms. Fleming, the great soprano, is one of the most celebrated opera stars in the world.

headline: We’ll Have Manhattan
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE  — So smart. Super sophisticated. We have an alliterative theme in this Tuesday puzzle, created by Gerry Wildenberg, and it includes several stumpers. So let’s start slowly.

headline: Israel: Leaders Decline to Meet Carter
text: Israel’s president and prime minister have declined requests for meetings with former President Jimmy Carter, who has long been a harsh critic of Israel’s policy toward the Palestinians. Mr. Carter has been persona non grata in Israel at least since his 2006 book, “Palestine: Peace Not Apartheid,” and he prompted further ire during last summer’s war between Israel and Hamas, the militant Palestinian group that dominates the Gaza Strip. Mr. Carter, 90, called for an international investigation into Israel’s prosecution of the war and renewed his plea to remove Hamas from Washington’s list of terrorist groups. Jason Pearlman, a spokesman for President Reuven Rivlin of Israel, said Mr. Rivlin had declined Mr. Carter’s request to meet based on the Foreign Ministry’s counsel. When Mr. Carter visited Jerusalem in 2012 with a group of former leaders called The Elders, he met with Shimon Peres, then president, but said he had been denied meetings with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his cabinet.

headline: New York Investigates Whether Boy Scouts’ Employment Practices Discriminated Against Gays
text: The New York State attorney general’s office has opened an inquiry into the Boy Scouts of America’s hiring practices to determine whether the group has discriminated as an employer against gays.

headline: Daily Breeze Celebrates Its Surprise Pulitzer
text: Rebecca Kimitch was on her couch, poring over a new story, when word of the Pulitzer Prize arrived.

headline: South Korean Premier Offers His Resignation
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Prime Minister Lee Wan-koo of South Korea said Tuesday that he had offered to resign over a snowballing bribery scandal, dealing a blow to President Park Geun-hye, whose government has already been rocked by a ferry disaster.

headline: Rangers Stifle Penguins for 40 Minutes, Then Withstand a Flurry
text: PITTSBURGH — The Rangers put an eye-opening 20-minute hiccup from Saturday behind them and regained their defensive consciousness Monday.

headline: C. C. Sabathia Flashes Old Form for Yankees; Result Evokes More Recent Past
text: DETROIT — As C. C. Sabathia stood on the mound, the wind whipping his oversize uniform as if it were a Christo installation, he nevertheless displayed the unflappable countenance of his earlier years as a Yankee, before his knee began to disintegrate and his fastball began to desert him.

headline: Amiable but Intense Defenseman Adds Punch to Islanders
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Lubomir Visnovsky, a quietly intense defenseman, played a vital role in the Islanders’ overtime victory on Sunday over the Washington Capitals.

headline: Giants’ Eli Manning Says Contract Will Not Be His Focus
text: Eli Manning said Monday that he was comfortable playing the 2015 season in the final year of his current Giants contract.

headline: New Genetic Tests for Breast Cancer Hold Promise
text: A Silicon Valley start-up with some big-name backers is threatening to upend genetic screening for breast and ovarian cancer by offering a test on a sample of saliva that is so inexpensive that most women could get it.

headline: Word of the Day | disengage
text: disengage • \ˌdis-ən-ˈgaj\ • verb

headline: Shinzo Abe, Japanese Premier, Sends Gift to Contentious Yasukuni Shrine
text: TOKYO — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe sent a ritual gift to a Tokyo war shrine on Tuesday, a gesture that could anger Japan’s neighbors ahead of a visit by Mr. Abe to Washington that will put his views of history under intense scrutiny.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
text: 8:30 P.M. (TCM) MARRIAGE ITALIAN STYLE (1964) Sophia Loren, the subject of this Turner Classic Movies tribute, stars as an ex-prostitute who tricks her longtime lover (Marcello Mastroianni) into marrying her instead of a younger woman by claiming to be dying. But soon enough it becomes evident that she isn’t. Whenever the director Vittorio De Sica joins forces with Ms. Loren, “something wonderful happens,” Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times about this flamboyant Oscar nominee for best foreign-language film. “The something wonderful that’s happened is the conception and projection of a film so frank and free and understanding of a certain kind of vital woman — and man, too — that it sends you forth from the theater feeling you’ve known her — and him — all your life.” A short film directed by Ms. Loren’s son Edoardo Ponti, “Human Voice” (2014), based on the Jean Cocteau play about a woman’s final telephone conversation with her lover, leads in at 8 p.m.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “It’s very comfortable here, especially now that my sister has moved out. But they do treat you like a child.”

headline: Block by Block | Carroll Gardens

headline: Rand Paul, Lukewarm Libertarian
text: LOS ANGELES — LIBERTARIANS, to the extent we can ever hope for real political success, should be excited about Rand Paul. But Mr. Paul, the Kentucky senator who is running for president, has treated his libertarian inheritance as more burden than boon. He’s even called libertarianism an “albatross,” though a growing, and young, share of the Republican Party is rallying around libertarian ideals.

headline: The Talented Mr. Rubio
text: Political audiences always like patriotic rhetoric, but as several reporters have noticed, this year’s Republican audiences have a special hunger for it. The phrase “American exceptionalism” has become a rallying cry. There is a common feeling on the right that the American idea is losing force and focus, that the American dream is slipping out of reach, that America is stepping back from its traditional role in the world and that President Obama doesn’t forthrightly champion the American gospel.

headline: Fix the Flaws in Forensic Science
text: THE F.B.I. stunned the legal community on Monday with its acknowledgment that testimony by its forensic scientists about hair identification was scientifically indefensible in nearly every one of more than 250 cases reviewed. But the conclusion should come as no surprise to scientists. It is the culmination of a collision between law and science that began in 1989 in a Bronx courtroom with the murder trial of a janitor.

headline: In Trade Talks, Secrecy or Openness?
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Violent Legacy of Chicago’s Police
text: Rahm Emanuel inherited a Police Department with a history of serious misconduct when he became mayor of Chicago four years ago. Mr. Emanuel tried to break with the past on Wednesday when he co-sponsored a proposal in City Council that would provide reparations to scores of people who were systematically tortured by the police during the 1970s and ’80s under the infamous police commander Jon Burge.

headline: Credit Suisse Profit Rises 23 Percent in First Quarter
text: LONDON — Credit Suisse said on Tuesday that its profit rose 23 percent in the first quarter as the bank benefited from an uptick in market activity and measures it took to offset a sharp rise in the value of the Swiss franc.

headline: Blue Bell Recalls All Products After Listeria Outbreak
text: Blue Bell Creameries, which distributes frozen desserts to about half of the United States, said that it was voluntarily recalling all of its products after the bacteria listeria was found in two cartons of ice cream last month.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Europe Considers Response as Hundreds of Migrants Die in Mediterranean Sinkings
text: In “Europe Considers Response as Hundreds of Migrants Die in Mediterranean Sinkings,” Jim Yardley reports on a full-blown humanitarian crisis in the Mediterranean Sea.

headline: Migrant Boat Captain Steered Toward Tragedy in Mediterranean, Authorities Say
text: MINEO, Sicily — When the Italian Coast Guard first got a call Saturday night from a fishing boat alerting it to a large vessel carrying migrants in the Mediterranean between the Libyan coast and the Italian island of Lampedusa, it radioed the nearest commercial ship, a Portuguese freighter called the King Jacob, to go help.

headline: What a Difference a Decade Makes: Xinjiang Film Emerges From the Past
text: One camera, one two-man crew, 16 poems, about 16 prostitutes and roughly 40 days in Xinjiang were all it took to make the road movie “Poet on a Business Trip.” That, and about 12 years of leaving the footage on a shelf, an incubation period that transformed the film into an inadvertent documentary of a seemingly more tranquil time in the ethnically divided region in western China.

headline: An Eye for an Eye
text: After Ameneh Bahrami was blinded and disfigured by a scorned suitor who poured acid on her face, she fought for her right to punish her attacker in kind.

headline: What Is Your Favorite Street?
text: Some of us love the glitz of a fancy shopping thoroughfare, like Fifth Avenue or Rodeo Drive, while others prefer leafy residential streets with stately homes. Or maybe you like quirky neighborhoods with hip cafes and cool restaurants.

headline: A Ballet Dancer, Offstage, With a Camera
text: Who is to stop Daniil Simkin, a principal dancer at American Ballet Theater, from photographing his friends inside the “bubble” of one of the world’s leading classical ballet companies?

headline: Steven A. Ballmer Speaks Loudly and Carries a Big Wallet
text: LOS ANGELES — Speaking last month to a few hundred M.B.A. students at the University of Southern California, Steven A. Ballmer, the owner of the Los Angeles Clippers, broke into verse. He recited a snippet of a song from the Broadway musical “Pippin”: “Rivers belong where they can ramble. Eagles belong where they can fly. I’ve got to be where my spirit can run free. Got to find my corner of the sky.”

headline: An Eye for an Eye
text: Ameneh Bahrami, whom Thomas Erdbrink first wrote about in 2008 when she won the right to exact revenge on a spurned suitor who doused her with a bucket of sulfuric acid, answered readers’ questions.

headline: At Supreme Court, Eric Holder’s Justice Dept. Routinely Backs Officers’ Use of Force
text: WASHINGTON — Teresa Sheehan was alone in her apartment at a mental health center, clutching what her lawyers said was a small bread knife and demanding to be left alone. San Francisco police officers, responding to a call from a social worker, forced open the door, blinded her with pepper spray and shot her.

headline: Penalty Phase Opens With Image of Boston Marathon Bomber Making Obscene Gesture
text: BOSTON — Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the man at the center of the Boston Marathon bombing trial, has been something of a mystery in the two years since his incarceration and throughout his trial. He has made no statements, and as he has sat in court, he has seemed disengaged, his blank expression revealing nothing.

headline: Negotiated at The Hague, a Child Support Treaty Falters in Boise
text: POST FALLS, Idaho — It took five years for negotiators to work out the details of a multinational treaty on child support that would make it easier to track delinquent parents around the world. It took only a couple of minutes for a committee of the Idaho Legislature to endanger America’s participation.

headline: Campaign Casts Hillary Clinton as the Populist It Insists She Has Always Been
text: CLAREMONT, N.H. — In her first week as a 2016 presidential candidate, Hillary Rodham Clinton seemed to channel another high-profile Democrat. “The deck is stacked in their favor,” Mrs. Clinton said of the wealthy and powerful. “My job is to reshuffle the cards.”

headline: Target’s Hasty Exit From Canada Leaves Anger Behind
text: TORONTO — Target’s exodus from Canada has left gaping holes at some of the most prominent shopping centers across the country, the biggest symbol of an exceptional period of retailing turmoil.

headline: Former SS Member, on Trial in Germany, Says He Was ‘Morally Complicit’ at Auschwitz
text: LÜNEBURG, Germany — Seven decades after the liberation of Auschwitz, a 93-year-old former SS member at the Nazi death camp shuffled into a German court on Tuesday to answer charges of complicity in the murders of 300,000 mostly Hungarian Jews in two months during the summer of 1944.

headline: Test Yourself | A Dog’s Gaze
text: Here are several paragraphs from an April 16 article, “The Look of Love Is in the Dog’s Eyes.”

headline: ‘The Light of the World,’ by Elizabeth Alexander
text: In the spring of 2012, four days after his 50th-birthday party, Ficre Ghebreyesus had a heart attack while exercising on a treadmill in the home he shared with his wife, the distinguished poet Elizabeth Alexander. He was probably dead before he hit the ground, but when Alexander and her sons found his warm body, she felt sure his soul was still in it. “It’s not easy to die,” Ficre used to say to her. But in Ficre’s case it seemed improbably easy. One minute he was full of life, gathering provisions for Easter dinner, buying lottery tickets, sending his wife to a kabbalah poetry reading. (“You are an artist, and you need it — I will take the children to the orthodontist!”) The next, he was lying on the ground, a small pool of yellowish fluid (plasma?) beside his head.

headline: ‘Infamy’ and ‘The Train to Crystal City’
text: In the days after the Japanese sneak attack on Pearl Harbor in December 1941, America was roiled with fears about spies and saboteurs. The anxiety was greatest on the West Coast, but it quickly spread across the country. “The editorial cartoonist of PM, New York City’s most liberal newspaper, drew a cartoon showing multitudes of bucktoothed, squinteyed Japanese lined up across the entire West Coast to be given packs of dynamite at a stand called ‘Honorable Fifth Column,’ ” Richard Reeves says in “Infamy.” “The caption was ‘Waiting for the signal from home.’ The artist’s name was Theodor Seuss Geisel, later to become famous writing children’s books under the name ‘Dr. Seuss.’ ”

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: A Lesson From Sally Mann: ‘Just Take the Picture’
text: My assignment, from The Times Magazine, was to show what life is like on Sally Mann’s farm. My decision to drive to Virginia was somewhat strategic; the seven hours on the road would allow more time for planning and visualizing shots than would a 90-minute plane ride. The short video vignettes would run online, alongside an excerpt from her soon-to-be-published memoir.

headline: New York Today: Finding Cuba in New York
text: Good morning on this clammy Tuesday.

headline: The Stability Two-Step
text: Yes, I’m wide awake at a ridiculous hour thanks to jet lag. Why do you ask?

headline: Editorial Contest Winner | Have We Lost Our Cents?
text: We are honoring each of the Top 10 winners of our Second Annual Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay a day, in the order of submission.

headline: Daily Report: IBM Profit Slips as Company Enters Transition Year
text: IBM reported earnings that surpassed Wall Street estimates, helped by solid sales of its new mainframe computers, even as its revenue fell, writes Steve Lohr.

headline: India Says It Seized Heroin Believed to Be Worth Nearly $100 Million From Boat
text: NEW DELHI — India said on Tuesday that it had intercepted a Pakistani boat in waters off its west coast with what appeared to be nearly $100 million worth of heroin aboard.

headline: 7 Thoughts From a Chronically Unhappy Person
Today in Politics: Hillary Clinton Will Always Have New Hampshire
text: Good Tuesday morning from Washington, where a Supreme Court justice is urging his colleagues to seek wisdom from abroad and Republicans with an eye on the White House are juggling the campaign trail with the fund-raising circuit. Social Security is resurfacing as a hot topic for conservatives, and Hillary Rodham Clinton is waxing nostalgic about the good old days in New Hampshire – and hoping for more good ones ahead.

headline: Mediterranean Graveyard
text: Europe searches for a response as the refugee toll soars.

headline: Lawyers’ Group Seeks Overhaul of a Postal Service Surveillance Program
text: WASHINGTON — A Postal Service surveillance program that records the information on the outside of letters and packages delivered to people suspected of criminal activity should be overhauled because of a lack of oversight, according to a report by a national defense lawyers’ group.

headline: Freddie Freeman Is Another Mets Tormentor, on a Far Different Braves Team
text: Even late in his career, whenever Chipper Jones came to bat and Mets fans chanted “Lar-ry! Lar-ry!” — his given name — he got a look in his eyes. The newspapers still called him a Met Killer, a name he had earned from years of clutch hits at Shea Stadium. Jones even named his son Shea, then denied that he had done so just to rile the Mets.

headline: For Travelers to Russia, it’s Deals and More Deals
text: “Be careful.”

headline: Seeking the Elusive Fee-Free Exchange Rate
text: Traveling on a budget can mean counting every penny, but that’s a lot harder to do if you are converting from centimes or centavos. Most of us do a lot of rounding: that yak wool blanket for 100,000 Mongolian tugrik, at 1,924 tugrik to the dollar? Divide by 2,000 — it’s about $50.

headline: Beyond the Boundary Principle
text: It was a murky winter morning; I could tell that much from my hospital window. I carefully shifted my neck, trying to keep my head straight so that my newly bald scalp wouldn’t burn as it brushed against the pillowcase. A small sea rock rested in my right palm.

headline: Morning Agenda: Financial Crisis Veteran Cautions China
text: FINANCIAL CRISIS VETERAN CAUTIONS CHINA | In a new book, Henry M. Paulson, the Treasury secretary and chief firefighter during the 2008 financial crisis, warns that China’s financial system will undoubtedly have to “face a reckoning and have to contend with a wave of credit losses and debt restructurings.” It is a remarkably cautionary message from the former chief executive of Goldman Sachs, writes Andrew Ross Sorkin in the DealBook column, given Mr. Paulson’s deep and long-established ties with the senior leadership of China.

headline: Pulitzer for International Reporting
text: The New York Times’s coverage of the Ebola epidemic in Africa won the Pulitzer Prize.

headline: Eric Lipton Accepts Pulitzer
text: Eric Lipton accepts the Pulitzer Prize for investigative journalism.

headline: Daniel Berehulak Accepts Pulitzer Prize
text: Daniel Berehulak accepts the Pulitzer Prize for feature photography on the Ebola epidemic in West Africa.

headline: Jon Stewart Announces August Date for Final Show
text: After more than 16 years at the helm of “The Daily Show,” Jon Stewart said that his final episode as host of the Comedy Central news satire would be on Aug. 6.

headline: Adderall in the Office
text: What will happen as more workers try to get an edge with stimulants intended to counteract attention deficit hyperactivity disorder?

headline: Hundreds of Chinese Cities Don’t Meet Air Standards, Report Finds
text: BEIJING — Air pollution data from the Chinese government shows that more than 90 percent of 360 Chinese cities failed to meet national air quality standards in the first three months of this year, according to a report released on Tuesday by Greenpeace East Asia.

headline: Hillary Clinton to Hold Five Fund-Raisers at End of April
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton will hold five fund-raisers in two days this month, low-key events in private homes hosted by a number of longtime supporters of hers — and one prominent 2008 backer of Barack Obama.

headline: In Performance: Kelli Barrett of ‘Doctor Zhivago’
text: This week’s video features the actress Kelli Barrett singing the number “He’s There” from the new Broadway musical “Doctor Zhivago,” a stage adaptation of Boris Pasternak’s 1957 novel about lovers in Russia during World War I. Ms. Barrett stars as Lara, the paramour of the show’s title character, played by Tam Mutu. “Doctor Zhivago,” directed by Des McAnuff, opens tonight at the Broadway Theater.

headline: An Unprecedented Tsunami of Hyperbole
text: We all want our stories to be engaging, even exciting. Deep reporting, clear writing and sharp detail are the best tools. But sometimes we can’t resist the impulse to pump up the prose with hyperbolic language.

headline: Robert Finn, Missouri Bishop Convicted of Shielding Pedophile Priest, Resigns
text: Pope Francis accepted the resignation on Tuesday of Bishop Robert W. Finn as head of the Diocese of Kansas City-St. Joseph in Missouri, heeding pleas from parishioners and priests that the bishop had lost the credibility to lead after being convicted three years ago of failing to report a priest who took pornographic pictures of girls.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | April 14-20, 2015
text: Have you been following the news?

headline: Information-Hungry Millennial Parents, Making It Hard on Themselves
text: My mother gave me a gift when my first baby was born. When my newborn daughter was released from the hospital, my husband and I brought her home to my parents’ house, where (in true Millennial form) we were living at the time. Walking back into the house after a hellish, messy labor was a balm — the kitchen was immaculate and lemon-scented, and there was chicken salad in the refrigerator.

headline: Even Locals Get Confused
text: Dear Diary:

headline: As Cash Dwindles, Greece Negotiates With Gazprom on ‘Energy Cooperation’
text: ATHENS — With their country running desperately low on cash, Greek officials met on Tuesday with the head of the Russian energy giant Gazprom, spurring speculation about a possible multibillion-dollar pipeline deal between Athens and Moscow.

headline: How a Color Becomes a Trend: Introducing Minion Yellow
text: This week, for the first time in three years, Pantone, the company whose shades are ground zero for pretty much all home, apparel or design work (in case you were wondering why you cared), has released a new color into the world: Minion Yellow.

headline: Study Tracks Accelerated Pace and Growing Pains of China’s Urbanization
text: China is in the midst of a sweeping government-led effort to transform the country from a once-predominantly rural economy to a land of modern city dwellers, with a goal of integrating 70 percent of the population, or about 900 million people, into urban areas within the coming decade.

headline: ‘A Danger on Rails’
text: In recent years, small towns across the United States have begun hosting an increasingly common phenomenon: long trains, made up of 100-plus black cylindrical cars, rolling slowly past our hospitals, schools and homes.

headline: A Danger on the Rails
text: This short documentary warns about the dangers posed by trains that transport explosive oil across North America.

headline: What Do You Read While You Write?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Zoë Heller and Anna Holmes discuss their reading habits when they’re working.

headline: An Unexpected, and Surprisingly Useful, Gift for Grads
text: This spring, opt out of buying yet another copy of “Oh, The Places You’ll Go” for the recently minted college grad in your life — she’s sure to receive at least three. Instead, give the new book from Jessica C. White and Kseniya Thomas, the founders of the international trade organization Ladies of Letterpress (its design community comprises some 2,000 members, and despite the moniker, boys are allowed). You may get a befuddled “Thanks?” in response, until you explain that the oversize book contains 86 detachable poster pages, with plenty of prints ideal for decorating the walls of those brand-new, grown-up starter apartments.

headline: Egyptian Court Sentences Mohamed Morsi to 20 Years in Prison
text: CAIRO — Mohamed Morsi, the deposed president of Egypt, was sentenced to 20 years in prison by an Egyptian court on Tuesday, in the first verdict handed down in any of the four significant criminal cases brought against him since the military ousted him in 2013.

headline: Teva, Maker of Generic Drugs, Bids $40 Billion to Acquire Its Rival Mylan
text: Eat or be eaten. That is the philosophy among drug makers that is underpinning a frenzied burst of consolidation and rapidly reshaping the global pharmaceutical industry.

headline: Shyp, an On-Demand Mailing Service, Raises $50 Million
text: From private rides to hamburgers to marijuana, there is perhaps no better time in history to get anything delivered with little more than a tap of a smartphone button.

headline: Chinese State-Owned Company, in a First, Defaults on Its Domestic Bonds
text: HONG KONG — For decades, regardless of weaknesses or inefficiencies, an overriding certainty of state-backed capitalism in China has been that the government looks after its own.

headline: Eritrea and North Korea Are World’s Most Censored Countries, Advocacy Group Says
text: The impoverished African nation of Eritrea has the lowest rate of cellphone ownership in the world, less than 1 percent of its people can go online, and its journalists are so terrified of offending the president that even reporters for the state-run news media live in perpetual fear of arrest.

headline: Slovakia Seeks to Raise Up to $1.1 Billion in Slovak Telecom I.P.O.
text: The government of Slovakia is seeking to raise as much as $1.1 billion in an initial public offering of its 49 percent stake in Slovak Telekom, the company said Tuesday.

headline: 1915: German Base Bombed
text: Further excellent work by French and Belgian aviators was reported yesterday [April 21] by the French Press Bureau. A communiqué issued last night says: ‘‘Our aeroplanes have bombarded the headquarters of General von Strantz and German convoys in the Voivre, and a power station at Lorrach in the Grand Duchy of Baden.’’ An earlier official announcement says: ‘‘Belgian aviators have bombarded the arsenal at Bruges and the Lissevegh aviation ground.’’ News received in Amsterdam from a German source confirms that Lorrach was bombarded by French aviators on Tuesday morning. — The New York Herald, European Edition, April 22, 1915

headline: Readers’ Turn: How to Help Black Men
text: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: Senate Reaches Deal on Sex Trafficking Bill
text: Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican and majority leader, announced Tuesday that a deal had been reached to resolve a dispute with Democrats over a bill to halt sex trafficking.

headline: Blue Bell C.E.O. Apologizes for Recall
text: In a video message on Monday, Paul Kruse, Blue Bell’s chief executive and president, apologized for recalling products on the market after two samples of ice cream tested positive for listeria.

headline: N.F.L. Draft Watchers Favor Jameis Winston Over Marcus Mariota
text: At the N.F.L. draft each year, a parade of tackles, safeties and linebackers streams to the podium to try on hats with logos and hold up jerseys. But for all the pundits’ talk about how teams desperately need a center or a cornerback, the choices that create the most excitement will always be the quarterbacks. And this year there are two big names.

headline: Australian Director Barrie Kosky Carries on Innovative Operatic Tradition in Berlin
text: BERLIN — In this city of three major opera houses, a feted star of recent seasons has been off stage: Barrie Kosky, a self-described “gay Jewish kangaroo” from Australia who has staged everything from Rameau and Mozart to forgotten 1930s operettas and “West Side Story.”

headline: Russian Premier Says Annexation of Crimea Was Worth Sanctions Fallout
text: MOSCOW — Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev said on Tuesday that sanctions imposed on Russia over its annexation of the Crimean Peninsula had done “meaningful” harm to the economy, but that it was a price worth paying.

headline: Twitter Broadens Ban on Violent Threats
text: When it comes to violent posts on its social network, Twitter has long held that it would only seek to ban direct, specific threats made against others on its microblogging service. Now, the company has decided that simply promoting violence against others is enough to get a user suspended.

headline: Jeb Bush, Not Yet a Candidate, Leads Fund-Raiser Rankings
text: Allies of Jeb Bush have joked that if he runs for president, he will use a strategy of “shock and awe” to overwhelm his Republican rivals, and when it comes to making his way around the fund-raising circuit, he is proving them right.

headline: A New Way to Look at Endive
text: Americans view endive differently than the French do: We associate it with salads, mostly served as a first course. But the French cook it all the time. They cut endive heads in half and sear them just enough to brown beautifully on the cut side, and serve them hot from the pan. The endive remains crisp, but the quick sear also renders it sort of juicy.

headline: Senate, Clearing Hurdle, Sets a Thursday Vote on Loretta Lynch
text: WASHINGTON — After weeks of difficult negotiations, the Senate on Tuesday reached an agreement to clear the way for the long-delayed confirmation of Loretta E. Lynch to replace Eric H. Holder Jr. as the attorney general.

headline: Defending the Family Routine
text: I remember my childhood as a time of routine, with days chugging along in much the same form for entire school years at a time. Is that just how I remember it, or how it really was? I don’t know, but what I do know is that I struggle to find a similar routine for my own family. It seems like it’s all sudden changes and just-this-once meetings and rescheduled car pool pickups.

headline: Daily Report: New Genetic Tests for Breast Cancer Hold Promise
text: A Silicon Valley start-up with some big-name backers is threatening to upend genetic screening for breast and ovarian cancer by offering a test on a sample of saliva that is so inexpensive that most women could get it, Andrew Pollack writes.

headline: Charlie Parker to Return to the Apollo Theater in Gotham Chamber Opera Season
text: The real Charlie Parker played the Apollo Theater. And next year the tenor Lawrence Brownlee will portray Charlie Parker there when a new opera exploring his life and work is given its New York premiere at the Apollo as part of Gotham Chamber Opera’s 15th-anniversary season.

headline: ‘Jurassic World’ Trailer Offers a Closer Look at a Killer Dinosaur
text: They gotta eat, they gotta hunt, you gotta watch. On Monday, Universal Pictures released its most robust trailer for the newest addition to the “Jurassic Park” franchise, with a more detailed look at the many dinos in action (raptors in training, raptors on the run), along with a good deal more menace. In its earlier trailer, released in November, the studio gave only a hint of the potential havoc a new genetically modified dinosaur might wreak on the park.

headline: Unpaid Russian Workers Unite in Protest Against Putin
text: MOSCOW — In the far east, the teachers went on strike. In central Russia, it was the employees of a metallurgical plant. In St. Petersburg, autoworkers laid down their tools. And at a remote construction site in Siberia, laborers painted their complaints in gigantic white letters on the roofs of their dormitories.

headline: The Next Era of Campaign-Finance Craziness Is Already Underway
text: There may be no political adviser closer to Rand Paul than Jesse Benton. Benton was integral to Paul’s Senate run in 2010 and was a top strategist for both of Ron Paul’s Republican presidential campaigns. When a fellow Kentuckian, Senator Mitch McConnell, needed help with his re-election campaign last year, Rand Paul lent him Benton. Benton also happens to be married to Paul’s niece. So it would have been natural to expect Benton to move into Paul’s campaign headquarters as soon as he declared his candidacy for president.

headline: New York Public Libraries Warn of a ‘Staggering’ Crisis With Infrastructure
text: The Hunts Point Library in the South Bronx uses only two of the three floors in its Italian Renaissance building, which was built in 1929 with money from the industrialist and philanthropist Andrew Carnegie. The quarters are so cramped that adult classes in English and computer skills spill over into the children’s area.

headline: ‘Full House’ Sequel Coming to Netflix
text: Netflix has bet its future on original programming but its latest announcement stretches the notion of original. On Tuesday, it officially confirmed that the long rumored reboot of the family sitcom “Full House” would debut on the streaming service in 2016.

headline: Survivors on Former Nazi’s Trial
text: Hedy Bohm and Eva Fahidi, Auschwitz survivors and co-plaintiffs in the trial of a former SS member who worked at the Nazi death camp, spoke on Tuesday at a press conference in Lüneburg, Germany.

headline: Finding the Right Credit Card, No Matter How Much You Travel
text: To rack up frequent-flier miles and loyalty points quickly and easily, you need the right credit cards. And now is a terrific time to sign up for one (or more), thanks to increased competition among issuers, resulting in some of the best offers in years.

headline: Co-Pilot’s Coffee Spill Blamed in Plunge of Serbian President’s Plane
text: WARSAW — The nearly disastrous plunge of the Serbian president’s plane Friday was the fault of the co-pilot, who spilled coffee in the cockpit and accidentally activated an emergency switch, the Serbian Civil Aviation Directorate said in a report published Tuesday.

headline: Areas With Large Black Populations Have the Smallest Shares of Black Men
text: Why do some places have so many more missing African-American men than others?

headline: Artisans and Crafts in London
text: London has long had a design week and a fashion festival, and now it’s turning the spotlight on potters, glass blowers, textile artists, metalsmiths and other artisans during London Craft Week, which runs from May 6 to 10.

headline: China’s Economy Puts New Pressure on Its Lopsided Job Market
text: HONG KONG — Wang Junping worked as a farmer in his native Hebei Province and as a coal miner in Inner Mongolia. But on a recent afternoon, Mr. Wang, 49, smartly dressed in a suit jacket, was awaiting lessons at an employment agency on the proper way to use a broom and mop to clean Beijing’s sprawling subway system.

headline: A Christie’s Auction Brings Together the Art, and History, of Jeff Koons and Martin Kippenberger
text: People in the art world are fond of saying that their business is all about personal relationships. Some others look at recent prices for art – $250 million for a single Cezanne, $142.4 million for a Francis Bacon – and believe it’s only about money. Both sides of that coin will be in plain view on May 13, when Christie’s auctions an untitled self-portrait from 1988 by the late Martin Kippenberger and a gleaming, stainless steel bust of Louis XIV made in 1986 by Jeff Koons, currently the most expensive artist alive.

headline: Former Met Director Becomes Chairman of Hispanic Society Museum
text: Philippe de Montebello, the longtime former director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is becoming chairman of the Hispanic Society of America to raise the profile of the organization, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday.

headline: Baryshnikov to Perform in a Show Based on Brodsky’s Poetry
text: Mikhail Baryshnikov will perform in a new solo work based on the poems of Joseph Brodsky, created for him by Alvis Hermanis, the director of the New Riga Theater in Riga, Latvia, where Mr. Baryshnikov was born. Called “Brodsky/Baryshnikov,” the piece will have its premiere in Riga on Oct. 15. A tour to the United States, as part of an international tour, is planned for 2016.

headline: Utah Gymnastics Coach Greg Marsden to Retire
text: With more victories than any other college gymnastics coach and a program that averaged 14,950 spectators per home meet last season, Greg Marsden announced his retirement on Tuesday after leading the University of Utah program he started 40 years ago to 10 national championships and a second-place finish at last weekend’s N.C.A.A. championships.

headline: South African Army Deployed in Areas Hit by Anti-Immigrant Violence
text: South Africa deployed troops on Tuesday to areas recently hit by a surge in anti-immigrant attacks that has claimed seven lives and exposed the government’s inability to stop the violence.

headline: Phil Rudd, AC/DC Drummer, Pleads Guilty to Threatening Murder and Having Drugs
text: Phil Rudd, the drummer for the still-kicking Australian rock band AC/DC, pleaded guilty to charges of threatening murder and drug possession on Tuesday in New Zealand, the BBC reported. Mr. Rudd, 60, was arrested in November and charged with trying to hire a hit man — apparently because of frustrations with the release of his solo album, “Head Job,” last year — although that more serious charge was promptly dropped because of a lack of evidence.

headline: A Third-Grade Rap Portraitist’s First Visit To New York, for His Tribeca Film Festival Debut
text: Yung Lenox, at just eight years old, walked the red carpet on Friday — which paled in comparison, in his opinion, to eating doughnuts during the film’s two-day shoot last year.

headline: Baltimore Officers Suspended Over Death of Freddie Gray Are Identified
text: The Baltimore Police Department on Tuesday identified the six officers who have been suspended in the death of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old black man who was taken to a hospital with a severed spinal cord after being chased and arrested.

headline: Santina
text: It’s always summer at this new restaurant from Mario Carbone, Rich Torrisi and Jeff Zalaznick.

headline: Restaurant Review: Santina in the Meatpacking District
text: The calendar said January when Santina opened early this year. The temperature outside hovered just above freezing. That said January, too.

headline: Morsi Sentenced to 20 Years in Prison
text: A court in Egypt on Tuesday sentenced Mohamed Morsi, the former president, to 20 years in prison for inciting violence and directing illegal detentions and torture.

headline: Trader Arrested in Manipulation That Contributed to 2010 ‘Flash Crash’
text: Five years ago, the global financial system was rocked by the “flash crash,” 15 minutes of chaos that shook the world’s biggest markets and prompted investors both big and small to question how such a vital part of the economy could be brought to its knees.

headline: Justices Rule That Police Can’t Extend Traffic Stops
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday ruled that the police may not prolong traffic stops to wait for drug-sniffing dogs to inspect vehicles.

headline: Smart City Technology May Be Vulnerable to Hackers
text: So-called smart cities, with wireless sensors controlling everything from traffic lights to water management, may be vulnerable to cyberattacks, according to a computer security expert.

headline: Israel to Remove Name of Slain Palestinian Teenager From Memorial
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli authorities said late Tuesday that the name of Muhammad Abu Khdeir, the Palestinian teenager from East Jerusalem who was abducted, beaten and burned to death by three Israelis last summer, would be removed from the state’s memorial to victims of hostile acts at the request of his father.

headline: Why American Workers Without Much Education Are Being Hammered
text: The last couple of decades have been terrible for American workers without much education. New research calculates just how bad, and offers some evidence as to why that is.

headline: Judge Orders Stony Brook University to Defend Its Custody of 2 Chimps
text: They may not know it, and they most certainly will not be in attendance, but Hercules and Leo will have their day in court.

headline: Super PACs Are Gobbling Up Even More Power, Jeb Bush Edition
text: The super PAC, which transformed the 2012 presidential election as a new conduit of influence for wealthy donors, is gaining even more power and flexibility for the 2016 elections.

headline: At the Intersection
text: Making the city safe for pedestrians begins by acknowledging that New Yorkers will walk wherever they damn well please.

headline: The Term ‘African-American’ Appears Earlier Than Thought: Reporter’s Notebook
text: As a reporter on the academic beat, I get lots of emails tipping me off to seemingly arcane items discovered in archives and libraries. I’m temperamentally inclined to find such things extremely interesting. But my ears prick up a bit more than usual when the item relates to the history of language, and the tip comes from Fred Shapiro as did the one that formed the article I wrote on Monday about the discovery that the term “African-American” originated much earlier than previously thought.

headline: Deal on Trade Pact Gives Obama Authority but Builds In a Delay
text: WASHINGTON — Republican lawmakers and the White House have agreed to subject any trade deal negotiated by President Obama to a monthslong review by Congress and the public, a concession aimed at winning the support of Democrats who view trade agreements as a threat to American workers.

headline: Saudis Announce Halt to Yemen Bombing Campaign
text: OBOCK, Djibouti — Saudi Arabia said Tuesday that it was halting a nearly month-old bombing campaign against a rebel group in neighboring Yemen that has touched off a devastating humanitarian crisis and threatened to ignite a broader regional conflict.

headline: Facts & Figures: Loretta Lynch’s Long Wait
text: Loretta Lynch has spent 164 days waiting to be confirmed as United States attorney general — longer than the framers spent writing the Constitution, according to The Huffington Post. Amanda Terkel and Jennifer Bendery offer a few other points of comparison:

headline: A Cooking Club That’s 124 Years Old and Counting
text: WICHITA, Kan. — Texas cattle, Turkey Red wheat and Pizza Hut all helped build this city on the Plains. And in its own quiet way, so has the Thursday Afternoon Cooking Club.

headline: A Third-Grade Rap Portraitist’s First Visit to New York, for His Tribeca Film Festival Debut
text: When 8-year-old Lenox Buringrud, known by the name Yung Lenox, was asked about his first impressions of New York City, during a visit to town last weekend, he responded with appropriate candor: “It’s kinda smelly,” he said. Despite it being the hometown of several of his favorite rap artists — Action Bronson and A$AP Ferg, for example — the city’s trademark characteristics, such as the steady noise and unidentifiable odors, were clearly less impressive for the Seattle-based third grader who had arrived for the premiere of “Live Fast, Draw Yung,” a lighthearted, 16-minute documentary which debuted at the Tribeca Film Festival last Friday.

headline: Midsummer Night Swing at Lincoln Center to Kick Off June 23
text: Lincoln Center’s Midsummer Night Swing, the annual dance party marathon at the outdoor ballroom in Damrosch Park, will run this year for 15 evenings from June 23 to July 11, featuring a buffet of acts in various styles. They include Jonathan Stout’s All Star Orchestra for the jazzy Lindy Hop, Cachao’s Mambo All Stars for Cuban dance, Nikki Hill for rock ’n’ roll, Conjunto Sabrosura for salsa, and many more.

headline: In a New Music Video, All Eyes Are on Speedy Ortiz
Cecily Strong’s Trial by Fire at the White House Correspondents Dinner
text: Sitting in her tiny dressing room at “Saturday Night Live” on a Friday afternoon, Cecily Strong was trying to keep her mind off a big looming commitment.

headline: Colm Toibin on Elizabeth Bishop: A Different Kind of Literary Tango
text: Captivating books are often born when one writer is obsessed with another. Nicholson Baker’s “U and I” (about John Updike) and Geoff Dyer’s “Out of Sheer Rage” (about D. H. Lawrence, sort of) spring to mind, but those are wild, hilarious books, almost like antic pranks. “On Elizabeth Bishop,” the novelist and critic Colm Toibin’s  compact new study of the poet’s work, has little in common with them, but it succeeds as a different kind of literary tango. It hums instead of crows. Its pull on the reader is almost tidal.

headline: Fear and Loathing in American Politics
text: New York Magazine’s Jonathan Chait and the Washington Post’s Dan Balz both have interesting pieces up this week discussing new research on polarization in America, though the basic findings they cite will not necessarily surprise anyone following our politics: The parties’ supporters are more ideologically distinct than in the past, split-ticket voting is disappearing, the electoral college map favors Democrats in presidential elections but population density creates a district map that favors House Republicans, etc. But the paper’s authors (Alan Abramowitz and Steven Webster) deploy a very useful term, “negative polarization,” to describe what they’re seeing in the data. As Balz puts it, “people don’t like their own party any more or less than they used to, but they dislike the other party much more.” Or to quote Chait: Today’s “voters form strong loyalties based more on loathing for the opposing party than on the old kind of tribal loyalty (‘My daddy was a Democrat, his daddy was a Democrat …’) that used to prevail. The party system has split along racial, cultural, and religious lines, creating a kind of tribal system where each party’s supports regard the other side with incomprehension and loathing.”

headline: First Draft Focus: Congratulations to a Nascar Champion
text: Kevin Harvick, winner of the 2014 Nascar Sprint Cup, was honored at the White House.

headline: Decatur, a Commuter Town Near Atlanta, Turns Trendsetter
text: Equal parts molasses-drawled Southern and au courant, Decatur, Ga., has in the last 20 years recast itself from the sleepy DeKalb County seat catering to commuting government nine-to-fivers to one of the South’s trendsetters. Residents say the township, six miles from Atlanta proper, is where “Mayberry meets Berkeley.” Bordered by Emory University and Agnes Scott College, Decatur is anchored by a late 19th-century courthouse (now the DeKalb History Center) and a leafy square dense with some of the state’s best restaurants, pubs and shops. The walkable downtown hosts more than three dozen festivals a year.

headline: Michele Leonhart, Head of D.E.A., to Retire Over Handling of Sex Scandal
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration’s top drug enforcement official will step down next month, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. announced on Tuesday, after her agency was tarnished by a scandal over sex parties with prostitutes and she broke with President Obama on drug policy.

headline: Celebrating the Lost Art of Flyers Through the Lens of the Louisville Punk Music Scene
text: Gone are the days when all a person needed to disseminate information were some paper, markers, a glue stick and a stapler — along with the required telephone poles on which to attach the resultant flyers. This is how bands publicized their shows, creating announcements with just the vitals — who, what, when, where and how much — using only the most basic materials. “White Glove Test: Louisville Punk Flyers 1978-1994” (Drag City, $40) showcases a collection of these DIY works of art that came out of one of the most storied independent music scenes in the country, responsible for such seminal bands as No Fun, Slint and Bonnie Prince Billy.

headline: The Republican Recipe for Widening Inequality
text: This week, House and Senate Republicans will be working on a final budget plan. They are operating from templates that call for cuts of about 40 percent on average by 2025 in programs for low and moderate income households — things like food assistance, college aid and tax credits for the working poor.

headline: Reassembling Woeful Knicks Tops Phil Jackson’s To-Do List

These migrants from Syria, Mali, Eritrea, Somalia and beyond had set out from North Africa hoping to reach Europe’s southern shores. Fleeing war and poverty, most had paid large sums to traffickers.

The Prancing Elites specialize in J-setting, a fluid style with roots in cheerleading and traditionally performed by women. The group had applied through the formal channels, was accepted and showed up in Santa-themed costumes ready to dance.

Both groups would be missing out on a thoughtful bit of filmmaking, one that at heart is not really about birds at all.

headline: Review: In ‘Don’t Think I’ve Forgotten,’ Cambodia’s Lost Generation of Pop Stars
text: “Don’t Think I’ve Forgotten,” a moving and informative documentary by John Pirozzi, takes its name from a hit song of the 1960s. The title may not ring a bell among Western audiences, though the tune itself might carry a sonic reminder of that era. Like almost all the music heard in the film, it was a product of the vibrant pop music scene that flourished in Cambodia during the ill-fated reign of Prince Norodom Sihanouk.

headline: Frederic Morton, Author Who Chronicled the Rothschilds, Dies at 90

headline: Freddie Gray in Baltimore: Another City, Another Death in the Public Eye

headline: American Marine Veteran Held in Iran Assails ‘Serial Hostage-Taking’
text: Relatives of a Marine veteran incarcerated in Iran for more than three and a half years sent a letter to congressional leaders on Tuesday, dictated by him over the phone from prison, denouncing what he called Iran’s “serial hostage-taking and mistreatment” and demanding tougher pressure on the Iranian authorities to release him and two other American prisoners as part of the nuclear negotiations.

headline: James Venture, 93, Dies; Resistance Fighter Survived Nazi Death Train

He was 93.

headline: Hong Kong Presents Plan for Elections, Offering Little to Democrats

Opposition lawmakers denounced the latest proposals, signaling the start of a political contest that will make or break the government’s plans.

headline: Eli Reed’s Long Walk Home
text: A few years ago, Eli Reed decided to show a bunch of his photographs to David Hamrick of University of Texas Press. It was early evening as he made his way to Mr. Hamrick’s office with a box of prints, a MacBook with color work and some other things from his office at the university, where he has taught photography since 2005. The images included scenes from his childhood home in Perth Amboy, N.J., battlefields in Lebanon, Hollywood sets and American poverty.

Amid the policy fights that followed the Republican victories of 1994, President Bill Clinton and the new majorities in Congress reached one particularly good deal: doubling the budget for the National Institutes of Health.
