headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
text: 7:30 P.M. (HBO) SAVING MY TOMORROW “You are the future generation,” says Grace, 10, a member of Plant-to-Planet in Seattle, which plants trees to help counter carbon dioxide emissions, the most prominent factor in climate change. “You are the ones who are going to have to deal with this mess that everybody else behind us has gotten us into.” Grace is one in a chorus of children speaking up for the planet in this kaleidoscopic family Earth Day special, the third of six episodes created with the American Museum of Natural History that melds science, animation, readings by Alan Cumming, Laura Dern, Tina Fey and Neil deGrasse Tyson, and music by Pharrell Williams, They Might Be Giants and Pete Seeger (in a previously unreleased performance) to address the perils of pollution, oil and gas drilling and climate change. “The adults clearly aren’t doing enough to stop this,” says Zoe, 12, “so we have to take it into our own hands.”

headline: The Iranian Foreign Minister’s Call for a Nuclear Deal
Fresh Outlooks From a Summer Getaway
text: Every child deserves a summer vacation or at least some relief from the heat. For Ricky Cruz, who was raised by his grandmother in the Bronx, the Fresh Air Fund provided an opportunity to escape. Spending a few weeks out of town as a young boy gave Mr. Cruz, now 22, a new outlook and a chance “to see different things that I would not normally see in my neighborhood,” he said.

headline: Who Flew First? Gustave Whitehead or the Wright Brothers?
Profiting From His Mother’s Crime
text: The speaker of the New York State Assembly, Carl Heastie, one of the three most powerful politicians in the state, has promised real reform in scandal-tainted Albany. Yet, as Russ Buettner and David Chen reported in The Times, Mr. Heastie himself is under a cloud for benefiting from his mother’s crimes nearly 20 years ago.

headline: The Gulf, Still at Risk
text: In the run-up to the fifth anniversary on Monday of one of the worst environmental disasters in American history, the 2010 BP oil blowout in the Gulf of Mexico, the country has heard happy talk from the company most responsible for it. Using phrases like “returning to pre-spill” or “baseline” conditions, and by emphasizing a rebound in fishing and tourism, BP has been suggesting in its reports and advertising that recovery of the entire ecosystem is just around the corner.

headline: A Pawn in the Iran Nuclear Deal
text: Plenty of irresponsible detractors have sought to derail negotiations between world powers and Iran over its nuclear program. The Iranian judiciary stands to further poison the atmosphere surrounding the talks by its continued detention of Jason Rezaian, an American-born correspondent for The Washington Post.

headline: A Year After Sinking, South Korea Will Try to Salvage Sewol Ferry
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea formally announced on Wednesday that it would try to raise the 6,825-ton ferry that sank more than a year ago, killing more than 300 people, most of them high school students.

headline: A Guide to the Proposed Changes to Hong Kong’s Election Rules
text: On Wednesday, Hong Kong’s government presented its proposal for how the city’s top official, the chief executive, could be chosen in future elections, starting in 2017. The government’s initial proposal was vehemently opposed by tens of thousands of protesters who occupied streets in the former British colony for nearly three months late last year. They demanded a far more open and democratic process. The new proposal now leaves opposition lawmakers with the choice of endorsing it and allowing universal suffrage for the first time but restricting the list of candidates, or rejecting it and risking the forfeiting any changes to the electoral system.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | 1.5 Million Missing Black Men
text: In “1.5 Million Missing Black Men,” The Upshot investigates why, across the country, hundreds of thousands of black men are missing from everyday life.

headline: Test Yourself | High-Fives Between Free Throws
text: Here are several paragraphs from an April 11 article, “He Missed a Shot? Give That Man a Hand.”

headline: In Chatham, N.J., a Strollable Downtown and Good Schools
text: Julie and Thomas Blackstock moved to Chatham Borough from Union City, N.J., in 2013 for a reason Ms. Blackstock, a freelance photographer, called “really unoriginal.”

headline: On the Night Willie Mays Hit No. 660, It Was Just Another Number
text: As New Yorkers filed into Shea Stadium that night in 1973, there was much more for fans to think about than an aging baseball star’s home run total.

headline: Wladimir Klitschko Seeks Recognition of Himself and Ukraine
text: Wladimir Klitschko, the heavyweight champion of the world, was trying to rescue a news conference that was supposed to be promoting a title bout at Madison Square Garden.

headline: House Passes Cybersecurity Bill After Companies Fall Victim to Data Breaches
text: WASHINGTON — Responding to a series of computer security breaches in government and the private sector, the House passed an expansive measure Wednesday that would push companies to share access to their computer networks and records with federal investigators.

headline: Ted Cruz Showed Eloquence, and Limits, as Debater at Princeton
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — By the time he was a senior at Princeton University in 1992, Ted Cruz had developed an arsenal of rhetorical skills and theatrical gestures that made him one of the most polished performers on the college debate circuit. So when he reached the quarterfinals of the national championships at M.I.T., with the title that had eluded him so far now in sight, he decided to try to knock his Harvard opponents off balance with one of his favorite tricks.

headline: Brooklyn Movie Palace Throws Regal Arms Around Restored Lobby Suite
text: Dorothy Solomon Panzica always knew what to do.

headline: The Prada Foundation’s New Arts Complex in Milan
text: MILAN — For more than 20 years, the Prada Foundation has been staging contemporary art exhibitions in abandoned warehouses and disused churches here, bringing contemporary artists like Anish Kapoor and Michael Heizer to Italian audiences, often for the first time. The foundation has masterminded projects elsewhere, too, like the time the Belgian artist Carsten Holler created the Double Club, a restaurant and club in a Victorian warehouse in London, drawing patrons like Mick Jagger and Penélope Cruz.

headline: Taliban Are Said to Target Hazaras to Try to Match ISIS’ Brutality
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A wave of kidnappings followed by numerous beheadings of members of Afghanistan’s Hazara ethnic group have spread alarm and anger among a people who historically have been this country’s most persecuted.

headline: How Emotionally Intelligent Are You?
text: This most-emailed article about emotional intelligence published in The Times’s Education Life section suggests skills we all need to be real leaders.

headline: New Orleans Bars Issue Last Call for Smoking
text: NEW ORLEANS — No one goes to a bar here, particularly one that advertises its hours as “2 p.m. till,” and expects precision about the time of day. But it was right on the stroke of midnight that Frankie Mazzanti, 56, one of the owners of the low-ceilinged neighborhood joint called 45 Tchoup, went along the bar picking up ashtrays and tossing them in a plastic bag.

headline: ‘The Do-Over,’ by Kathleen Ossip
text: “Oh, wow, mausoleums”: That’s the title Kathleen Ossip gives to the final poem in “The Do-Over,” her third book, and that disarming phrase sums up her goals. Ossip writes to remember the dead, ­especially Andrea Ossip (1944-2008), her husband’s stepmother; to face her own death without panic, if she can; to help us face ours; and to show how an aggressively up-to-date vocabulary — one that would make a lesser writer sound jaded, or bored, or distracted by pings from her iPhone — can fit the most serious of poetic concerns.

headline: Wislawa Szymborska’s ‘Map: Collected and Last Poems’
text: The mass of men may “lead lives of ­quiet desperation,” as Thoreau wrote, but the Polish poet Wislawa Szymborska (1923-2012) did just the opposite: She lived a life of quiet amazement, reflected in poems that are both plain-spoken and luminous. Many of them are gathered now in “Map: Collected and Last Poems.”

headline: ‘Mr. West,’ Sarah Blake’s Poems About Kanye West
text: The cynic (or is it the realist?) may look at Sarah Blake’s first volume of poetry, “Mr. West,” with a skeptical eye toward its interest in pop culture: The book is about Kanye West. It is also about contemporary media, motherhood, appropriation, infatuation and race. But it is mainly about Kanye West. Yet neither the cynic nor the realist need worry that Blake is merely using that mercurial genius as an attention-grabbing gimmick. No, “Mr. West” is a book that is in utterly good faith. That doesn’t quite make it a good book, however.

headline: The World’s Fastest Recreational Runners
text: Who are the world’s fastest slower runners?

headline: New Zealand’s Premier Apologizes for Pulling Waitress’s Hair
text: New Zealand’s prime minister, John Key, has apologized to a cafe worker who accused him of a form of torment usually associated with playground bullies: hair-pulling.

headline: Speculation to Condolences: Tales From the Comments Section
text: Bassey Etim leads The Times’s community team, which is responsible for comment moderation.

headline: This Earth Day, Green Is the New Denim
text: Earth Day, April 22, means different things to different people: a chance to plant some seedlings; a call to activism; the time to actually make that New Year’s resolution compost heap.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: New York Today: In Praise of Earth
text: Good morning on this unpredictable Wednesday.

headline: Obama Uses a Visit to the Everglades to Press His Climate Agenda
text: EVERGLADES NATIONAL PARK, Fla. — President Obama on Wednesday made his first visit while in office to the Florida Everglades, choosing the backyard of a former Republican governor of the state, Jeb Bush, and its Republican senator, Marco Rubio, to demand action on climate change in a critical battleground in the 2016 presidential election.

headline: Calixto Bieito Coming to Met Opera with a New ‘Forza’
text: Calixto Bieito, the daring Catalan theater and opera director, will make his Metropolitan Opera debut in the 2017-18 season with a new production of Verdi’s “La Forza del Destino” that is to be conducted by James Levine, company officials announced Wednesday.

headline: In Accusing Russian Energy Giant Gazprom, E.U. Begins a Test of Wills
text: BRUSSELS — European antitrust regulators on Wednesday charged the Russian energy giant Gazprom with abusing its dominance in natural gas markets, a move amounting to a direct challenge to the authorities in Moscow.

headline: Student Arrested on Suspicion of Planning Attack in France
text: PARIS — A 24-year-old Algerian computer science student suspected of planning an imminent terror attack was taken into custody in Paris over the weekend, the French authorities said on Wednesday.

headline: Tesco Posts $9.5 Billion Loss in Latest Hurdle
text: LONDON — Tesco, Britain’s largest grocery store chain, capped a year marred by an accounting scandal, management turmoil and shrinking market share with a whopping loss of 6.4 billion pounds, or about $9.5 billion, it announced on Wednesday.

headline: Saudi Resolve on Yemen Reflects Limits of U.S. Strategy
text: WASHINGTON — Saudi Arabia’s resumption of airstrikes against Houthi rebels in Yemen on Wednesday, only hours after it abruptly declared a halt to most military operations, reflected the difficulty of finding a political solution to the crisis. It also showed the challenges facing the Obama administration as it increasingly relies on allies in the Middle East.

headline: British Regulator Fines Merrill Lynch $19.8 Million for Reporting Failures
text: LONDON — A British regulator on Wednesday fined an arm of Bank of America Merrill Lynch 13.3 million pounds, or about $19.8 million, for failing to properly report tens of millions of client transactions over a seven-year period.

headline: Daily Report: ‘Flash Crash’ Arrest Raises New Worries About High-Frequency Trading
text: Five years ago, the global financial system was rocked by the “flash crash,” 15 minutes of chaos that shook the world’s biggest markets and prompted investors both big and small to question how such a vital part of the economy could be brought to its knees.

headline: An Earth Day Message in a Bottle
text: On our early morning dog walk in the Hudson Highlands woods near our new old home yesterday, my wife and I spotted this odd bit of Anthropocene ecology — the first ferns of spring growing in a bit of dirt inside a bottle discarded along the trail.

headline: Obama and Republicans Agree on the Trans-Pacific Partnership … Unfortunately
text: There’s an important issue out there you may never have heard of, which is just what its proponents would like. That’s the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), currently being pushed by the Obama administration and its corporate (and mostly Republican!) allies. It’s a blatant attack on labor, farmers, food safety, public health and even national sovereignty.

headline: Thatcher Wine on Creating a Travel Book Library
text: Regularly hitting the road is an obvious way to express a love of traveling; collecting books on travel is another. At least according to Thatcher Wine, 42, who, through his Boulder, Colo., company Juniper Books, creates custom libraries for avid readers.

headline: Obamacare, Hands Off My Medicare
text: A number of factors underpin the anti-redistributionist shift in public opinion that I wrote about last week.

headline: For Visitors to the Florida Keys, More Hotel Choices
text: The Florida Keys have long attracted fans of its no-shirt-no-shoes-no-problem culture. Now the 125-mile island chain may see more of them as hoteliers expand capacity, with nine new or substantially renovated hotels.

headline: Editorial Contest Winner | Journalistic Objectivity Was Yesterday’s Saving Grace
text: We are honoring each of the Top 10 winners of our Second Annual Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay a day, in the order of submission.

headline: Guest Post | Climate Change Questions for Young Citizen Scientists
text: A special Earth Day guest lesson, written with NASA’s Goddard Institute for Space Studies, a leader in global climate change research, and the Columbia University Earth Institute. It offers resources for teaching about this issue, while addressing important 21st-century literacy skills.

headline: Can People With Dementia Have a Sex Life?
text: Two philosophers, Ron Belgau and John Corvino, consider the case of Henry Rayhons, marriage and consent.

headline: Today in Politics: Labor Looks to Push Hillary Clinton to the Left
text: Good Wednesday morning from Washington, where political fund-raising pitches are getting increasingly personal and free-flowing amendments are stalling bills in Congress. President Obama is talking about climate change in the Everglades, while Gov. Chris Christie will look to lighten things up on Jimmy Fallon’s show. We look back at how Senator Ted Cruz handled humor in his college years, and we look ahead at how labor unions are gearing up to pressure a likely Democratic presidential nominee.

headline: Morning Agenda: ‘Flash Crash’ Arrest Raises New Concerns
text: ‘FLASH CRASH’ ARREST RAISES NEW CONCERNS | One of the most baffling financial mysteries of recent years – who caused the “flash crash” of May 6, 2010, when the stock market went into a free fall for 15 harrowing minutes – has now been solved. Well, up to a point. A major instigator of the crash, although not the sole cause, authorities say, was a single man, now 36 years old, who has been arrested in London.

headline: Italy’s Premier Calls for Action Before European Meeting on Migrants
text: LONDON — On the eve of an emergency summit meeting to address Europe’s spiraling migration crisis, Prime Minister Matteo Renzi of Italy on Wednesday issued a plea for collective action, and he alluded to a call for the creation of centers in Africa that would process asylum applications in a bid to spare many the perilous sea crossing to Europe.

headline: U.S. and South Korea Reach Revised Nuclear Deal
text: SEOUL, South Korea — After four and a half years of low-key yet highly sensitive negotiations, the United States and South Korea announced a revised treaty on Wednesday that continues to deny — but not permanently rule out — South Korea the right to enrich uranium or reprocess spent nuclear fuel, even for peaceful purposes.

headline: Rites of Spring
text: New picture books welcome spring weather — even the downpours.

headline: James Spader Prepares for ‘Avengers: Age of Ultron’
text: One overcast spring afternoon, James Spader was lurking in plain sight, standing on the stoop of the Greenwich Village townhouse where he lives, wearing a sport coat, a fedora and a bright purple scarf, smoking a cigarette and talking on a cellphone with the producers of his NBC series, “The Blacklist.”

headline: Airbrushing Austerity
text: Ken Rogoff weighs in on the secular stagnation debate, arguing basically that it’s Minsky, not Hansen — that we’re suffering from a painful but temporary era of deleveraging, and that normal policy will resume in a few years.

headline: Feel It in the Air
text: Dear Diary:

headline: A Coyote Eludes the Police on the Upper West Side
text: After a three-hour chase involving tranquilizer guns, trucks, patrol cars and helicopters, the police surrendered Riverside Park back to a coyote who, on Wednesday morning, had started its day atop a big rock near 87th Street in the park, then journeyed north toward Grant’s Tomb. In addition to eluding pursuers, the coyote threw into question the city’s recently stated policy that it would leave the predators alone in city parks.

headline: Trader Charged in ‘Flash Crash’ Case to Fight Extradition to U.S.
text: LONDON — A 36-year-old futures trader who operated from his London-area home indicated Wednesday that he would oppose extradition to the United States on criminal fraud charges, including claims that he had helped set off a huge crash in the United States stock market, known as the flash crash, in 2010.

headline: $1.35 Million Homes in Montana, Houston and Virginia Beach
text: ENNIS, MONT.

headline: In ‘Permission,’ Robert Askins Pairs Romance and Spanking
text: Robert Askins’s current Broadway horror-comedy is “Hand to God,” but his new play is about hand to something else entirely. In “Permission,” which begins performances April 29 at the Lucille Lortel Theater, Mr. Askins, who is having something of a moment right now, has written a work about romance with spanking. Like the critically acclaimed “Hand to God,” a scathingly funny, occasionally obscene play about a demonic force in church puppetry, “Permission,” directed by Alex Timbers, covers another Christian subculture. And this one may well appeal to fans of “Fifty Shades of Grey.”

headline: Xi Jinping of China and Shinzo Abe of Japan Meet Amid Slight Thaw in Ties
text: BEIJING — China’s president, Xi Jinping, and Japan’s prime minister, Shinzo Abe, met in Indonesia on Wednesday, a signal of a continued slight warming in relations that still remain frosty between Asia’s two biggest economies.

headline: House Hunting in ... Bali
text: A THREE-BEDROOM TRADITIONAL-STYLE HOME IN UBUD

headline: 1965: Disarmament Group Meets
text: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. — The 114-member UN Disarmament Commission met today [April 21] for the first time since 1960. Addressing the opening session, Secretary- General U Thant warned that ‘‘there is evidence that we may be approaching yet another crucial point in the nuclear arms race.’’ Mr. Thant urged the commission to give close attention to proposals to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons, to expand the 1963 partial test ban treaty to include all experimental weapons explosion and to plans for ‘‘denuclearized zones’’ such as Africa and Latin America. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 22, 1965

headline: McDonald’s Earnings Stumble on Sluggish Sales
text: McDonald’s reported gloomy earnings on Wednesday, warning of fewer customers around the world and striking a stark contrast to the booming fortunes of fast-casual restaurants like Chipotle that are sapping the Golden Arches.

headline: An Online Tune-Up for the Used-Car Marketplace
text: Linda Lo tried shopping for a car in the usual way, and like everyone else, she hated it.

headline: 1915: Save Hungary, Kaiser Says
text: LONDON — Latest advices received as to the situation in the Karpathians show that the Russians are solidly fortifying and extending the positions wrested from the enemy in preparation for their next big forward drive. The official communiqué issued in Petrograd to-day [April 22] says: ‘‘In the Karpathians the Austrians during the day and night of April 20 endeavored to attack our position on the Telepotche-Rumina front. The enemy’s offensive was repulsed by our counter-attacks carried out with the bayonet.’’ The Kaiser, reviewing his troops at Czernowitz, told them they must prevent the Russians entering Hungary. ‘‘Such an event,’’ he said, ‘‘would be the end of Austria.’’ — The New York Herald, European Edition, April 23, 1915

headline: E.U. on Antitrust Case Against Gazprom
text: Margrethe Vestager, the European Union’s commissioner for competition, said in Brussels on Wednesday that Gazprom was abusing its market dominance in central and eastern European member states.

headline: 2015 N.F.L. Schedule Matchups to Circle on the Calendar
text: In case you missed the three-hour (!) television special that revealed next season’s N.F.L. schedule, here is a look at five games that are particularly intriguing. (Yes, two involve the Buffalo Bills.)

headline: Parkour for Beginners
text: Last week, we invited 10 readers from the Well Book Club to learn parkour in New York’s Central Park with Chris McDougall, author of the new book “Natural Born Heroes.”

headline: Why I Love ‘Full House’ and Why We Need a Sequel Done Right
text: “Full House” reruns have eclipsed the Disney/Nickelodeon line-up that once dominated our screen on weekends. “Jessie” has been replaced by Uncle Jessie, and “Austin & Ally” by D.J., Stephanie and Michelle.

headline: The Hole Left by Tamir Rice’s Death
text: Five months after a Cleveland police officer shot and killed Tamir Rice, 12, his family and friends are still struggling to make sense of their loss. This video captures an intimate portrait of the lives upended by Tamir’s death.

headline: After Death of Tamir Rice, Pain Lingers
text: Family and friends of Tamir Rice, 12, struggle with their loss five months after a Cleveland police officer fatally shot the boy as he played with a toy gun in a park.

headline: Ted Cruz, the Great Debater … Sort Of
text: A Times article about Ted Cruz on the college debate circuit touched on his preference for prepared cases, where he could examine all angles and prepare for possible attacks.

headline: U.S. and South Korea on Nuclear Accord
text: The American ambassador to South Korea and the chief South Korean negotiator discussed a deal reached between the two countries that included supplying fuel for nuclear power generation.

headline: Former Microsoft Executive Nancy Tellem to Join Interlude Start-Up
text: LOS ANGELES — Nancy Tellem, a longtime entertainment executive recently caught in the crosscurrents of a leadership change at Microsoft, is joining senior management at Interlude, a start-up focused on interactive music videos.

headline: 1965: A Bloody Battle in Vietnam
text: SAIGON — Viet Cong guerrillas, entrenched 30 miles south of the key Da Nang air base, today [April 22] hurled back six battalions of South Vietnamese troops in a bloody battle. A U.S. military spokesman said the government forces retreated and were ‘‘operating in another direction.’’ The Communists are dug in near Viet An, a hilly area 350 miles northeast of Saigon. Only a few weeks ago South Vietnamese troops suffered heavy losses in trying to drive them out. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 23, 1965

headline: Sweet Spring Confections, Courtesy of Chic French Collaborations
text: It isn’t spring in Paris until the city’s leading high-minded pâtisseries and chocolatiers unveil their new, seasonal collections — which, more than ever, involve collaborations with top-shelf names in fashion, beauty and bubbles. Here, some of the season’s best, illustrated for T by Jessie Kanelos Weiner, an American artist in Paris.

headline: In This Corner, a Dominant Heavyweight Who Creates Much Less Buzz
text: The Dempsey-Tunney fight in September 1926 got plenty of attention. A crowd reported at the time as 135,000 fans — including Charlie Chaplin, the cowboy movie star Tom Mix and the English Channel swimmer Gertrude Ederle — packed Sesquicentennial Stadium in Philadelphia for the bout.

headline: James Earl Jones and Cicely Tyson Will Star in ‘Gin Game’ on Broadway
text: She’s 90. He’s 84. Between them they have three Tony Awards and five nominations. But you have to go all the way back to 1966 for the last time Cicely Tyson and James Earl Jones shared a Broadway stage.

headline: Helping Women and Girls. Period. Part Two.
text: Earlier this year, On the Ground posted my article highlighting how lack of ability to afford feminine hygiene products can compromise the health, productivity and dignity of low-income women and girls in the United States. While the challenges of managing menstruation for those living in developing countries has received significant publicity, less attention has been paid to how America’s poor fare.

headline: High School Students, Doing Their Teacher’s Taxes
text: As a teacher in the Portland, Ore., public schools a decade ago, Kary Aloveah set out to give her students lessons in some of the things that she had not learned herself. Her family didn’t have much money when she was growing up, and she didn’t learn much about the topic either.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
text: Tens of thousands of low-wage workers and activists hit the streets last week in an ongoing nationwide campaign for $15 an hour. While opponents of higher wages say a raise would cost jobs, proponents point to a new study by the Berkeley Center for Labor Research and Education that shows low wages cost taxpayers nearly $153 billion a year in government support for the working poor.

headline: Pope Francis Plans to Visit Cuba This Year
text: ROME — Pope Francis will visit Cuba later this year, stopping there on his way to the United States, the Vatican said on Wednesday.

headline: French Official on Foiled Church Attack
text: Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve of France said on Wednesday that over the weekend the police had arrested a 24-year-old student suspected of planning an imminent attack on at least one church.

headline: Opponents of Gay Marriage Ponder Strategy as Issue Reaches Supreme Court
text: EDEN, N.C. — John G. Kallam Jr., 67, carries a worn black Bible and another copy on his iPad, and believes Scripture is unequivocal.

headline: Driven | 2015 Volkswagen Jetta Hybrid
text: For fuel efficiency, Toyota is known for hybrids, while Volkswagen is known for diesel. This 2015 Jetta Hybrid, however, might surprise a few car buyers.

headline: Video Review: The VW Jetta Hybrid Offers Fuel-Efficient Fun
text: WHEN it comes to hybrids, Toyota owns the market with the Prius, but drivers looking for performance find overcooked pasta more appealing. The Prius’s acceleration can be measured with the Mayan calendar. Cabin quality is on par with Rubbermaid bins.

headline: New York Philharmonic’s Challenges Go Beyond the Music
text: The New York Philharmonic, the nation’s oldest symphony orchestra and the former home of Leonard Bernstein and Gustav Mahler, is preparing for its greatest upheaval in decades.

headline: Struggling After a Dramatic Weight Loss
text: At one time, Paul Mason was known as the world’s fattest man. Since losing two thirds of his body weight, he has struggled with the burden of excess skin, and hopes for surgery soon.

headline: Losing 650 Pounds, and Preparing to Shed a Reminder of That Weight
text: ORANGE, Mass. — Once weighing 980 pounds and a contender for the dismaying title of world’s fattest man, Paul Mason lost an astonishing 650 pounds after gastric bypass surgery five years ago. But he was left with a cruel, perpetual reminder of the person he had once been: 100 or so pounds of loose skin that enveloped him like a living shroud.

headline: 36 Hours in Honolulu
text: The name Honolulu can conjure up frenzied activity: exploring the sea with electric scooters, high-altitude extreme parasailing, close encounters with sharks, 40-miles-per-hour motorboat rides that guarantee you’ll get wet. But Honolulu can also mean mellow: the fragrance of a custom-made orchid lei, the taste and texture of a perfect tuna sashimi slice, the elegance of a hula dancer, the deepening of the blues and greens of the sea as the sun sets. Even the steel-mesh netting to prevent falling rocks is partly hidden so as to blend with the landscape. Then there is the pace, the feeling that no one is ever too rushed to give you directions, take your dinner order or explain the history of a 100-year-old banyan tree.

headline: ‘Flash Crash’ Case Suggests Small Problems Can Cause Systemic Issues
text: The flash crash of 2010 resurfaced with an arrest on Tuesday. Prosecutors at the Department of Justice along with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission have accused one self-employed trader in Britain of manipulating futures markets so much that he played a significant role in the events that led to the five-minute, 1,000-point plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average on May 6, 2010.

headline: 36 Hours in Honolulu
text: The fragrance of an orchid lei; the taste of perfect sushi; grand island residences and the blue-green sea: This is Honolulu.

headline: 36 Hours in Honolulu
text: Explore street view, find things to do in Honolulu and sign in to your Google account to save your map.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Knocks Obama Over Trade Deal Transparency
text: Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts criticized the Obama administration for failing to be transparent over the trade deal it is pursuing, arguing that the White House should not “keep the American people in the dark.”

headline: How a Kansas Cooking Club Made Its Way Into The Times
text: Newspaper editors of a certain generation still refer to a certain kind of story as “one that came in over the transom.” That’s because people actually used to slip documents and other tips to reporters that way.

headline: The New Flygirl Blog Focuses on Women and Travel
text: Since 2007, Jezebel, part of the Gawker Media group, has been covering women’s issues, and more, with a tone that’s smart and a touch snarky. Thanks to Jessica Coen, the site’s editor at large (and former editor in chief), it is also now home to Flygirl, a blog-within-a-blog covering travel from a female perspective.

headline: Fact-Checking Can Help You Learn About Politics (True!)
text: Fact-checks of politicians’ statements have become increasingly prominent in media coverage of American politics. With dedicated fact-checkers like PolitiFact and recurring features in newspapers like The New York Times and news agencies like The Associated Press, more journalists are trying to assess the accuracy of claims made by public figures than ever before.

headline: Ebola Drug Works Against West African Strain in Study of Monkeys
text: A study in monkeys offers the first evidence that a leading drug developed to fight Ebola works against the strain causing the current outbreak in West Africa.

headline: A New Exhibition Examines Alexander Calder in Miniature, With an Assist from Santiago Calatrava
text: At a moment when art — and the social and commercial rumpus around it — seems to be getting bigger and bigger, a new Alexander Calder exhibition in Manhattan attests to the power of small details. Opening today at Dominique Lévy in Manhattan, “Alexander Calder: Multum in Parvo” displays more than 40 of the late sculptor’s miniature works, many of which have never before been exhibited. Taking its name from a Latin phrase meaning “much in little,” the show includes standing sculptures and mobiles that span several decades of Calder’s career, ranging from postage-stamp height to 30 inches tall.

headline: Start-Up Blends Old-Fashioned Matchmaking and Algorithms
text: Lauren Kay and Emma Tessler are not stereotypical start-up founders. They’re women, for one, and neither has a technology background. In fact, Ms. Tessler is a college dropout who taught sex education in Newark, then built a teenage pregnancy prevention program in Harlem.

headline: Maxim Gorki Theater Leads an Immigrant Vanguard in Berlin
text: BERLIN — Standing in her office at the Maxim Gorki Theater here, a pack of Gauloises cigarettes in hand, Shermin Langhoff gestured at an image of one of Jeff Koons’s gleaming balloon sculptures hanging on her wall.

headline: Milan Pins Hopes on World Expo After Graft Scandal
text: MILAN — On a recent morning, with the inauguration of Expo Milano 2015, the next world’s fair, less than two weeks away, the dominant soundtrack at the site on the far outskirts of the city was the deep rumble of heavy machinery.

headline: Alex Rodriguez’s Quest Is Going, Going ... Unobserved
text: DETROIT — The Yankees seem to have never met a moment they could not monetize. They scooped up the infield dirt from the game in which Derek Jeter recorded his 3,000th hit  and put it in capsules that dangled from key chains. They offered a bullpen rubber from one of Mariano Rivera’s last games for $15,000. When the old Yankee Stadium closed, it was sold off brick by Monument Park brick.

headline: Italian Leader Urges Action for Migrants
text: Prime Minister Matteo Renzi of Italy addressed the lower house of Parliament on Wednesday in Rome and said the European Union must change its path to tackle the migrant crisis in the Mediterranean.

headline: Kanye West Shakes Up Time 100 Gala
text: Time magazine celebrates its annual list of “The 100 Most Influential People.”

headline: What Bangladeshi Garment Workers Need From the West
text: Despite corporate and government efforts to improve the safety of Bangladesh’s garment factories since the collapse of a building killed more than 1,100 workers two years ago, there is still a lot of work to be done.

headline: Jeremiah Tower Leaves Tavern on the Green
text: Jeremiah Tower, the veteran chef who stepped up last fall to help rescue the faltering Tavern on the Green, has left as executive chef, the owners said Wednesday. In his place, they have hired John Stevenson, who was most recently the chef at Russ & Daughters Cafe, on the Lower East Side.

headline: Drone, Possibly Radioactive, Is Found at Office of Japan’s Prime Minister
text: TOKYO — A small propeller-driven drone possibly tainted with radioactive cesium was discovered Wednesday on the roof of the prime minister’s office, unsettling officials, who said they were reviewing antiterrorism measures in response.

headline: A Sustainable Chef
text: This short documentary explains why one world-class chef overhauled his menu to emphasize sustainable ingredients.

headline: Verbatim: On Not Being Ted Cruz
text: — Ted Niblock, a Johns Hopkins University debater who was recruited as a protest candidate in a 1991 emergency meeting to run against Mr. Cruz, then at Princeton, for the presidency of the American Parliamentary Debate Association. Mr. Niblock won.

headline: Thunderstorm in Eastern India Leaves at Least 40 Dead
text: NEW DELHI — A huge, fast-moving thunderstorm killed at least 40 people in the eastern Indian state of Bihar on Tuesday night, most of them trapped under fallen roofs or struck by falling trees and tree limbs.

headline: Bruce LaBruce on ‘Virginia Woolf’ and Other Influences
text: Over the course of his career, the Canadian filmmaker Bruce LaBruce has made often subversive, sometimes playful and always queer work for the big screen. And he has mined mainstream Hollywood films for inspiration along the way. He’s become known for drawing out the gay subtext in movies from Robert Altman and  Billy Wilder, and bringing it to the forefront in his features “Super 8 1/2 (1994),” “No Skin Off My Ass” (1991) and “Hustler White” (1996). That could mean using the same dialogue, creating scenes that mimicked the originals or  taking footage directly from them.

headline: ‘A Sustainable Chef’
text: When it comes to sustainability, the world of fine dining has never been better. As the chefs behind the most innovative restaurants discover their increasing societal influence, we’re witnessing the rise of a new kind of cook — one devoted to his or her craft, wielding masterly knife skills and a deft palate, as well as a social conscience.

headline: Study of Sundance Filmmakers Finds Men Get Stronger Deals at Festival Than Women Do
text: The Sundance Film Festival, a proving ground for filmmakers, helps the careers of male and female directors at a nearly equal rate, a new study found. But after that, their professional fortunes split along gender lines, with male narrative filmmakers getting stronger distribution deals early on and having an easier time ascending through the Hollywood ranks, according to data and interviews compiled over three years of research.

headline: Senate Approves Stalled Human Trafficking Bill, Clearing Way for Lynch Vote
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Wednesday overwhelmingly approved a stalled bill to fight human trafficking, freeing members to consider the nomination of Loretta E. Lynch to be the next attorney general.

headline: Working With Old Office Files on a New Mac OS
text: Q. I’m running Mac OS 10.6.8 and want to upgrade to the new OS X 10.10 (Yosemite). When installing, I got a warning that Yosemite won’t support Microsoft Office, so I stopped. Is there any way to use Yosemite and still have access to Word and Excel files?

headline: We Need a Role Reversal in the Conversation on Dying
text: In most doctor-patient conversations, the doctor leads the way.

headline: Euronext C.E.O. to Leave in July for French Consulting Firm
text: The stock market operator Euronext said on Wednesday that its chief executive, Dominique Cerutti, will leave in July and take the top job at Altran, a French engineering consultancy.

headline: Deutsche Bank Expects $1.6 Billion in Legal Costs
text: FRANKFURT — Deutsche Bank said on Wednesday that it would incur 1.5 billion euros, or $1.6 billion, in costs from legal proceedings as reports surfaced that the bank was set to accept a record penalty for its involvement in a plan to rig the benchmark rates used to set trillions of dollars in interest rates.

headline: Kanye West, Amy Schumer Shake Up Time 100 Gala
text: Time magazine celebrated its annual list of “The 100 Most Influential People” with a Tuesday night gala that featured a rousing performance by one of its cover subjects, Kanye West.

headline: Germany’s Small Towns Feel the Cost of Europe’s Migrant Crisis
text: VORRA, Germany — Even as European officials struggle with an unrelenting tide of migrants trying to enter the Continent, tranquil villages like this one in a picture-book valley in northern Bavaria are coping with the legions who have already arrived.

headline: Bulls’ Jimmy Butler Knows the Drill: Work Hard, Get Paid
text: CHICAGO — The home locker room at United Center was beginning to clear out late Monday night, but Joakim Noah was waiting around.

headline: At RSA Conference, Computer Security Done Right and Wrong
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The annual RSA security conference here is one of the largest gatherings of computer security professionals and companies in the world. It is also an opportunity for complaining and perhaps just a bit of navel gazing.

headline: Judge Approves Deal in N.F.L. Concussion Suit
text: A federal district court judge on Wednesday gave her final approval to the settlement of a lawsuit brought by more than 5,000 former players who accused the N.F.L. of hiding from them the dangers of concussions, a major step toward ending one of the most contentious legal battles in league history.

headline: Backers Say USB-C Is the Cable of the Future
text: BUYING a shiny new laptop, whether it’s a Mac or Windows PC, often evokes both joy and dread.

headline: Bill Requiring Vaccination of Children Advances in California, but Hurdles Remain
text: LOS ANGELES — A bill that would require nearly all children in California to be vaccinated by eliminating “personal belief” exemptions advanced through the State Legislature on Wednesday, though it still has several hurdles to clear. If approved, California would become one of only three states that require all parents to vaccinate their children as a condition of going to school, unless there is a medical reason not to do so.

headline: A Trove of Pop Art and Other Works Goes to Art Institute of Chicago
text: A Robert Rauschenberg “combine” painting from 1955 that once belonged to his collaborator and lover Jasper Johns is among the 42 artworks that the husband and wife collectors Stefan Edlis and Gael Neeson have donated to the Art Institute of Chicago — a gift valued at nearly $500 million. The gift also features important early paintings by Mr. Johns, including a “Target” image from 1961 and an “Alphabet” painting from 1959; nine paintings by Andy Warhol; four by Gerhard Richter; and six photographs by Richard Prince and six by Cindy Sherman.

headline: Shawn Mendes Is No. 1
text: Two years ago, Shawn Mendes, a high school student in Pickering, Ontario, began covering popular songs on Vine, the mobile app that specializes in six-second videos. As the videos spread online he came to be seen as the next Justin Bieber — a baby-faced crooner with a mastery of social media — and today Mr. Mendes, 16, has taken a big step in that direction with a No. 1 album.

headline: New Christo Work to Temporarily Bridge Italy’s Lake Iseo
text: ROME – One of Italy’s lesser-known lakes (without American movie stars to stalk) is likely to become considerably more famous after the wrap artist Christo has his way with it. For just over two weeks, in June 2016, floating walkways lined with bright yellow fabric will create a walkway around Lake Iseo, in the Lombardy region, joining the mainland to the lake islands. The fabric will continue on pedestrian streets in two mainland towns.

headline: Gazprom Faces Effects of Politics on Its Bottom Line
text: MOSCOW — European antitrust regulators are striking at Gazprom’s core, going after the Russian energy giant’s pricing policies and its politically hued control over natural gas pipelines.

headline: N.F.L. Concussion Settlement Ruling
text: A federal district court judge on Wednesday gave her final approval to the settlement brought by more than 5,000 former players who accused the N.F.L. of hiding from them the dangers of concussions.

headline: Indian Farmer Commits Suicide at Rally Against Narendra Modi’s Land Policies
text: NEW DELHI — The public suicide of a farmer at a political rally on Wednesday appeared to add momentum to the opposition to Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s land policies.

headline: Black Men Rally for Confirmation of Loretta Lynch as Attorney General
text: At least two dozen black men showed up at the Capitol on Wednesday to demand a long-awaited confirmation vote of Loretta E. Lynch as attorney general.

headline: Audi to Test Plan to Deliver Amazon Packages to Drivers’ Trunks
text: FRANKFURT — Almost since the invention of the automobile, people have been using cars for more than just getting from place to place. The car is also a place to eat, to sleep and soon, it appears, to receive packages.

headline: First Draft Focus: Clinton Awards Presented for Advancing Women
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton presented awards for advancing women in peace and security to Staffan de Mistura and Dr. Miriam Coronel-Ferrer.

headline: Google Introduces Wireless Service Called Project Fi
text: Now you can Google a phone call.

headline: Some Los Angeles Theaters Told by Actors’ Union to Pay Minimum Wage
text: The national union representing stage actors has decided to require some small theaters in Los Angeles to pay the minimum wage, despite considerable opposition from supporters of that city’s thriving theater scene.

headline: What’s That on Beyoncé’s Wrist? Let Me Guess ... an Apple Watch
text: Two weeks ago, Pharrell Williams posted an Instagram video of his Apple Watch. The clip has more than 119,000 likes.

headline: Supreme Court Hears Appeal in Raisin Case
text: WASHINGTON — With scorn bordering on anger, some of the Supreme Court’s more conservative members on Wednesday gave a hostile reception to a government program dating to the Great Depression meant to increase raisin prices by keeping some raisins off the market.

headline: Emma Watson’s Perfect 10 Ensemble at Last Night’s Time 100 Gala
text: The Star: Emma Watson

headline: Biking the Great Allegheny Passage
text: The 335-mile-long ride is almost entirely car-free and weaves through terrain that forms a tour of American history.

headline: Biking a Trail of History from Pittsburgh to Washington
text: As we zoomed up the gentle hills of the Interstate between Washington and Pittsburgh, we passed forests, farms and urban sprawl, the kinds of vistas that usually lull you to sleep. But I was wide awake, overcome by a feeling that you usually don’t have at the start of a vacation: fear.

headline: Airmail via Drones Is Vexing for Prisons
text: BISHOPVILLE, S.C. — During the graveyard shift at 1:44 a.m., security cameras at the prison here picked up the blinking lights of an unidentified flying object approaching the facility’s fence.

headline: Pope Francis Weighs the Bishops’ Role in the Sex Abuse Scandal
text: More than 700 Catholic priests had to be dismissed in a three-year period when the United States bishops finally reacted to the Church’s child abuse scandal. But noticeably absent in their accounting was any mention of disciplining themselves — the bishops and other church superiors who systematically covered up the crimes of wayward priests typically rotated on to threaten other parishes. This has remained a scandal postscript, despite the warning eleven years ago from the bishops’ own review panel of laity that “there must be consequences” for ranking prelates who engineered cover-ups.

headline: Intimate Archival Images from 30 Years of the Hyères Fashion Festival
text: For its anniversary, the annual event shares photos that even include a snapshot of the elusive Martin Margiela.

headline: Scott Walker vs. the World
text: On the same day that my colleague Nick Confessore reported that he might be the Koch brothers’ first choice for president, Scott Walker went on Glenn Beck’s radio show and delivered some definitely not-Koch-approved remarks on immigration. Given the reaction, they’re worth quoting in full:

headline: Former Sri Lankan Minister Is Charged With Misuse of Public Funds
text: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — The Sri Lankan police on Wednesday arrested Basil Rajapaksa, the country’s former economic development minister and a brother of former President Mahinda Rajapaksa, on charges of misappropriating thousands of dollars in public funds from a development program for the poor run by his ministry.

headline: ‘True Story,’ ‘The Jinx’ and Serving Up Truth With the Imagination
text: A few months ago, at the height of Oscar season, journalists indulged in what has become an annual orgy of fact checking. Feature films like the best-picture nominees “Selma” and “American Sniper” were subjected to special scrutiny because they were based on true stories. Departures from the record were parsed and debated, then everybody moved on.

headline: Globe Trotters
text: As recent immigrants find their way on New York’s streets, their lives are often hidden to the people walking past.

headline: Working Through the Past
text: In a few weeks it will be 70 years since World War II on the European continent came to an end, yet the complex questions of culpability, victimhood, shame and guilt associated with the enormous crimes of Nazi Germany continue to rise painfully and regularly to the surface.

headline: Star-Studded Book Tour Planned for Judy Blume’s Latest
text: Judy Blume’s hotly anticipated new novel, “In the Unlikely Event,” is becoming quite an event of its own.

headline: Review: John Pizzarelli Sings Love Songs and Sinatra at Café Carlyle
text: The musical equivalent of Viagra: That was John Pizzarelli’s description of “Amoroso,” the Brazilian guitarist and singer João Gilberto’s lush mid-1970s album of bossa nova love songs to which he paid tribute on Tuesday evening at Café Carlyle. Flanked by Daniel Jobim, the grandson of the genre’s pioneer, Antonio Carlos Jobim, he recreated the mood of that album, minus its soaring strings, arranged by Claus Ogerman. Around me, couples were holding hands and fervently gazing into each other’s eyes. Some cynics might relegate “Amoroso” to the category of make-out music, but even within that category it has singularly cosmic dimension.

headline: Home Depot Says It Will Phase Out Chemical Used in Vinyl Flooring
text: Facing pressure from consumer groups, Home Depot said it would discontinue use of a potentially harmful chemical in its vinyl flooring by the end of the year.

headline: The Apple Watch Arrives in Stores (Just Not Its Own)
text: Rumors of the Apple Watch’s unavailability have, it turns out, been slightly, if not greatly, exaggerated.

headline: Rebuilding Lives After a Factory Collapse in Bangladesh
text: Abir Abdullah has been following the mostly young, female survivors of the Rana Plaza factory collapse as they rebuild their lives.

headline: Review: ‘Now en Español’ Uncovers a Slice of Latino Life in Hollywood
text: With the competition growing fierce to find new subjects for a seemingly limitless procession of documentaries, Andrea Meller’s “Now en Español” offers a window onto an offbeat and intriguing scene. Ms. Meller, following five actresses who did Spanish-language dubbing for the ABC series “Desperate Housewives,” reveals a demimonde of mostly immigrant artists, some stars in their home countries, living subsistence-suburban lives around Los Angeles and doing whatever they can to keep a Hollywood dream alive. Within a profession defined by hardship, they struggle even more tenaciously than most.

headline: Iowa Man Found Not Guilty of Sexually Abusing Wife With Alzheimer’s
text: An Iowa jury on Wednesday found Henry Rayhons not guilty of charges that he sexually abused his wife, an Alzheimer’s patient, by having sex with her in a nursing home after staff members told him she was cognitively unable to give consent.

headline: Facebook’s Growth Slows Slightly, but Mobile Shift Intensifies
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook is now so thoroughly a mobile service that its original website may soon become a footnote in the company’s financial statements.

headline: PayPal Unit Helps Lift eBay Revenue
text: EBay is speeding toward a split of its online marketplace and payments businesses. For some analysts and investors, it cannot come soon enough.

headline: Final Grateful Dead Shows to Be Offered via Pay-Per-View
text: Now Deadheads have no excuse for missing the end.

headline: A Challenge From Climate Change Regulations
text: WASHINGTON — As President Obama prepares to unveil his climate change regulations on coal-fired power plants, the nation’s electric utilities are preparing to transform the system that keeps the lights on in America. But some companies fear that in the process, the lights may go out.

headline: Troubling Interdependency of Water and Power
text: In Modesto, Calif., utility records chart an 18 percent rise in farmers’ energy use in 2014 compared with 2013. No evidence shows exactly why this happened, but California’s drought, now in its fourth year, sent many farmers to their wells to pump from hidden aquifers water that normally would be found at ground level.

headline: New Balance of Power
text: HOUSTON — For the better part of the last century, crude oil prices have swung like a pendulum, pushing and pulling the fortunes of nations. More often than not, global supplies of the volatile commodity were controlled by the rulers of desert domains who would otherwise have been powerless had it not been for the oil that bubbled beneath their thrones.

headline: Homes Try to Reach Smart Switch
text: Dustin Bond of Cottonwood Heights, Utah, trimmed his electricity bill last summer by about 40 percent thanks to the sensors and clever software of a digital thermostat.

headline: A Mayor’s Green-Power Moonshot
text: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. — It is no secret that Mayor Bill Finch idolizes President John F. Kennedy. He has converted a room off his office into a shrine filled with campaign buttons, banners and busts of the former president.

headline: Recycling Peanuts and Cracker Jack
text: For years, sports fans have been told to put their glass bottles and aluminum cans in recycling bins at arenas and stadiums.

headline: Liquid Batteries for Solar and Wind Power
text: In an industrial park on the outskirts of Pullman, Wash., 10 white storage trailers sit side by side, neatly arranged in two rows.

headline: Cowboys’ Greg Hardy Suspended for 10 Games
text: The N.F.L. on Wednesday suspended Greg Hardy of the Dallas Cowboys for 10 games for his role in a domestic-violence case, the stiffest penalty handed out under the league’s new and stronger personal-conduct policy.

headline: Storming the Barriers Around China’s Judiciary
text: Eager to get a ruling in a long-running case where she was the plaintiff, the lawyer Cui Hui jammed her foot against a security door in a courthouse near Beijing to stop it from closing and Judge Lai Xiulin from escaping.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Lawyer Says No Need for Private Interview in House Benghazi Inquiry
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s lawyer told Representative Trey Gowdy, chairman of the House committee investigating the 2012 Benghazi attacks, that she saw no need for a private interview over her use of a private email account while secretary of state and asked that he not delay her next appearance before the committee.

headline: Europe Looks Offshore for Wind Power
text: On the outskirts of Groningen, a medieval Dutch town near the German border, a major construction project is underway.

headline: As ‘Mad Men’ Ends, the Woman Behind the Costumes Is Just Getting Started
text: Janie Bryant, the costume designer of “Mad Men,” was standing in a cordoned-off area in the second-floor shoe department of Nordstrom at the Westfield Garden State Plaza mall in Paramus, N.J., on a recent Thursday evening, wearing a red blouse and a pencil skirt and clutching a microphone. “Hello, everybody!” she said over the general din of piped-in Ariana Grande and Cinnabon.

headline: Julian Ungano Brings a Cinematic Eye to Fashion Photography
text: AGE 32

headline: Pictures of the Day: Hong Kong and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Hong Kong, Israel, India and Hungary.

headline: Jonathan Groff’s Life Imitates His Art
text: Decorating is not really Jonathan Groff’s thing. In the spartan living room of the actor’s one-bedroom apartment in Chelsea is a sofa from Room & Board, and the only reason he bought it there is because he loves “The Comeback,” the HBO show in which Lisa Kudrow plays a desperate actress named Valerie Cherish, who lands a role on a sitcom called “Room and Bored.”

headline: April 22, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Hong Kong, Israel, India and Hungary.

headline: Research Suggests Pesticide Is Alluring and Harmful to Bees
text: Research by European scientists raised fresh questions on Wednesday about the impact on bees of neonicotinoids, a ubiquitous and controversial class of pesticides whose future use was restricted this month by the Environmental Protection Agency.

headline: Lilly Pulitzer for Target: They Came, They Waited, They Went Home Mad
text: Never underestimate the hunger of a barely thawed populace for a warm breeze of Palm Beach.

headline: Alex Garland of ‘Ex Machina’ Talks About Artificial Intelligence
text: In the last few years, I’ve become increasingly fascinated by artificial intelligence, and in particular our escalating fear of it. It seemed to me that our increasingly holistic relationship with technology and abstract clouds of information was compounding this fear and perhaps edging it into paranoia.

headline: Striking Archival Images from 30 Years of the Hyères Fashion Festival
text: Jean-Pierre Blanc dreamed up the Festival International de Mode in 1986, as part of a school project and case study for his business degree. He was 20 years old, and he wanted, he says, to “invent a moment for creative encounters that wasn’t too complicated.” He ended up getting backing from his native city of Hyères, a French hillside town flanking the Mediterranean; and over several decades, the festival went from being an endeavor powered by 50,000 francs to a nearly million-euro affair. Today, the festival, which has expanded to include photography in addition to fashion, is celebrating its 30th year — “more than half of my life,” Blanc notes — and it “still drums up enthusiasm.” And having Chanel on the roster — Karl Lagerfeld is this year’s artistic director, and two of his colleagues at the inimitable fashion house will oversee fashion and photography — “puts the festival in another orbit,” Blanc says.

headline: Catching Waves and Turning Them Into Electricity
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Off the coast of Western Australia, three big buoys floating beneath the ocean’s surface look like giant jellyfish tethered to the seafloor. The steel machines, 36 feet wide, are buffeted by the powerful waves of the Indian Ocean. By harnessing the constant motion of the waves, the buoys generate about 5 percent of the electricity used at a nearby military base on Garden Island.

headline: Oil Makes a Comeback in Pennsylvania
text: It wasn’t quite a Jed Clampett moment: Instead of shootin’ for some food, Samuel Kier was drillin’ for some salt in his salt wells in the appropriately named Saltsburg in Indiana County, Pa., close to Pittsburgh.

headline: Balancing Costs and Competition
text: Renewable energy was never a bargain compared with fossil fuels like natural gas and coal. Steep price declines in those commodities, especially lately, make it even tougher for alternatives like solar, wind and hydroelectric power to compete.

headline: Families Ditch Cars for Cargo Bikes
text: When Dave Hoverman, 38, a business strategy consultant in Berkeley, Calif., goes to Costco on the weekends, he ditches his Audi Q7 and instead loads his four children into a Cetma cargo bike with a trailer hitched to the rear.

headline: The Kooples Is for Couples (Usually European)
text: The world is awash in basics. A shopper can find silk shirts, cigarette pants, cashmere sweaters and pencil skirts for a range of prices starting at $12.90 (for a little black dress at Forever 21) to $3,495 (for a little black dress by Rosie Assoulin). Stocking up on wardrobe basics is no longer a problem of availability, but one of selection.

headline: Box Opens Tools for Developers, Suggesting the Future of Business Software
text: Box announced changes on Wednesday that it hopes will take it into a new phase of growth, and potentially dominance of a critical part of the new way businesses use computers.

headline: ‘Sultans of Deccan India’
text: A look at a new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Review: Tim Berne’s Snakeoil at the Jazz Standard
text: There’s a coolheaded but decisive tension between moment-to-moment details and the arc of a larger design in the recent music by the alto saxophonist Tim Berne. That conceptual push and pull has been a hallmark of his working band, Snakeoil, since its auspicious debut album several years ago. Still, it probably hasn’t had a more potent distillation than “Embraceable Me,” the composition that closed the band’s first set at the Jazz Standard on Tuesday night.

headline: How to Get a Fresh Face for the New Season
text: Forget beauty balms. Blur products, which impart velvety finishes that diffuse the look of pores and imperfections, are the season’s new obsession.

headline: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York
text: On Thursday from 6 to 8 p.m., Viktor & Rolf will celebrate the first birthday of its haute confectionary scent, Bonbon, at Saks Fifth Avenue. With any two-piece purchase from the fragrance collection, including the new satin body powder ($80) and limited-edition eau de parfum shimmer bottle ($120), customers will receive a free sketch from the illustrator Brooke Hagel, inspired by runway looks from the fashion house.

headline: A Deal From the Trials for the Venice Cup
text: The trial to select the two United States women’s teams for this year’s Venice Cup world championship took place last week in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The 120-board second final was between Connie Goldberg, JoAnn Sprung, Linda Lewis and Disa Eythorsdottir, and Sylvia Moss, Joann Glasson, Lynn Deas, Beth Palmer, Janice Seamon-Molson and Tobi Sokolow.

headline: Review: ‘Orson Welles’s Last Movie,’ by Josh Karp
text: Orson Welles stayed away from Hollywood in the 1960s, having a laundry list of reasons to feel like a pariah. But when he returned in 1970, he found a film business newly receptive to rogue talent. It didn’t get more roguish than a 350-pound former boy genius seeking to make a barely describable film-within-a-film about a great man who has lost his creative powers.

headline: ‘The Heidi Chronicles’ Is Trailed by Questions of Feminism and Legacy
text: Twenty-five years after “The Heidi Chronicles” closed on Broadway, believers in the work of Wendy Wasserstein seized an opening. In the era of “Lean In” and “Girls,” and a paucity of female voices on Broadway, they would revive Ms. Wasserstein’s most acclaimed play, “The Heidi Chronicles,” with a beloved television star, Elisabeth Moss, in the title role.

headline: Review: ‘The Unexpected Guest,’ From Agatha Christie, Dispenses With a Bully
text: The actors weren’t even onstage yet when a man behind me tried to guess the culprit in Agatha Christie’s “The Unexpected Guest.” Clues were scarce, but he deduced what he could from the set: a wainscoted room with French windows, a cane-back wheelchair parked in front of them.

headline: Gregory Pardlo, Pulitzer Winner for Poetry, on His Sudden Fame
text: On an unabashedly glorious afternoon this week, the poet and essayist Phillip Lopate stood in front of a small group of graduate students in Columbia University’s creative writing program. He took attendance, noting a few absences, before turning to a discussion about the German filmmaker Harun Farocki.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: ‘America’s Ballroom Challenge,’ a Dance Series on PBS
text: Dance forms evolve. Because of the phenomenal popularity that ballroom-based competitions have achieved on television, there are many thousands of people out there — including members of my family and close friends — who feel they have a good grasp of the rudiments of the rumba and the Viennese waltz, without themselves having danced much or any of them. But because I watch little television and because I briefly studied ballroom, my first reaction to what I occasionally see being done on screen (and, even more rarely, onstage) to the fox trot, the rumba and other styles tends to be one of reactionary horror.

headline: Susie Cave’s Seaside Short List for Shopping, Antiquing and Feasting Around Brighton
text: “Ever since I was a child, I’ve been designing entire collections of dresses in my head. Now seems like the right time to create them,” says Susie Cave (formerly Susie Bick, before she married the musician Nick Cave), the darkly drawn English beauty who modeled for Steven Meisel, Helmut Newton and Sarah Moon during the ’80s and ’90s. This spring, Cave brings her fashion fantasies to life with a sample collection of skirts and dresses that she calls “casually opulent,” in rich hues inspired by trips to the Russian ballet. “Sergei Diaghilev used unusual color combinations to evoke certain emotional responses. That’s what set me off on the color trail,” she explains of The Vampire’s Wife line, which takes its gothic moniker from an unwritten novel by her husband. “I’m so happy he let me have that name,” says Cave, who hopes to launch a complete spring/summer 2016 collection in the fall. “I love that it sounds quite serious and dark, and yet the collection is bursting with color.”

headline: Tsarnaev Seen Making Obscene Gesture
text: In surveillance video captured from his holding cell, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the man at the center of the Boston Marathon bombing trial, is seen making a hand gesture to the camera.

headline: After Jury Sees Gesture by Boston Marathon Bomber, Defense Tries to Blunt Its Meaning
text: BOSTON — The defense team for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev on Wednesday tried to blunt the shock value of an incendiary photo that the prosecution showed the jury of him thrusting his middle finger at a security camera three months after the bombing.

headline: Obama Talks of Climate Change in Florida
text: President Obama spent Earth Day in Everglades National Park, where he spoke about the threat of climate change in Florida.

headline: Pitorro, Anyone? Craft Distilleries and Breweries Take Hold in South Bronx
text: On family trips to Puerto Rico, Rafael Barbosa got a taste for his uncle’s pitorro: a potent concoction made from sugar cane in a crude backyard still.

headline: Their Future’s So Bright …
text: This is the tale of a bipartisan fist bump between senators in shades.

headline: Promising Full College Credit, Arizona State University Offers Online Freshman Program
text: Arizona State University, one of the nation’s largest universities, is joining with edX, a nonprofit online venture founded by M.I.T. and Harvard, to offer an online freshman year that will be available worldwide with no admissions process and full university credit.

headline: Funding Circle Raises Another $150 Million
text: LONDON — Funding Circle, the British peer-to-peer lender, announced on Wednesday that it had raised $150 million in financing that valued the company at roughly $1 billion.

headline: Appeals Court Overturns Barry Bonds’s Only Conviction
text: After years of investigations and court proceedings in the performance-enhancing drug case involving Barry Bonds, baseball’s home run king, federal prosecutors were able to pin only one obstruction of justice conviction on him.

headline: Grief Mixes With Anger Over Christian Ethiopian Deaths
text: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — In a downtrodden neighborhood called Cherkos, not far from the headquarters of the African Union, an olive-green tent stands as a tangible symbol of this nation’s grief.

headline: Ship’s Captains Call for Uniform Policies on Migrants at Sea
text: LONDON — As a growing number of migrants and refugees travel to Europe by land, air or, most tragically recently, by sea, southern countries of the European Union like Greece and Italy face the largest burdens, and Bulgaria, a newer member, has rebuilt walls to keep out illegal migrants.

headline: Trader’s Arrest in ‘Flash Crash’ Raises Concerns About Market Rigging
text: The arrest of a little-known futures trader this week drew back the curtain on one of the pernicious-sounding practices that have been linked to the distortion of global financial markets.

headline: White House Seeks to Publicly Mend Fences With Netanyahu, but Issues Remain
text: WASHINGTON — As President Obama sat with Jewish leaders at the White House last week, trying to reassure them of his deep commitment to Israel, some wanted to know whether he would soon invite Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu for an in-person visit.

headline: Turning Over a New Leaf, New York Assembly Pushes Paper Out and Adopts Tablets
text: ALBANY — Charging headfirst into the modern world — sort of — the New York State Legislature went partly digital on Wednesday, as the Assembly established itself as “an electronic chamber,” complete with tablet computers, touch screens and exceptionally limited web-surfing options.

headline: Boeing Droops as Dreamliner Jet Fails to Deliver
text: Boeing’s stock fell by 1.4 percent on Wednesday after the company reported that it had generated less cash in the first quarter than most analysts had expected.

headline: A.I.G. Bailout Lawsuit Trial Ends as It Began, With Most Issues in Dispute
text: WASHINGTON — The unusual trial of Maurice R. Greenberg’s $40 billion lawsuit against the government ended on Wednesday in much the same way it started, with both sides presenting starkly different narratives about the 2008 taxpayer bailout of the American International Group.

headline: New York City’s Environmental Goals Draw Praise, and Questions on How to Fulfill Them
text: As Mayor Bill de Blasio on Wednesday released a long-term blueprint for the city — calling on New Yorkers to send no waste to landfills by 2030, and aiming to lift 800,000 people from poverty or near-poverty in a decade, among other far-reaching goals — attention turned quickly to a follow-up question.

headline: Disney Joins in Criticism of Verizon’s Cable Plan
text: The dispute between Verizon and some of the most popular and prominent TV networks escalated on Wednesday when Disney said that the new, slimmer FiOS cable offering violated agreements with all of its cable networks.

headline: Richard C. Holbrooke’s Diary of Disagreement With Obama Administration
text: WASHINGTON — In the summer of 2010, Richard C. Holbrooke, the Obama administration’s special representative for Afghanistan and Pakistan, began recording a secret audio diary, detailing his frustrations with a White House that he believed was too willing to listen to the military and too often mistook domestic political calculations for strategic thinking.

headline: As War Grinds On, Yemenis Share Their Anguish Online
text: As a Saudi-led coalition continued to launch airstrikes against Houthi rebels in Yemen, one day after the operation’s name was changed from Decisive Storm to Renewal of Hope, online dispatches from Yemeni bloggers and activists were filled with anguish over the growing toll of the conflict.

headline: Guardrail Maker Is Said to Be Focus of U.S. Case
text: The Justice Department has begun a criminal investigation of the guardrail maker Trinity Industries and is examining the company’s relationship with the Federal Highway Administration, according to people with knowledge of the effort.

headline: Opening Salvos in a Condiment War, and the Hot Dog Is the Battlefield
text: Like the Gingham Dog and Calico Cat, Heinz ketchup and French’s mustard have side by side in the condiments aisle sat for more than a century.

headline: Comcast Critics Cast Doubt on Its Intentions
text: CHICAGO — David L. Cohen stood between the rappers Ludacris and Chance on stage in the gymnasium of Alcott College Prep high school here one afternoon last month, holding up one of the dozen laptops they were giving away to the roaring crowd. The scene was like a pep rally for the Internet: Students waved posters emblazoned with Comcast’s logo and the hashtag #InternetEssentials.

headline: Few People Lost Jobs With V.A. in Scandal
text: The nationwide scandal last spring over manipulated wait times at Department of Veterans Affairs hospitals led to the ouster of the secretary of veterans affairs and vows from the new leadership that people would be held accountable.

headline: M.H. Abrams, 102, Dies; Shaped Romantic Criticism and Literary ‘Bible’
text: M. H. Abrams, who transformed the study of Romanticism with the critical histories “The Mirror and the Lamp” and “Natural Supernaturalism,” and who edited the first seven editions of “The Norton Anthology of English Literature,” a virtual Bible in literature survey courses, died on Tuesday in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 102.

headline: Putin Bolsters His Forces Near Ukraine, U.S. Says
text: WASHINGTON — In a sign that the tense crisis in Ukraine could soon escalate, Russia has continued to deploy air defense systems in eastern Ukraine and has built up its forces near the border, American officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Video Feature: Apps to Kindle the Imagination
text: Nearly everything in our daily lives is driven by rules, habits and social norms, which can stymie creative habits at work or elsewhere. Don’t panic: There are apps to help ignite that spark.

headline: App Smart | Spark Creative Thinking

headline: Swimmer Braves Brooklyn’s Gowanus Canal, a Superfund Site
text: Like most people who have heard anything about the Gowanus Canal — of its murky sludge, oil slicks, raw sewage, carcinogenic chemicals and dying dolphins — Christopher Swain strongly advises against swimming in it.

headline: Betty Willis, Whose ‘Fabulous’ Sign Defined Las Vegas, Dies at 91
text: Betty Willis, a commercial artist whose 25-foot-high neon sign blazingly and irrevocably linked Las Vegas with fabulousness, died on Sunday at her home in Overton, Nev. She was 91.

headline: Cameras on Calbuco: In Chile, Volcano’s Eruption Caught in Extraordinary Time-Lapse Videos
text: The endless, but spasmodic, dynamism of Earth’s crust produced extraordinary scenes in Chile, and across the Web, this week as the Calbuco volcano, quiescent for 42 years, powerfully erupted.

headline: Review: ‘Something Rotten!,’ an Over-the-Top Take on Shakespeare
text: Unchecked enthusiasm is not always an asset in musical comedy, despite the genre’s reputation for wholesale peppiness. “Something Rotten!,” the rambunctious new show that opened on Wednesday night at the St. James Theater, dances dangerously on the line between tireless and tedious, and winds up collapsing into the second camp.

headline: More Than a Joke

headline: Sony Pictures Announces Plan for Animated Spider-Man Movie

headline: Jury Reviews the Testimony of Etan Patz’s Childhood Friend

headline: Nets Can’t Sink Shot to Stay Out of Hole

headline: Mets Rally Past Braves to Extend Their Streak to 10 Games
text: When Curtis Granderson drew a walk to lead off the eighth inning at Citi Field on Wednesday, the reaction from his teammates demonstrated the confidence that this team, the one with the best record in baseball, is starting to exude.

headline: Season 3 Finale of ‘The Americans’: More Secrets, Lies and Torture
text: The jig is not up, not yet. But the third season of FX’s “The Americans” ended on Wednesday night with the disclosure that the series’ superspies, Philip (Matthew Rhys) and Elizabeth (Keri Russell), have been dreading — and dodging — since the very first episode.

headline: Review: British and American Ballets Showcase Youthful Blend of Style and Skill

headline: Once Again, Rangers Edge the Penguins

Given another opportunity, Hayes came through — sending the Rangers to the brink of the Eastern Conference semifinals.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Revives Plan for a Utica Avenue Subway Line

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
text: 1:30 A.M. (Flix) THE MAGDALENE SISTERS (2002) Four Roman Catholic Irish teenagers (Anne-Marie Duff; Dorothy Duffy; Nora-Jane Noone; and Eileen Walsh) are sentenced in the late 1960s to toil in convent laundries run by the Sisters of the Magdalene as punishment for sexual misconduct in this semifictional story. (The existence of these religious labor camps, which 30,000 women are thought to have endured, came to light in the ’70s with the discovery of the unmarked graves of some who lived there; the last laundry was closed in 1996.) Geraldine McEwan plays Sister Bridget, the twisted head nun — with a soft spot for “The Bells of St. Mary’s” and John F. Kennedy — who turns into a demon if her rules are flouted. “ ‘The Magdalene Sisters’ would be too painful to watch if it didn’t have a silver lining,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about this drama, which was written and directed by Peter Mullan and won the top prize at the Venice Film Festival. “Suffice it to say that it is possible to fly over this religious cuckoo’s nest and remain free. All it takes is courage and the timely kindness of strangers.”

More than a thousand people had died and hundreds more were trapped alive in the rubble. Injured workers were screaming and crying all around him as rescue workers pulled bodies from the debris.

headline: The Perils of Smokeless Tobacco
text: The makers of smokeless tobacco products like to claim that their products are safer than cigarettes because users don’t inhale the tars and toxic chemicals from burning tobacco. Of course, they play down other harms and risks, which are also potentially dangerous. For federal regulators, protecting public health will require looking beyond the smoke to other hazards.

headline: China’s Big Plunge in Pakistan
text: President Xi Jinping of China showed up in Pakistan this week with one of his government’s most powerful weapons — money, and lots of it. He signed agreements worth more than $28 billion as part of a total promised investment of some $46 billion in a new “Silk Road,” an ambitious land-and-sea-based economic corridor connecting China to Europe and the Middle East through Pakistan, Central Asia and Russia.

headline: Bobby Jindal: I’m Holding Firm Against Gay Marriage

headline: Eat Up. You’ll Be Happier.
text: PARIS — MY father-in-law, an anthropologist, likes to talk about the time he ate dog penis. He was visiting a remote town in South Korea, and the mayor invited him to lunch. Once they’d finished the dog soup (not a big deal), a waitress carried out the boiled penis on a silver plate. The mayor cut it lengthwise with scissors, then served half to each of them.
