text: To the Editor:

headline: Brian Williams Inquiry Is Said to Expand
text: An NBC News internal investigation into Brian Williams has examined a half-dozen instances in which he is thought to have fabricated, misrepresented or embellished his accounts, two people with inside knowledge of the investigation said.

headline: American Naval Force Off Yemen Gets Credit After Iranian Convoy Turns Away
text: WASHINGTON — Pentagon officials on Friday credited the deployment of an American aircraft carrier group in waters off the coast of Yemen for a decision by Iran to turn back a naval convoy suspected of carrying weapons bound for Shiite rebels.

headline: Grass That Never Needs Watering
text: In California, interest in artificial turf for residential yards surged after Gov. Jerry Brown imposed statewide water restrictions this month.

headline: Some Bright Green Lawns in California Require No Water
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Sitting in the sun on a patch of green grass behind his home, Paul O’Valle does not feel bad about having an urban oasis despite the state’s drought.

headline: Robert Patterson Jr., Lawyer and Judge Who Fought for the Accused, Dies at 91
text: Robert P. Patterson Jr., a former federal judge who championed legal rights for the accused and the convicted and fought to hold guards and state troopers accountable for the casualties among inmates after the Attica prison rebellion in 1971, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 91.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

text: To the Editor:

headline: For a Migrant Airlift to U.S.
Councilman Wants New York City’s Pools and Beaches Open Past Labor Day
text: The highest temperature recorded in New York City last year was on the day after Labor Day. The mercury climbed to 92 degrees, and New Yorkers turned on their fans, cranked up their air-conditioners and chased ice cream trucks.

headline: Parents’ Role in the New York Test Protest
text: To the Editor:

headline: Clinton Charities Review Tax Returns Amid Scrutiny of Foreign Grants
text: The Clinton family’s namesake foundation and signature health initiative are reviewing several years of tax returns after questions were raised about the charities’ reporting of tens of millions of dollars in grants from foreign governments, foundation officials said Friday.

headline: Training of Deputy in Tulsa Was Faulted in a Report
text: In an internal investigation six years ago into the volunteer reserve deputy who shot an unarmed man this month, sheriff’s officers in Tulsa County, Okla., said that he did not have the training or skills required for his post, but that commanders told them to ignore such concerns.

headline: To Lure Back Young Shoppers, Abercrombie Puts On a Shirt
text: Smooth, shirtless torsos have long greeted shoppers at Abercrombie & Fitch — in its ads, and sometimes in the flesh.

headline: New York’s Subway Madness
text: Anyone who has squeezed into a subway car recently in New York City knows in a very up-close and uncomfortable way that the city’s mass transit system is overloaded. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority confirmed this week that ridership has indeed soared. The system handled 1.75 billion rides last year — a number not seen since the late 1940s, when many fewer people drove. That compares with just over a billion rides in 1980 and 1.3 billion in 2000.

headline: Bill Clinton Ends Role With Chain of For-Profit Colleges
text: Bill Clinton ended his role with a for-profit college system on Friday, nearly two weeks after his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, began her second presidential campaign and singled out that industry for criticism.

headline: Gunmen Kill Arts Advocate in Pakistan After Human Rights Event
text: KARACHI, Pakistan — Gunmen killed the director of a popular arts center in Pakistan’s largest city on Friday, shortly after she had hosted a contentious event on human rights abuses in western Baluchistan Province.

headline: Should a Court Approve All Drone Strikes?
text: Would civilian casualties be reduced if judges reviewed proposed drone attacks before they were launched?

headline: Comcast Withdraws Purchase Bid, but It Isn’t Going Anywhere
text: As a boy, Brian L. Roberts watched his father, Ralph, build Comcast into a cable empire.

headline: Big Mistake When Posing as an Officer: Pulling Up Behind the Real Thing
text: A driver waited at a red light on Bath Avenue and 21st Avenue in Bath Beach, Brooklyn, last Friday morning. He heard the familiar sound of a short blast from a police siren behind him — “whoop-whoop” — and realized the traffic light had turned green.

headline: Intense Lobbying Failed to Assure Comcast’s Deal
text: WASHINGTON — David L. Cohen, the master salesman who runs the Comcast Corporation’s lobbying efforts, stood before a room full of Latino House lawmakers one morning in early December trying to convince them that they should embrace his $45 billion deal to acquire Time Warner Cable.

headline: 15 Bison Escape From New York Farm, Cross Thruway, and Are Shot
text: ALBANY — It was, in hindsight, an ill-fated escape, a seemingly aimless ramble that took a small herd of runaway bison from a farm to a river, through lawns and lots, and onto the New York State Thruway.

headline: Minor League Hockey Goes West
text: With the formation of the American Hockey League’s Pacific Division, three Northeast teams are pulling out for California.

headline: Mary Keefe, Model for Rockwell’s ‘Rosie the Riveter,’ Dies at 92
text: Mary Keefe, a 19-year-old Vermont telephone operator whom her neighbor Norman Rockwell immortalized as his model for the heroine of “Rosie the Riveter,” the World War II feminist anthem that empowered women to leave home and pinch-hit in military plants, died on Tuesday at her home in Simsbury, Conn. She was 92.

headline: What’s So Great About Young Writers?
text: PHILADELPHIA — MY Facebook feed clogged this week with news that Meryl Streep was funding a screenwriting “lab” for women 40 and older. I am not a screenwriter, but as the author of two books of fiction, published when I was 48 and 52, I couldn’t help but cheer.

headline: Amid Errors, Obama Publicly Wrestles With Drones’ Limits
text: WASHINGTON — He looked down at his text, but seemed to drift away from it. He had planned to say something about the drone strike that killed two hostages by mistake, about how the tragedy would be reviewed.

headline: Activists Say Both North Korea and South Korea Approve Women’s Peace Walk
text: Organizers of a women’s international peace walk across the Korean Peninsula’s heavily mined Demilitarized Zone next month said Friday that the governments of both North and South Korea had given their conditional approval for the event, which is meant to create new pressure for a formal end to the Korean War. But the organizers acknowledged that they did not yet have the final written confirmations or visa approvals.

headline: Richard Corliss, 71, Longtime Film Critic for Time, Dies
text: Richard Corliss, whose well-informed and spirited movie reviews appeared in Time magazine for 35 years, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 71.

headline: A Better Way to Rein In Lobbying
text: WASHINGTON — CORPORATE influence is an old problem in American democracy. But in the last decade or so, corporate spending to influence Congress and federal agencies has reached a new, and probably unsustainable, level.

headline: Outpouring of Grief and Anger as Pakistani Activist Is Gunned Down
text: A leading proponent of civil society in Pakistan was shot and killed in the port city of Karachi on Friday night, officials said, shortly after hosting a discussion with dissidents from Baluchistan, the country’s largest province, at the cultural center she founded.

headline: Fans Suffer as Hockey Teams Leave Their Hotbeds for Warmer Climes
text: WORCESTER, Mass. — Before one of the Worcester Sharks’ final home games this season, fans gathered for a party at a popular pregame hangout near DCU Center, the team’s home rink for the past nine years.

headline: Baltimore’s ‘Broken Relationship’ With Police
text: BALTIMORE — For nearly two years, ever since her brother Tyrone West died after a struggle with the police, a 35-year-old preschool teacher named Tawanda Jones has been in the streets here on Wednesday nights, protesting. Her message: “We need killer cops in cellblocks.”

headline: Bruce Jenner Says He’s Transitioning to a Woman
text: Bruce Jenner, the Olympic gold medalist and member of the Kardashian family, ended months of speculation Friday night when he announced during an ABC television special that he identified as a woman and was making the transition from male to female.

headline: Will the Vietnam War Ever Go Away?
text: It’s not much fun returning to Vietnam.

headline: System Crash for Starbucks Leads to Free Coffee for Some
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The in-store payment systems at Starbucks went down Friday at 8,000 company-operated stores in the United States and Canada, leading to an unexpected giveaway of coffee drinks at some stores.

headline: With Bernie Williams’s Retirement, a Storied Yankees Era Ends
text: It was a long, overdue formality that became a feel-good photo opportunity. But with a dotting of the i’s in Bernie Williams and the crossing of the t’s in a nearly decade-old retirement, a beloved era of iconic Yankees was officially laid to rest.

headline: A Big Machine Gets to Work
text: The I Lift New York Super Crane, painted red, white and blue, was brought in to help build the replacement Tappan Zee Bridge. On Friday, it made its inaugural lift: a pile cap.

headline: Presidential Primary Book Club
text: Concerned citizens bear many great burdens, one of which is trying to follow a presidential race in which virtually every candidate has written one or more books about their lives, hopes, dreams, theories — and, in the case of Mike Huckabee, diets.

headline: Books and Board Games
text: SATURDAY’S POST — This puzzle has got all the trappings for a quiet Saturday night in. Books and board games, anyone?

headline: On the Export-Import Bank, the Numbers Come First
text: In June, for the third time since 2012, the Export-Import Bank of the United States, an export credit agency that backs loans to foreign entities that help cement deals with American exporters — and thus helps create American jobs — must be reauthorized by Congress. Otherwise it will go out of business.

headline: A Contest in the Bronx Helps Young Scientists Explore
text: Lawrence Abu-Hammour always knew he wanted to do scientific research, but he did not get into the Bronx High School of Science or any of New York City’s other elite schools with robust science programs and activities.

headline: Cuomo Says He Wants M.T.A. Chairman to Stay On
text: The announcement came as a surprise on Friday to Thomas F. Prendergast, the leader of the New York City region’s vast transit system: You can keep your job.

headline: Jets Want Quantity From Draft, but Also a Potentially Costly Prospect in Marcus Mariota
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Mike Maccagnan graduated from Trinity College expecting to become not a football scout but a financial analyst. He applied for positions on Wall Street but then chose to pursue a career working in the N.F.L., where he has still managed to put his degree in economics to good use.

headline: Government Releases Once-Secret Report on Post-9/11 Surveillance
text: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by The New York Times, the government has declassified a 2009 report by five agencies’ inspectors general about the Stellarwind program, the group of N.S.A. warrantless wiretapping and bulk phone and e-mail records collection activities initiated by President George W. Bush after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Islanders Aim to Avoid Last Hurrah at Home
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Facing playoff elimination against the Washington Capitals on Saturday, the Islanders are hoping their crowd can lift them one more time.

headline: Rangers Oust Penguins by a Familiar Margin
text: The Rangers and the Pittsburgh Penguins were destined to play a one-goal game Friday night at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Declassified Report Shows Doubts About Value of N.S.A.’s Warrantless Spying
text: WASHINGTON — The secrecy surrounding the National Security Agency’s post-9/11 warrantless surveillance and bulk data collection program hampered its effectiveness, and many members of the intelligence community later struggled to identify any specific terrorist attacks it thwarted, a newly declassified document shows.

headline: Mets’ Ride Ends at Yankees’ House
text: Jacob deGrom, the Mets’ promising young starter, turned, looked, then craned his neck higher, as if he were trying to spot a bird. He had floated a belt-high fastball over the plate, and Mark Teixeira had crushed it into the early evening sky down the right-field line at Yankee Stadium.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (Showtime) BOYHOOD (2014) Starting in 2002, Richard Linklater began to film four characters — a boy (Ellar Coltrane), then 6; his sister (Lorelei Linklater, Mr. Linklater’s daughter); and their parents (the Oscar-winning Patricia Arquette and Ethan Hawke, in a nominated role) — over 12 consecutive years, composing the script as the movie progressed. “What emerged from those dozen years is a series of meticulously textured and structured scenes set to the rhythm of life,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Siblings argue. A mother struggles with men, paying the bills and earning several college degrees. An estranged father roars into his children’s lives in a 1968 GTO. “The story in ‘Boyhood’ is blissfully simple: A child grows up,” Ms. Dargis added about this film, which also earned Oscar nominations for best picture, directing, original screenplay and editing. “This, along with the modesty of its physical production — its humble rooms, quiet moments, ordinary lives — can obscure Mr. Linklater’s ambitions and the greatness of his achievement.” But in his masterpiece, she said, “he both captures moments in time and relinquishes them as he moves from year to year. He isn’t fighting time but embracing it in all its glorious and agonizingly fleeting beauty.”

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “I am always hungry.”

headline: 时尚交汇处 — 日本东京原宿
text: 尤利娅小姐，一位染着蓝色头发的时装设计师和时尚偶像，说她深受东京原宿地区时髦而又多彩的风格的启发。

headline: Mapping the Clashes Between Baltimore Police and Protesters
text: Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland declared a state of emergency and activated the National Guard when riots broke out after the funeral of Freddie Gray.

headline: 廉价的机器人，更少的工人
text: 中国面临人力成本上涨和工人短缺问题。但一项名为“机器换人”的政府项目正在改变广东省的劳动力模式。

headline: Earthquake Devastates Nepal, Killing More Than 1,900
text: NEW DELHI — A powerful earthquake shook Nepal on Saturday near its capital, Katmandu, killing more than 1,900 people, flattening sections of the city’s historic center, and trapping dozens of sightseers in a 200-foot watchtower that came crashing down into a pile of bricks.

headline: Lawsuit Over Banned Memoir Asks China to Explain Censorship
text: BEIJING — When Li Nanyang flew here from Hong Kong two years ago, she brought something eagerly anticipated by many Chinese historians and thinkers: several dozen copies of her father’s memoir. In it, Li Rui, a 98-year-old retired Communist Party official, offered an unvarnished, insider’s account of his experiences in the leadership.

headline: Earthquake Strikes Near Nepal’s Capital
text: People described scenes of panic and collapsed buildings after the quake, with an estimated magnitude of 7.8, struck on Saturday.

headline: The Week on Instagram
text: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took viewers from a one-woman show in Manhattan to the skies over Poland.

headline: Wingnut Welfare and Work Incentives
text: Wingnut welfare is an important, underrated feature of the modern U.S. political scene. I don’t know who came up with the term, but anyone who follows right-wing careers knows whereof I speak: the lavishly-funded ecosystem of billionaire-financed think tanks, media outlets, and so on provides a comfortable cushion for politicians and pundits who tell such people what they want to hear. Lose an election, make economic forecasts that turn out laughably wrong, whatever — no matter, there’s always a fallback job available.

headline: A Horse With the Right Name to Tie the Kentucky Derby to a Prizefight
text: After his final major workout ahead of next Saturday’s Kentucky Derby, the colt Itsaknockout retreated to Barn 40 on Friday for a bath. He was swaddled in a black blanket with the words “Mayweather,” in orange, and “Pacquiao,” in yellow, printed on the side.

headline: Long-Predicted Death Toll in Nepal Earthquake Reflects Wider Himalayan Seismic Risk
text: The Himalayas are one of the world’s most worrisome hot zones for earthquake risk, which is a function of tectonic activity, human population size and the quality (or lack thereof) of construction.

headline: Firsthand Accounts of Nepal Earthquake
text: As a devastating earthquake hit about 50 miles from Katmandu, killing hundreds, residents took to social media to share information on the destruction and injured, post photographs of collapsed buildings and let their friends and family know they were safe.

headline: 1915: Armenian Genocide in Turkey
text: The roots of the Armenian genocide lie in the collapse of the Ottoman Empire, and date as far back as the Armenian uprising of 1895. By the beginning of 1915, the empire was fully embroiled in World War I, facing direct attacks by the Allies on the Dardanelles and a threat from the Russian Army on its eastern border.

headline: Bruce Jenner, Embracing Transgender Identity, Says ‘It’s Just Who I Am’
text: This was shocking: Bruce Jenner is a Republican.

headline: When a Co-op Neighbor Breaks the Law
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Earthquake in Nepal Kills Hundreds
text: An earthquake with an estimated magnitude of 7.8 shook Nepal on Saturday near its capital, Katmandu, flattening sections of the city’s historic center.

headline: Anonymous Donors Keep ‘The Fantasticks’ Open
text: About that closing of “The Fantasticks”: Never mind.

headline: Variety: Opposable Sums
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Solving a variety puzzle is a bit like cross-training — it works out a different set of muscles. For a standard crossword we’re just focused on filling in the blanks, but for an Opposable Sums puzzle, all the letters are right in front of you — you just have to rearrange them.

headline: Bruce Jenner’s Transgender Announcement Draws 16.8 Million on ABC News
text: More than 16.8 million people tuned in Friday night to watch the ABC News television special in which Bruce Jenner said that he identified as a woman, according to preliminary ratings data provided by the network.

headline: Scott Walker, a Pastor’s Son, Runs on Faith as Iowa Beckons

headline: Push for Buses on Sabbath Sets Off Debate in Israel

headline: Thomas Staggs: Disney’s Heir, Apparently
text: Robert A. Iger was grasping for words. Standing before shareholders in San Francisco last month, the normally quick-witted Mr. Iger, chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, had been caught off guard by Brooke Ledwith, an inquisitive 6-year-old. “Who was the first Disney princess to walk on a Disney cruise ship?” she asked, standing on tiptoe to reach a microphone.

headline: In Footgolf, Argentina Establishes Itself as the Dominant Force
text: GENERAL RODRÍGUEZ, Argentina — With dusk falling, Nico García squatted down to read the perilous 20-foot par putt. Needing only a bogey to win Argentina’s national championship, he sent the ball snaking downhill across the green, where it stopped just short of the hole. He tapped in for victory — not with a putter, but with the instep of his soccer cleat.

headline: What About Those Three Kingman Homers? Oops
text: The soothing, authoritative voice that greets fans at Yankee Stadium is the same one that sparked the first widely broadcast manager’s rant. Yes, Paul Olden, the Yankees’ public-address announcer, was the reporter whose simple question inspired Tommy Lasorda’s famous Dave Kingman tirade at Dodger Stadium in 1978.

headline: With Drybar, a Curly-Haired Girl Wages a Global War on Frizz
text: About 18 people gathered in a semicircle inside Drybar’s new location in the meatpacking district of Manhattan. It was mid-December, and in the previous weeks they had been trained in the fine art of giving the greatest possible blow-dry. They knew how to create the beachy rumpled look of the Mai Tai blowout and the sharp, pointy, uptightness of the Straight Up; they knew how to make you look like an extra from “Steel Magnolias” with the Southern Comfort. They could twist your hair into an Uptini, if that was your need on a particular day. They knew how to turn around the salon chair with a flourish so that the customer, who up to this point had been too mesmerized by watching “The Devil Wears Prada” on a big-screen TV to notice what was being done, could see her hair, shiny and smooth, in the mirror on the wall behind her. As Drybar’s founder, Alli Webb, sitting atop the bar to greet these new employees, likes to say: “We’re not selling blowouts. We’re selling happiness and confidence.”

headline: Unbeaten Red Bulls Score on Another Front
text: HANOVER, N.J. — The shouting is as loud as ever around the Red Bulls, but then that is nothing new. Fortunately for the team, the reasons for it are entirely different these days.

headline: A Case of Too Many Viennas
text: THE drone strike that accidentally killed two hostages held by Al Qaeda, one of them American, in Pakistan’s northwest frontier was a rare moment of media attention for a seemingly endless military campaign. It’s six years old if you date it to President Obama’s escalation of drone warfare, 11 if you date it to the first American drone strike inside Pakistan, and 14 if you date it to when United States Special Forces first slipped into Afghanistan after 9/11. By any estimate, our AfPak intervention has lasted longer than most major wars in American history. By the third estimate, it’s lasted longer than several of the biggest ones combined.

headline: What Role Do You Want to Play?
text: A CHARACTER in a book by Flaubert, or perhaps someone even smarter, like La Rochefoucauld, said that most people would never fall in love if they had not first read about it in a book. Like many tasty ideas, it’s an emulsion of true and not-so-true but points us toward an illuminating insight: We can’t be the people we are without drawing on sources outside ourselves.

headline: Forcing Black Men Out of Society
text: An analysis in The Times — “1.5 Million Missing Black Men” — showed that more than one in every six black men in the 24-to-54 age group has disappeared from civic life, mainly because they died young or are locked away in prison. This means that there are only 83 black men living outside of jail for every 100 black women — in striking contrast to the white population, where men and women are about equal in numbers.

When added to rising ticket prices and fees, the problems on the ground become even more of an annoyance. Congress now has a chance to help fix some of them by raising the cap on a fee used to pay for airport improvements.

Not quite the wannabe actress arriving in Hollywood and waitressing, but not far off. I came to love London once I’d conquered its back streets and understood its secrets, but my first year living there was bleak and harrowing.

headline: Portraits of an Execution in Indonesia

headline: ‘Electronic Africa’ at Red Bull Music Academy Festival
text: “Electronic Africa,” this Friday at Villain in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is the first night of the monthlong Red Bull Music Academy New York festival. This festival’s programming tends to expose secret histories of old music or uncover thriving, noncommercialized scenes of new music; true to form, this is not the organic, lilting African music of Putumayo stores and the college-theater circuit. DJ Spoko and Nozinja, both from South Africa, have created fast-paced versions of Kwaito house; Islam Chipsy, from Egypt, plays blistering, distorted electro chaabi, using his fists to make tone clusters on his electronic keyboard over rhythm tracks; Titica, a popular transgender Angolan singer and dancer, performs the rap-techno style called kuduro. You’ll get an education. (Villain, 50 North Third Street, Brooklyn; Friday, 9 p.m.; tickets $20; redbullmusicacademy.com)

headline: Milka Djordjevich Puts Dancers on a Pedestal in ‘MASS’
text: When choreographers talk of putting dancers on pedestals, they’re often speaking metaphorically about attempts to idealize bodies. But Milka Djordjevich is putting three dancers onto an actual pedestal in “MASS,” her new collaboration with the composer Chris Peck. The constantly changing bodily shapes will be seen as moving sculptures in a surrounding sea of darkness.

headline: From Chaplin to ‘Avatar,’ a Film Tasting Menu
text: This week, filmgoers can taste the fruit of Hollywood’s earliest technology, then sample a modern big-money audience-grabber. In its Essential Cinema series, Anthology Film Archives culminates a focus on Charlie Chaplin on Sunday with “City Lights” (1931), a seamless blend of physical comedy and genuine pathos. Chaplin released this silent masterwork more than three years into the sound era at great personal risk — and to resounding acclaim. (32 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village; anthologyfilmarchives.org.) On Friday, BAMcinématek begins “3D in the 21st Century,” demonstrating that what was once a gimmick is now a sophisticated tool. “Avatar,” James Cameron’s sci-fi epic that mandated every blockbuster have 3-D, is on Saturday. One of the best uses, though, is by a documentary next Sunday: “Cave of Forgotten Dreams,” Werner Herzog’s transcendent tour of Chauvet Cave, home, fittingly, to the world’s earliest-known man-made images. (Friday through May 17 at 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, 718-636-4100; bam.org.)

headline: John Eliot Gardiner Returns to Monteverdi’s Vespers
text: In 1964, when John Eliot Gardiner was a 20-year-old undergraduate at the University of Cambridge, he presented Monteverdi’s scintillating multi-choir Vespers of 1610 at the chapel of King’s College. He fashioned his own performance audition, rounded up the few cornetto players active in England, auditioned singers from London, including the tenor Robert Tear, and borrowed Trevor Pinnock’s harpsichord. The show caused a stir and put Mr. Gardiner on the map as a conductor of immense persuasive gifts.

headline: New Portraits by Chantal Joffe at the Jewish Museum
text: Susan Sontag wrote that “the painter constructs, the photographer discloses.” But the work of photography-based painters like Chantal Joffe (her early interest in nudes led her to paint mostly from pictures in pornographic magazines) has always existed somewhere in between, a fictive nonfiction. Starting Friday, the Jewish Museum will present 34 new portraits by Ms. Joffe of Jewish women of the 20th century whose contributions to art, literature and politics have interested her. The redoubtable group includes Sontag, as well as Diane Arbus, Gertrude Stein and Claude Cahun, the Surrealist shape-shifter whose photographic self-portraits as a man, amid many other guises, prefigured Cindy Sherman by decades. Ms. Joffe made the portraits after immersing herself not only in pictures of the women but also in what they wrote and made, striving for depictions charged with her own imagining of what her heroes would have looked like at various stages of their lives. (Through Oct. 18, 1109 Fifth Avenue, 212-423-3200, thejewishmuseum.org.)

headline: ‘Tales of the Grim Sleeper,’ on HBO, Explores a Murder Case
text: We all know how to make a documentary about a serial-murder case: Structure it around interviews with prosecutors and police investigators, who reconstruct the crimes and the pursuit of the suspect. Well, someone forgot to explain that formula to Nick Broomfield.

headline: William Price Fox, Admired Southern Novelist and Humorist, Dies at 89

He was 89.

headline: Ellen Turner Dies at 87; Opened Kitchen to Feed the Needy of Knoxville

headline: Ancient Collision Made Nepal Earthquake Inevitable
text: More than 25 million years ago, India, once a separate island on a quickly sliding piece of the Earth’s crust, crashed into Asia. The two land masses are still colliding, pushed together at a speed of 1.5 to 2 inches a year. The forces have pushed up the highest mountains in the world, in the Himalayas, and have set off devastating earthquakes.

headline: Emma Wood and Conner Bassett
text: Emma Winsor Wood and Conner Dylan Bassett were married Saturday in the library of the Colony Club in New York. The officiant was Willard L. Wood, an uncle and the godfather of the bride, who became a Universal Life minister for the event.

headline: Bethany Fong and Brian Tse
text: Bethany Hana Fong and Brian Kar-Yan Tse were married Saturday at the Allied Arts Guild in Menlo Park, Calif., by Pastor Les Yee of the Free Methodist Church.

headline: Katherine Sharpe and Jesse Kraai
text: Katherine Gibson Sharpe and Jesse Paul Kraai are to be married Sunday by Conor McDowell, a Universal Life minister, at the Berkeley City Club in Berkeley, Calif.

headline: Jonah Nigh, Patrick Herron
text: Jonah Christopher Nigh and Patrick Daniel Herron were married Thursday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Edwina Townes, a staff member of the New York City clerk’s office, officiated.

headline: Anikah McLaren, Mark Wallace
text: Anikah Elizabeth McLaren and Mark Steven Wallace were married Saturday by Tiana Murillo, a Universal Life minister, at Descanso Gardens in La Cañada Flintridge, Calif.

headline: Kathy Choi, Douglas Mansfield
text: Kathy Sunyung Choi and Douglas Andrew Mansfield were married Saturday at the Villa Montalvo, an event space at the Montalvo Arts Center in Saratoga, Calif. The Rev. Joe A. Hamby, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

headline: JoAnna Wasserman, Michael Marando
text: JoAnna Wasserman and Michael John Marando were married Saturday evening at Meridian House in Washington. Rainey R. Brandt, a District of Columbia Superior Court magistrate judge, officiated.

headline: Wladimir Klitschko Retains His Crown Against Bryant Jennings
text: At a February news conference promoting his bout with Bryant Jennings, Wladimir Klitschko, the heavyweight champion of the world, invoked an unofficial title often associated with the crown.

headline: Laughter (and a Few Boos) as Obama Takes Aim at Correspondents’ Dinner
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama might have that cool, professorial exterior. But what would happen if he ever got really mad?

headline: What’s on TV Sunday
text: 9:30 P.M. (Showtime) HAPPYISH Steve Coogan stars as Thom Payne, a 44-year-old burned-out advertising executive living in Woodstock, N.Y., with his painter wife, Lee (Kathryn Hahn, above, with Mr. Coogan). He finds his world spiraling into disarray when his agency hires some young Swedes to bring the company into the new millennium. Bradley Whitford plays Jonathan, Thom’s office mentor, who advises him to rebrand himself. Ellen Barkin is Dani, the headhunter who thinks that Thom has hit his “joy ceiling.” Writing in The New York Times, Alessandra Stanley called this new series, created by the novelist Shalom Auslander (“Hope: A Tragedy,” “Foreskin’s Lament”), “funnyish.” But mostly, she said, “it’s annoyingesque.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “It was like being on a boat in heavy seas.”

headline: Corrections: April 26, 2015
text: NATIONAL

headline: Nepal Searches for Survivors After Earthquake
text: Officials in Nepal said that most of the deaths occurred in and around the capital, but the quake touched a vast expanse of the subcontinent.

headline: Perseverance and Grace as Nepal Is Turned Upside Down
text: KATMANDU, Nepal — There has not been a day in the two years I have lived in Nepal that I haven’t thought about earthquakes. They were, in many ways, my obsession.

headline: George W. Bush Opens Up About 2016 Race
text: LAS VEGAS – Former President George W. Bush offered rare, and broad-ranging, remarks Saturday night about current national security threats and the 2016 presidential campaign to a large audience of Jewish donors, suggesting that sanctions on Iran should not be lifted, that his last name was a burden to his brother, the likely presidential candidate Jeb Bush, and that Hillary Rodham Clinton, while “formidable,” was beatable.

headline: Nepal Terrorized by Aftershocks, Hampering Relief Efforts
text: KATMANDU, Nepal — A growing sense of despair spread through Katmandu on Sunday as the devastated Nepali capital was convulsed by aftershocks that sent residents screaming into the streets, where they were pelted by heavy rain.

headline: For Jeb Bush Donors, Yoga Mats and Tesla Brochures
text: MIAMI BEACH – This is not your grandfather’s Republican Party donor retreat.

headline: The Sensor-Rich, Data-Scooping Future
text: The technology world is looking at ways to make everything more efficient.

headline: A View of Katmandu After the Earthquake
text: KATMANDU, Nepal — It had been an unseasonably cold and rainy Saturday morning. Twelve of us from the staff of The Nepali Times were on a hiking retreat on a hill overlooking the city. The sky was overcast, and we were disappointed not to have a view of the Himalayas to the north. Some of us looked down at the capital spreading out in the bowl-shaped valley below and talked about its rapid, haphazard growth.

headline: 1915: French and British Join Allied Fleet in Dardanelles Campaign
text: LONDON — The Franco-British Expeditionary Corps which has left Egypt under command of General Sir Ian Hamilton, is now co-operating with the Allied fleet in the attack on the Dardanelles. Statements issued by the Admiralty and the War Office announce that the general attack on the Dardanelles was resumed yesterday [April 26] by the fleet.

headline: Deutsche Bank Profit Falls on Legal Costs
text: FRANKFURT — Deutsche Bank, Germany’s largest bank, said on Sunday that its net profit fell by half in the first quarter as it absorbed the legal costs of past wrongdoing by bank employees.

headline: 1965: Indian Armed Forces on High Alert
text: NEW DELHI — India put its armed forces on an emergency alert today as Pakistani troops were reported to have launched another attack on an Indian position in the Rann of Kutch wasteland. Indian Defense Minister Y.B. Chavan told parliament that a Pakistani brigade — with 3,000 frontline soldiers and the support of ‘‘a sizable force of armor’’ — attacked the post of Biarbet, said to be six miles within Indian territory. An Indian spokesman tonight said fighting was continuing around Biarbet.

headline: ‘Furious 7’ Tops Box Office For Fourth Week
text: LOS ANGELES — Big-budget, visual effects-driven summer movies will be packed cheek by jowl for four months starting Friday, with the release of “Avengers: Age of Ultron.” So it was the box office calm before the storm over the weekend, with no major movies arriving to challenge “Furious 7,” which was the No. 1 movie in North America for the fourth week in a row.

headline: This Is Not A Trade Agreement
text: OK, Greg Mankiw has me puzzled. Has he really read nothing about TPP? Is he completely unaware of the nature of the argument?

headline: A Journalist’s Night Off
text: Politicians and their critics graced the red carpet at the White House Correspondent’s Dinner, often referred to as a nerd prom.

headline: A Dozen Whitney Works to Be Displayed in Lights on the Empire State Building
text: “King Kong” was so 20th century. All that climbing and heavy breathing — so low-tech. This is the 21st century. Marc Brickman can have his way with the Empire State Building from wherever he happens to be, which, on Friday, will probably be his usual hangout, somewhere in a hotel with an unobstructed view.

headline: Tax Break Used by Investors in Flipping Art Faces Scrutiny
text: Introduced in the 1920s to ease the tax burden of farmers who wanted to swap property, it soon became a tool for real estate investors flipping, say, office buildings for shopping malls.

headline: World Nomads Festival Will Put Focus on Tunisia
text: The culture of Tunisia will be on display once again at the French Institute Alliance Française’s World Nomads festival, coming to New York from May 8 to 10. The biennial festival, which in 2011 presented artists inspired by the Arab Spring, will feature the singer Sonia M’Barek, the musician Bassam Saba, and the filmmaker Nejib Belkadhi.

headline: Earthquake Aftershocks Jolt Nepal as Death Toll Rises Above 3,400
text: KATMANDU, Nepal — Each time this city shuddered with aftershocks from the earthquake that convulsed Nepal, Samaj Gautam felt an urge to join the millions of residents who fled to safety outdoors. But working in a hospital emergency ward inundated with the wounded, and their broken limbs, fractured skulls and other physical traumas, Dr. Gautam said Sunday night, he and his colleagues had to suppress their fears and stick to treating patients.

headline: Turning a Children’s Rating System Into an Advocacy Army
text: WASHINGTON — James P. Steyer came here from San Francisco last week on a whirlwind tour to try to engage the country’s power brokers in his new crusade to put children and education at the top of the nation’s political agenda.

headline: Justices to Hear Challenge That Argues Lethal-Injection Drug Causes Agony
text: The use of a lethal-injection drug involved in prolonged, apparently agonizing executions last year will come under scrutiny in the Supreme Court on Wednesday as the justices hear a case brought by three condemned prisoners from Oklahoma.

headline: Rescue Efforts Continue in Nepal Quake
text: The Indian government and rescue workers discussed the search and relief efforts in Nepal on Sunday, following the magnitude 7.8 earthquake that struck the country a day earlier.

headline: Searching for Survivors at Mount Everest
text: An avalanche, set off by the Nepal earthquake, rumbled down a treacherous icefall into a Mount Everest base camp, killing at least 17 climbers and injuring many others, officials said.

headline: New Group to Host Stage Adaptation of ‘To Kill a Mockingbird’ in Harper Lee’s Hometown
text: Harper Lee’s hometown of Monroeville will continue to be able to host a stage adaptation of her novel “To Kill a Mockingbird” next year but the production will be run by a new not-for-profit organization being created, not the local museum.

headline: 2 Dead After Storm Strikes Alabama Sailing Regatta
text: By the time the Dauphin Island Race began in South Alabama on Saturday morning, the worst of the day’s weather seemed to have passed. Another shower, the sailors thought, might drop from the skies, but perhaps the rains would stay to the north, or over the shore.

headline: Jeb Bush Says Spending $1 Billion on a Campaign Is Unnecessary
text: MIAMI BEACH — Jeb Bush said he thought it was unnecessary to spend $1 billion on a presidential campaign, a figure reached by both Mitt Romney and President Obama in 2012, saying a smart team could run a leaner operation.

headline: As Boardroom Struggle Ends, Volkswagen Looks to the Future
text: FRANKFURT — Ferdinand Piëch inspired many stories, and one comes from many years ago, when he noticed that cars on display at the Volkswagen dealership in Salzburg, Austria, were covered in snow.

headline: We Weren’t Soldiers (Personal and Trivial)
text: I’m going belatedly through files my father left, and discovered a folder of stuff about myself — report cards and all that. Plus this:

headline: Nepal Earthquake Poses Challenge to International Aid Agencies
text: LONDON — International aid agencies and governments mobilized on Sunday to respond to the earthquake in Nepal, saying they faced challenges in getting assistance to the country and distributing it amid the widespread devastation there.

headline: A Life on the Gridiron
text: Patrick Risha was born into a football family in a football-first community, and he became a star running back. After he graduated from college, though, there were signs that something was off.

headline: Tennessee Williams Plays Coming to 59E59 Theaters Next Season
text: 59E59 Theaters announced its next season’s lineup, which includes six new short plays adapted from Tennessee Williams short stories. Pulitzer Prize-winner Beth Henley, PEN/Laura Pels Award-winner Marcus Gardley, and other playwrights have signed on to adapt Williams’s works for productions starting in August.

headline: Julian Fellowes to Adopt Trollope Novel for TV
text: The Julian Fellowes era continues.

headline: Packed Field Stokes Competition for Digital Ad Dollars
text: Over the next two weeks, some of the biggest Internet companies and publishers will showcase their original programming in an annual attempt to attract advertising dollars. The events, taking place in New York under the banner of the Digital Content NewFronts, are equal parts sales pitch and festival. This year, they are also something else: crowded.

headline: Jailed Venezuelan Mayor Is Moved to Hospital for Surgery
text: The mayor of Caracas, Venezuela, who has been jailed on charges of conspiring against the government of President Nicolás Maduro, was moved to a private hospital over the weekend for a hernia operation on Sunday. He will be transferred to house arrest later while he recuperates, according to his wife and a spokesman.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of April 27
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Burdened With Debt, Law School Graduates Struggle in Job Market
text: Jonathan Wang has not practiced law since he graduated from Columbia Law School in 2010, but he did not plan it that way.

headline: Cavaliers Finish Sweep of Celtics but Lose Kevin Love to Injury
text: BOSTON — The Celtics were undeniably a feel-good story over the last two months of the N.B.A.’s regular season. But in the playoffs, the cold, hard reality is that warm and wonderful stories of plucky underdogs and spunky overachievers invariably end when they collide head-on with showstopping talent.

headline: A Son of Football Calls His Mother
text: DOYLESTOWN, Pa. — A mother sat at the edge of her bed. Angel figurines gazed down from a shelf, and a wooden sign on the wall offered inspirational words about life and love. They provided no comfort. She was on the edge, cellphone pressed to her ear.

headline: Concerns on Jeep Safety Remain, Despite Recall
text: DETROIT — Since its bankruptcy and government bailout in 2009, the American automaker Chrysler has made a stirring comeback primarily by expanding sales of its popular Jeep sport utility vehicles.

headline: Review: A Young Man’s Voyage, Awash in Taboo Desires, in ‘Blackbird’
text: There’s impressive, palpable conviction in Patrik-Ian Polk’s drama “Blackbird,” an adaptation — written by Mr. Polk and Rikki Beadle Blair — of Larry Duplechan’s 1986 novel about a young black man’s coming out. But despite its sense of mission, the film suffers from soapy excesses and narrative disjunctures.

headline: Review: In ‘Look Who’s Back,’ Hitler Returns and He’s Amusing
text: A time traveler in military uniform wakes up on a sunny Berlin afternoon in 2011, looking up at a blue sky without enemy aircraft overhead. He hears no shelling, explosions or sirens. That the city still stands despite his orders that it be destroyed, right down to the screws and door handles, is something that puzzles him. “On the other hand, I am here too,” he thinks, “and I cannot understand that either.”

headline: U.S. - Japan Alliance
text: Shinzo Abe, Prime Minister of Japan, will visit the U.S. this week to highlight close ties between the two countries.

headline: Kazakhstan President Set to Win Fifth Term, Even as Economy Falters
text: MOSCOW — Voters in Kazakhstan were set to re-elect an incumbent on Sunday who has ruled the country since the Soviet Union collapsed, in an election that could have only one outcome.

headline: Bill Hicks, Revived on Video to Jar Viewers Out of Apathy
text: Years ago, the comedian Bill Hicks began one of his stand-up specials with a video of himself riding a white horse and wearing a cowboy hat while talking about fighting corruption and evil. In another, he walked onstage in a black turtleneck sweater, arms extended like a guru welcoming his acolytes. He called himself a “dark poet” and an artist trying “to illuminate the collective unconscious and help humanity.”

headline: ‘A Night of Philosophy,’ 12 Hours of a Mental Marathon
text: The mental marathon billed as “A Night of Philosophy” began in an analytic frenzy at 7 p.m. on Friday as three speakers held forth simultaneously in separate lecture rooms: Monique Canto-Sperber, of the National Center for Scientific Research in Paris, dissected the notion of free speech in a liberal society. Chiara Bottici, of the New School for Social Research, discussed Machiavelli’s ideas about fortune. And Pascal Engel, of the University of Geneva, issued a ringing call for deep thought in a talk titled “Must Intellectual Life Be Boring?”

headline: Review: ‘Yokohama Rosa,’ With Michiko Godai, at Japan Society
text: Twenty-four years ago, the Japanese actress Michiko Godai caught sight of a homeless woman in Yokohama. A frail, stooped figure, the woman wandered the city in a white dress and ghostly white makeup. Fascinated, Ms. Godai began to interview anyone who knew her, gathering the scattered details of her life. Joining a few unconfirmed facts with considerable invention, she and the playwright Giho Sugiyama created “Yokohama Rosa,” which played briefly at the Japan Society in Manhattan as part of its “Stories From the War” series commemorating the end of World War II.

headline: Review: ‘Tales of the Grim Sleeper’ Investigates Los Angeles Murders
text: After its success with Andrew Jarecki’s “The Jinx: The Life and Deaths of Robert Durst,” HBO on Monday night offers another documentary about a man accused of murders that have gone unsolved for decades. Nick Broomfield’s “Tales of the Grim Sleeper” couldn’t be more different from “The Jinx,” however.

headline: Vietnam Is Focus of TV Programs During Fall of Saigon Anniversary
text: The PBS programmers get a little carried away this week with the 40th anniversary of the fall of Saigon, but the occasion at least gives Rory Kennedy’s excellent “Last Days in Vietnam” an opportunity to reach a broader audience. And if the other PBS offerings aren’t as compelling, you can wander over to the Smithsonian Channel for an absorbing special called “The Spy in the Hanoi Hilton.”

headline: Reflecting as a Run Comes to an End
text: It was with much sadness that I learned The New York Times has decided to eliminate its bridge column. I wish to end our coverage of the world’s greatest card game over the next week by mentioning the paper’s bridge columnists.

headline: Review: I Fagiolini, Richard Goode and the Juilliard Opera in Concert
text: I FAGIOLINI

headline: Losing Speech
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — HECK YES, it’s time to start the week off fresh with a breezy Monday puzzle.

headline: Survivors Rescued From Mount Everest
text: Rescue crews airlifted survivors from the Mount Everest base camp on Sunday after Nepal’s worst earthquake in 81 years triggered a series of avalanches.

headline: Dewey & LeBoeuf Trial Is Expected to Be Lengthy
text: For the legal profession, the trial of three lawyers charged with concealing Dewey & LeBoeuf’s failing financial situation from investors in the once mighty New York law firm may well be the most closely watched trial in years.

headline: Sharon Levin to Leave U.S. Attorney’s Office for WilmerHale, Joining Other Ex-Prosecutors
text: Over the last 24 years, Sharon Cohen Levin built a multibillion-dollar operation — not as a trader or banker, but as a prosecutor.

headline: Saudi-Led Air Campaign Resumes in Yemeni Capital
text: AL MUKALLA, Yemen — Warplanes of the Saudi-led military coalition bombed targets in the Yemeni capital on Sunday for the first time since Saudi officials said they were shifting the focus of their campaign against a Yemeni rebel group toward political negotiations and humanitarian relief.

headline: Brazil’s Power Dynamics Shifting Amid Political Scandals
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The head of Brazil’s Senate, Renan Calheiros, has been accused of tax evasion, using a government jet to visit a surgeon who alleviated his baldness with hair implants and allowing a construction company’s lobbyist to pay child support for his daughter from an extramarital affair with a television journalist.

headline: The Stoop and the Universe
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Remember Llama Drama? These Folks Do
text: A retirement community in Sun City, Ariz., was a focus of Internet attention in February, when two llamas escaped after a visit. Residents fondly remember their brush with fame.

headline: Jay Z Counters Reports of Struggles at Tidal Music Streaming Service
text: Jay Z took to Twitter on Sunday to defend his new streaming music service Tidal, after news reports suggested that the app was slipping into early oblivion.

headline: Clippers Absorb Their Coach’s Tongue-Lashing, Then Make a Statement
text: SAN ANTONIO — When Doc Rivers, the coach of the Los Angeles Clippers, gathered to review film with his players on Saturday, the experience was not enjoyable.

headline: After Great Escape, Llamas (and Owners) Adjust to Fame
text: PHOENIX — Their brush with freedom was over, and now the most notorious llamas in Arizona, if not the nation, were back in their dusty backyard, peeking out of their pen with their long necks and big eyes. They were home, though their lives were anything but the same.

headline: Gay Businessman Who Hosted Ted Cruz Event Apologizes
text: Ian Reisner, one of the two gay hoteliers facing boycott calls for hosting an event for Senator Ted Cruz, who is adamantly opposed to same-sex marriage, apologized to the gay community for showing “poor judgment.”

headline: Fashion Is Trending, in Google Searches
text: What’s in or out: an analysis of six billion Google searches shows how clothing styles spread from state to state.

headline: The Latest Fashion, Trending on Google
text: Normcore? So last year. String bikinis? Most definitely over.

headline: Deron Williams’s Injury Lingers After Nets’ Reviving Win
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Deron Williams’s mercurial postseason took another hairpin turn Sunday when his Nets teammate Joe Johnson let slip that Williams might be playing with “severe” tendinitis.

headline: White House Takes Cybersecurity Pitch to Silicon Valley
text: SAN FRANCISCO — President Obama’s newly installed defense secretary, Ashton B. Carter, toured Silicon Valley last week to announce a new military strategy for computer conflict, starting the latest Pentagon effort to invest in promising start-ups and to meet with engineers whose talent he declared the Pentagon desperately needed in fending off the nation’s adversaries.

headline: Effort by Japan to Stifle News Media Is Working
text: TOKYO — It was an unexpected act of protest that shook Japan’s carefully managed media world: Shigeaki Koga, a regular television commentator and fierce critic of the political establishment, abruptly departed from the scripted conversation during a live TV news program to announce that this would be his last day on the show because, as he put it, network executives had succumbed to political pressure for his removal.

headline: Israeli Military Says It Killed Armed Men in Strike on Golan Heights Frontier
text: JERUSALEM — An Israeli airstrike killed members of an armed squad that was preparing to bomb Israeli forces on Sunday along the Israeli-Syrian frontier in the Golan Heights, the Israeli military said.

headline: Suspect Fatally Shot by Detective in East Village Had Mental Illness and a Troubled Past
text: Harold Carter and Vicente Matias, two veteran detectives from a Harlem police precinct, arrived at a six-story building on East Sixth Street in Manhattan on Saturday afternoon in search of a robbery suspect.

headline: Comcast-Time Warner Cable Deal’s Collapse Leaves Frustrated Customers Out in the Cold
text: In the vast realm of unhappy cable customers, Time Warner Cable subscribers stand out as an especially miserable bunch.

headline: G.O.P. Struggling With Shifts on Gay Marriage
text: Rick Santorum said he would never attend a same-sex wedding. Marco Rubio said he might attend one. Scott Walker actually went to a same-sex wedding reception, not to be confused with an actual same-sex wedding ceremony. Ted Cruz said he is firmly opposed to gay marriage, but would be comfortable if his daughter were gay.

headline: In Rare Remarks, George W. Bush Argues Against the Lifting of Iran Sanctions
text: LAS VEGAS — Former President George W. Bush said the United States must show that it can follow through on its promises, and argued against the lifting of sanctions against Iran during rare remarks about foreign policy in a meeting with hundreds of Jewish donors here Saturday night.

headline: Chipotle to Stop Using Genetically Altered Ingredients
text: In a first for a major restaurant chain, Chipotle Mexican Grill on Monday will begin preparing only food that is free of genetically engineered ingredients.

headline: Republican Contenders Reach Out to Sheldon Adelson, Palms Up
text: LAS VEGAS — In a country wary of dynasties, former President George W. Bush said he could be a liability for his younger brother Jeb, a likely presidential candidate.

headline: Jeb Bush Adopts a Surprising Style in Eco-Friendly Miami Beach
text: MIAMI BEACH — On his way to an ecologically friendly hotel here on Sunday, Jeb Bush ate a Paleo-diet-approved bison burger wrapped in lettuce and served by a Democrat-loving drag queen turned waiter.

headline: New Amendments Imperil Measure on Iran in Congress
text: WASHINGTON — A bill to give Congress a voice in the nuclear deal with Iran is now endangered by Republican amendments that would peel away bipartisan support for a measure begrudgingly accepted by the White House this month.

headline: Apple Earnings, Automaker Results and New Products From Tesla
text: Here are some of the top business stories to pay attention to in the coming week.

headline: Six PEN Members Decline Gala After Award for Charlie Hebdo
text: The decision by PEN American Center to give its annual Freedom of Expression Courage award to the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo has prompted six writers to withdraw as literary hosts at the group’s annual gala on May 5, adding a new twist to the continuing debate over the publication’s status as a martyr for free speech.

headline: Ellis Island Museum to Update the Story of Immigration in America
text: Everywhere in America, immigration is an unending story. Everywhere, that is, except at the Ellis Island Immigration Museum, where the story ends in 1954, when the immigrant processing and detention station there was closed.

headline: Nepal Earthquake: Where to Donate
text: Here is a list of some of the groups soliciting donations for relief efforts in Nepal:

headline: Opposition Grows as Home for Troubled Youths Comes to Quiet Queens Block
text: Michael Duvalle squared up in front of a two-story brick building on a quiet residential block in southern Queens and brought a megaphone to his lips. A retired security executive and local resident, Mr. Duvalle had a message for the commissioner of the city’s Administration for Children’s Services, Gladys Carrión.

headline: Downside of Police Body Cameras: Your Arrest Hits YouTube
text: Police departments around the country have been moving with unusual speed to equip officers with body cameras to film their often edgy encounters with the public. But the adoption of these cameras has created a new conflict over who has the right to view the recordings.

headline: In an Already Troubled Nepal, a Picture of Despair Emerges
text: NEW DELHI — Her home and village near the earthquake’s epicenter were destroyed, her grandfather was killed, and no one from outside the village — not a soldier, police officer or rescue worker — had arrived to help.

headline: More Meh Than Meaning in Early Subway Series
text: So many people, it seemed, wanted to make this series between the Mets and the Yankees into something significant. The teams each owned a share of first place — the first time that has happened when they met each other. Matt Harvey would face Alex Rodriguez, a showdown that might have had historic — and theatrical — implications if Rodriguez were to tie Willie Mays on the career home run list. Were the Mets, who had won 11 in a row, really for real? Were the Yankees, who had won six of seven, tiptoeing back toward relevance?

headline: Popular Demand
text: It’s no surprise that the largest Internet properties, which offer multiple services like email, social media applications, entertainment and search, reached the most users in March.

headline: Character Building at Japanese Festival
text: The annual Sakura Matsuri Festival, which showcases traditional and modern Japanese culture, was held over the weekend at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

headline: Odd Goal Against Galaxy Leads to Draw, and Red Bulls Stay Unbeaten
text: HARRISON, N.J. — The early wins were one thing. But when the Red Bulls started scoring goals accidentally — shots that went in off a teammate’s face, say, instead of out after clipping the post — it became easier to believe that their unbeaten start in Major League Soccer might not be a fluke.

headline: Review: Anne Hathaway as a Fighter Pilot in ‘Grounded’ at the Public Theater
text: Here’s some unusual tabloid fodder: Anne Hathaway has joined the Air Force!

headline: At TPG, a Low-Profile Fund’s Diversity Thrives
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Since its inception, TPG has been best known for the leveraged buyouts of prominent companies including Continental Airlines, Neiman Marcus and a now-bankrupt Texas utility that was a big player in the energy sector.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Recap: The Faith and the Crown
text: Here be spoilers and more High Septon than you wanted to see.

headline: Not Your Dad’s Pinewood Derby (at Least in Theory)
text: BROOKFIELD, Wis. — It starts with a block of wood, four wheels and four nails. It fills boys with hope and creativity; it fills parents with obsession or dread.

headline: In Full Bloom at Japanese Festival in Brooklyn
text: The annual Sakura Matsuri Festival, which showcases traditional and modern Japanese culture, was held over the weekend at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The festival, in its 34th year, has expanded to include a fashion show of cosplay, short for costume play, in which people dress as characters from anime, video games, film and elsewhere in popular culture.

headline: Drought Frames Economic Divide of Californians
text: COMPTON, Calif. — Alysia Thomas, a stay-at-home mother in this working-class city, tells her children to skip a bath on days when they do not play outside; that holds down the water bill. Lillian Barrera, a housekeeper who travels 25 miles to clean homes in Beverly Hills, serves dinner to her family on paper plates for much the same reason. In the fourth year of a severe drought, conservation is a fine thing, but in this Southern California community, saving water means saving money.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Record Fund-Raising Total
text: MIAMI BEACH — Jeb Bush told donors here that he believed his political action committee had raised more money in 100 days than any other modern Republican political operation, according to those who heard him.

headline: ‘Silicon Valley’ Recap: It’s Not About How Much You Earn
text: Season 2, Episode 3: “Bad Money”

headline: Man Is Arrested in Fatal Shooting of Queens Woman, 70, at Her Door
text: The police have arrested a man in the death last month of a 70-year-old Queens woman who was shot when she answered her front door.

headline: Program Aims to Reduce Energy Costs and Keep Rents Affordable in Bronx
text: Long before it finally died last month, the old, rusted boiler in the basement of the five-story apartment building in the Bronx needed to go. It routinely broke down, leaving tenants without heat or hot water. It burned through copious amounts of heating oil and ran up thousands of extra dollars in bills.

headline: Islanders Enter Finale on Road Buoyed by a Win at Home
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — John Tavares always exudes calmness, so it is no surprise to hear that he views his first postseason Game 7 as he would any road game.

headline: Alex Rodriguez Revives Familiar Pattern With Approach to Matching Willie Mays
text: For a designated hitter who is soon to be 40, going more than a week without a home run is nothing to be alarmed about. But for Alex Rodriguez, who, entering Sunday’s game, was two shy of tying Willie Mays at 660 homers for fourth on the career list, it followed a familiar pattern.

headline: Officer’s Indictment Is Protested
text: Marchers on the Brooklyn Bridge Sunday condemned the February indictment of Peter Liang, 28, in the fatal shooting of an unarmed man in a Brooklyn housing project in November.

headline: ‘The Good Wife’ Recap: So Long, Farewell

headline: What’s On TV Monday
text: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) WILD AT HEART (1990) Lula Pace Fortune (Laura Dern, above), a 20-year-old peach who describes herself as hotter than Georgia asphalt, and Sailor Ripley (Nicolas Cage), her gentle ex-con beau, take off from Cape Fear, N.C., for Big Tuna, Tex., on what they see as a trip down their own Yellow Brick Road in search of the Wizard of Oz. But the private detective Johnnie Farragut (Harry Dean Stanton) is fast on their trail with Lula’s beauty queen mother, Marietta (Diane Ladd, in an Oscar-nominated performance), who wants Sailor dead. Willem Dafoe, wearing brown, wired-together teeth, plays the no-good gangster Bobby Peru; Isabella Rossellini is his unnaturally blond Mexican mistress; and Crispin Glover is Lula’s cousin, who puts cockroaches in his underwear for pleasure. The director David Lynch “believes that more is more but, after a while, the film’s odd inventions begin to exhaust,” Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times about this adaptation of Barry Gifford’s road novel, which won the Palme d’Or at the Cannes Film Festival. But “though Miss Dern and Mr. Cage are constantly upstaged by the rest of the movie, they triumph.”

headline: Think of Undocumented Immigrants as Parents, Not Problems
text: LOS ANGELES — SOMETHING happened while the immigration system in the United States got broken, something that should change the way we talk about fixing it. Years went by, and nature took its course. More than 11 million unauthorized immigrants settled into our communities; many formed families and had children. Now at least one of every 15 children living in the United States has an unauthorized parent, and nearly all of those children are native-born United States citizens.

headline: A Spotlight on Japan’s Wartime Past

headline: ‘The Life of Saul Bellow: To Fame and Fortune, 1915-1964,’ by Zachary Leader
text: The very long first volume of Zachary Leader’s biography of Saul Bellow — a second book will cover the later years — ends in 1964, with the publication of “Herzog,” the novel that secured Bellow’s position, at age 49, as the more or less undisputed champ of midcentury American fiction. The country was becoming steadily citified, and Bellow — born outside Montreal, raised in Chicago, at home in Manhattan — was the laureate of the new urban cosmos. “Mr. Bellow has something like a genius for place,” V. S. Pritchett marveled in The New York Review of Books. “There is not a descriptive insinuator of what a city like New York is like from minute to minute who comes anywhere near him. Some novelists stage it, others document it; he is breathing in it.” The big ideas and Great Books blurtings of Moses Herzog, a cuckolded professor and “poor soldier of culture” who goes on a half-crazed ­letter-writing spree (“Dear Doktor Professor Heideg­ger”), bounce like molecules off the shifting surfaces and bristling planes of Manhattan: the crowded sidewalks and pinched apartments, the humps of brown rock “speckled with mica” in Central Park, glimpsed between the blinds of an Upper West Side doctor’s office whose “dark walls seemed swollen with the disease of old buildings in New York.” Dropping his subway fare in the slot, Herzog sees “a whole series of tokens lighted from within and magnified by the glass” and notes that “innumerable millions of passengers had polished the wood of the turnstile with their hips.” In Bellow’s urban pastoral, mass human activity both exhilarates and terrifies, duplicating nature’s impersonal patterned randomness — as “megatons of water shape organisms on the ocean floor. As tides polish stones. As winds hollow cliffs.”

headline: ‘There Is Simply Too Much to Think About,’ Saul Bellow’s Nonfiction
text: “The flies wait hungrily in the air,” writes Saul Bellow (in a description of Shawneetown in southern Illinois), “sheets of flies that make a noise like the tearing of tissue paper.” Go and tear some tissue paper in two, ­slowly: It sounds just like the sullen purr of bristling vermin. But how, you wonder, did Bellow know what torn tissue paper sounded like in the first place? And then you wonder what this minutely vigilant detail is doing in Holiday magazine (in 1957), rather than in the work in progress, “Henderson the Rain King” (1959). It or something even better probably is in “Henderson.” For Bellow’s fictional and nonfictional voices intertwine and cross-pollinate. This is from a film review of 1962: “There she is, stout and old, a sinking, squarish frame of bones.” Two decades later the image would effloresce in the story/novella “Cousins”:

headline: Reclaiming the Power of Play
text: Play is the highest form of human activity. At least that’s what Friedrich Nietzsche suggested in “Thus Spoke Zarathustra,” when he described a three-step development of the human spirit. First, the human psyche has the form of a camel because it takes on the heavy burden of cultural duties — ethical obligations, social rank, and the weight of tradition. Next, the camel transforms into a lion, which represents the rebellion of the psyche — the “holy nay” that frees a rule-governed person from slavish obedience to authority. Finally, this negative insurgent phase evolves into the highest level of humanity, symbolized as the playing child — innocent and creative, the “holy yea.” Cue the Richard Strauss music.

headline: Getting In to College Doesn’t Mean Students Are Ready to Go
text: Last October I held a hastily scheduled psychotherapy session with a teenager facing a disastrous start to her college career. When we met, she somberly shared that she was on her university’s radar for her uncontrolled drinking and had a coming court date for a disorderly conduct charge. Her parents wanted her to withdraw right away, but she had just started to make some solid friendships at college and was reluctant to go home. I saw her point, but understood where her parents were coming from: Given that she was clearly struggling, it was hard to imagine how she would handle the additional strain of trying to recover from her faltering start.

headline: 1940: Fighting in Three Directions

In addition, there were sharp engagements in the Trondhjem sector, where the Allies north and south of the port continued to hold up German attempts to link their forces coming from Namsos and Andalsnes. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 28, 1940

headline: 1965: Forces Storm Santo Domingo
text: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic — Military forces opposed to the return of former President Juan D. Bosch stormed into Santo Domingo today [April 27] with tanks and infantry. The anti-Bosch forces, under Army Gen. Elias Wessin y Wessin, fought their way into the capital across two bridges after the Navy joined anti-Bosch air-force planes in bombarding the city from sea and air. The forces under Gen. Wessin y Wessin approved last weekend’s military coup ousting the civilian junta of Donald Reid Cabral, but opposed the return of Mr. Bosch from his 19-month exile in Puerto Rico. — New York Herald Tribune, European edition, April 28, 1965

headline: The Fine Line Between Smart and Illegal

headline: New Study Links Weather Extremes to Global Warming

headline: Only Three Wolves Left on an Island Full of Prey
text: Only three wolves — a male, a female and a 9-month-old pup — remain in Isle Royale National Park in Michigan, where wolves have been studied for nearly 60 years. Researchers first noticed their numbers declining in 2009, possibly because of inbreeding. The population will probably not recover naturally, biologists have concluded. The pup appears to be sickly, with a constricted waistline, hunched posture and a deformed tail. The wolves prey on moose, whose population is on the rise. More than 1,000 have been spotted on the island.
